<question>



Is it possible that I lost my mucus plug? 6 weeks pregnant?



Just went to the loo and saw brown stringy, mucus looking stuff on the loo roll (Sorry, TMI but I wouldn't normally bother looking if it wasn't for browna dn pink discharge th last couple of days)



Is it possible this is my mucus plug? Or part of it?



If so, will the preganncy still go to term? I have an emergency scan booked for tomorrow because of the discharge.



Trying to relax as I know I'm making things worse, but everytime I try things like this happen!



</question>

<answer>



Hi



This does not sound like your mucus plug as this happens close to labor. I would suggest that it is from implantation bleeding, but any bleeding or strange discharge should be reported to your midwife/doctor straight away. Im sure all will be ok as it is not bright red blood, but better to get it checked out to be safe. Good luck with your pregnancy and congratulations! xx



Source(s):



39 weeks + 3 days Pregnant



</answer>

It's not the mucus plug. I had similar discharge. It's just dried blood mixed with mucus. Don't worry and stay positive !

I too have been feeling movement and I don't think it's too early.  Most first timers feel their baby move for the first time around week 16 or so.  From everything I've read we will feel the baby move earlier this time because we know what to feel for.  So it's not that the baby is really moving earlier we just know what to look for.

<question from>



Sarah Ann

Total points: 155 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Light period could i be pregnant?



my period has always been kind of irregular but i only bled VERY little for like 2 days and now i dont see any more blood. usually my period it heavy for the first 3 days and lasts a week. i just started having sex with my bf but we use condoms and he pulls out too (sorry for TMI) and he said they worked everytime but im like freaking out could i be pregnant???!!



</question>



<answer from>



luis c
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 9 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



by a pregnant kit, they are very cheap.



</answer>



<answer from>



Just Me♪♫
Member since: 15 November 2007
Total points: 2585 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You could be pregnant if there was a rip/tear in the condom, or if it was used incorrectly.  Wait another week and if you don't have what you consider your normal period, try a home pregnancy test.  Good luck!  Try not to stress about it too much, that'll make it worse.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sam.I.Am
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 160 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Pulling out isn't 100% effective. But nothing is other than abstinence. If you are having any bleeding at all, then you shouldn't be pregnant. Although some women do tend to bleed, it isn't that common. A simple pregnancy test can tell you everything you need to know.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lou
Member since: 14 November 2007
Total points: 254 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Unless you he does anything such as touching himself whislt turned on, then touching you, then you're not pregnant. The stress of worrying about being pregnant could be delaying your period too. Have you been ill recently? This often affects it.



</answer>

well as long as you bled...you cannot be pregnant...but take a pregnancy test or go to a gyno to make sure everything is ok and to be 100% about whether you can be pregnant or not

<answer>



if you have your period at all, it is official that you are not pregnant. when you're pregnant, you dont get another egg release, which is why you bleed because its the lining of your womb that is readying for pregnancy. it comes out because the egg wasn't fertilised. if it was and you were pregnant, you wouldn't have your period whatsoever.

<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Don't listen to the people judging you honey. They don't know your circumstances.



It is free on the NHS, but often anything from 2 - 4 week wait from the first time you see your doctor... so if you are 8 weeks gone or more....



Speak with your GP; there's lots of support and advice available to help you come to a decision. You don't have to make it alone.



Good luck - and I hope you have someone who can support you whatever your decision. x

<answer>



I'm sure it can be done for free.



But guess what else is free?  You giving up your baby to an adoption agency, or leaving your baby at a hospital, police station, or fire department after birth.



So, they can both be free.  With abortion, you will most likely regret it for the rest of your life.  With adoption, SOMEONE will give your baby a chance at life, and you could even be a part of that life if you chose to.



Good luck and I really hope you give the baby a chance.  It is not the baby's fault it was conceived, so he/she should not have to die for something he/she did not do!



EDIT:  Yes Lola, here in the United States it's called the Safe Haven Law.  Any baby can be brought to a hospital, police station, or fire department within 72 hours of birth, no questions asked, and they will give the baby to a proper government agency for adoption.  So, yes, I am "for real", just like that baby in her tummy is "for real" and deserves to be treated as such!

8 month old son, and 16 weeks pregnant with baby boy #2!!

</answer from>



<answer>



no you do not count a miscarriage as a period.



did you speak to your doctor about when it's safe to try and conceive again. getting pregnant too soon can really up your odds of another miscarriage and you should always wait to try until after you've had at least one full cycle because you want to make sure all the materials passed or else you could end up with a wicked infection.



because you haven't had a period yet i'm not sure what the symptoms mean because they could mean preg or period. wait a bit and take a test.



best wishes



</answer>

<answer>



Firstly you should have been advised to wait at least 3 months before trying to conceive again. As it will be hard to pin point when your last period was as you cant use the miscarriage as a guide. But sit back and wait a week to see if you do have a period, as most pregnant women have period like cramping etc when the period is due during pregnancy.



I hope this helps

<answer from>



Jes G
Member since: 04 December 2006
Total points: 873 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are certain pregnancy tests the claim to give accurate result up to a week before a missed period, but I don't trust them.  I'm a big fan of EPT tests.  You can get pretty accurate results 1 day after a missed period.  It's hard to say what you are experiencing right now.



My first pregnancy ended in a miscarriage.  My doctor advised me to wait a month before actively trying to get pregnant again.  Which I did.  But then the following month a did get pregnant again and this time it was a healthy pregnancy and now I have a 19 month old healthy boy.  Hang in there.  It'll happen for you.



</answer>



<answer from>

Good luck I would check with your Doctor an Ectopic pregnancy can be very dangerous for the mother.

uchinasu...

<answer>



The reason the doctor has you wait three months before trying to conceive again is that it gives your body time to get back on a normal cycle, the chances of carrying are higher, and it gives your body time to return to normal after being pregnant.
I had two miscarriages and now have a beautiful 20 month old girl.  We had another miscarriage after that but am now 5 months pregnant.
This all took place over five years so try to be patient....I know it is hard.  After our second miscarriage, I had genetic testing done on me to see if there was a problem on my side.  We were going to test my husband next however the small problem was on my side and was easily fixed.



</answer>

<question>



Colour of nipples during pregnancy?



when does your nipples change colour during pregnancy?



</question>



<answer from>



Sam.I.Am
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 160 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most women can notice a light coloring of the nipples in the first trimester along with the breast tenderness. Women and pregnancies are different though. It could be a light change that you may not notice or it could be dramatic, but if you are concerned with it, it should go back to normal after having the baby.



</answer>



<answer from>



Louise
Member since: 29 December 2006
Total points: 3557 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



they slowly change throughout the pregnancy. they get darker and the areola gets bigger.



</answer>

<question>



Why do I have to have prenatal care?



I know there are diseases and std's out there, but woman have been giving birth for thousands of years without any medical care. I know we are spoiled today with doctors and luxury hospitals, but if I choose not to have prenatal care, would I be judged? I am a married woman, and I am fully healthy, and I choose not to pay some quack to tell me if I'm having a boy or a girl. And I don't want to be told what I can and Can't eat. I don't want to be told what activities I can and can't take part in. It's womanly instinct. Why do I need some jerk off telling me what to do with my baby and my body?



</question>

Or else how do we have so many damn people on this earth? The only thing I did with my first was take those Wal*Mart prenatal vitamins. Even if I didn't, I'm healthy, all of my shots are up to date, so I'm not worried about my second coming out looking like Quasimodo.



</additional details>

<answer>



Well there is an infection out there called the Strep B and if you have it and pass it on to your baby he could die from it. <answer from>



kaylaxki...
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 3745 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



because they test for tons of diseases and worst case scenarios, like chromosomal defects, which lead to developmental disabilities. also, if something goes wrong, or there is something that could be harmful to you or your baby, they'll tell you and do whatever they can to help it. It's a seriously bad thing if you don't get prenatal care, because so much can go wrong, and you need to be tested for so many things that could be harmful to the baby if not treated. If you want the best for your child i suggest you take that small amount of time it takes to get prenatal care, i think it would be selfish otherwise.



It's detrimental to your baby to eat certain things and do certain activities during pregnancy, it could literally kill your baby, and you need to know what those things are. these doctors arent here to control you, theyre here to help insure the best possible health for your child.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kitty

The prenatal visit is to make sure you and your baby is doing fine. If there is anything wrong, the doctor can correct at an early stage. You can choose not to know the gender of the baby.



For my case, i have low lying placenta. If i didn't go for any checkup like in olden days and have my baby naturally, i will actually bleed to death. i checked online and found out in the olden days, this condition is a sure death for the mother and there is no way of knowing if you have this condition unless you go for a ultrasound. Also I'm having a series of injection to make sure my bleeding stop also. I'm having on and off bleeding.



I love going for my prenatal visit and see my baby on the monitor. I cried when i first saw my baby move on the monitor. You can go to my blog and view my baby's ultrasound videos and pictures. Maybe you will understand better.

<answer>



Second children come out fast, meaning, less time in labor.  It's not true that 2nd children are born before they are due.



The doctor should not wait any longer.  They really need to take the baby out.  I think 2 weeks is the max because the placenta starts to get old.



Congratulations!



</answer>



<answer from>



Baby Boy Due Dec 2!!
Member since: 28 May 2008

<answer>



I'm surprised they waited 2 weeks.  My Dr said he wont let me go over 1 week past my due date.



They will probably induce her. Nothing to be concerned about, they will either break her water or put her on pitocin drip and that should start the contractions.  I have heard that contractions are more intense and painful when labour is induced, but I also have a friend who says she wwouldn'twant it any other way.
Her labour will probably be shorter than her first (This isnt set in stone, but generally 2nd babys come out a bit easier.)
Best of luck to you and, of course, your wife!

<answer>



Yes, it is possible to feel your baby's head through your cervical opening (os). When I would do my own checks when pregnant with my daughter I could even feel her hair matted against the membrane! That was really cool and weird at the same time.



It's OK to stick your clean finger in to feel around. It's natural and normal to get to know your body, pregnant or not. Sex during pregnancy is more invasive then a cervix check! Doing a check won't start labor for just that reason....a penis does more poking and prodding then your finger. As long as you're not tugging and pulling on anything you'll be fine. If a cervix check was all it took to induce labor then there would be alot more premature babies on this earth!

<answer>



I don't believe for a minute that any decent midwife would give the all clear on that - it's dangerous and for about 99% of women, not even possible to reach your own cervix.
Do you have any idea how unhygienic your own hands are? You could be at risk of infection, you could induce labour when your body isn't ready for it, you could be risking your baby's life.



Source(s):



Add - In the UK, midwives won't even check your cervix till you're in labour unless there's some other medical reason, there's a reason for that, because sometimes it can be dangerous. And if they do it, they will use surgical gloves and well scrubbed and sterlised hands.They are trained in how to do it - you are not.
And MOST women, not ALL women cannot reach their own cervix during pregnancy.



Add again - Jayah - A penis is sterile. Urine is sterile and for healthy men, sperm is sterile. Do you know any men who cut chicken using their penis? Or wipe their backsides?

Total points: 335 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it is possible to feel the baby's head through the cervix and there is no problem with you checking yourself as long as your full term. As other people have said you could stimulate labour and if you are preterm its not a good idea.
I don't know how many weeks pregnant you are but well done for being able to feel anything with a big bump in the way!!



Source(s):



Im a midwife.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lulu86
Member since: 05 February 2008
Total points: 3739 (Level 4)

<answer>



I can't imagine why your midwife would say it's OK to check your own cervix, I'd be too scared I'd start labour off early!!  I suppose it is possible to feel the baby's head through the cervix if you're dilated slightly.



I use evening primrose oil to help ripen my cervix, which does involve inserting a capsule as near to my cervix as possible, but I'd be wary of actually checking how dilated I am!  Plus, it's too far back and my bump is far too big for me to be able to!



</answer>

<question>

I am 5'6...weight at about 110lbs?? is this normal for me to lose weight during pregnancy?? I can't eat much, I get sick very easily =(



how long will this last?? until I can start eating normally?? any experience on it??



THNKS x]

<answer from>



Proud mummy and girl due 10 Oct
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 2771 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Every body is different. For most woman the sickness usually starts to fade away as you enter into the 2nd trimester around week 13 however if you are like i was during my first pregnancy i had it really bad and couldn't keep any food down at all right up until about 24 weeks. Just try to eat small and often even if you bring it back you still need to eat something. Also drink plenty of fluids. My midwife told me to try and eat dry ginger biscuits to relieve some of sickness feeling but not sure if it works as i never tried it as i hate ginger. Congrats on baby



Source(s):



Mummy to Chloe and Keira and 38+ weeks



</answer>

<answer>



Hi dear, first of all, congratulations on your pregnancy! well what you are experiencing is morning sickness, and with some women, its lasts till the 12/13 th week, for some really unlucky ones, it lasts the whole9 months. hopefully, you wont be that unlucky, losing weight is absolutely normal, i know someone, who always loses 12/15 lbds at the beginning of her pregnancy, and towards the end, she gains an extra 50lbds. it all depends on your pregnancy. for now, what u can do is survive on crackers, nuts, also if u can tolerate, juices, keep some crackers beside ur bed everynight, and put some in your mouth before u get out of bed, u can also keep some fruit flavoured candies, esp at night after brushing your teeth, u can put one in your mouth and then go to sleep, that might help you through the acidity that results from not being able to eat enough. i used to like chinese food at this time, esp pan fried noodles with beef n broccoli (not very healthy i know!) the smell seemed tolerable to me. this is all part of this wonderful journey, but trust me, all this will go away pretty soon............congratulations once again!!!



</answer>

<answer>



I have had several dreams where I've miscarried.  I really believe it is simply because I worry about it so often (even if only in the back of my mind,) that my subconcious feels the need to try and work it out as I sleep.



Even worse...I've had several dreams while pregnant that I murder people....



Clearly, I'm not going to do that.  And I probably won't miscarry.  Dreams are especially vivid while pregnant....but they do NOT predict the future!  Don't worry!  :)

<answer from>



Ellia
Member since: 08 September 2008
Total points: 426 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Please don't freak yourself out!! First, every week that you are pregnant, the chances of something going wrong decreases. You are within days of being 12wks along, which is a milestone when the chances fall off drastically. I'm sure you will be fine!



When I was pregnant with my first, I was lying in bed one night and noticed that my heart was racing a little--so I said to myself, "you HAVE to calm down or you are going to freak out and miscarry." This made my heart beat even faster! and so on until i was thoroughly flipping out. Your freak-out moment happened in a dream, but I think that they happen to all of us moms when we are pregnant.



Something that comforted me was being reminded that women have been having babies for thousands and thousands of years. Unless you know that there is something wrong with the pregnancy, relax and enjoy growing a person! Your appt. will likely be a comfort and not be scary! Best wishes!



</answer>

<answer from>



Ellen Kate due March 5th
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 9541 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



How they afford baby items: Get a part time job/full time job, go to a pregnancy counseling center that helps with baby items, baby showers, friends.



How they prepare for parenting: Parenting classes, Teen pregnancy classes at hospitals



Risks that are higher for teens: Pre-term birth, hyperemesis (severe morning sickness,) placenta previa



Source(s):



18 and pregnant :-)



</answer>



<answer from>



Harley
Member since: 27 February 2007
Total points: 9214 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Peer Pressure would be a good start.  Television programming created toward teenagers that always seem to give a "happy" ending when they become pregnant instead of the nitty-gritty details of how to pay for the formula, bottles, clothes, diapers, wipes, basic necessities, etc.  Look at the social life decline they endure.  Some school systems even make teens leave the main HS and move to an alternative school.  Look at the 4 choices they have once they become pregnant (abortion, keeping the child, closed adoption, open adoption).



</answer>

Topic could be Teen pregnancies and how it effects them



Rember that highschool that had a whole bunch of female students all at one time who got pregnant recently I foget where that highschool was and the entire story but you can do a blurb on that topic. Do some research and get some stories on this topic it will help move along your writing. Include articles and discuss in your own words what the articles are about and if you know anyone whose gone through teen pregnancy you can discuss how it effected her life but dont give away her identity. Now go back to when you started writing figure out the who, what when, where, why and hows. Who-females in their teens from ages... to..., What-teen pregnancy, When-today, Where-Pick a location of the highest teen pregnancy rate whether it be more in the city or in the suburbs or the county, Why- Figure out why females are getting pregnant is it because they need someone to love them or is it because their friends are all doing it and dont want the peer pressure, was it a mistake, were they raped, and finally How- You could do something on oh gosh this is tough like how many partners do they have and how many times do they try to get pregnant each with in a weeks time or over a course of a months time. <answer from>



KKingS
Member since: 20 December 2006
Total points: 22122 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Prevention/Education
*Sex Education in schools/home
*Availability of contraceptives
*Society/Religious views on premarital sex/contraceptives



Rates/Stats (nation/local?)
*Number of teens having sex
*Number of teens pregnant
*Risks associated with pregnancy at that age...harm to fetus/mother (can include emotional and physical)



Options for teen moms
*Pregnancy/parenting classes offered
*Abortion/Adoption...availability
*Community/government support



</answer>

<question>



Scan tomorrow... did you now you were having twins before the scan?



well my scan day is finally here yay!! cant wait :)



i have awful sickness since 6 weeks and a few people have said thats a sign of twins although i had sickness with my daughter too.



to anyone whos had or having twins or just has a suggestion did you now you were having twins before it was confirmed?



and what made you think you were carrying two??



thanks to everybody x x x

<answer from>



Tina
Member since: 02 January 2008
Total points: 24490 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



Despite going through fertility treatments, I was surprised to find out that it was twins.  I did have all-day morning sickness but it was not any more intense than my friends with single pregnancies.  Even at the end of my  pregnancy, people were surprised to find out that I was carrying twins as I didn't put on a lot of weight.



We saw them at a 6 1/2 week ultrasound but even then it seemed unreal.  Once they started kicking and I could feel one moving and then the other . . . then I really knew.  It was my "WOW moment".



Best wishes for a happy & healthy pregnancy whether it by one or or more!



Source(s):



My twins are 10 weeks old today.



</answer>

Hydrocodone is one of the more commonly prescribed pains meds when pregnant....



IMO its completely safe, I took it for back pain with my twins and they are both very healthy 8yr olds...

<answer>



i had this problem bad with both my daughter and now with my son. try not to get up from sitting or laying down so fast. if you are standing up and you feel lightheaded put your hands on your knees and bend over so your head is sort of down until you feel it go away. it worked for me.

<answer from>



Keira’s Mummy ≈☼♥
Member since: 14 June 2007
Total points: 3122 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes totally normal in the early stages of pregnancy.  All of your energy and blood cells are concentrating on growing your little baby.
Your placenta will take over later on in pregnancy (cant remember what week sorry) and you will start to produce more blood cells and the dizziness will go away.
The second trimester is the best, your energy should return



</answer>

<answer>



yeah, all the time. the doc says to sit up or stand up slowly or sit up in bed for a minute before getting up. it still happens now and again though. it can't be helped really since now your body is supporting a baby as well there's simply more blood going round than there used to be.



you'll get used to it though, and it won't last. keep an eye on your blood pressure though k? just in case.x

<answer from>



ange
Member since: 20 July 2007
Total points: 764 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi there,congratulations on your pregnancy and don't worry about this symptom.......it is completely normal.I have had this with all three of my pregnancies and it is due to your blood pressure being lower than normal.During early pregnancy your blood pressure lowers until you are 20 weeks pregnant and then slowly starts to rise again until you give birth at which point your blood pressure should be back to normal.As the other comments say try not to stand up too quickly or if you are standing and feel like this try to sit down as I have fainted twice with the same thing! Also try to eat little and often and try to keep hydrated .Hope your pregnancy goes well x.



</answer>

<question>



Which way is the best way to sleep while pregnant? Tips for sleeping better?

Source(s):

<answer from>



Krystle
Member since: 18 July 2007
Total points: 137 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



when i was pregnant with my daughter i used to put a pillow behind my back so i could lean back then i would put one in front of me kinda under my stomach and in between my knees. your kind of slightly tilted so your not on your back but not directly on your side. it seemed to work for me. now im pregnant with my son and im sure i'll use the same method.



</answer>



<answer from>



Millie C
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 8817 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sleep on your side, with a maternity pillow and pillow between your legs with your legs drawn up.  The maternity pillow can fit behind your back too, so it gives support there.  They say sleep only on your left side, but, that's impossible.  Usually either side is fine and if you roll on your back once in a while, well that will be OK too.  If you find it absolutely impossible to sleep, Tylenol PM is OK once in a while.



</answer>



<answer from>



momma2B
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 480 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's ok to sleep on your back for a few minutes at a time, but not all night at this point in your pregnancy.  I have some back pain too (29 weeks) and it's' better for me to sleep on my side- but it has to be very well supported....a pillow between the knees and one supporting the belly in front.  Sleeping on the side of the pain is usually better because it helps to stabilize that side- but I need to flip back and forth a few times at night.  It's horrible, i know, good luck!



</answer>

The best advice I can give you is get away for a couple of days so that you aren't getting interrogated every day. If you will just pray about it and try to remember that it's not over, you can have a perfectly healthy baby, this one just wasn't meant to be and start trying again it will make things alot easier. Have the child and do not have an abortion.  You have two possible choices:



a. Give it up for adoption but you must keep knowledge of where your child is through out your child’s life.  When your child becomes an adult, he or she will want to know who the biological mother is and will want to contact you.  So keep the link going and be prepared in 25 to 30 years for contact.  I have seen this in a friend who was adopted and pursued this route to put closure in her life.



b. Raise the child yourself and try to get on many social programs as possible.  At the same time, if you can get support from your family then get it.  But you still have to finish high school and post-secondary education (vocational or college).  Try to get as much school aid as possible.  After that, you must get a job.  You need a job regardless if you are married, single, parentless, or have children.  The modern world demands it.



Remember, dating again and finding a man to marry gets more complicated if you keep the child.  Most men in their twenties do not want to date or marry a woman who has a child.  That is just the way most men are.  But do not let this detract you from keeping the child if you really want to.  The child comes first.



I hope this help.

Kristi is 12 weeks!
Member since: 29 July 2007
Total points: 6442 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



One of the biggest problems with ovulation calculators online (which is what I assume you used) is that they predict when the average woman with a 28 day cycle will ovulate.  Almost no one ovulates on day 14.  It's rare.  It's entirely possible that you ovulate early, even as early as day 10 of your cycle and you really are pregnant.  Like you said, wait it out until your period is due.  If you don't get it, then test.



Good luck!



Source(s):



baby #4 due 5/20



</answer>

<question>



How can you tell if it's an actual contraction?



I'm 36 weeks and 4 day's pregnant with my first baby.



Since about week 30 i've been experiencing real bad (what i thought were) contractions,and they kept getting worse, so i went to the hospital a total of 2 times.



They said the first time it was from dehydration, and the second time they said that those weren't even contractions, they were the ones that prepare you for the real thing.



So my question is what does the real contractions feel like? and how would you know they are real not false?



It's like this morning at 5 am after i took a shower and had breakfast i had that pain again but it only lasted for a min @ 5:58am-5:59am.



I just don't want another embarrassing trip to the hospital and then my husband thing i'm lying about it,kinda like the boy who cried wolf basically,lol.



</question>



<answer from>



Kitty
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 620 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



they are right your body is preparing for labor, i went to a class last week, they said if you cannot walk through a contraction that is when it is real... if you can walk through it and it doesn't drop you to your knees, then you are not quite there yet. sounds wonderful doesn't it. they don't call it labor for nothing lol



</answer>

<answer from>



Jessica B
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 1099 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



They REALLY hurt...and progressively get worse and have a rhythm...like one every ten minutes then they become closer and closer together. If you think you are having contractions, walk around...if they go away, they are not true contractions. For me, it felt like my hips and pelvic bone were being squeezed in a vise...burning cramping pain. But, it is different for everyone. You should also have some other signs of pending labor...bloody show, loss of mucous plug, lightening, etc... Good Luck!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



A
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 144 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your having Braxton Hicks, they feel like contractions  but contraction are a whole lot worse



</answer>



<answer from>



Carrie S
Member since: 04 April 2008
Total points: 1666 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



sounds like you are still have braxton hicks contractions they only last for no more than like a minute, and are not consistent.



They are uncomfortable and hurt a bit sometimes but they are tolerable.



The real ones last longer, and come in regular intervals. And you will know it when they come because they HURT!  If you start to have them in regular intervals of like 10-15 minutes for over an hour or two its time to call the doctor!



If you start to get them try changing positions, drinking plenty of h20 and put your feet up. If they are braxton hicks that usually makes them go away.



Source(s):



2 babies and had braxton hicks from about 24 weeks on with both!



</answer>



<answer from>



shantel B BABY GIRL DUE 2/4/2009
Member since: 15 October 2008
Total points: 442 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well unlike braxton hicks they are far apart and they are not consistent with the onset to real labor the contractions are closer together more painful and they won't let up when your in labor you will be able to tell the differience because they will be stronger then the ones you are getting now I wish you luck on your delivery



Source(s):



My seventh child is on the way



</answer>



<answer from>



Shannon
Member since: 31 October 2006
Total points: 7355 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on the woman. When I went into labor with my first son I did not even know because my braxton hicks hurt much worse. (I was having a stress test because I was 41 weeks and my doctor came in and told me "you are in labor" and I was surprised.) Even after 4 cm, I was not in that much pain and I did not have an epidural. (It did get progressively worse in the hospital though, but it was hard to determine when I needed to go to the hospital.)



What everyone else has said is true for most women though, so try to wait until you have intense contractions every 5 minutes before going back to the hospital. That is what I was told for this pregnancy after going to the hospital twice in two weeks. And it is better to be safe than sorry, if you think they are real, then let your doctor know. And shame on your hubby for thinking you are crying wolf, many many many women have several false alarms before going into true labor. It is quite normal, even for a woman experiencing her third pregnancy. My hubby did not think this of me, but my brother and my hubby's boss thought so. They are jerks, do not worry. It is better to be safe than sorry regardless of what others think.



Keep hydrated and rest and good luck.



Source(s):



Was due Nov 1 with #3



</answer>

<question from>



lostlitt...

<question>



High pulse rate during pregnacy?



is it normal to have a resting heart rate of 100-104 and being 10 weeks pregnant? should i be worried? i'm not in any pain and my chest doesn't hurt.



</question>



<answer from>



Joey S
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 188 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Me too. I know...Pregnancy is so wiered.I am already 17 weeks and my heartbeat gets worth but usually when my body gets tired like at the evening time.I think it is normal!



Source(s):



mom to be



</answer>



<answer from>



Due May 19th with our first !!!
Member since: 28 May 2008
Total points: 492 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had the same concern as mine runs around 99-102 (which never happened before pregnancy). I asked my gyno and he said that it is absolutely normal and necessary. You body has to supply blood for the baby and a lot of changes in your body. According to what to expect when you're expecting, a woman's heart will continue to work harder and harder until around birth when it's pumping almost 50% more than the "pre pregnancy rate". I can get you the page numbers on that if you could like them.



Long story short, it's really normal. It's your over all blood pressure that they worry about. If it's okay, then you're okay. Also, if you're not having chest pains, then you're okay.



I would still mention it to your doctor, but I'm sure your doc will say the same thing mine did.



So, congrats on the pregnancy!!



Source(s):



My Gyno



and



What to expect when you're expecting.



</answer>



<answer from>



malinday...
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 205 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



LOL this must be your first pregnancy calm down honey you are fine just wait till the baby start to get an arm or a leg stuck in your rib cage or kick you so hard you pee on yourself. Every pregnancy is different but what your going through is normal. Remember you are carrying extra weight around now so just walking sometimes will take a toll on your body, and as always if you have a concern talk to your OBGYN I am sure he or she will put your mind at ease



</answer>



<answer from>



Lauren R
Member since: 28 November 2007
Total points: 2558 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, that's very normal. When I was pregnant, my resting heartbeat was always over 100, sometimes up to 120. It went back to normal a few days after delivering my baby. Your body is really working overtime now, so it's to be expected that your heart is, too. Nothing to worry about!



</answer>

<question from>

<question>

<question>

I took a pregnancy test this morning (brand: One Step Pregnancy Test) Its one of those +/- tests and less than 2 minutes after I peed on it the test showed + - (first being the pregnancy results, second being control line) The only thing thats bothering me is the vertical line on the + is very, very thin and very faint! I am worried it's an evap line b/c I read about +/- tests at peeonastick.com...anyways..what should I take it as..a positive or should I just assume its an evap line? Has anyone ever gotten results like this from a +/- test? If so, what happened..were you pregnant? Oh and the vertical line on the + was blue, not shadowy. i will be testing again in a few days. Thanks in advance!

<answer>



No matter how faint the line is, it's still a positive result. It should tell you that on the instructions. You're pregnant! :)

<answer from>



NUGirl. Due 3/14/09
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 762 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had one where 2 lines means pregnant, and I had a really hard time reading mine too. The second line was VERY faint, but from what I can tell, any line, no matter how faint, is a positive result.



To be sure, check out www.peeonastick.com where they have pictures of actual confirmed positive tests so you can compare what yours looks like to those. When I saw how faint those positives were I knew I was preggers.



I hope this means congrats!



</answer>

<question>



Are these feelings normal at 37 weeks?



Hi all,
I am over 37 weeks and everything is going great. My Husband and I are nearly ready and are so excited.
The thing is, I have this horrible overwhelming feeling sometimes that something is going to go wrong and even that we will come back from the hospital alone. Theres no reason why I should expect the worse (although I have suffered from depression for 12 years) but I just find myself getting all excited and then having to stop myself because I dont want to get too excited if something bad is going to happen.



I have always expected the worst all my life and whenever everything is going great in anything I will be "waiting" for it to go wrong. But I just want to enjoy every second of the last 2-3 weeks we have left and stop worrying.



Are these normal concerns and feelings that every woman gets at this time or is it simply my history of depression that is causing it? I just want to know that I am not alone in feeling this way.



Thank you



</question>

<answer from>



NUGirl. Due 3/14/09
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 762 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are NOT alone. It is very common for women with no history of depression to have scary dreams about things going wrong with the baby, or to wrestle with waking worries. Very very normal.



I was totally sure I would miscarry, although I have no history of miscarriage and I am young and healthy. But it haunted me until we passed week 12.



As someone with a history of depression myself, I can really admire the battle you are going through. But it seems like you are just where you are supposed to be: you know in your head that these concerns are not founded on fact, they are things that you are scared about. See if your husband can help you out, he seems like a nice supportive guy. Explain to him "I need you to remind me every day that everything is fine with our baby, that he is going to come to us happy and healthy and that it will all work out okay." Let him reassure you. When I was struggling with my miscarriage concerns and would cry about my worries my husband would hug me and say "This baby loves us already. He is safe and happy. You are doing a great job growing our kid! Everything is going to be fine. I am sure of it." and it was just what I needed to hear to calm me down.



</answer>



<answer from>



kade*
Member since: 22 June 2007
Total points: 2033 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes its totally normal i was like that only i had a minor complication at the end of my pregnnacy which made me even worse but i didnt have any problems, good labour good recovery n most of all a perfect healthy baby.



best of luck n plz dont worry



Source(s):



niamh's mummy



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I understand. When my husband and I went in, I was so excited to see that there was a baby in there! And was hopeful that it was healthy. I was worried that there would be a sac with no baby. I was worried it would not have a heartbeat. I was worried it had stopped developing earlier. You name it, I feared it.



Unfortunately, I did see a problem right awa on the ultrasound. It threw me hard. Until we got an all clear 2 weeks later, I was a wreck.



You can only hope for the best. For most women, the ultrasound will go perfectly smoothly.

Be there for your daughter, and never give up fighting for her.

<question>



Look at this crazy pregnancy story..i didnt know this was possible?

i dont have a period because i just stopped birth control 3 months ago so i guess my body is still re-adjusting but i changed my diet and everything an im still gaining weight and my stomach is big and looks pregnant but i jus thought it was water retention or something but i had white blood cells in my urine but i had no infection so the doc gave e antibiotics but i still have the white blood cells which i read may increase wen your pregnant..but i keep feelig this fluttering in my uterus and stomach...its not gas i definately know the difference so i know its not that..i know if you think about something 2 long you can make your self develope symptoms but thats not the case..yes my fiance and i have unprotected sex a lot so there is a possibility but how big of one??



if not pregnancy why am i feeling these flutters that ive been feeling for about 3 months now, what about the bad lower back pain, the nauses feeling, or the white blood cells in my urine with no knid of infection wat so ever?? the doctors cant seem 2 give me any good explinations could you please help?????



its not my mind playing tricks on me..i never thought about pregnancy until a couple of weeks ago..i jus thought it was a kidney infection or bladder infection so its not me mkaing my body do this, my body has been doing this for some time now..i had amiscarriage back in feb and i was on birth control since march, i havent had a period since then, i only spot bled about a month ago i was asking could i have gotten pregnant in that time even though i was on birth control with no period if i was ovulating..i keep cramping and having mood swings like my period wants 2 come but it never does

<answer>



umm if you have  "unprotected sex a lot" pregnancy is certainly a possibility. You certainly have some symptoms that suggest pregnancy. In addition, increased urination and sore breasts are two very common early symptoms--have you had either of those? At the same time, yes psychology or other physical issues can also make you manifest some of the symptoms you describe.



A home pregnancy test is only like $7 at the drug store. Pee on a stick first thing in the morning and know for sure before your doctors start putting you through a battery of tests that could be harmful to the (potential) baby.



</answer>

<answer>



We're not trying to be rude, but you keep asking the same question over and over and expect a miracle. I've had the same thing where I had all the pregnancy symptoms, and missed my period, and it ended up just being me being psychosamatic. I asked like a thousand questions on yahoo asking the same thing. Your not going to know unless you take a test. Every situation is different, just because someone else may have had the same thing happened and became pregnant, doesn't mean you will be. And since you just came off bc it seems like your body is just getting used to being off bc and the hormones are messing with you.

<answer>



If you forget and take them asap and then keep going as you should, you will be ok. <answer from>



strawber...
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 270 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



To be honest it depends from woman to woman.



It took 5 months for me to conceive after stopping the pill and I had many false alarms and always tried to have intercourse when I believed I was ovulating.  However since it can take several months for your body to get back to normal (my cycle ranged from 28 days to 35) it's difficult to pin point when you're most likely to be most fertile.  I'd wait til you're about 35 days since the first day of your last period and if nothing arrives take a test.  If negative chart how many days between your period so you can get at least an estimate of when you're likely to be ovulating.



Hope this helps x



</answer>



<answer from>



Kristi is 12 weeks!
Member since: 29 July 2007
Total points: 6444 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to rely on your body's signals that you're ovulating not some stupid website.  Those things are designed for the average 28 day cycle with ovulation on day 14.  That almost never happens!  Rely on your own symptoms, not a computer that doesn't even know you.



Source(s):



baby #4 due 5/20



</answer>



<answer from>



Trick
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 152 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most doctors would tell you to wait 6 months after going off the pill to make sure that it is out of your system because you are more likely to have a miscarriage. Plus that gives your body time to get back together and your ovulating will be right.



</answer>

<question>



Nose bleeds and pregnancy?



Anyone only have nose bleeds when pregnant? Were they a definite giveaway that you were pregnant?



</question>



<answer from>



Baby girl due Feb 5!!!!
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 404 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yes I did start having nose bleeds when I got pregnant and when I asked my doctor about it he said I was the fourth person that week to say the same thing. It must be pretty common with pregnancy. He said that it had to do with the amount of estrogen in your body and the membranes in your nose, he also said that it can cause your gums to bleed. I wouldn't think that I was pregnant just because my nose was bleeding though, take a home pregnancy test if you want to know for sure. Good Luck!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for sharing your experience!



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Well, I  have wide hips, so I don't seem to show for a while.  I would say around 4-5 months is average for me.  On the other hand, I feel bloated right away and hardly fit into my jeans after 3 months.  I get jealous when I see a lady (whom I used to babysit) who is due 2 weeks before me and she already has this huge baby bump!  No one can even tell I am pregnant yet and I am about 15 weeks now.  I even had a tummy tuck after having children, so I started with a flat stomach.  I think everyone is different, but I'm trying to enjoy the fact that I can still wear my jeans and not worry about the baby showing that I'm not just getting fat.  Smile.  I'm going on and on, but I think it really depends on each pregnancy and the size of your baby.  By the time I am 8 months, people will be asking if I am having twins, so just enjoy the time of just looking bloated.  I always feel bloated too almost right away.  Hang in there.



Source(s):



4th Pregnancy



</answer>

<answer>



Uh...my doctor prescribed me something like the monistat cream. He said that the cream itself could be dangerous to the baby but he wanted to treat it so that I wasn't uncomfortable for the remainder of my pregnancy. The cream he prescribed to me is called Terconazole Vaginal Cream. You use it over a period of three nights, I felt results after the first night. Perhaps you should ask your doctor about this.

<answer from>



Tyler's Mom-to-Be
Member since: 26 November 2007
Total points: 992 (Level 2)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



I am taking a childbirth class and my instructor told us last night that walking does not induce labor.  She said that it can really tire you out and can actually slow down labor if it should start, because you are too worn out to work hard!  I've heard that sex can help speed things along.  My instructor said that the best thing you can do is try to stay really relaxed--that helps the hormones necessary for labor to start to work their best.  If you get stressed or anxious, labor can really stall out.



Hopefully you'll see your baby before Christmas!  Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 20 August 2008
Total points: 366 (Level 2)

Chris R

<answer>



No form of birth control is 100 percent unfortunately.  Most like a beginning period of time to get to full affect and that varies with the drug and the agency testing the drug.



Get a pregnancy test done, because if you are pregnant, you will want to discontinue use of your birth control until the pregnancy has resolved itself in some manner.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jenna
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 636 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My doctor told me that if you start taking it on the first day of your period then you should be protected after the first couple of days. If not then it should take a week or so to start protecting you. You should be fine. It is important to remember that it isn't 100% effective, and that it is possible for someone to get pregnant so if you're worried then wait a couple of weeks and then take a test but the chances are you're not pregnant.



</answer>

<question>

last month I started getting this weird pain in my lower left abdomen. So I called my doctor, and was seen, first thought was tubular pregnancy. well it was negative. knew it couldn't come back positive because i had JUST ovulated. So my doctor thought maybe cyst on my ovaries, witch is what i was thinking. so i got a ultrasound, to look at everything. Everything came back normal, i started feeling a little better. Then I "started" my period. I normally start on CD 29, but i started CD 31. I normally have my period for about 4-5 days. it lasted 3. It was quite light too. after my period ended i started getting REALLY tired, and my back was hurting even more then it normally does. i was still getting that pain once and a while. well now I'm getting the pain pretty bad, for 3 days. now its more of a cramp across the lower abdomen. I really just don't know what it is.. i just dont feel right. so i told my boyfriend that i wanted to get a pregnancy test, just to clear my mind. of course it came back negative.



with my daughter i had cramping from about 5 weeks to 13 weeks. that's why I'm thinking so much that I'm pregnant, but nothings coming back positive. Ive looked everywhere to try to find out what this pain could be. I know that it can sometimes take weeks for a positive result to come, but i don't think i could be pregnant, but maybe?

<answer>

If you are expecting your third, good luck and here's hoping for a relatively pain free labour!

<question>



Bleeding at 6.5 weeks pregnant. Should I expect the worst?



I am 6.5 weeks pregnant. I had a rountine scan on Saturday which showed a fetal heartbeat and all seemed well.
However on Sunday I came down with a nasty virus and had a very high temperature for most of the day.
Last night (Monday) I started to have some light bleeding which is continuing today.



I spoke to the on-call doctor last night who told me it is probably a miscarriage and that there is nothing that can be done. I am hopefully going to the early pregnancy unit today to have a scan.



Has anyone else had bleeding at this stage of pregnancy - what was the outcome (good or bad)?



</question>



<answer from>



Hayley France
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 1268 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hope for the best but be prepared for the worse...I have friends who have experienced bleeding this early on and it's been nothing but I've had four miscarriages...



Good luck...I hope it's ok...



</answer>



<answer from>



CutThroa...
Member since: 04 February 2008
Total points: 787 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Light bleeding can be normal this early in a pregnancy. But it's always a good idea to get it checked out. I would get in to see your doctor as soon as you can so your beta hCG levels can be checked, and if you had them drawn Saturday compared to those values.



I am sorry that you have to go through this...it is difficult to wait. Hugs to you.



Source(s):



Had miscarriage 3 weeks ago at 6 weeks pregnant



</answer>



<answer from>



JMK
Member since: 30 April 2007
Total points: 5673 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had bleeding at 6 weeks and everything was fine.



It could be serious, it could just be normal spotting. Statistically speaking though, once a heartbeat is seen the chances of miscarriage go down to about 2%. So there is a possibility but not likely a miscarriage.



</answer>

<answer>



I am so sorry, but my experience as an OB/GYN office nurse and my experiences with 5 miscarriages says that this is PROBABLY going to end in miscarriage.  6.5 weeks is just to early to really do any medications or bedrest or anything to save the pregnancy.  Go ahead and scream, cry, yell, whatever...and don't let anyone tell you how to feel about this.  Early miscarriages can be just as painful as later ones.  God Bless you.



</answer>



<answer from>



sara j
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 1166 (Level 3)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



This has just happened to me as I turned 6 weeks. Sunday I started bleeding, I knew of many women who spotted so I wasn't to worried at first. Later on I started getting cramps and a few clot tissues, then I was pretty sure I was having a miscarriage. I went to the doctor today, had blood drawn and get the results tomorrow, though I already know what's going to be said.



I'm not sure if it's anything to worry about with only light bleeding, that can be normal. If you start cramping or clotting and having tissue like clots of blood, that's a sure sign of miscarriage.



I hope to God that everything goes well and your baby is fine.



Even so early on in the pregnancy, it's heartbreaking for a miscarriage to happen. I already loved the baby that was growing inside of me and I can't believe it's gone just like that.



Source(s):



Miscarried yesterday.



</answer>

<answer from>



SOC JO!
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 11802 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Other - Spain



</answer from>



<answer>



Vaginal bleeding can occur frequently in the first trimester of pregnancy and may not be a sign of problems. But bleeding that occurs in the second and third trimester of pregnancy can often be a sign of a possible complication. Bleeding can be caused by a number of reasons.Bleeding can be a sign of miscarriage but does not mean that you´ll be having one.
Signs of Miscarriage include:
Vaginal bleeding (quite a lot,like a period or stronger)
Cramping pain felt low in the stomach (stronger than menstrual cramps)



Tissue passing through the vagina



I just hope your baby will be OK.
I was bleeding on my first pregnancy,when I was 8 weeks pregnant.The blood was darker than the period blood,and just small quantity.My baby was perfectly OK.So I just hope you don´t have a miscarriage.I´ll keep my fingers crossed.
XXX



</answer>

<answer>



You should certainly be ready to find out the worst, although it may not come to that. I've twice had spotting at that stage of pregnancy that was the first sign of a miscarriage. I've also twice had spotting/light bleeding at the same stage, that wasn't a miscarriage. It just seems to be the way my body reacts to pregnancy. Hopefully you will be the same. Try to get as much rest as you can. Good luck.



</answer>

<question from>



browneye...
Member since: 21 October 2007

</question from>



<question>



Is it normal to get pains in my lower stomach while I am pregnant? ?



Hi I am 23 years old and am pregnant with my first child. I am only 7 weeks into my pregnancy and feel some discomfort and pains in my lower stomach. Is that normal? It comes and goes some people tell me its my uterus stretching to make room for the baby. But while reading alot of articles online, I am a little freaked out about miscarriages and making sure the baby is healthy. There is no bleeding with these cramps, but sometimes hurt alot.



</question>



<answer from>



Stina
Member since: 29 January 2008
Total points: 755 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you don't have any other miscarrige symptoms, then it is most likely round ligament pain. these are being stretched by both homones and your uterus. If you do experience bleeding or other symptoms go see a doctor.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bethany M
Member since: 02 June 2007
Total points: 188 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Many women experience lower abdominal pain during early pregnancy.  While there are a lot of bad reasons why you might be experiencing it, most of the time everything is just fine.  It could be a sign of preecmaplsia, miscarriage, preterm labor, ectopic pregnancy.... but I don't mean to scare you!  Most likely everything is just fine.



As long as this pain is not accompanied by bleeding, excessive discharge, or other worrisome symptoms, you should be ok.  But do not hesitate to call your doctor!  These days most doctors would rather have you come in and get checked out than leave you to worry by yourself.



</answer>

Kadrien

</answer from>



<answer>



Honestly, since she is irregular... you cant rely on her period alone as there are bigger issues involved it seems.  There is no specific time to take it.. some are better depending on how early you test, but it wouldve definitely showed up at this point if her missing pd was the culprit to being pregnant.



She may want to get checked out for Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome.. basically cysts that prevents her from ovulating. That is a symptom. If she has it, the cysts will prevent her from ovulating normally... and obviously without ovulation there would be no period or 'cleansing' of the female system.



Good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



lingtan1...

<answer>



Best time to test is early in the morning. The 1st urine as it's more concentrated. Otherwise maybe you could go to the doctor to get a blood test done. It's more accurate. My friend miss her period for 2 weeks and all 5 urine test are negative. In the end she went for a blood test and it's a positive result. She has a healthy baby boy now. GOOD LUCK!!



I'm 13 weeks pregnant. You can view my baby's ultrasound pictures and videos at http://joanna-shawn.blogspot.com/

<answer from>



dreamcat...
Member since: 20 June 2006
Total points: 1112 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



the very best time to do a pregnancy test is first wee of the morning as more hormones are present in the urine.  test first thing tomorrow. you can get a false neg test result but not a false positive as the tests check for a hormone only present when a woman is pregnant or on certain drugs (her doctor would have told her if she was on these meds).  if the test result comes back neg again you can arrange a blood test to check if she is preg.  best of luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



desiree...
Member since: 21 March 2006
Total points: 2464 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Since her period is irregular it will be hard to judge by that alone.  Is she having any other pregnancy symptoms?



As for the home test coming back negative, you can't always trust those anyway.  With my first child and the one I'm carrying now the tests I took a week after missing my period came back negative because my body was not yet producing enough of the pregnancy hormones for the test to pick it up.



I would say just give it time and wait for other symptoms, if she has none and her period still does not start go to the doctor.



</answer>

<question>



Premature Labour??????????



How often does it happen??? who do you know who its happened to?? Reasons for it???



</question>



<answer from>



Kayla
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 141 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



My cousin have birth to her little girl at 26 weeks pregnant. She is nearly 8 now. And my friend gave birth at 23 weeks pregnant. And she now nearly 2. There was no apparant reason why either went into premature labour. x



</answer>



<asker's comment>



great thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



ruthdot2...
Member since: 20 August 2008
Total points: 737 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It happened to my friend for no apparent reason.  If you think you might be in labour prematurely, go to the doctor and get it checked out.  My friend was given steroids for a week (which helps the lungs develop) and he was born soon after about 32 weeks.  He was in an incubator for a while but is now completely fine and a normal healthy child.



</answer>



<answer from>



burgerme...
Member since: 28 November 2006
Total points: 473 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've never had premature labor but was always overdue which is also a risk factor. Premature labor can come from stress, caffeine, over activity, or uterine complications. There is no precise answer for that because women I know that are very healthy have gone through premature labor. If you're overdue, the baby can pass a BM in the womb and inhale/swallow it which will cause infection and lifelong respiratory problems.



</answer>



<answer from>



titchyri...
Member since: 29 January 2008
Total points: 1776 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



there are no particular reasons for it happening, stress, high blod pressure, trauma like a fall or other causes can bring it on. but if the baby is born about 30 weks there is a good chance that it may be ok esoecially with all the medical advances. if you were to go into prematire labour you would be given an injection of steroids to strengthen the babies lungs and there are drugs that you would be given to try stop the labour and you would be put on bed rest. but there is no definite causes for it



</answer>

<question>



I just found out that Im pred I have bad gnant, anChest congestion/asthma/cough..What is safe to do to help me?



Especially home remedies. I cant get into the doc for at least a week or so. I dont want to take anything that will hurt the baby. I was taking mucinex and Zyrtec but immediately stopped once i saw those two pink lines.



</question>



<answer from>



ladylove
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 2391 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



i think zyrtec is safe to take. as well as sudafed. u can always just call ur doc and they can tell u over the phone



</answer>



<answer from>



becca
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 2880 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Unfortunately they wont have you take anything but Robitussin/Tusin generic! I know it sucks because I had bad bronchitis when I was early on in pregnancy and had to wait it out and only use that. They will let you use a rescue inhaler/ inhaler if it is necessary! That will depend upon if you have asthma and if you are having constriction in breathing! I was able to use an inhaler on a limited bases because I have asthma! The doctor said she would rather I be able to breath and get oxygen to baby then not to be able to breath and the baby be deprived of vital oxygen! If you can't get in you should be able to at least speak to a phone nurse whom can assist you with the meds you are taking and let you know which are safe and what you might take instead! Good luck!



P.S. Zyrtec is not safe! It is too strong and my doctor said to use Claritin non- drowsy! She said to look for the active ingredient Loratadine 10 mg and no stronger, one a day! She also said to only use that is it was very necessary from my allergies! Again consult your doctor to be sure!



</answer>

<answer from>



weirdfis...
Member since: 25 January 2008
Total points: 2424 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



You won't be sure to get pregnant, there is a small *chance* you will get pregnant. The problem is not every woman is regular in her ovulation and some women do ovulate during the period sometimes.



Really, though, you should use some kind of real birth control, either something hormonal like the pill or the shot or the ring or the implant, or an IUD or condoms. If you think you can't afford it, go to Planned Parenthood, they have a sliding scale, and if you're poor enough it's free.



Use one of those methods properly and you're 99% sure not to get pregnant.



</answer>



<answer from>



dhoomboy...
Member since: 04 July 2008
Total points: 206 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



during periods if you have sex means the chance of pregnancy is too low... its better avoiding sex during the time of periods as it is bleeding time and there is a lot chance for getting infection to both boy and girl.... if you want to have sex means do sex after her bleeding stops (bleeding will be over within 7 days you can do safe sex after these for 3-5 days) or within before 7 days before the periods starts.



</answer>

<answer from>



Way
Member since: 12 July 2007
Total points: 5423 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



abstinence based sex education at work.



a) If you're going to have sex practice safe sex- if you don't want to get pregnant use condomns or the pill, or the injection, or the hundreds of other options available to your and your partner that you can get from your pharmacist or doctor- no ifs, no buts, no other method but those prescribed will properly prevent pregnancy- and ONLY condoms will stop you guys from sharing diseases- don't take my word for it- ask your doctor- they are paid to tell you this stuff in strict confidence and hook you up with whatever contraceptive you decide upon.



b) don't have sex during periods- it's gross, it's unhygienic- it's really unhealthy- once a month, no sex for a few days- deal with it- this is how humans have always lived- there are lots of good reasons (and a few of them end in you losing that thing between your legs that gives you so much joy and frustration- seriously- an infected penis is not going to make anybody happy).



</answer>

<answer from>



caz
Member since: 02 October 2006
Total points: 252 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It seems like it could be either. It could be the start of early labour and if it is they will increase is strength (get more painful) and they will last for longer (lasting 30-60 seconds) and become more frequent. They will slowly become closer together until they are every 3 minutes lasting 30-60 seconds it is that time you would need to phone delivery suite. You would also need to phone if your baby does not move as much as normal or is you start bleeding of if your waters break.



But the contraction which you are feeling now could be a false alarm and they could all settle down and stop and start again when they feel like it. It could be your body having a practice run.
I hope this helps you.
Good luck you will be fine!



Source(s):



I am a Midwife



</answer>



<answer from>



isabella louise parr DOB 14/5/08
Member since: 29 April 2008
Total points: 398 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



look for other signs that you might be going into labour. it might be just braxton hicks. check for a pinky discharge, abdominal pains or your waters breaking. theyare ten mins apart so don't get stressed. you got a long time till they are 2 mins apart. give it another hour and if the pains are getting more painful and the contractions are getting closer together then get yourself to your doctors so you can be checked over to make sure.



</answer>



<answer from>



chase G
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 106 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer>



it seems from reading other questions and answers on this site that different countries have scans at different times but in Australia the first one is usually at 12 weeks and they briefly check internal organs and arms, legs and measure length and heart beat etc. but the main reason for that scan is to measure the fold on the back of the neck to determine the chances of your baby having down syndrome it goes for about half an hour you cannot find out the sex at thyis scan but the next one at 18 weeks they can and they spend about an hour checking everything they can see (the baby wont always cooperate) good luck and have fun

<answer from>



sammyyy
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 2119 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Normally at this scan you will need to have a full bladder (not so full that it's uncomfortable!) as this will push up your uterus and gives a clearer view. That's all you're expected to do for it really. At my scan, the sonographer put the rather cold scan gel on my belly, got a picture up on the screen but kept the telly turned away to she could check everything first (I was told this was totally normal procedure, so don't panic if this happens!) and then turned the screen so we could see it. Words can't describe how amazing that is. I don't know about you, but before I saw my baby I didn't feel pregnant - I had all the symptoms, but due to my morning sickness i'd lost a lot of weight and I wasn't really showing at all. It's truely incredible to see this little tiny person on the screen, knowing that she was actually there! (Obviously at this point I didn't know the gender, but have since found out). Seeing her heart beating as well hit me hardest, it brought tears to my eyes. The sonographer checks out everything - limbs, heart, kidneys etc. and record them on notes within your maternity notes. Depending on how co-operative the baby is, this could take anything from 20 mins to an hour.. there's no set time as to how long they should or will take. At my scan though, I think what made us laugh the most was that my daugher wouldn't co-operate for the sonographer haha. I had to lift my bottom in the air and wriggle my belly to try and get her to move, and had to repeat this about 3 times before she obliged!



Make sure you ask questions about anything if you're not sure, make sure you ask for photos (if your hospital allows this of course) and have some change in case there is a charge for photos. Enjoy it hunny!!



Source(s):



24wk 3d with a girl :)



</answer>

Under the guise of being overly gracious, put the plate aside.  Then, If you would be eating at the table, place it where you mother-in-law would most likely sit. In all three scenarios, I can imagine, your mother-in-law, jumping up and, screaming out of shear joy.

<answer from>



Caroline H
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 215 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think your getting Braxton Hicks. Usually women will notice them by casually brushing their hands against their protruding belly and notice that it has tightened, while others will notice the tight feeling without having to feel it with their hands. Don't panic if you don't notice them. Some women only notice them because they find them to be uncomfortable.



While Taber's medical dictionary may say that they are painless, pregnant women tell a different story, though most would call it uncomfortable rather than painful. If you experience discomfort or pain with these practice contractions, try out techniques you've learned in class to deal with labour, such as breathing, relaxation, massage, movement and more. Often women will find that simply changing position can help with any pain from these contractions. A nice warm bath or shower can also help relieve any achiness and promote relaxation.



So how would you tell the difference between a Braxton Hicks contraction and a true labor contraction? Generally true labour contractions will get longer in length, closer in frequency and stronger in intensity. A Braxton Hicks contraction might get closer together but not consistently, or they may feel stronger but go away when you move around. Some moms say that they only experience Braxton Hicks contractions when moving around and they cease when mom sits down.



Calling your doctor or midwife should happen if you have contractions closer than 12 minutes apart prior to 37 weeks, as this might indicate preterm labour and not Braxton Hicks contractions.



While these many seem like an annoyance, yet another thing to deal with in pregnancy, they are believed to be helpful in preparing your body for labour, even though no noticeable progress can be seen.



True Labour vs. Braxton Hicks



Braxton Hicks V True Labour



Contractions don't get closer together. Contractions do get closer together.



Contractions don't get stronger. Contractions do get stronger.



Contractions tend to be felt only in the front. Contractions tend to be felt all over.



Contractions don't last longer. Contractions do last longer.



Walking has no effect on the contractions. Walking makes the contractions stronger.



Cervix doesn't change with contractions. Cervix opens and thins with contractions.



Hope this helps Good Luck Hun xx.



</answer>



<answer from>



B
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 108 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Try combining the ovulation kit with charting.



Taking your temperature every morning and checking your cervical mucus will let you know when ovulation may be approaching so you won't waste your kits.

<answer>



Your Dr can confirm it with another urine test, and if it's positive they will schedule your first dating ultrasound.  But, just like everyone else said, you will have to get used to being poked.  They take what seems like a ton of blood from you at one of the first few visits, then of course the lovely IV while giving birth, plus epidural, plus whatever else, etc. lol.  The blood test at the Dr will be the most accurate because it will tell you your HCG level.  So, if I were you, I would just get the blood test done if your Dr is offering it!  Good luck and congrats if you are!!



Source(s):



8 month old son, and 16 weeks pregnant with baby #2!!



I used First Reponse 5 days before my missed period for both pregnancies (very anxious to get the results), and they were positive!



</answer>
