<answer>



Generally, if you are pregnant, you will have to get a blood test to confirm it anyway.



When I was pregnant with my son, I had 3 positive tests and I still had to have blood drawn. I was so freaked out I threw up, then fainted. But we got it done!



I would trust the first response over the other two. I know it can read pretty low levels. Dollar store? Eh.



Call your doctor, tell them about the 3 tests, and ask if you need to come in for a blood test.



Source(s):



Personal



</answer>

I've tried walking it out that makes it worse, laying down all day today didnt help, baths and panadol do nothing any suggestions appreciated



</question>



<answer from>
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 782 (Level 2)

<answer>

<answer from>



Hazel T
Member since: 01 April 2008
Total points: 231 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You could always try some antenatal yoga or some simple stretches in the evening after having a bath- it will help you to become more supple and therefore your body should be able to cope with the stretching and rearranging a bit more easily- you can also try rubbing a small amount of deep heat lotion on your joints to help soothe the pain- although not too much!!! lying down will only make you feel more stiff so you do need to keep moving even if it is only small stretches!



</answer>



<answer from>



ndcase07
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 275 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi, I had this same problem, sadly, unless you can lay down there isn't much you can do. Its from the baby pushing on your spine in a funny way. Maybe a nice back rub when you get home would work? I used to rub icy hot on it all the time, it takes the real bad pain away but doesn't take all of it away. Also maybe going in for a better pair of shoes, I know its sounds funny but my doctor told me if you work on your feet all day, you should get a pair of "nurses" shoes, they are made for standing and it would help with taking the stress off your body. That did work for me. Good luck, I feel for you.



Omg I almost forgot two very important ones, I have a yoga ball, one of the bigger ones and I used to sit on it with my legs spread and to the side and I would roll my hips around in a circular motion, oh did that ever so  help me. Also I would get in the position of if you where doing it doggie style (With your butt up) and  roll your hips again in a circular motion like on the ball. This helps move the baby off the spine and it is supposed to help with a better delivery.  I could go on..



</answer>

There are 79 days until your due date on December 20, 2008.

You are 6.6 months pregnant.

Your 1st trimester: March 15, 2008 to June 13, 2008. (0 - 12 weeks)



Your 2nd trimester: June 14, 2008 to September 26, 2008. (13 - 27 weeks)



Your 3rd trimester: September 27, 2008 to December 20, 2008. (28 - 40 weeks)



And Your estimated conception date was between Saturday, February 23, 2008 and Friday, February 29, 2008. ( roughly)

<answer>

I expect it will say on the packet not to use of you are pregnant if that is the case as i think that anything like that is a legal requirement these days.



Best thing is to look at the packet or ask at a pharmacy... some brands may be better to use than others.

<answer>



I read that the body isn't actually craving that particular food it's something else about that food (ingredient wise) that the body may want.



My first pregnancy I craved Cheese (blocks of it).
My second one I craved a mixture of banana and chocolate shakes and pickles and chili.
My third one it was a quart of hamburger dill pickles each day I would eat.
This one I crave Tomatoes, cucumbers and mountain dew.



Who knows what all that means.

<answer from>



me**
Member since: 08 February 2008
Total points: 380 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i ended up having my first and only baby by emaergency c section as i was only 6 months pregnant and once my waters broke they stopped, so i had to be rushed in.



But i went through all of labour and would of done i guess if he hadn't have been so tiny and small.



I went through ALL of the contractions and only had gas and air for 5 mins before i was rushed through to theatre (it was a close call i got to the hosp in time!)



The contractions were excrutiating---i remember thinking "thank god there's no knife in this car else i'll be ending my own life so i dont have to go throught his anymore" lol!!



One minute i was screaming with the pain the next whimpering as i couldnt take it anymore. (My labour went VERY VERY quickly though)



But, looking back, i am glad of the pain as it really helped me to push him out (or try)



Now i didnt GIVE birth (poor fellow only got his little arm and the cord just out of my cervix) but i gave birth to my waters....lol very strange! That did kind of sting down there, but compared to the contractions...... and asking my mum....id say the contractions are the most painful.



However, i personally get more scared thinking about it ocming out and ripping rather than the mind-blowingly painful contractions! lol



</answer>



<answer from>



delivered 1st on 18th march 08
Member since: 17 July 2007
Total points: 390 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Contractions are certainly more painful. Most ppl do not feel much during pushing due to several reasons like they already had contractions so the pain of pushing seems less, The idea of just getting it out gives power , and its quick. For me contractions were 4 hours and pushing was for 10 mins. so later was quite easy...



</answer>



<answer from>



Charli ♥ NOT-SO-PERFECT MUM
Member since: 07 April 2008
Total points: 8101 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



For me yes.
I never even felt my son's coming out, the contractions were killing me. I had 2 drug-free vaginal births, and with my first, I was trying to get off the bed, and my first born son's head was half out. I had no idea.
I didn't know they were out, till they were getting my Husband to cut the cord. But I felt every single contraction.



</answer>



<answer from>



V. S
Member since: 15 November 2007
Total points: 151 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was in labor with no painkillers for 19 hours total. The first 10 hours were uncomfortable but not terribly painful. Sort of like wearing jeans that are too tight, then popping the button open and going aaahh, then they button themselves back up and you're going ow ow but not dying in pain.



The last 9 hours were really bad BUT they are manageable. Definitely the most painful part of childbirth by far.



When it got time to push, it was painful but at that point you really don't care, and you push & push and it's over. I was sore from head to toe but not in pain once he was born. And you really forget the worst of it with time, it's all worth it.



Congrats!



</answer>



<answer from>



Superwom...
Member since: 25 February 2008
Total points: 2987 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most pains are unique but I would have to say yes the contractions hurt much more worse than the actual pushing and without a pain killer, the pushing will be burning and hurting quite a bit but you'll want to do it to get it over with.



</answer>

<question>



Where were you when your water broke?

However, I am 36 weeks pregnant with our 2nd baby, and I'm dilating fast. I'm already at 4cm. (Up from 2cm just 2 weeks ago.) With my daughter, I didn't start to dilate until my water broke.



Now I'm afraid my water will break at work...and in a big gush since I'm already dilated. Lord, that will be embarrassing...I work with hundreds of people. LOL

<question from>



Yahoo girl
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 79 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Need opinions on a woman issue...PLEASE...?



Hello,



Okay, I know a little while ago I posted pretty much the same question, but I was getting it all wrong and what not. I do apologize, because I am tired. Sorry about this.



Anyways, my question is:



I have always had somewhat normal periods and what not. Just in the past two years they have changed a bit, all in all with their times when they come and the flow and that.



Well, I never really worried about that because my doctor told me that is was normal for a woman to have changes like that as they get older.



However, most recently I am experiencing a clear sticky discharge after I am done bleeding from my cycle. What exactly is this, and why does this happen after I am done bleeding?



I have gone to my doctor, and she told me it was due to hormones, but I am not so sure it is. What are your opinions?



Here's some more info to help. My periods usually last for about 5 days and the first two days are the worst with pain/cramps and flow. The other days are not so bad with pain/cramps and flow. Th flow is lighter. When I am fully done bleeding, that's when the discharge begins and it lasts about 4-days thereafter.



Why is this? I can just be standing or sitting and all of a sudden, I will feel like I peed my pants. It's bad, and I always have to change my pants.



Sometimes it's a lot, and sometimes it's not. It can also be thick and sticky, and then runny and very slick. There's no odor or anything. Some people have told me that this means I am fertile, and this is the time to get pregnant, Is that true? I also didn't think that you could get pregnant after your bleeding had stopped.



I am confused, please help. Thanks in advance.



</question>



<answer from>



DenverDi...
Member since: 10 December 2007
Total points: 643 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well unless you have a vaginal infection which consists of discharge, itching, burning, odor, then it shouldn't be anything to worry about. Some women give off discharge automatically without a problem, so your doctor is probably right.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mr. WGAF
Member since: 01 July 2007
Total points: 796 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, if your doctor says it is nothing to worry about, than don't.  I do not think you will find anyone on yahoo answrers that will know more about this than your doctor.  Just continue to act as though you are on your period for an extra 3-4 days.  Wear a pad or something.  I bet after w while this will go away and change also, but may take years.



</answer>



<answer from>



ladylove
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 2391 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



to me it sounds like fertile discharge. as long as u have been checked for stds. i (before i got pregnant) would get this about 1 to 2 weeks after my period.



</answer>



<answer from>



Renate
Member since: 26 March 2007
Total points: 1190 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, after your period you become more fertile that is why the discharge changes every day or other day!  This is the time where you can become pregnant.  "You thought that you can't get pregnant after a period" - you're wrong, that is when the cervical fluid becomes more fertile and allows sperm to last longer, the more fertile the fluid the longer the sperm will last until you ovulate.  Your mos fertile cervical would be the one you describe and runny and very slick.



I agree with your doctor that there is nothing to worry about, it is your body going through changes.



Source(s):



28 weeks pregnant with baby boy



</answer>

<question from>



xhelenx
Member since: 20 November 2006
Total points: 356 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Holidays during maternity Leave?



Is it true that whilst your on maternity leave you are still entitiled to your full anual holiday leave??? So If Im off from the start of next year and dont return to work untill Sept 2009 I will still have 5 weeks to take holiday??? Can't be right can it???



</question>



<answer from>



Canada Baby, 24 weeks :)
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 1444 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I can take all my holidays for the fiscal year before I go on Mat Leave, but I won't get paid for all of them...the company will work out how much I owe once I come back from mat leave.
So kind of (in my company) I'm entitled to the time off, but not necessarily all the pay.



You'll need to check with your own HR dept, every company will be different.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Great



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



baby lexie due 1/8/2009
Member since: 09 May 2008
Total points: 2851 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



with FMLA you get 12 weeks off. Most companies will try to tell you to take any vacation time, or personal days you have because they don't want you to take anymore time off. But they cannot make you do that. My company tries to tell the employees who go on it, that they have to use any vacation time they have but they are not allowed to tell them that. So in other words yes if you do not use any of your time off during your leave then you will have your vacation time there waiting for you when you get back. I'm guessing you are in the UK since you said Holiday, I'm in the states, so I'm not sure if it works the same but I'm guessing it does.



</answer>



<answer from>



burgerme...
Member since: 28 November 2006
Total points: 473 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



All company policy is different so if I were you, I'd as my manager or better yet H.R. I'm on maternity leave now and won't be back til middle of January 2009. I don't think holidays count like Thanksgiving or Christmas because my work will pay me a certain percentage only and EDD will pay the rest. I work for a well known company and they're pretty cool when it comes to any type of leave, but my H.R. hasn't told me about holidays. Good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



jenn
Member since: 19 May 2006
Total points: 647 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't know if it's everywhere.  I'm a teacher and I have almost 2 weeks of Christmas break and 1 week winter break added to my maternity leave because school is closed.  You need to ask your HR department.



</answer>



<answer from>



SydneyMu...
Member since: 13 February 2007
Total points: 14966 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't know where you are, but in Australia they "stop the clock" while you are on maternity leave, so you don't accrue any leave benefits while you are on maternity leave.



Source(s):



RN Midwife, IVF Consultant and mother of 7



</answer>

Yes, before the baby engages it can move in all positions. I used to find my sons leg in the most oddest places.



When they are feet down they are in breach position and when they are head down they are engaged.



I think the baby becomes fully engaged in the mid 30 weeks in preparation for the birth.



So dont worry, sounds like you have a right live one there... but as long as she is in the right place at the right time, and you feel her moving everything is fine

<answer>



At this stage it cannot be a clogged milk duct. If you are worried about breast cancer, thats probably also not it -usually there is no pain involved , so the fact that it is red and bruised shows its something else.

<answer from>



4th & last, due 10/15!
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 4474 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



This happened to me, around the same time, when I was pregnant with my third child. I felt it, had it checked by my doc, she sent me to get an ultrasound, and they said it was 'suspicious' and 'doesn't look good.' So, I was supposed to get a biopsy, and when I got there, a doc came in, looked at it on ultrasound, again, and told me it doesn't look like cancer; it's fibrous tissue, which can be common during pregnancy, as the breasts change... He said I could still have the biopsy, if I insisted, but I decided to wait for 6 months, and get it re-checked... Well, I never went back, because it disappeared! For me, it must have been fibrous tissue, but it was scary, because my birth mom died of breast cancer, at age 55. And, because for a whole month, I thought I may have cancer, being pregnant, and with two other kids! Definitely get it checked, but, don't panic. It could very well be normal changes... Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



Yes I had exactly the same



Did you have an epidural? If so you need to let midwife, doctor or health visitor know as soon as possible.

Hope you get it sorted soon so you can enjoy your new baby

<question>

<answer>



Prawns won't harm you unless you get food poisoning from them. So taking them OUT of something they have been cooked with is completely pointless - if they are carrying listeria they will have contaminated the rest of the food! At that point you might as well at least enjoy them...



You have to decide whether you want to take the very small risk of getting food poisoning from them. You're not any more likely to get it just because you're pregnant, but if you did do then it could harm your baby or make you miscarry.



</answer>

<question from>



justme
Member since: 28 September 2006
Total points: 1059 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Anyone else worried about the effects of the ultrasound?



I read an article that a study at Yale shows that doing a half hour ultra sound at a fairly high intensity but one that is not unheard of, caused neurological damage in the babies of pregnant mice. My first thought was that I have a baby inside me, not a mouse, but the article went on to explain how it does pertain to human fetuses and explained why.
I was very excited to get my ultrasound in two weeks and find out the sex of baby #3 (third and final) but my oldest has high functioning autism which I am sure is due to environmental toxins being too much for her system. So I don't want to stress this new little one's system by having an ultra sound if it really does affect the fetus.



I was never and "alarmist" before but after seeing that my own child has been affected by the toxins of "progress" I can't help but think I am being irresponsible if I just ignore the article and study that was done by Yale.
What do you mom's think?
Here is the link if you want to see:
http://www.pnas.org/content/103/34/12903...



Finally though, I did get a 10 week ultrasound (before I read the article) am worried to not get the 20 week ultrasound becuase what if there is something wrong that they need to deal with right at birth? Everything looked good at the first one but I haven't had any testing done since we would have the baby even if there were problems.



OK, thanks for reading this whole thing and please let me know how you feel as a mom, and about getting the 20 week ultrasound or not (and how this affects you, if at all.)



</question>



<answer from>



Mommy to a prince and a peanut!!
Member since: 04 November 2007
Total points: 5540 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ultrasounds have been found to be completely harmless. It's just another scare tactic....like saying that broccoli causes cancer or that immunizations cause autism.



</answer>

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Starsfan...

<answer>



Well with my first child I has many ultrasounds because at 26 weeks I had a DVT.  So it seemed like at almost every appointment they were doing one after my blood clot to check on my baby. Now she is 2 years old and her doctor always talks about how healthy she is.

shadowta...

<answer>

<answer from>



mommy of twins. #3 Due Feb 09
Member since: 24 July 2007
Total points: 2334 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



it used to be thought that they can be harmful but there has been studies to show them they are completely harmless.. My last pregnancy I was pregnant with twins and was very high risk. I seen my reg dr and a MFM dr and i had ultrasounds preformed every 2 weeks for the first trimester and after that weekly and in the end i had then done a few times a week. They did several external and internal ultrasounds and my daughters are very healthy and smart.. i had more ultrasounds that i could count.. They are done by sound waves.. and have changed much over the years due to their demand and knowledge they provide.. if there were by chance a risk, which i really believe to not be there, the benefits far out weigh any possible risk there could be. Many babies are saved from life threatening conditions because they have been detected in the uterus.



</answer>



<answer from>



wednesday child
Member since: 22 April 2008
Total points: 970 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i am not a mom but i've had ultrasound before both in my heart and in tummy. ultrasound is commonly used by medical technicians for various reasons and there's really nothing to worry about. it's just a procedure to find out more about what's going on inside us without doing invasive surgeries.
so don't worry and advanced congratulations on your forthcoming baby.



</answer>



<answer from>



not_yet_...
Member since: 20 January 2008
Total points: 2556 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've had 2 ultrasounds, one for my daughter and one for my cousin (my aunt can't carry children), both are fine, my daughter is very smart for her age as in my cousin, ultrasounds help find out if there is something wrong early and it is the safest way to check on the baby, x-rays are very dangerous. they've been doing ultrasounds for a long time and if there was really that big of a problem then they wouldn't do them



</answer>



<answer from>



nikki g
Member since: 15 July 2008
Total points: 317 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



As a mom of 4 and a nurse, I think that the US that you have at 20wks is the most important one that you could have.  That's when they do a complete look at your uterus, placenta, and most important the size of the baby, and measurements (arms, head, torso, legs, etc).  They also have the ability to measure the Fluid on the baby's neck, called the nuchal translucency-also known as the nuchal fold.  Fetal nasal bone evaluation is another type of US exam that increases Downs Syndrome detection to 95%, making the combined screening more effective than any other screening tests.
I have to have an US every month because I have a uterine abnormality, and after 4 kids and lots and lots of US, I feel that the benefits outweigh any risks with US.  Hope this helps you, Congratulations on your baby!



</answer>



<answer from>



Angellov...
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 1170 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



i have three children i had alot of ultrasounds because of medical situations. all three of my kids are healthy, normal, and really smart so no i dont worry about ultrasounds.



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Does anyone know what the average fetal heartbeat for boys and girls is?



I'm just curious actually as they are so many stories that you hear about, and how you can distinguish whether the baby is a boy or a girl by the rates and how different the heart rates are! Any answers appreciated, thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



M Kerr RN L&D
Member since: 04 March 2007
Total points: 48052 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



120-180!



They can vary with both sexes!



Both my boys and girls were in the 160 range.



Source(s):



Mom of twin girls and 2 boys!



</answer>

<question from>



A A
Member since: 21 May 2008
Total points: 2133 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Is recovery time @ the hospital LONGER for a C-section birth?



I'm curious what the OVERALL hospital time required is for a C-section as opposed to traditional birth.



Anyone know/ have experience?



</question>



<additional details>



If you guys vote this as interesting I will favorite answer a RANDOM person!!!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Erica M
Member since: 07 June 2006
Total points: 1076 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yes...Well, when you deliver normally they keep you for 24-48 hours. and for a C-section they keep you for three days.



Source(s):



Had c-section



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thx



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Alesha S
Member since: 27 June 2008
Total points: 943 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



With a vaginal birth, no complications, you must be in the hospital for 24 hours after delivery. For a C-section, no other complications, you have a minimum of 48 hours after delivery. They can keep you longer depending on the healing of your incision. For example, if it is still seeping they may want to keep you an extra day. If you had to have a c-section because of fetal distress they may keep your baby and release you. It is all determined on a case to case basis if extra time is needed, but the above times are the normal minimum.



Source(s):



20 weeks with baby girl #3



</answer>



<answer from>



Stephanie M
Member since: 22 March 2007
Total points: 3688 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's at least 2 days for a c-section.  They need to make sure your uterus is contracting back to normal and make sure your incision is healing properly.  It can be up to 5 days though.  It really depends on the hospital and of course if there are complications you will definitely be in longer.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tracy B
Member since: 13 April 2008
Total points: 1145 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had a csection and was in the hospital for 5 days. they want to make sure, since its a major surgery that your healing the right way. Youcant walk for 24 hours after you have a csection. You cant even feel your legs and your hooked up to a catheter. Honestly, I prefered it over a vaginal because you feel nothing. THe scar heals but i think its safer then vaginal. they pamper you more too when your a csection patient.



Source(s):



Mommy of a 3 month old baby girl



</answer>

Member since: 19 July 2008

my sister had vaginal birth and was out of the hospital in a day ...my first c section i was in the hospital for 5 days. second c section i was in hospital for 2 days



</answer>



<answer from>



swt_blu_...
Member since: 06 March 2007

<answer>



I was told to expect 24-48 hours with a vaginal birth and 48-36 hours with a c-section. Also, total recovery time (including time at home) is longer with a section.



</answer>

<answer from>



Dr. Arnold
Member since: 15 September 2006
Total points: 715 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The reason we never provide answers over the phone to our patients stems from there usually being bad news that needs to be discussed in person as opposed to over the phone. When nothing is wrong, we will provide the results (ex. Positive or Negative.) on pregnancies.



Source(s):



M.D.



</answer>

dont worry too much in this matter, important is you must have the right focus one at a time, then move on with another once u achieve..life will be much easier and contented. remember to stay healthy and happy, you will know what u want eventually.

<answer from>



Vpot
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 3123 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well... assume that you are 4-8 weeks, which is when the symptoms would normally start showing up, and wait another 4 weeks before you schedule an ultrasound, this will make sure that you will actually see something.



ALSO, it is not uncommon for women who are breastfeeding to produce positive pregnancy readings, because you are breastfeeding, your body still thinks it's pregnant, which is why most people don't get a period while breastfeeding.



</answer>

<question>

I read all over the web that this is typical and if I lose a few pounds in the first trimester, there's nothing to worry about.  I went to my Doctor last week for a bad cold and I lost 3 lbs since my pre-natal check up 3 weeks prior! I love food and although I haven't had a huge appetite I try to eat a lot of whole grains, fruits, and veggies.  I always feel like I'm still hungry though.  I'm 5'6 and a size 13, so you know I'm eating!  Did anyone else have this problem during Pregnancy?  This is my first.  Thanks



</question>



<answer from>

<answer from>



Barbara
Member since: 24 March 2007
Total points: 4805 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You will no doubt get lots of helpful answers with suggestions as to what this might be, but please, please call your doctor's office for the "best answer" rather than relying on Yahoo!Answers for this one.



From my own four pregnancies I can remember many different pains and sensations in the last weeks such as the one you're describing, none of which was ever a problem.  But it's always best to rely on your doctor's advice at this point.



Best of luck to you!



</answer>



<answer from>



kelsey
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 12256 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It could be a fibroid. A fibroid is a growth that lots of women have, but aren't even aware of until they are pregnant.  If the fibroid gets pinched, it can cause pain.  this happened to me.



</answer>

<answer from>



Marie
Member since: 23 March 2008
Total points: 1056 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



First, I would try getting some kind of cat repellent and putting it in or near the doorway of the room. It won't hurt the kitty or people, just give her a nasty whiff of air every time she tries to go close.  I know, however, that this does not deter a lot of persistent darlings, so the next step might be getting a hanging rod and some kind of curtains that could hang over the door to the baby's room, and find some way to attach it to the frame, via hooks or some nice-looking method.



When it comes down to it, you're going to have to find some way to keep that cat out of the baby's room, either now or when it has arrived.



I have a cat and love her, and would not get rid of her in this case.  However, I would have no reservations about doing whatever it took to keep her out of the nursery room.



Last resort in my book, because it could be expensive and hard to install, would be a shock collar.  They make them for settings like yours, where they just extend for the doorway you don't want your animal near.  When they get too close, it shocks them.  You may want to look into that, because I guarantee you, it may sound cruel, but if that cat gets shocked once, it's not going to chance it again.



Best of luck!!



</answer>



<answer from>



tamson.a...
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 523 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Wow that is a difficult one. Remember she is hormonal and stressed and uncomfortable, it's all part of being pregnant, I spent the whole time completely irrational and on the verge of tears so tread carefully.



There are a few things you can try, tin foil in the cot, cats hate it so they jump straight back out and learn not to do it, slightly more extreme is sticky fly paper, not nice but if its the safety of your baby.



Try writing what you asked us down in a letter to her, she may scrunch it up, but she'll go back and read it when she's calmed down again. Just make it about the babies safety, remember it's a mother's instinct to protect her baby, it's just that she may be mothering the pets untill the baby's born, again its the hormones, they do funny things.



And good luck, it's refreshing to hear a father to be that's doing his bit so thank you for giving me some hope for the men on here.

<question>



I was really stupid and had sex without protection but just started to have sex...?

<answer>



Hey chick, you could well be pregnant wether youve had your period or not and wether he came or not, id wait a few weeks and do a test, xxx

<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 25270 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Extremely low.



LAM (lactational amenhorrhea method) is a highly reliable form of birth control, (1% failure rate) and if you are 3 months post-partum, haven't had a period, and are breastfeeding exclusively, you meet the criteria.



</answer>

<question>

When she had my Baby Sister Emily, they detected meth in both my moms and the baby's systems. We were taken and put in my grandmothers custody and a year later pat died and my mom got pregnant with a different mans child and got clean. She had my brother David and he is now 4. Then Davids father went back to prison. When David turned two my mother started dating a guy named Eric. He doesn't let her drink or do any drugs. 5 months ago she announced that she was pregnant again and a week ago she gave birth to my newest Babys sister Kasey (which made me angry that she named her one letter away from my name, Katey, because she doesn't try to be apart of my life). I may be wrong, but i do not think it is right for her to have any other children after she got three of her kids taken away. All she will do is send me 30$ in the mail. About two months ago i had my wisdom teeth removed, and it was a slightly major surgery because I have TMJ (my joints in my jaw don't fit right because of my over bite) and all four teeth were EXTREMELY impacted. Member since: 13 December 2006
Total points: 3220 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Pregnancy tests are not reliable until it is within 4 or 5 days of when your girlfriend would normally begin her period. If it is within 5 days of having sex and your girlfriend does not want to get pregnant, I would suggest she try to get the morning-after pill. It is now available without a prescription over the counter at certain pharmacies (you have to ask the pharmacist to get it for you).Anyone 18 or over can get morning after pills (they are called Plan B) this way. If she is under 18, then you need a doctor's prescription for it. Fortunately, you should be able to get it without much bother if you and/or her go to Planned Parenthood, which is a very helpful and supportive place. You can also get other birth control, free condoms and plenty of useful advice on how to avoid these sorts of situations in the future.



Source(s):



my own experience



</answer>



<asker's comment>



how do i get that morning after pill? any generic name?



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Jaedyn's Mommy
Member since: 27 August 2007
Total points: 344 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



it depends on her period. the soonest you'll be able to tell would be around 3 days before she's supposed to get her period. if her period is late, the test will be really accurate. just remember that it is possible to have a false negative (a test that says she's not pregnant, but she really is). a false positive is possible but not likely. also, she could get her period and still be pregnant, which is why its best to wait until after her period is late



</answer>

snowbarb...

<question>



Question about planned parenthood?



Well i had sex with my gf 2 weeks ago, we used a condom, but she missed her period for a week. Thanks, and i know there will be alot of people who flame us but please, just keep it to yourself.

<additional details>

</additional details>



<answer from>



KKingS
Member since: 20 December 2006
Total points: 21102 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



First, you are worrying way before it is necessary.  If you only had sex one time and you used protection...chances are not high for her to be pregnant.



You two sound rather young.  It is very common for girls to have irregular periods off and on for years until their bodies really adjust.  Even after 15 years of having a cycle, I will still occassionaly get a strange period, or even miss one.



You will have to call planned parenthood in your area to find those questions out.  It differs from state to state, so it is just best to call the source.  If she is a minor, she *may* need a parent or legal guardian to approve of an abortion.  And from that point on, she would need to inform every new doctor she sees that she has had an abortion (new client forms request that information...particularly with GYNs.)



But until you get a positive on a test, just calm down!



</answer>



<answer from>



In Love
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 202 (Level 1)



</answer from>

I plan on starting on a regular birth control as soon as possible, so no need to advise me on that. I understand that condoms and birth control should always be used, Plan B is just for emergencies, but this is an emergency. I unfortunately made a mistake two days ago that I very much regret.

Kell-o
Member since: 13 May 2008

<answer>



You could take another plan b - but just so you know they can mess up your system making your very irregular for awhile.  So, if you are irregular after that, don't assume you are pregnant.  You probably weren't ovulating so the chances aren't that high, BUT anytime you have unprotected sex you could get pregnant.  Also, maybe if drinking is the reason you are making bad choices, you shouldn't be drinking.  You can't blame alcohol for a bad choice, because you made the choice to drink . . .



Please get some birth control and calm down on the drinking until you are responsible enough to handle things.



</answer>

<question>



How long after a missed period should i freak out?



how long after a missed period should i begin to worry if i'm pregnant. i was due on sun/mon and now it's wends. i did a prego test on tues morning but it came back neg and now it's wends and still no auntie flow? i have an apt with my gyn next week but i'm a little anxious.



i have full boobs now and puffy niples they're not as sensitive as late last week.



</question>



<answer from>



2 Due June 6, 2009!
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 450 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Some pregnancy tests aren't as sensitive and suggest waiting one week after your missed period. Good luck, and baby dust.



</answer>



<answer from>



HooKooDo...
Member since: 12 September 2007
Total points: 10131 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



If AF is late and an HPT gave a BFN, then you apparently ovulated late this month.  That doesn't change the odds of if you are pregnant or not this month, ovulation was just late (and therefore AF will be late, assuming you're not pregnant).  So it might be that you're pregnant and it might be that you are simply late.  The normal advice is to wait a week.  If AF still has not shown up, take another test.  Repeat the process until you get either AF or a BFP.



</answer>



<answer from>



xenathir...
Member since: 31 March 2007
Total points: 158 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you are that freaked out about being pregnant maybe you should not be having sex or should be on birth control at the very least.



</answer>

<answer>



That is a ridiculous misconception! I remember hearing it all over the place when I was younger. Two condoms do not work better than one. If one is used properly, it is 99.7% effective. <question>



I'm experiencing chills with no fever, is this normal during pregnancy\?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



As long as there isn't a fever, I would say there is nothing you can do, even if it isn't normal. I experience times when i was pregnant that I was colder then everyone else. <question>



Do you know what happens when you smoke while you prego?



im at school and i need help on this project



</question>



<answer from>



Due today
Member since: 29 June 2007
Total points: 11199 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



baby can be born with many health problems especially in the lungs. asthma will most likel be a factor..low birth weight.. and as for themother.. youll be huffin and puffin alot earlier than a non smoking pregnnt woman would.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kell-o
Member since: 13 May 2008
Total points: 4937 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



The baby ingests everything you do.  So, if you have a cigarette the baby is having one also.  It can cause low birth weight and deprivation of oxygen.



</answer>



<answer from>



angelmom...
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 2549 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It can cause pre-term labor and premature rupture of membranes. For the baby it can cause asthma and other breathing problems that they will experience for life. It will have many horrible effects on their lung development. If the mother does have premature rupture of membranes and give birth prematurely they suffer from many more problems, such as brain bleeds which can cause cerebral pausy, blindness, etc. It can also cause death.



</answer>



<answer from>



Freyas Mummy & Daddy
Member since: 28 December 2007
Total points: 1149 (Level 3)



</answer from>

</answer>

Okay, For the past 3 or 4 weeks i have been feeling sort of out of wack.
Pretty much my "symptoms" are.



- Feeling tired, or worn out and irritated for everything.



- i feel heavy, i dont know how to explain i just "feel" heavier ( Like my stomache, boobs arms, etc)



- I feel like i need to eat, not BIG meals, but just small meals throughout the day...?



- Ive had the worst back ache and sleepless nights for the past 3 days, i feel like i havent gotten a good nights rest in ages.



- Im also having something kind of like a period..?



The blood is mostly, ( if not all) brownish blood, some red blood but i think that was like a drop or two, its been about happening on and off since last tuesday, ( keep in mind its not BLEEDING, its more like an occasional drip )

Tia P
Member since: 14 July 2008

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



all your symtoms could just be that your going to get your period,or that your pregnant.the only way to tell is by going to the doctors and getting a blood test or buying a home pregnancy test.everyones pregnancy symtoms differ so it's a bit hard to accuretly say if you sound pregnant or not. good luck,i hope you get the result your looking for.



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Pregnancy Going Horrible. Help ?



im somewhere between 6-7 weeks pregnant not sure exactly last period august 5th. Im getting Horrible pains, in my stomach and my back. what can i take for pain? Everything i can smell is making me throw up, I cant eat anything without feeling sick after wards and throwing up. I bought some prenatal vitamins from the store last night and i started taking them. What can i do to feel better. This is my first baby and this experience so far is horrible.



</question>



<answer from>



Emma-on-the-way~39 weeks~
Member since: 04 July 2008
Total points: 4287 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Join the club! Pregnancy is no where close to being fun, especially in the beginning and in the end. You can take regular srength tylenol for the pains you are having but nothing really helps the morning sickness and the feeling you get with that. Try as much as you can to relax. take your prenatal vitamins right before you lie down to go to bed for the night, this should help you keep them down. Good luck and enjoy it!



Source(s):



39 weeks due Oct 8th and won't miss pregnancy one bit!



</answer>



<answer from>



Sparkler...
Member since: 19 June 2008
Total points: 1077 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are going through a hormone surge and I promise it will get easier....I experienced similar pain at 5 weeks all in my back and hips.  I spent a whole day in agony, but it did go away.  The smells were also unbearable and the intensity lasted until about 13 weeks.  As difficult as this time is and as insensitve as this sounds, please be grateful for all that you are experiencing as its an indication that everything is going as it should.  You should be worried if you did not have any symptoms at all.  Best wishes.



</answer>



<answer from>



angelmom...
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 2555 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Don't complain so much, that is not a pregnancy going horrible. A pregnancy going horrible is when your water breaks at 24 weeks, you give birth at 24 weeks 4 days and your son dies 26 days later. Be happy you are being able to experience the "joys" of being pregnant.



To answer your question you can take Tylenol for the pain, only one tablet of regular strength, and as for the nausea and vomiting try eating some crackers with some mustard. If that doesn't work try some ginger, or some vitamin B6.



</answer>

<answer>



for the belly and back cramps..you can take regular tylenol..those period like cramps are normal. if you cant hold ANYTHING down you doctor may be able to prescribe you a pill made specificaaly for pregnant woman.. its an anti nausea pill called diclectin.. its a little white pill that even has a little picture of a pregnant woman on it.



other than that.. one weird thing i heard of from my sister in laws doctor to stop nausea is..salted chips.

<answer>



Welcome to the wonderful world of pregnancy. Eat crackers and try to avoid spicy and greasy foods. That will make your nausea worse. The only thing you can take is Tylenol. Or you can ask your doctor if it gets to bad.



</answer>



<answer from>



ZeZe
Member since: 30 July 2008
Total points: 4559 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



ha ha sweetie, this is just the beginning next you'll have bloating, heartburn, cramps, everything in your body will ache, trouble sleeping and the list just goes on!!! Unfortunately until you're twelve weeks it's not a good idea to take any medications, the first twelve weeks are crucial for your babies development and any medication you take can harm him or her. For the nausea I suggest saltine crackers, keep them by your bed and eat them as soon as you wake up or when ever you feel tummy trouble. Also, do your best to always have food in your tummy, the longer you go without food the sicker you'll become. Another option, is ginger. I've never tried it but I heard it works great. You could also try sucking on hard candy, that helps me! As for the horrible pains in your tummy and back the only thing you can really do is take a warm bath (not over 110 degrees) or have your partner massage you. Stay away from heating pads, the heat could harm the baby unless your doctor says differently.  Good luck. Also, morning sickness usually goes away at about twelve weeks. So there is some hope! :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Mama to be
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 4293 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was the same way,  I know it's hard, but you have to try to keep some food in your stomache.  Leaving yourself hungry will just make it worse.



Especially if you take your prenatal vitamin on an empty stomache.



Talk to your doctor, there are medications out there made specifically for nausea in pregnancy.  I live in Canada and was prescribed Diclectin.  It would be worth it to ask about it.



IF your last period started on the 5th of August then you would be 8 weeks and one day pregnant today.  (being october 1st.)



</answer>

<answer>



yup all sounds well so far. when i was pregnant with my daughter i was sick all the way through, morning and night, right up until she was born. nothing i could do made me better. walking along the street, oops, throw up, cooking was a big no no, went right off coffee. it was awful i couldn't keep food down and actually lost weight. my doctor wouldn't give me anything and all the advice anyone would give was peppermint tea and ginger biscuits yuck! so apart from going to see your doctor, who may well be more understanding than mine, your pretty stuck with it hopefully your like the majority who stop feeling sick around 12 weeks. all i can advise is taking it as easy as is possible and it will all be over sooner than you think and it will all be worth it good luck .

<answer>



With my first pregnancy I bled a total of three times. The first two was around the time that I would have had my regular period, the first two months of my pregnancy. It was light and lasted only a couple of days each. The third time was when I was 12 weeks and I had a lot of really dark blood. I went to the ER and was told I was having a miscarriage. I had an ultrasound, and she was still in there. I went full term with her with no other complications, she came out 8.8lbs, and very healthy. She is now almost 5 years old and doing great! :)



Source(s):



Now 32 weeks pregnant with my second, no bleeding so far, thank goodness. It can be a bit of a scare.

<answer>

My Son was born 8lbs. 5oz. and he just turned 9 last Sunday.  My daughter was born 6lbs. 14oz. and is now 15 months old.  Both are extremely healthy and happy.  Just follow what your Dr. tells you and you should be fine.  I was on bed rest for 3 months with my daughter in the beginning but things worked out great.

<question>



When do you think I should take a hpt?



I had my last period Aug 30, it was my first one since having a baby. I had unprotected sex with my hubby a few times last week. I'm feeling slightly nauseous...like I was when I was pregnant the first time...and haven't had my period again. I don't know what my cycle would be since I've only had the one period.I don't know what my regular cycle was even before baby. I went off BC, got pregnant, miscarried, got pregnant after the next normal period. Before that I was on BC for 7 years. I don't take any birth control now. It's only 6 months sooner than TT#2 so I'm not worried about being pregnant, just the financial part of it.I took a hpt this afternoon, but it came out negative. How long should I wait before taking another home pregnancy test to see if I'm pregnant again?



</question>



<additional details>



DS is 10 months, so I think my body is used to no baby



</additional details>



<answer from>



Lily N
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 153 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



With a take home pregnancy test you won't be able to tell until about 5 weeks after you conceived, so I would wait a month to see if you have your period and then take the test if you don't flow. It could be that your body is still getting used to not having a baby in it eh? :)



</answer>

</asker's comment>

<answer from>



catcarle...
Member since: 02 June 2006
Total points: 452 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are many prescription prenatal vitamins out there, and they're often combinations of vitamins, dha supplements, and stool softeners (since preggo ladies are often constipated).  If you are trying to conceive, or are pregnant, your doctor will either automatically write an rx or ask if you want one.



There are also numerous prenatal vitamins available over the counter.



Personally, I chose to stick with an over the counter prenatal, as it was just as good and cheaper than the rx one, even with a copay.



</answer>



<answer from>



Shevin R
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 646 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



They can if you want them to. I had them prescribed with my first baby. It got annoying though b/c almost every time I went to get them they were a different price. Then when I compared them to the ones that I had from OTC that I was taking before I got pregnant they were the same. So, with my last 2 pregnancies I took OTC and I & the both boys were fine.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sharon C

<answer>



My doctor did. In fact some docs might give you samples of several prenatal vitamins so that you can try them and determine which you prefer. You may want to your doctor or a person at the clinic you are going to for prenatal care to ask if they want to prescribe something or if there is an acceptable over the counter (OTC) alternative.



</answer>



<answer from>



Pampered Chef VA!
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 115 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Doctors do prescribe prenatal vitamins, but there are also various over-the-counter prenatals available for anyone to purchase.  In order for you baby to benefit the most from your prenatals, the MD may prescribe you one high in a specific vitamin/mineral/ingredient.  Some prenatals can cause sickness (morning/all day-depends!) while others are less harsh on a woman's system.  I'd check with your MD before taking any additional vitamin, for the safety and maximum benefit of yourself and your unborn child,



</answer>

<question from>



stuffy nose
Member since: 26 September 2008

</question from>



<question>



My throat is swollen?



I am 36 weeks pregnant and I am miserable. I cannot breathe through my nose (for the past 6 month) and now since two weeks ago I feel like my throat is swollen.  I feel like there is something stuck in my throat (I don’t have the cold or the flue). My ob told me to take Sudafed but it doesn’t help. Is anyone going through this, and if so did you find a way to deal with it???? Please help it’s so uncomfortable.



</question>



<answer from>



Emma-on-the-way~39 weeks~
Member since: 04 July 2008
Total points: 4289 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Go buy a baby vapor bath soap. Its like 5.00 in Canada. Soak in a warm, not hot, bath for a while and try and relax. Go to the local healthy food store and get some eucalyptus oil, then go get some peppermint tea, lemon, and honey.  Rub the oil directly on your chest and throat, you can also diffuse it in water or in the air to help you breathe. Drink the peppermint tea ( to help you relax) mixed with the honey and lemon ( both  remedies of the throat).



Not only am I 39 weeks pregnant and experiencing the same things, I am in the middle of training to be a professional singer and thus use these remedies when I need these problems fixed fast. They work! Good luck!



Source(s):



39 weeks due Oct 8th, in second year of Bachelor of Music degree majoring in Opera Performance.



</answer>

stellaba...

<question>



Could I be expecting again?



I was due for my period on 5th September but only had a very slight bleed, i have spoken to someone who said it sounded very much like an implantation bleed as it only lasted one day and was very dark brown, It was not even enough to fill a panty liner.
I have taken several HPT's but all have come back negative.
I have still not received my normal period and am always very regular following my 28 day cycle.
Do you think there is a possibility I could be expecting baby number 2?
I already have a 10 month old daughter via c-section.
Do you think I could be pregnant again..?



I HAVE JUST TAKEN ANOTHER HPT AND IT'S STILL SAYING NEGATIVE!!



WHAT ARE MY CHANCES OF ACTUALLY BEING PREGNANT??



</question>



<additional details>



LOULOU the month has passed already



</additional details>



<answer from>



2 Due June 6, 2009!
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 460 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sounds like chances are good. Some women will never test positive on a home pregnancy test, and it differs from pregnancy to pregnancy. I would see your doctor to get a blood test performed. Good luck, and congrats.



</answer>



<answer from>



Emma-on-the-way~39 weeks~
Member since: 04 July 2008
Total points: 4289 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would wait another week and test one more time. In the mean time, book an appointment with your doctor and get a blood test done because that does seem super frustrating and there is definitely a possibility that you are.



Source(s):



39 weeks due Oct 8th



</answer>



<answer from>



LouLou
Member since: 21 January 2007
Total points: 1207 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Could be anything...periods play up, as most women know. It may be that you come on later in the month. I had problems with spotting this month when my normal period was due, kept coming on/off then at the end of this month, i get my period as normal...These things happen !



</answer>



<answer from>



nikki g
Member since: 15 July 2008
Total points: 331 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are almost a month late for your period, and most HPT can detect HCG in your urine by now.  If you have had unprotected sex around the time you were ovulating than yes you could be, but I would probably see your Dr. just to make sure nothing else is wrong.  If you are pregnant, don't freak, all 4 of my children are 15 months apart.  4 under 4!



</answer>

<answer>



If you think that you might be pregnant then you should either see a doctor a take a home pregnancy test, because a lot of the symptoms are the same for PMS and pregnancy. Never assume you are or aren't pregnant. Its best to find out so you can take the necessary precautions.

<answer from>



Emma-on-the-way~39 weeks~
Member since: 04 July 2008
Total points: 4289 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer from>



HotMama♥ 33wks with a Girl!
Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 3753 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I hear/feel movements that could be mistake for bones cracking but I am pretty sure that's not the the case.  I am pretty sure its just the baby flicking against the inside of your uterus and swishing around the amniotic fluid.  The baby's bones are too flexible to be "cracking".  I wouldn't worry about it.  Ask your OB if you're concerned.



Source(s):



33 weeks pregnant with a very active baby girl!!!

<answer from>



Jill
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 61321 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



With the ones used in medical facilities - the earliest is about 12 weeks.



With the ones you buy online or in retail stores - sometimes you will never hear it, because they are cheaply made and most women don't know how to use them properly or know where to look for the heartbeat or know all the little tricks of the trade in picking up the heartbeat.



So don't be surprised if you can't find it.



Source(s):



RN, OB, L&D



</answer>



<answer from>



Lynne N
Member since: 15 August 2008
Total points: 2944 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The recommendation is about 20 weeks for the home ones - simply because they're not as good as the professional ones, nor are you as well trained in how to use them as the professionals! If you fail to hear a heartbeat at say, 17 weeks - you might panic unnecessarily, as a midwife would probably find it within seconds.



It's possible to hear the heartbeat as early as 10 weeks, but i urge you not to depend on it until 20 weeks. You'll get yourself worked up over nothing.
My sister in law had one and made a hospital trip at about 15 weeks when she couldn't hear it. Yesterday, she gave birth to a healthy 8lb 13 girl.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kirsty. Mummy To Be 19.12.08

<answer from>



jya_1124
Member since: 24 June 2007
Total points: 135 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



How early you can hear the baby's heartbeat is dependent on many variables. We expect to be able to hear the baby with an amplified doppler by about 12 weeks of gestation -- BUT there are many variables to be taken into consideration.



One of the reasons that we may not be able to hear the baby at that point is the position of the uterus or the position of the baby in the uterus. Another reason is that many mothers have an additional layer of fat just above the pubic bone. This is the area we listen through when we are looking for a very small baby at around 12 weeks. Sometimes it can be difficult to locate the baby or hear it when you are listening through a little extra padding.



If there is any question about the well-being of the baby, we usually do a quick ultrasound in our office to reassure us and the mother that the baby is okay. That way we can actually see the heart beating, and we don't worry about hearing it until the next visit.



Good luck :)



Source(s):



http://pregnancyandbaby.com/pregnancy/ba...



</answer>



<answer from>



Take My Cherry its Tasty ;) ™
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 6731 (Level 5)

<answer from>



sammyyy
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 2129 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Well when I was 17 weeks pregnant my doctor couldn't pick up my baby's heartbeat on a doppler! I was terrified. But he told me not worry because the baby can be laying awkwardly and the position of the placenta plays a role too. Mine's 'anterior' which means it's at the front, which is why it's harder to pick up my baby's heartbeat. Also your uterus is still between your pelvis which obviously makes a difference. I think 12 weeks onwards it starts to 'come out' so I reckon around then would be good to start trying to hear it. It's well worth the wait though :)



</answer>



<answer from>



DIDI =0]
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 237 (Level 1)

<answer from>



P&B
Member since: 17 July 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



From around 10 weeks, however, it very much depends on your anatomy and that size of the foetus.  Eg. If you have an anterior placenta (placenta is on the font wall of your uterus) it can be more difficult to locate.



Source(s):



http://www.anawiz.com/acatalog/fetal_dop...
http://www.hi-bebe.co.uk/doppler_tips.ht...



http://www.fetaldopplerfacts.org/facts/d...



</answer>

<answer from>



Jill
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 61321 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Talk to your doctor. It's normal to have many aches and pains as pregnancy progresses, it's also normal to be tired and not feel well. But usually by 4-6 months you start feeling more normal, have more energy, etc.



You can certainly take days off if you need them, but there's no need to go off work completely and on bedrest unless your doctor orders it. One early miscarriage does not pose a risk to this pregnancy, especially since you have now made it out of the first trimester.



Source(s):



RN, OB, L&D



</answer>



<answer from>

It is always better to be safer then sorry.

<answer>



I've had 2 children, 1 miscarriage & now pregnant again. Know that feeling light headed can be anemia or just part of your body trying to keep the blood flow up since you are pregnant. Mine always seem to be on the lower stomach to the sides a little bit and going down to the pubic area.  It is always a good idea to call your dr if you are concerned.  Best of luck to you!

tricksie...

yes they are. your body can play plenty of tricks on you, trust me you'll know when your ready!



</answer>



<answer from>



Jill
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 61323 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Are they coming and going and regular intervals, or is it a constant cramp? Does your uterus feel like it's getting firm when you feel it?



It could just be normal pregnancy cramping and not actually contractions at all.



Source(s):



RN, OB, L&D



</answer>



<answer from>



Mrs S.
Member since: 08 August 2007
Total points: 2277 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



it's not that it's false labor, it's just everything starting up slowly.  Your body is getting ready.  Yes that's how contractions feel at first when they're small--like cramping.  If they become more intense or regular then you should go to the hospital.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jessica S
Member since: 12 March 2008
Total points: 1237 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It could just be Braxton Hicks contractions. But on the other hand, it could be actual contractions. If you feel them in a consistent pattern for 3 or more hours, you should go to L&D. Its not cramping, its actual contractions. I would say since you are close to having the baby it was just BH though.



</answer>

Yep its true!

<answer>



Yes. WOmen ovulate about 14 days after their period. So you really have about 4-5 days that you can get pregnant. Because sperm can live inside a women for up to 72 hrs you can have sex a few days before you ovulate. But yes if you don't get pregnant, you have to wait till next month to try.



</answer>

<answer from>



Leenie B
Member since: 20 March 2008
Total points: 1275 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your wife is absolutely right.  There's a 3-day long (ish) window in the middle of the month when she can conceive.  The first poster is slightly off--she will actually ovulate 14 days BEFORE her next period, not 14 days after her previous one.  There's only a difference if she doesn't have 28-day cycles.



Also-and you probably don't want to hear this-having sex too much can actually decrease your chances of conceiving.  Every other day is usually sufficient, and any more than that can lower your sperm count too much to be effective.  Not saying daily sex won't do the job, but it actually doesn't make it more likely like lots of people think.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lori L
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 395 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

Nadia Levassuer
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 195 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Even if you did everything naturally with your miscarriage, you still need to see a gynocologist. They can help see why you may of miscarried and how to help you prevent that in the future.



Also, I have often heard that having sex everyday is the best way to get pregnant. If you wait awhile the sperm won't be as active.



I'd also suggest a digital ovulation predictor.I tryed the line ones and they never seem to work for me.



Try getting a basal thermometer- it has a chart in there where you can chart your temperature, if you have a normal 28 day cycle, you should be most fertile around the 14th day from the day your period starts. When you are ovulating your basal temperature will rise. You ahve to make sure you take if every morning before you do anything- get out of bed, brush your teeth, even pee- then write it down.



Good luck to you :)



</answer>

<answer>



I use the Saliva Ovulation Scope (I purchased at Wal-Mart for $20), ovulation predictor strips (Bought LH Strips off ebay-100 for $20), Ovulation Chart (www.yourdays.com) and cough syrup ($2 per bottle). Yes, cough syrup. I swear it helped me get pregnant with my second child. Some cough syrups contain an agent, guaifenesin, that helps thin cervical mucous., which helps sperm travel through the cervix and get to the egg so it can fertilize it! I took 2 tsp three times daily around the time of the month that I ovulated, it worked the first month! These are all the things I suggest to conceive. Hope they help! Best of luck TTC!



</answer>

<answer>

Member since: 29 July 2008

<question>



Planned c-section. How early befor due date?



my due dat is december 24. my doc told me today the c/section will be made no early than 39 weeks.?????? is that normal? i had my first child also c/section with 37. that was in germany tho. he said he is just following what the united states thing says is recommended. im way to scared i go in labor and then i have to have emergency c/section. he said the lungs are not fully mature before 39 weeks and if he would be born early he would might have to be in NICU. my daughter was perfect with 37 weeks. is he just crazy or is that normal what he thinks?



</question>



<answer from>



angelmom...
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 2559 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The baby is full term at 37 weeks, so that is odd. I think I would get a second opinion.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kristi
Member since: 29 July 2007
Total points: 5715 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



That's standard in the USA.  C-sections are scheduled at 39 weeks, no earlier.  With my second son, I went into labor and then went to the hospital.  They just prepped me for my c-section anyway the way they would have if I'd been scheduled ahead of time.  It wasn't an emergency c-section at all.  It'll be okay.  If you go early, they'll just do the c-section early.  That's all.  Good luck!



Source(s):



mom of 4, 1 in heaven, 3 c-sections



</answer>



<answer from>



Jill
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 61341 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Some doctors just prefer to wait that long. I think he's being a little overly cautious by stating that earlier might require NICU. I have never seen a 37 week baby with immature lungs who needed NICU care unless there were other severe medical issues with the child.



Labor is a lengthy process, and if you go into labor you'll be just fine as long as you go to the hospital immediately.



Good luck.



Source(s):



RN, OB, L&D



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 09 June 2008
Total points: 1030 (Level 3)

why take the baby out before it is ready anyways?

CuriousG...

<answer from>



Jenna A
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I'm a little confused by your timetables...  Where are you getting 3 weeks if you feel it might have been 5 weeks since you conceived?  If it has been 5 weeks since you had unprotected sex, you should be due or overdue for your period, right?



If you're due or overdue for your period, you've got a good chance of getting an accurate result.  Try a brand of test that specializes in picking up low levels of pregnancy hormone, such as First Response.



Good luck with whatever result you desire!

<question from>



sally M
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Has anyone had a 1-250 chance of having a baby with downs or inhibin-a result a bit abnormal?



I have a 1-250 chance of having a baby with downs. I had my u/s and baby looks great. So I decided not to get the amnio. Two weeks later which was yesterday I had my doc app and she told me the doctor who gave me the ultrasound said she wants me to come back at 28 and 36 weeks for more u/s because my inhibin-a was a bit high. Now my doc said it really wasnt that high and the other two docs would have disreguarded it. It was only up .3  She said the good thing about this is more u/s ANYONE OUT THERE WHO CAN GIVE ME ADVICE I REALLY NEED IT



</question>



<answer from>



Millie C
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 8709 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



1.  I have a 1 in 100 chance just being at my age.
2.  You don't have to do this.  It's too late anyway and you're keeping the baby.  The only reason to know really for sure is if you aren't going to keep the baby if it had down's syndrom.  You can opt out.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jill
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 61341 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



A 1 in 250 chance is still pretty low, and many women get elevated screening risks who go on to have totally normal babies. So don't stress out about it, odds are still in your favor that baby is fine.



But personally, if it were me, I would have all the other diagnostic tests I could to either confirm or rule out any diagnosis - in the off chance baby did have a genetic condition I would want to know ahead of time, to be prepared and educate myself on what I am getting into as a parent of a special needs child, and so the medical staff is prepared for taking care of the baby immediately from the time of birth. People always assume that finding out is only going to affect your choices if you're thinking about abortion. That's not the case. It's about being empowered by knowledge and being prepared for what comes next instead of being surprised in the delivery room.



Source(s):



RN, OB, L&D



</answer>



<answer from>



Sparkler...
Member since: 19 June 2008
Total points: 1093 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just ask yourself...would you love your child any less if he/she were born with downs or any other sort of abnormalty?  If not, I would say to go forward with the u/s, but not to worry too much until anything is determined by the doctors as a greater risk.  Mentally prepare yourself for the fact that your child may not be exactly as you planned, but also he/she may be just fine.  The worst thing you can do is worry and stress when there truly is nothing certain at this point.



</answer>

<question>



If I can't sleep at 5 AM and have a touch of nausea should I eat something?

<answer from>



O'Gasmic...
Member since: 02 April 2008
Total points: 12790 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



When I got pregnant for my son I suffered nausea everyday until about a half hour after he was born. (Ultimately resulting in the loss of 24 pounds) If you feel like you can eat something, try some crackers or toast.
The caffeine in tea and coffee can actually work as an appetite supressant, so i would opt for a small snack before drinking it.  Don't be too concerned about your weight right now. It's tempting, I know, but you got a little guy (gal) in there who might want that snack.



Who says you can't relax on the computer??  Silly rabbit! Is there anything more relaxing than checking out some of these Q&A's? &lt;g&gt;



</answer>

unfortunately, it's hard to know if you are prego those first 4 weeks. while every week is important, those are probably some of the most crucial. i drank and found out the next day i was prego. it didn't have any effect that i can tell, so i was probably lucky. it is possible that it could cause problems, but you won't know until later. i wouldn't worry yourself over it, because it's not like you did it when you knew you were pregnant. more than likely, everything will be fine, but i would def watch my actions from here on out.

<answer from>



ZeZe
Member since: 30 July 2008
Total points: 4581 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes this is normal, during your second trimester many woman don't feel pregnant because there are very few symptoms for many women at this time. It's normal to have a weird appetite. I always got full really quickly but at 12:00am I woke up starving and had to get a snack. It was crazy! Also, the reason your stomach is getting hard is probably braxton hicks contractions, it's just your bodies way of preparing for childbirth. this early you don't feel pain from them though. Your stomache will just get hard and then release. With my first pregnancy this started for me at about fifteen weeks.



</answer>

I have two kids, 5 years and 5 months.  What you are experiencing also happened to me.  I had no appetite in the am but was ravenous in the evening. Nothing to be concerned about, but check with your Dr. anyway.  It happened to me with my second pregnancy.  There's so much going on with your body right now.  You will notice all sorts of things.  Try to enjoy it.  It really does go quickly.  I miss being pregnant.  Congratulations and good luck!

<question from>



belle
