</question from>



<question>



When calculating your date of conception?



is using your LMP accurate? like when trying to conceive as well? (if you tend to have a normal period (28 days))



</question>



<answer from>



rosie babayyy!
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 4662 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



i believe the date of conception is usually considered to be 2 weeks after the start of your LMP. this is because ovulation usually occurs about 2 weeks into your cycle, so that is the best time to conceive. if you are trying to get pregnant you can use fertilityfriend.com, its a big help. ive always found that it is easier to get pregnant when you arent thinking about it though.



</answer>



<answer from>



kyra
Member since: 19 February 2008
Total points: 1145 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm pretty sure it is..All the dates for me were right on for this pregnancy (twins) at my ultrasound..and also for my son and my daughter..ive never known my date on conception..just my lmp



</answer>



<answer from>



wiggle worm due jan 29
Member since: 09 June 2008
Total points: 1038 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



they always go off of the date of your last period. conception is around 2 weeks after that date but they figure your due date around the last period begin date



</answer>



<answer from>



2 in the oven
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 13956 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ovulation occurs about 14 days before missed period, no matter the cycle length. Best way to calculate if you have a 28 day cycle is 2 weeks from the start of last period.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sparkler...
Member since: 19 June 2008
Total points: 1106 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had a normal period (28 day cycle) and tracked for 3 months to make sure...I knew my LMP and conceived on day 14.  I was lucky, I know, but I was also pretty familiar with my cycle by then.  Also, I was not trying to get pregnant, but not preventing it either.  It was a "see what happens" scenario...I'm due Dec 3rd so I guess that's what happened in my case!



</answer>

They have a mini of the book also.. and they have one for boys also.. i got one as a family gift from my daughter uncle.. and i got my brother the one for boys at their baby shower (hes a first time dad and was having a boy) They have them at book stores and Costco you could get him that (link http://www.harpercollins.com/books/97800... ) and tell him he better catch up.. or go to the book store and they have a lot of other books about being a dad or a girl.. or a boy..



You could just frame the u/s picture and let him figure it out.



At wal-mart (here anyways) they have a bag of Hershey chocolate kisses that say its a boy or its a girl (wrapped in pink or blue kiss wrappers.. cute)



if its a boy you could go get a football or some type of manly thing and tell him he better start to practice for when his son is born..



You could get him a small cake made decorated in pink or blue saying congratulations daddy your going to have a.. or some phrase on it..



good luck and congrats

<question>



Is my pregnancy going ok?



Basically I found out about 2 weeks ago that I was pregnant. I've been to the doctors with the intentions of getting rid of it as the financial position I'm in isn't good and my boyfriend wasn't very supportive. My doctor then told me I was probably around 10/11 weeks pregnant, since then I've cancelled two abortion appointments & I've decided on keeping it as my boyfriend is a lot happier with the idea now & we're both feeling quite excited! I keep getting sharp pains in my lower stomach & was just wondering if any other women have experienced this & everything's gone okay? I'm yet to book the doctors to have it all sorted out properly, just wanted the heads up really!



Thanks alot.



</question>



<answer from>



angelmom...
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 2565 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It sounds like what you are experiencing is round ligament pains. They are perfectly normal as your body and your uterus stretches for accommodating the growing baby.



</answer>



<answer from>



LiL mami
Member since: 19 May 2008
Total points: 591 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



you'll tend to get some pain in your lower abdomen because your uterus is stretching to make room for the baby..you should be fine..but schedule a doc apt just to be sure



</answer>

if ur in the uk it goes like htis huni,



u see a dr, he will refer you 2 a family planning clinic, they will give u the once over and refer you to an abortion clinic, now considering your very early on you probs wont require surgery.



but if you do, you are put to sleep and it takes about 10 mins afterwards you will feel groggy from the anesthesia. you will bleed after also(like a period) and suffer cramps. however, this is usually for later abortions (after 9 weeks)

<answer>



Yes it is painful and can be painful years after if you later on feel regret. I know someone who regretted hers because the dr performing hers was having a hard time, the nurse asked what was wrong and he said "it wont stay still" and then "oh I got it" at 8 weeks.

That might give you something to feel good about later, knowing that you helped a childless couple find love with the child that would have burdened you. Your child will be loved and appreciated by someone suffering with infertility.



Do what you feel you need to, no one can judge you, only yourself.



I had my first at 19, things worked themselves out beautifully. No regrets and I had that abortion scheduled too, I backed out when I heard the heartbeat at 7 weeks.

<question from>



beachbab...

</question from>



<question>



Mirgraines and pregnancy ?



Everyday for weeks ive had mirgraines that come and go all day and the headache/mirgraine starts at the temple and makes one side of my face really sore...any ideas to help it?



</question>



<answer from>



Canada Baby, 24 weeks :)
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 1436 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Tylenol and massage and lots of water to drink.



A massage therapist suggested a cold pack on your neck while you soak your feet in warm/hot water.  This apparently pulls the blood from your head, the extra blood may be causing the headaches.



I had horrible headaches for weeks, all I could do was take the tylenol and lay down for as long as possible.



</answer>



<answer from>



Brooke
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 119 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



these are the top ten prgnancy symptoms



10. Tender, swollen breasts
9. Fatigue
8. Implantation bleeding
7. Nausea or vomiting you might not throw up though
6. Increased sensitivity to odors
5. Abdominal bloating
4. Frequent urination
3. A missed period
2. Your basal body temperature stays high
1. The proof: A positive home pregnancy test



Source(s):



babycenter.com



</answer>



<answer from>



vhighfil...
Member since: 08 November 2006
Total points: 391 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sounds like tension headaches to me not migraines. I have had migraines before and it is a whole lot worse than you describe so something is causing you to much stress and tension. so find what is causing the problem and eliminate it. Get away from anyone who may be causing you such anxiety and stress and they will go away. If you can't seem to find the source then I found that going outside and taking an hour walk will get rid of the head ache and you won't have to take anything for it. It is hard to get up and go for a walk but when you try it and it does work you won't mind doing it. Believe me it helps circulate your blood and will ease the pain.



</answer>



<answer from>



becca
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 2874 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It sucks but the only med you can take is Tylenol! I got some severe migraines during the first part of my pregnancy and went to the ER. They could do nothing and just made sure baby and my vitals were ok. They gave me a med for nausea and sent me home both times! The one time I thought for sure I would die or explode the pain was so bad! The only thing i found to help was hot rag on my head then alternating with a cold rag on my head! I also secluded myself away from noise and and light! Eat small meals so you don't upset your stomach! Also make sure to get plenty of water! Sometimes headache and migraines are made worse if you are dehydrated! I've heard that Head On stuff is safe but ask your doctor to know for sure! Good luck and I can understand how painful it is!



</answer>

I just started having these cramps today. However, they just come and go. I don't know if this is normal or what? Luckily I have my doc's appt this morning. Just wanted to get some quick opinions on this for now.

<answer from>



killas86
Member since: 20 February 2008
Total points: 1541 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



They are completely normal as your baby is most likely getting into position ready for labour. If your cramps or contractions are happening at regular intervals start timing them. You may be going into an early labour.
Not all pregnancies start with the water breaking spontaneously but keep your eye out for "the show" which is the brown/ reddish mucous in your underwear which indicates the begiinning of labour.



Remember to stay calm and try to rest as much as possible ( yes I know its hard when your in pain), if you are at all concerned all you need to do is ring your midwife or hospital representative.



</answer>



<answer from>



Beth
Member since: 08 September 2008
Total points: 352 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had Braxton Hicks also, but they did NOT feel like menstrual cramps.  When I got the period like cramps, I was in labor.



</answer>

Kronth K

<question>



Mirgraines and pregnancy ?



Everyday for weeks ive had mirgraines that come and go all day and the headache/mirgraine starts at the temple and makes one side of my face really sore...any ideas to help it?



</question>



<answer from>



Canada Baby, 24 weeks :)
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 1458 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Tylenol and massage and lots of water to drink.



A massage therapist suggested a cold pack on your neck while you soak your feet in warm/hot water.  This apparently pulls the blood from your head, the extra blood may be causing the headaches.



I had horrible headaches for weeks, all I could do was take the tylenol and lay down for as long as possible.



</answer>

these are the top ten prgnancy symptoms



10. Tender, swollen breasts
9. Fatigue
8. Implantation bleeding
7. Nausea or vomiting you might not throw up though
6. Increased sensitivity to odors
5. Abdominal bloating
4. Frequent urination
3. A missed period
2. Your basal body temperature stays high
1. The proof: A positive home pregnancy test

Amber - Due 11/24/08

Total points: 1121 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is okay for your baby as long as you're not craving it because you're anemic. Craving ice can be a symptom of anemia, or an iron deficiency. I used to be anemic but haven't been since I've been pregnant and I always craved ice, which was one way I knew my iron was down. I've been craving ice lately so I mentioned it to my doctor, she checked my iron, and everything was fine. It can very well be a normal craving, but I would mention it to your doctor so s/he can make sure its not anemia. Best of luck to you!



</answer>

<question from>



wendy080...

Total points: 7154 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



No food until after delivery?



Why do many hospitals have the rule that once you are checked in, you are not supposed to eat anything until after you deliver?  When I had my son, I was in the hospital by 7:00 on Monday morning, and I didn't have my son until 11:15 Tuesday.  If I hadn't been able to bully my husband into going to the Subway in the hospital to sneak me a 6" turkey with cheese & something to drink, the hospital would have let me starve to death.  The nurse kept trying to convince me that the IV in my arm was supplying my body with all of the nutrients it needed, but my stomach wasn't buying it.  They wouldn't even let me have anything to drink, just ice chips to keep my throat from being dry.  For a while I thought they were just sadist, but most of my friends' have told me that their hospitals had the same policy.  Does anyone know the reason for this?  My delivery whent just fine, despite the sandwich and many snacks I ate when the nurse wasn't looking.



</question>



<answer from>



kalebsmo...
Member since: 10 December 2007
Total points: 371 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most hospitals have this policy for just in case situations. Unfortunately things can go wrong during labor and delivery. Not letting you eat is safer if they end up needing to do an emergency c-section.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jeremy R
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 4476 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



because they may need to do emerg. c-section.  Also, you may not want to have to have a BM in the middle of delivery.



Source(s):



mom of 5



</answer>



<answer from>



Jenifer C
Member since: 02 May 2007
Total points: 1707 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



it's just a caution in case they have to do surgery



</answer>



<answer from>



Sparkler...
Member since: 19 June 2008
Total points: 1059 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Possibly to avoid pooping on the table?  I know that you usually can't avoid that, but supposedly your body tries to expel everything it can in preparation for labor before you go in (which is why so many women get diarrhea as a labor symptom)....maybe its so that you don't mess with nature's expulsion.



That sounds horrible though...I hate when I'm starving.  I can't imagine I would be very pleasant in all that pain AND hungry.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kell-o
Member since: 13 May 2008
Total points: 4901 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



I was in labor 22 hours from when I woke up, so add another few hours of sleep to that and I wasn't allowed to eat for a whole day!  I was STARVING, but they wouldn't let me eat.  I know this is going to sound gross, but I think they want your system cleared because if you have food in your system it is more likely that you will poop on the table while pushing.  As soon as I popped my son out I asked for food and they brought me mac and cheese.  This time, I plan on eating before I go in - no matter how bad the contractions hurt!

<answer from>



Angellov...

<answer>



its so if they need to take you in to surgery they can with out fear of you throwing up while in there. they do have very good reasons why, like the throwing up part can happen while your in labor or in surgery, plus i think it might also have something to do with bowel movement while in labor. im not totally sure i just know that they told me it could make me throwup.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sunshine
Member since: 03 December 2007
Total points: 19267 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



If they have to do an emergency C-section, they need your stomach to be empty..



Another reason is basically because during pushing some women push their bowels and basically, they defecate, and having an empty stomach keeps this from continuing all through the labor.



Source(s):



RN



</answer>



<answer from>



jane j
Member since: 19 July 2007
Total points: 2982 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



when you are giving birth sometimes things don't go according to plan, meaning that even if you were intending on delivering vaginally, something could go wrong and you might end up needing a c-section.  this is why hospitals do not want you to eat...having something in your stomach increases your risk of vomitting during the c-section, which is very common.  vomitting could cause you to choke and could be dangerous, especially when you are flat on your back with a spinal and can't even move.  in rare cases you may have to be put under general anesthesia and the risk is even higher for vomitting to cause problems...therefore, hospitals do not want you to eat so they can have the best chance at keeping you healthy should you need a section.  hope this helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



blueberr...
Member since: 24 August 2007
Total points: 27363 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Marriage & Divorce



</answer from>



<answer>



maybe because you can poop on there hands while you're pushing? have no idea



</answer>



<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 25222 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



It's an old rule, based on the days when most women got general anesthesia during delivery.



Today, the logic goes something like this:  "You MIGHT need an emergency c-section (very unlikely) and you MIGHT need a general anesthestic (very rare -- most sections are done with an epidural) and you MIGHT vomit from the anesthesia (possible) and you MIGHT aspirate (virtually impossible with modern methods of aneshesia where you are intubated during surgery) and you MIGHT get pneumonia and die.



Many more enlightened hospitals are recognizing the absurdity of the rule (starving women during labor just makes it MORE likely that they will need that emergency c-section) .. and are permitting food/drink as desired.  If you DO need a c-section and a general, the staff will cope with it -- just as they do with the millions of people every year who need emergency surgery, having eaten in the past few hours.



(Some people think the rule is because many women vomit in labor anyway -- but eating doesn't make vomiting more likely -- you can vomit even if you've eaten nothing. And dry heaves are usually more unpleasant than vomiting up food. And neither does it have anything to do with having a bowel movement.  THe waste products passed during pushing are from food eaten long before labor even began.)



</answer>



<answer from>



Valerie
Member since: 05 June 2008
Total points: 906 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you would have to have an emergency C-section, they might have to give you general anesthesia.  When you go under, you need to have an empty stomach because some people get sick and can actually aspirate the vomit.



When I was in the hospital being induced, things were moving very slowly, so they did let me have a lunch tray.  I threw it up later - yuck.



Wondering... why were you in the hospital so long?  I thought for normal deliveries they wouldn't admit you until you were at least 4 cm, or your water broke?



Source(s):



I work in the medical device industry.  I was supposed to attend a surgery yesterday, but it was cancelled because the child ate...  They also discussed this in my prepared childbirth class.



</answer>



<answer from>



ange
Member since: 20 July 2007
Total points: 760 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think this is a silly rule too! With my first baby 11 years ago they told you not to eat when your labour started and I was totally knackered by the time it came to actually delivering my daughter.......Now with my third ,where I live they encourage you to eat in early labour to keep your strenght up.....Obviously when you are in the throes of hard labour you are not going to feel like having a three course meal so I say if you are hungry then you should be allowed to snack! After all it gives you the energy to keep going! I know that they have this rule just in case you end up needing a general aneasthetic but most people don't need this.x



</answer>



<answer from>



Bethany M
Member since: 02 June 2007
Total points: 182 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Technically, you can do whatever you feel like doing while you're in labor.  Even if the hospital strongly suggests that you do not eat, you are hiring THEM to assist you in the delivery of your child and you are allowed to do what makes you comfortable.



The only time you really have to avoid eating during labor is if you get an epidural.



Also, if you do eat while you are in labor, you should eat things that can be easily digested.  Avoid proteins and fatty foods.  The best things to eat are toast (with jelly, not butter),  cereal, fruit, etc.



Until the 1940's, women were actually told to eat and drink as they desired during labor. All of that changed in 1949 just because 1 study showed that women who ate during labor had a higher chance of food entering the lungs during anesthesia. Since then, women have often been told that as soon as they feel contractions or think they are in labor, they should stop eating.



There are several reasons why this study, done nearly 60 years ago, should no longer apply to women in labor today:
The original study was based on very high amounts of anesthesia, which are no longer used on women during cesarean births.



Fasting during labor does not guarantee an empty stomach.



The risk of aspiration only occurs with general anesthesia, which is used very rarely for cesareans.



Prolonged fasting increases the amount of hydrochloric acid in your stomach which can increase the complications with aspiration.



It is not good to base recommendations for practice on one study, especially given that this particular study is extremely outdated.



Arguments made for eating during labor include:
Eating small amounts of easily-digested foods during labor can give you the energy you need to keep going.



A 1989 National Birth Center study showed that 11,814 women who ate and drank at will during labor did not have a single case of aspiration, even among the 22% of women in the total group who required a cesarean.



Sometimes the knowledge that you can't eat during your labor can affect your sense of control. That alone might make you feel like giving up sooner.
Often midwives and doulas report that if a mother's labor is not progressing, often eating and drinking during labor helps to get things moving.



Source(s):



http://pregnancychildbirth.suite101.com/...



</answer>

comparing to my period cramps...will my labor be like that? or even worse? if worse...I'm going for C-section...I'll talk to my doctor about it.



any info?? experience??



THNKS x]

<answer>



My labor lasted 21 hours and let me first say that I am such a baby when it comes to pain!....however, I did the whole labor thing without any painkillers or medication...and if I can do it, anyone can! Early labor, when the contractions were just starting were like menstrual cramps, manageable.  Eventually the contractions get so bad you can't talk through them.  Although once I started pushing (30 min), I thought I'd rather live with the contractions forever the pain was so bad. Just think about how far you have to stretch to get a baby out, and that's how much it hurts.



Every labor is different though, I know some women who were in labor 6 hours and never felt anything more than a twinge! You could get lucky! I was up and walking right after I delivered my daughter though, and with the epidural it will take a little longer before they will let you move around.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bee
Member since: 08 April 2008
Total points: 6534 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Honestly, it will be worse than your cramps lol. It is the most excruciating thing in the world. It's enough to make you scream in a voice you never even knew you had. It was enough to make me want to kill myself at the time. But I got through it and so do thousands of other women. Afterwards I thought I'd never want to do it again, but now I'd love to, and knowing what it felt like and knowing what a very low pain threshold I have, I would still choose to deliver vaginally. It was the best experience of my life and I have such fond memories of it. Towards the end of my labour I was told I was going to need an emercency C-Section due to a complication if he hadn't arrived in an hour, but fortunately he made a last minute appearance. I can't explain how upset I was at the thought of having to miss the natural delivery of my son. I had the epidural by the way at the end of it, I'd had a very long labour and experienced a great deal of pain so after 85 hours I had the epidural and it killed the pain almost completely, I still felt everything but it was very good for the pain. You have that on offer to you, plus your other milder drugs. I fail to see why someone would want to miss the miracle of delivering their own baby for reasons other than medical reasons. It will also put you at risk of having an uncomfortable and painful recovery - honestly I had stitches and that was bad enough to deal with at the beginning of parenthood when you want to be up and mobile, so a caesarian scar would be ten times worse. Yes it is excruciatingly painful but honestly, it is the best experience you'll ever have. Nothing makes you any different to any other women - believe me I have the lowest pain threshold in the world, I'm virtually in tears over a papercut lol, and as I say if there's a next time for me I'll be making every effort to have another vaginal delivery. Billions of women have survived the pain, so nothing singles you out as being a special case. The fact that you've gone through pain makes the birth even more special as you have really earnt and deserved it, and you know that you've gone through it for your child and that's the most special feeling ever. To book a c-section because you're simply not willing to go through the same pain that billions of women have before you just seems like a bit of a cheat to me. Good luck.



</answer>

Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008

<answer>



How long is a piece of string?



Nobody can say how painful labor will be, and nobody knows what YOUR pain tolerance is.



I would NOT plan a c-section for fear of labor pain.  The post-op pain  after major surgery will be longer than any labor pain.  If the pain of labor is more than you can cope with, there are meds that can help.



</answer>

<answer from>



Jayah O
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 1064 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



I always THOUGHT I was constipated. I wasn't. I simply wasn't eating enough to have to go daily. I was lucky to go every 3 days. I was so nauseous and so sick that I barely ate 500 calories a day. Not by my choice though..ugh. It was brutal. Once I started feeling better and was able to eat, I used Metamucil and ate a high fiber diet. With this pregnancy I barely had any constipation. It was a totally different experience. YAY!



Make sure you eat well and stay hydrated. It should taper off in the next few weeks and you should be able to "go" more often. If it makes you really uncomfortable talk to your doctor/midwife. You may need stool softeners to get you going again.



Good Luck! =)



</answer>



<answer from>



Haven
Member since: 03 September 2007
Total points: 1225 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Answer hidden due to its low rating</evaluation>



One word: Enema



Not pretty but effective. Do see your doctor as constipation can be a serious problem...



</answer>

<question from>



leighann...

</question from>



<question>



How long do you have to be working to get maternity leave?



I was just wondering how long you have to be working with an employer to apply for maternity leave in Canada.
As well as if you are working for an employer at home does that count or does that make you self employed and then you would not be able to apply
Thanks in advance



</question>



<answer from>



Nina
Member since: 26 July 2008
Total points: 268 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its funny you should ask. I work with a traveler nurse from Montreal and he said that you are paid from the start of your pregnancy. Check into it because he says that canadians consider pregnancy to be a "disorder", if you would, where a mother should not be straining herself with work. Call your HR reps and ask them. Hope  this helps.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jade's Mommy♥
Member since: 25 July 2007
Total points: 4025 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



To qualify for maternity benefits you need to have worked 600 hours, doesnt matter how long you work as long as you have that number of hours. At 40 hours a week its only like 15 weeks.



As long as your paying into EI Insurance on your paycheck, you qualify for it, wheter you work in an office or at home for your employer... If you're EI exempt (no premiums coming off your paycheck for EI) then you won't be able to apply.



</answer>



<answer from>



rosieang...
Member since: 28 September 2008
Total points: 229 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



in the uk you have had to been with the company 26 weeks before you become pregnant  to be untitled to maternity pay not sure about leave it may be the same



</answer>

<question>



Pregnant right after miscarriage...?



ok i was pregnant in aug. and started miscarring from the 13th - 17th of aug. and my levels were pretty low. So i took a pregnancy test on sept. 9 and it was +. and eventually i went and took a blood test and it was +. So from when do i start counting on this pregnancy?



</question>



<answer from>



Angellov...
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 1146 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



i would take another test in a wk or two to be sure its not just the hormones from your miscarriage. but if your hormones from the miscarriage went away and now your getting positive test then i would schedule a doctor appointment asap they will wont to monitor you since you had a miscarriage.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kell-o
Member since: 13 May 2008
Total points: 4907 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Did you get a period in between the miscarriage and the positive pregnancy test?  If so you count from the first day of your last period.  If not, I guess I would count from the day you got a positive - maybe go back three weeks from that for a rough estimate?  So maybe about 7 weeks?



Your dr will probably do an early ultrasound for you to determine how far you are since you really have no way of knowing.  I would call and make an appointment right away due to your circumstances.  Sorry to hear about last time, I hope everything works out for you!  Good luck!



</answer>

<question from>



SidnEy08
Member since: 19 June 2007
Total points: 644 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Hip pain in pregnancy?



I am 24 weeks and 3 days pregnant and every morning I wake up my hips hurt sooo badly. It hurts to walk! Does anyoneknow what this is? I was guessing it's because I only sleep on my hips (on my sides) but I cant believe they hurt so bad. Any ideas?



</question>



<answer from>



WeLoveOu...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 169 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had the same problem with all three pregnancies, its just the extra weight gain on your hips now, your hips arnt used to the extra pressure. Try sleeping with one pillow slightly tucked under your belly, and one pillow in between your legs, so your body is level but slightly tilted back, and you may need a pillow behind your back. Welcome to pregnancy!! Sleeping sucks!! And it only gets worse. Pillows will be your best friend for the next 16 weeks.



</answer>



<answer from>



Emma S
Member since: 24 July 2008
Total points: 939 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your body releases a hormone called relaxin wich is known to relax your joints. When I was pregnant my hips hurt badly for three weeks and then became very lose. They would slip/dislocate during everyday activities.
Each women is different but it is normal to have this hip pain before your joints become lose!



Good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



ABear's Mom
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 347 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had this problem very bad!  Your hips are widening...it should subside a little down the road!!  I would put a warm (but not hot) hot pad just on my hip area while laying on my side.  The heat isn't making it's way to the baby...and it really helped the pain!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Sparkler...
Member since: 19 June 2008
Total points: 1067 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have this too, mostly on my left side because I am sure that I am favoring it more.  I think it is a combination of the pressure from laying on them so much as well as your ligaments stretching.



I have found that stretching before bed helped a bit and my neighbor swears that taking a bath at night before bed helps her.  Also, I have been pulling my legs up higher around my body pillows (more of a fetal position) which helps balance out the pressure a little.



I am 31 weeks today and my belly is definitely expanding and noticeably weighing a lot more, so that is a new pain I'm dealing with and trying to figure out.  The body pillow seems to be my only saving grace for such things.  Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



mrsross2...
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 1153 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



They hurt for a few reasons. They have to take alot of pressure not only from sleeping on your side throughout the night but also because of the growing uterus. The hips have a hormone called relaxin released into them once you become pregnant. This makes them more flexible and able to support the growing baby and uterus. Also everytime you walk your hips have to support even more. Thats alot of pressure for your hips and that is why they hurt. Don't worry though, they will feel better once you have the baby. It is a good reason for sore hips. I remember waking up one morning and feeling like my hips were going to dislocate from my spine. It was a weird and painful feeling. lol =P Good luck hun!



Source(s):



Mother to be 16 weeks and read alot



</answer>



<answer from>



Industri...
Member since: 09 July 2007
Total points: 6900 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



This might be a shot in the dark, but are you having urinary trouble?  I'm aware that you're pregnant and other posters have very good points as well, but if you have some form of a UTI, it might be your ureters acting up.  Mine are currently doing it.  Try drinking some cranberry juice and see if the pain alleviates at all.  Can't hurt to try.  Good Luck :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Jayah O
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 1066 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Your pelvis may be softening already. I know mine is. I sleep with a ton of pillows. A Snoogle pillow on the front of me and a regular pillow behind my back. I also do yoga to keep things in alignment. Ask your doc is that is something you can do. I have found it makes a HUGE difference and that the effects of yoga last for a few days. I am 25 weeks and have been feeling that pain for a few weeks now. I have to walk slowly and not step over things. I sit to put my clothes and I don't push my older kids stuff with my feet anymore..LOL



The pillows help a ton! I hope you get some relief soon. =)



</answer>

I don't think that any position will hurt the baby.  The missionary position is usually the first position to become uncomfortable for you.  I always found the spoon position (on your side with your husband behind you) to be the most comfortable position in late pregnancy.

<answer>



There is nothing that you have to worry about. You can pretty much have sex anyway you want without worrying about hurting the baby. The only thing that you will have problems with, is you being comfortable. As you progress in your pregnancy, some positions will be very uncomfortable. I know for me, waay into my pregnancy, if my husband and I did it missionary...I felt like I was being strangled! I couldn't get air because of all the pressure of the baby on my stomach. So we comprimised. You just have to work with what is comfortable for you. Have fun!!



</answer>

Maybe he didnty want to upset you and theres no more to it but if you think he wants his old life back, just try to communicate with him. <question from>



my.mothe...
Member since: 31 October 2007

</question from>



<question>



25 weeks pregnant.....steriod shots for baby's lungs?



My friend is in the hospital right now. She is 25 weeks pregnant with a little girl. She had  stillbirth last year at 22 weeks. We are really worried about her and the baby. Her face has been swelling and she has high blood pressure problems. They admitted her into the hospital with high blood pressure. They just now got her blood pressure down with three different types medicines including IV fluids. Now her perinatologist has order steroid shots and her nurse informed her that he expects her to deliver in the next few weeks. THEN, her OB asked her nurse what her urine levels were and she said there was 2+ protein so they are making her do  24 hour urine to see if her protein is getting higher because if they are were then the nurse said that would mean her blood was getting toxic and they would have to deliver her baby as soon as possible. She has a history of toxemia with previous pregnancies with her sons. Please if you have any medical experience or have had any similar problems,I need advice. Also any premature stories that you have experienced would be great. Thanks so much for your time.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I haven't experienced it, but I've read that babies born at 25 weeks can survive if the hospital has the right Neonatal Unit. The steroid shots will build the babies lungs, so they'll be more developed when baby is born, which will give the baby a better chance at survival.



</answer>

<question>



What to look for after a D&C?



I have a question... I just had a D&C fours weeks ago on Sept 4th. I was wondering what signs of infections should I look for other then fever. I have been feeling lots of cramping on and off near my ovaries. I haven't had a period yet. My doctor isn't that informative at all. I am just afraid of getting an infection.



</question>



<answer from>



ABear's Mom
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 349 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hopefully they gave you antibiotics right after your D + C to take.  I had to have one and I got sent home with some.  Fever, swelling in the abdomen...pain.  Seems like the cramping should be at least subsided by now.  If you already took antibiotics, haven't had intercourse and haven't had any signs of infection for a whole four weeks, you should be OK...things should be fairly healed.  Not having a period yet is not strange.  I got mine at 6 weeks.  And it's not even regualr still!!



</answer>



<answer from>



jenzito
Member since: 16 April 2007
Total points: 3053 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



maybe your just ovulating



</answer>

Back pain could be due to the weight gain and extra pressure on the spine, i would have it one day then not the next etc.. <question>



What does having a soft cervix mean?



I'm 38 weeks with baby #3 (due in 14 days) and my doctor said my cervix was soft. And this morning I am a bit sore in the belly. What do you ladies think of all this?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Its preparing for labor, a hard cervix can only dilate so far, your cervix has to be soft or "ripe" for progress to be made!  Still could be another 2 weeks though before the big day!



</answer>

Contributing In:



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



I always told everyone immediately with my first three and never understood how anyone could hold in such a great secret.  And then I had a miscarriage in July of this year and I got it.  When we're pregnant again, we won't tell until after the first appointment and we see a little heartbeat on our baby at the ultrasound.  At least that way I don't have to go back and "untell" everyone.  So many people don't know what to say after a miscarriage.  It makes them uncomfortable.  It makes you uncomfortable when they say the wrong thing.  I'd rather just wait and be sure.



You should do what feels right to you though.  Good luck with your decision and congrats on the newest baby!



Source(s):



mom of 4, 1 in heaven



</answer>



<answer from>



Mary
Member since: 24 July 2008
Total points: 361 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I told my parents and sisters at about 5 weeks - right when we found out.  I did not want to tell anyone else until I had reached 12 weeks.  My family was just too excited, and had told everyone by about seven weeks.  I started having a lot of problems early on, and was put on bed rest for two months beginning at seven weeks - which came as a surprise to me because I am so healthy.  I really regretted telling my family so early, because they did not respect the fact that this was our secret to share.  They thought that they had every right to tell everyone, despite the fact that we were so clear that it was very important to us to keep it a secret.  My mom had even told my hair dresser - I was lying in bed thinking, if I do miscarry, is the whole world going to know about it?  I love my family dearly, and know that it was not their intention to make us feel this way.  However, my husband and I have decided that NO ONE will be finding out until 12 weeks with our next one.  It is just too big of a secret to keep.  The last thing you want after a miscarriage is everyone and their dog asking how the pregnancy is going...



Source(s):



23 weeks pregnant with #1!



</answer>

<answer from>



Mia1385
Member since: 16 March 2007
Total points: 3456 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think you are dumb for keeping your baby.  I think you made the right decision to step up and take responsibility!



There are a lot of things you can do without, especially if you are short on cash.



Things that you must have:



*Crib
*Car seat
*Clothing
*Bottles
*Diapers (and lots of them)
*Changing supplies such as wipes and ointment
*Blankets



Things you can do without
*Changing Table
-you can just as easily change the baby on your bed or the floor.  Just put a blanket or towel down and make sure you always keep a hand on the baby so prevent him or her from falling.
*Stroller
-unless you plan on taking the baby out, you could do without this.  You don't need a super fancy one either.  I think you can find a simple one for under $50.
*Tons of elaborate outfits.
-most of them will end up ruined anyways.



That is all I can think of for now.



Good luck and Congrats!



</answer>

<answer from>



Larry R
Member since: 04 November 2006
Total points: 10240 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



First of all NOBODY is dumb to keep their baby....killing your own child before it is born isn't a good choice for anybody.  Adoption may be an option, but it's not good to abort innocent children.



Kids require a lot of gear...not as much as they want to sell you, but a lot.



1st you will need someone to sit with baby while you are out working...this is most important.



Brest feeding is better for the kids, and cheaper, but a bit harder on you...it pays huge benefits in the end though for the kids in terms of brain development and keeping their immune system up...which means they get sick less and have fewer doctor visits.



You will need clothes for the youngin, go with disposable diapers, a good diaper pail or a diaper genie is a wonder..it keeps the poopy diaper smell from stinking up the whole house. You will need a crib for baby to sleep in, and a high chair to feed baby in, and some toys. Couple of stuffed animals...some teething rings, and you need special laundry detergant to wash baby clothes in (all the crud they put in the regular detergants can give baby rashes).  You need diaper ointment, teething medicine, and a plastic bulb thingy to suck the snot out of their nose...(babies can't blow their nose on their own at first). I'm sure there are other things you will need too, but I cant think of them now



Source(s):



Dad of 2



</answer>



<answer from>



Sheri
Member since: 03 February 2007
Total points: 615 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<question>



7 weeks 3 days pregnant with horrible morning sickness...?



So, I've had "morning sickness" all day every day since last Sunday (9/21).  My doctor prescribed Zofran but it's not helping at all.  I haven't been able to keep anything down except crackers and pretzels... and water.  I feel horrible like I'm not feeding my baby... but I literally can't keep anything down.  I've tried everything- mints, lemon, zofran, crackers, ginger ale... Pepsi is kind of relieving the nausea but only for a short time and I'm only drinking a little bit of it since I heard I'm supposed to avoid caffeine.  My question is:  How harmful is this to my baby and do you have any other suggestions of what I can try?  Any advice would be appreciated!



</question>



<additional details>



LOL... actually brushing my teeth kinda makes me feel better cuz of the minty taste.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Meh
Member since: 01 September 2006
Total points: 1478 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was sick daily for the first 6 months with my first child, and nauseous the whole time with my second.  I survived on a diet of lucozade and mini mars bars.  Only eat what you fancy.  My doc prescribed me anti sickness which helped sometimes.  You can get anti sickness wrist bands too.  On the plus side, it means the pregnancy is well sustained.  Good luck, I don't envy you.. just don't look at your toothbrush, it'll have you gagging for the rest of the day! x



</answer>



<answer from>



moviebuf...
Member since: 03 March 2008
Total points: 3930 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Rest easy, if morning sickness hurt babies we would have a whole lot fewer people in this world.  by 12 weeks the morning sickness should lessen some. For right now just eat and drink what you can without getting sick.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jenni F
Member since: 05 June 2008
Total points: 1646 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



A little pepsi won't hurt you or your baby, but drink lots of water. Your baby will take everything he/she needs from you and will be fine. All you can really do is put up with this miserable state until it stops. It generally lasts about 3 months, I'm sorry to say. Most of us just live on crackers, pretzels and water!



</answer>

tam22
Member since: 28 September 2008
Total points: 106 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i was like that for my last pregnancy, i had morning sickness all day and night for the whole nine months. i was only able to keep fruit down and coke seemed to ,make me feel that little bit better. (even though i hate it) i actually was losing weight and thought that something was going to be wrong with my baby. the doctor occasionally would admit to hospital and put me on a drip just to get the extra iron and nutrients i needed. if your really concerned speak to your doctor again. my little one was only 4 pound but she is one now and you would never have known she was that tiny.
good luck.



</answer>

<question>



Anyone who has had more than 3 c-sections?



I am pregnant with our 4th baby. I have had 3 c-sections, so this will be my 4th. I don't know why, but it is REALLY bothering me because I do not know anyone who has ever had more than 3 c-sections. Is there anyone out there who has had more than 3, and if you have, were there any unusual problems, complications, etc... Please help- I can't stop thinking about it! Thank you!



</question>



<answer from>



Emma-on-the-way~38 weeks~
Member since: 04 July 2008
Total points: 4241 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



My mom had four c-sections, the last two being within the last 6 years. There was a ton of scar tissue and they tied my mom's tubes dring the operation. But nothing happened with the baby's or my mom.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you! I feel better knowing its not as unusual as I 1st thought!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



charsgiz...
Member since: 25 October 2006
Total points: 9753 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I know of people who have. I am a doula.
And it was a good thing for two of them. They had scar tissue and it was removed. They later had better periods and less pain wearing jeans. (Scar tissue can cause a few issues.)



You may have less time healing. Because the fourth child comes a little earlier. ( not always) And the baby is smaller and makes for a easier and faster time in the Surgery.



Thinking about it is ok. But please if it is keeping you up at night talk to your doctor. Anxiety is normal but do not let it wear your body down.
Congrats on the 4th little one.



Source(s):



Doula
mom of 3



</answer>

<question>

my 2nd with my son... no symptoms at all... hardly knew i was pregnant.



my 3rd... i lost that baby... miscarriage....



my 4th... queasy all the time, vomiting for 4 months, and had a girl....

CG

<answer>



I have two boys, and did find out the gender via ultrasound for both -- it would drive me crazy not knowing!



I was lucky with regards to symptoms - I had morning sickness briefly with my second pregnancy, but none at all with my first. I craved salty foods with both pregnancies, and carried both babies high and in front. All of my weight gain went to my tummy, so everyone "knew" I was having a boy each time. :)



</answer>



<answer from>



rudreami...
Member since: 26 September 2007
Total points: 775 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had a gut instinct that I was having a boy pretty early on in the pregnancy.  I craved what I would call man foods (hot dogs, red meat, and beer).  When I went for my ultrasound I wasn't the least bit shocked when the technician told me it was a boy.  He is now two months old and the most precious little boy I have ever seen.  Also, I didn't have any morning sickness.  I was just really tired all the time.  I carried him all around.  It looked like I had a watermelon turned long ways across my stomach.



</answer>

Karla A

<answer>



Well when I was pregnant w/ my 3 yr. old I really didn't have any symptoms. No morning sickness no feeling dizzy no cravings. Nothing! I had a lot of like energy though. I would get up like @ 6am which was early for me I would get up @ 9 before! I would like helping a lot around the house! So if you would call energized a symptom, the that's the only one I got like around the third month. Hope it helped at least a little bit!lol



As of telling the gender... well I just had the feeling it was gonna be a little boy. Then one time at a store when I was like 5 mths and still hadn't had my ultrasound this man who was like a "card reader"  (which I really don't believe in) touched my stomach and said it was gonna be a boy. But like I said I really don't believe in that stuff but thought I'd let you know!



</answer>



<answer from>



herdoula
Member since: 12 April 2006
Total points: 10363 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



With my first.  I thought for sure I was having a boy.  I had an acute sense of smell and horrible violent vomiting.  It didn't go away after the first trimester either like it was supposed to.  I had to go on medication for it because I couldn't keep food down.  At the twenty week ultrasound I found out we were having a girl.



My second pregnancy I had no symptoms whatsoever.  I miscarried at 13 weeks.



My third pregnancy started out just the same as the first.  Horrible nausea.  But the difference was that I actually felt better once I ate something.  And it went away after the first trimester.  We didn't find out the gender until the birth this time.  I had another girl.



</answer>



<answer from>



Joy
Member since: 13 September 2008
Total points: 762 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This pregnancy I had some nausea (not throwing up though), lots of cramps, waaaaaay moody, and not very hungry at all. Very very tired. Although I have heard when you are expecting a girl, you are more likely to have throwing up morning sickness, I was stoked to hear Im having a girl.



</answer>

<answer from>



Mom to 3 Awesome Kids
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 2660 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cramping accompanied with spotting is a sign of a miscarriage.  With my last pregnancy I had cramping in the beginning, probably up until my 13 or 14th week, and my doctor told me that it was my uterus stretching.  YOu might want to call your doctor or midwife just to make sure everything is okay.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ruby_123
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 117 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Probably just your muscles starting to stretch to allow room for the growing baby, so long as there is no bleeding and severe pain I would think it's okay.  But maybe just to be on the safe side you should call your midwife to make an appointment and they can listen for the heartbeat etc - that's what they are there for.



</answer>

<answer>



Unfortunatly not much will help with the UTI except for the medication the doc gives you. You can drink cranberry juice to limit the bacteria in your bladder though. UTIs are more likely to pop up again in pregnancy again after youve already had one. If you keep getting them, your doc might reccomend you keep taking the medication until delivery. Until then, its just a pain in the butt!!

I had one early in my pregnancy.

</answer from>



<answer>



Yes - if the 2nd line is there you are pregnant - no doubt.  Your doctor will be able to do an internal examination to determine approx how far along you are until you have a scan which will give a more accurate date.  Congratulations



</answer>

<answer from>

Member since: 29 July 2007
Total points: 5701 (Level 5)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



Nope, not at all.  It doesn't affect your odds of getting pregnant.



Source(s):



mom of 4, 1 in heaven



</answer>



<answer from>



pookiesm...
Member since: 31 May 2007
Total points: 12426 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it can cause complications in being able to conceive.



The presence of human papillomavirus (HPV) by itself should not affect your ability to get pregnant. But in some cases, having HPV can increase your risk of developing precancerous or cancerous cells in your cervix, which could affect both your fertility and your ability to carry a baby to term



Source(s):



http://www.babycenter.com/404_will-havin...



</answer>



<answer from>



Joy
Member since: 13 September 2008
Total points: 764 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



No it cant. It can pose some health risks to the baby if you have large genital warts around your area, although C-sections are reccommended in those cases.



Source(s):



More than 75% of sexually active people have HPV, and most dont even know it. Use a condom, get tested.



</answer>

mrsross2...

<answer>



I have HPV and honestly I think it is a little tougher however it is not impossible. Just make sure you go to the doctor regularly for your check ups and get anything fixed that needs it. I am happy to say so far I am 16 weeks pregnant and no complications that I know of. Good luck and keep trying.  --Note: I had to go into surgery about two years ago for benign cells on my cervix and have them removed. It took me a year and a half. I believe my difficulty had something to do with my cervix healing but otherwise once it did, it was healthy. I have not had ANY complications so far with my cervix being incompetent however if I had not had the surgery I think I would have had some problems. Make sure your cervix is checked and cleaned of any precancerous cells because I strongly believe these will affect you getting pregnant and holding to term. Try not to get pregnant before you have this checked out. You don't want to risk the damages.=/



Source(s):



Mother to be 16 weeks



</answer>

<answer>



Well personally speaking I found out that walking alot helps during pregnancy and labor My first born I was somewhat lazy and thought ahh I'll be fine I gained 70 lbs and was in labor for 22 hrs.(she was 7 lbs even)
So I did some research and found walking helps both. So I started walking with my second I gained 22 lbs the whole pregnancy and the labor was not hard it was more comfortable somehow (she was born 6lbs 5oz) I've had 2 more pregnancy's since and they were healthy too with minimal weight gain and the labor and delivery was soooo much easier.hope it helps you.

<answer>



Usually, they will do an amniocentisis to check the lungs.  But, I have heard lots of women getting induced early due to large babies.  The baby's shoulders can get stuck causing severe problems in the baby.  I guess your doctor doesn't want to risk that.  This is a relatively new thing.  Women used to give birth to huge babies all the time and go to term, but I guess there were too many complications and doctors decided to go ahead and induce.



</answer>

<answer from>



herdoula
Member since: 12 April 2006
Total points: 10367 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



37 weeks is term.  Ask your doctor about your bishop score before she does any sweeping of the membranes.  Your bishop score is how well you would take to the induction.  (sweeping membranes is inducing)  If you have a low bishop score you will not likely have a successful induction and end up with a cesarean for your trouble.  If you had your first baby at 39 weeks naturally then it is probably likely that your second will come right around the same time.  You do have the right to refuse any medical procedure that you don't feel comfortable with.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



Anything before 37 weeks is considered premature. Let me just tell you this just b/c she "scrapes" you doesn't mean it will work either. I still had to be induced b/c the membrane scraping did nothing for me. It wasn't a pleasant experience either! I went into labor by myself with my first one but had to be induced w/ #2 b/c he was 8 days late! My last guy (March) came super fast & he was my biggest (9.2) the other 2 were 8.4 & 8.5. If you really want to wait & see then your Dr should respect your plan on waiting. If they are afraid of you not being able to push the baby out then you need to take that into consideration but waiting at least 2 more weeks isn't going to make that much of a difference in the baby's weight. I say wait but just b/c that's what I did doesn't mean it will work for everyone. Congratulations & Good Luck!!

Experience 3 year old, 19 month old, & 6 month old boys!

<question>

I dont recall getting low back aches before periods - just bad headaches or extra hungry for 1-day before period & moody.  Or bad cramps or bloated feeling & sometimes back aches DURING my periods NOT before.



But yesterday afternoon & again this afternoon through to this evening - Ive had constant low back ache - its dull feeling & not comfortable.  (Im fit & have good core muscles due to yoga so dont usually get back aches unless ive been standing all day in which case I havent been standing lots)



I took a home pregnancy test today - negative.  Still waiting for my periods.



Is it common to experience low back aches before a missed period or very early stages of pregnancy?  My breasts feel a bit fuller but no different to usual before a period - nipples normal.  No implantation bleeding etc ... but constant back ache!

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



When you have few flow of blood in menstrual cycle?



Last march I stopped taking the pill  because i'm planning for a baby, and since then i had some trouble with my menstrual cycle. The first 2 months i had to take other pills to make my cycle come. But now my cycle is coming the right time, but i have very few blood flow. This month I just had very few browns spots. I also noticed this month that i don't produce enough mucus to identify if i'm having ovulation or not.
Please help Thanks alot



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



after taking the pill, it can take some woman 6 -12 months to become pregnant or regulate a normal cycle... be patient with it but still have sex often since you dont know exactly when ovulation is happening...even though your cycle isnt normal, dosnt mean you cant get pregnant.



</answer>

<question>



23 WEEK OLD FETUS AVERAGE WEIGHT?



Just wondering what others moms have to say about average weight for a baby at 23 weeks I had my ultrasound my little guy weighed 1lb 1oz! Is that average??



</question>



<answer from>



M Kerr RN L&D
Member since: 04 March 2007
Total points: 48040 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



herdoula
Member since: 12 April 2006
Total points: 10367 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Despite what they tell you.  An ultrasound is only a weight estimate.  There is no scale that can weigh your fetus.  You won't really know how much he weighs until after he is born.



</answer>

yeah that's fine your baby won't really start gaining noticable weight till about your 7th month. and then it seems to all happen at once. Don't worry your fine.

<question>



My friend took a pregnancy test what does this mean...?



She told me she took a test yesterday evening and it said negative.....this morning she calls to tell me that she can see a dark pink line and a lite pink line...which would mean positive right? Her question is does she need to test again or does this mean she is pregnant?? how long are the results good for??



</question>



<answer from>



M Kerr RN L&D
Member since: 04 March 2007
Total points: 48042 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Results are only good for 10 mins after taking the test, what shes probably seeing is an evaporation line!



http://peeonastick.com



</answer>



<answer from>



rosieang...
Member since: 28 September 2008
Total points: 237 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



get her to do another test to be sure



</answer>

Member since: 28 April 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



its more than likely an evaporation line, which doesnt mean anything, thats why you are supposed to read the results in a certain amount of time



</answer>

<answer>



well if she is pregnant, the results are good for another 8 months lol.
If she read the test in the time frame, usually 3 minutes, then she would be pregnant,... hcg doubles every other day, and the test she took last night maybe just couldnt pick it up... she can test again if she wants too, or just go into the doctors.



</answer>

is it the same test from last night? if so, its possible that it is an evaporation line, or maybe she just didnt see the line last night. tell her to get a test that reads pregnant or not pregnant, there is no confusion with those, and to use first morning urine because that is when hcg levels are at their highest. good luck to her!

<answer>



Please go to http://www.peeonastick.com/ and read about evaporation lines.  You can only read an HPT for the first ten minutes.  Anything that appears after that is an invalid result.  If she's still thinking she's pregnant, she needs to get another test and do it again.  Good luck.



Source(s):



mom of 4, 1 in heaven



</answer>

<answer>



No that would not be positive, you are supposed to discard the test after 10 minutes because it is not accurate anymore, apparently that happens sometimes. <answer from>



Lisa
Member since: 14 January 2007
Total points: 13287 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Reading the test the next day is not accurate.  With the majority of the tests, you can only read them in the first 10 minutes up to maybe an hour.  After that time, an evaporation line can appear and make it look like it is positive when it is actually negative.  She should wait a few days and if her period still hasn't show up, she should take another test.



</answer>

<question>



Are you more likely to have a girl if you have sex less frequently or more frequently? ?



Not sure if i believe in these thoery's, but im interested to know????



</question>



<answer from>



M Kerr RN L&D
Member since: 04 March 2007
Total points: 48042 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Neither!



</answer>



<answer from>



mrsross2...
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 1160 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The sex of the baby is determined as soon as the sperm lands in the egg. Your male or female baby then will start to grow according to their gender map. This theory you are speaking of is totally false.



Source(s):



MOther to be 16 weeks



</answer>



<answer from>



Ian M
Member since: 29 September 2008

Kelly S

<answer>



I don't believe that theory.  I really don't believe any of them, but my best friend tried to tell them that she and her husband had A LOT of sex and that is how she knew she was having a boy.  Than I got pregnant, and I had no sex drive at all, and I was also having a boy.  So that theory went down the drain.  I think every pregnancy is different regardless of what you are having. :)



</answer>



<answer from>



beetlemi...
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 13356 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Toddler & Preschooler



</answer from>



<answer>



Less.  Female sperm live longer, male sperm die quick but swim fast.  Since you are only fertile 2 days a month, for a female you want to have intercourse prior to ovulation by 48-72 hours giving the male sperm time to die off.



To increase the chances of having a male have intercourse every other day for the entire week of ovulation.



Look at those who do fertility treatments, the vast majority have sons, because the RE is making sure the egg and sperm get together by knowing precisely when ovulation occurs.



Source(s):



nurse
no theories here, just facts
3 sons and fertility treatments



</answer>



<answer from>



fancypan...
Member since: 13 March 2007
Total points: 4273 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You're likely to have a girl if the mans sperm has an xx chromosome, and there's nothing you can do to influence it



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



it matters what sperm meets the egg first...that is what determines gender, nothing else.



</answer>



<answer from>



Say Love

<answer>



The idea is that girls take longer to swim, so you should have sex 3 days before you ovulate and then your chances are greater for having a girl rather than a boy. This of course is not proven and is just a theory.



</answer>



<answer from>



14 wks along with baby # 4~
Member since: 31 December 2006
Total points: 1686 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



It is the sperm that decides if it will be a boy or a girl. If the "male" sperm get to the egg and fertilize it quicker then it will be a boy. If a "female" sperm get there first..then it will be a girl. Scientists say that the male sperm are faster but die quicker and the females are slower but live longer. So if you want a girl, you should have sex 2-3 days before your ovulation day. That way the male sperm will die off before you ovulate and the females will still be alive fertilize the egg. If you want a boy, then have sex the day of ovulation.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bee
Member since: 08 April 2008
Total points: 6542 (Level 5)



</answer from>

I'm not sure how true the theory is, but I guess it is based in some fact in that female sperm live longer than male sperm but male sperm are stronger, so according to that then there could possibly be some truth but it's by no means a dead cert! I only ever had unprotected sex once and I got a boy!



</answer>

<question from>



momtobe0...
Member since: 27 May 2008
Total points: 89 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Pregnancy or pms? advice please.?



here are the symptoms i've been feeling:



nauseau, no vomiting
a few headaches (sometimes normal regardless)
1 spell of diarrhea (sorry TMI)
now constipation
gas
heartburn
cramps
extreme fatigue
some cramps and sharp pains in groin (maybe in urethra)
my back has started hurting in the lower part
feel more hungry with some weight gain or bloating feeling



i also have heard that if you lay on your back on a bed with your feet on the floor, and push on your stomach above your pelvic bone, if you feel a hard circle, you're pregnant. i feel that.



my last period was on aug 24. i think i was ovulating around the 17 or 18 of sept. we were trying to target it so we had intercourse for about a week and a half around that time. i'm supposed to start tomorrow or friday, but i don't feel like i will. normally when i'm gonna start, i get diarrhea because everything in my stomach is churning...but i don't have that now. i've taken a few tests, and they were negative, but the last one i took was monday. i'm going to test again, but when should i? tomorrow? friday? please don't be smart about your answers. i'm just wanting advice. do you think i'm pregnant?



</question>



<additional details>



i've also noticed my aerolas (nipples) look darker and those bumps are coming up on them. and i think my temp has been a little higher than normal, but i haven't been tracking it. i just feel warmer.



</additional details>



<answer from>



blackshe...
Member since: 09 August 2008
Total points: 221 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



there is a possibility that you are pregnant, then again your symptoms could be caused by stress, or the fact that you really, really want to be pregnant.  only a pregnancy test will let you know for sure



</answer>



<answer from>



SteFF
Member since: 02 January 2008
Total points: 545 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You should wait a couple of days after your missed period just to be sure, or alternatively go to the doctors and ask for a blood test. I think it sounds like you are. Good Luck! i hope you get the results you want



</answer>

<answer from>



lillilou
Member since: 25 October 2006
Total points: 14489 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not really.  Being pregnant, can be a roller coaster ride on your emotions.  I spose one day, you can feel fulfilled, but the next day you're scared as hell, then the next day you feel like a big cow, then the next you may feel beautiful and glowing.



</answer>



<answer from>



mommy2on...

<answer from>



Starsfan...
Member since: 19 January 2007
Total points: 8863 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think you can answer that for all women, but I am sure that pregnancy does emotionally fulfill some.  Being pregnant has not given me any emotional fulfillment.  I don't enjoy being pregnant at all.  Now being a mother has, but I probably could have adopted a child and been just as fulfilled emotional, if not more.



</answer>



<answer from>



shadowta...
Member since: 16 October 2007
Total points: 223 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's not a baby's job to provide "emotional fullfilment" to a woman.  If she's looking or that, she needs to figure out the root cause of it and not drag some poor kid into the frey.



If anything, pregnancy (and being a mother) can make you second-guess your every move -- let alone provide any fulfillment.



As for how many kids to have, that depends on finances, time, realistic ability to provide attention to the kids, etc.  It should definately NOT be based on some fulfillment need.



</answer>

<question from>



holly

</question from>



<question>



Hypermobility and pregnancy?



hi i have hypermobility in my legs and am getting spasms in my legs when i need to stretch them, was wondering if anyone had this when they were pregnant.
when i had my first child i ended up in a wheelchair when i was 6 months pregnant because my hypermobility got worse i am trying to keep it under control this time so any advise would be helpful. thank you



</question>



<answer from>



Joy R
Member since: 27 May 2007
Total points: 158 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Is it possible that you have a connective tissue disorder such as Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome or Marfan Syndrome? If so, you should be evaluated for it, and if you're diagnosed then your doctor will know how to proceed.



Source(s):



I was married to someone who was diagnosed with Marfan syndrome and then later found out that he had Ehlers-Danlos Hypermobility Syndrome.



</answer>



<answer from>



Beatles Fan Xx
Member since: 04 March 2008
Total points: 1156 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have hypermobility but no kids. I'm only 16. I think you should go get it checked out because i was experiencing severe spasms in my legs and had to go to hospital. I would go sooner rather than later.

Good luck with the baby.



</answer>



<answer from>



silver_i...
Member since: 03 May 2007
Total points: 135 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have it too and I was back and forth to the hospital the whole time I was pregnant, every little twinge!

You should always get checked out but one of the things I founf great was getting some medium support pants (bon marche sell them) a couple of sizes bigger than I'd normally wear. These took the weight of the baby and made things a lot easier

Good luck! xxx



</answer>
