<question from>



kgirl
Member since: 09 July 2008
Total points: 283 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Can implantation after deprovera be like this?



I got my period on June 16, 2008 and was due to get second depo show but refused...had sex....period didn't come till July 29, 2008 and lasted 11 days. Hubby and I had sex at least once a week during this time. Also had sex on 8 day of period (it was a light flow) and sex on the last day of period.



Hubby and I had sex Thursday and blood flowed immediately after we finished. Period had just went off 3 day previous to that day. Now I have a light flow. Could I have gotten pregnant? One day period will be light pink. Then it will stop. Then it will return again brown with a lot of mucus. Then it will turn medium/dark red. I have had some small blood clots. So could I still be pregnant?

I don't know if this is what depo does to you when you implant.



</question>



<additional details>



thanks Purrfect and Kass. I hate that I ever got this shot. I seriously want to know what is going on but I am scared to test.



</additional details>



<answer from>



purrfect...
Member since: 20 September 2007
Total points: 3020 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I was on Depo for several months, and I suspect that rather than being pregnant, you are experiencing similar side effects to what I experienced.  For the first six months, Depo worked perfectly for me; but after that, I began having a period every single week.  One week would be like a normal period, starting heavy and lightening as the week wore on; but the other three weeks I would only bleed for two or three days, lighter than a normal period but heavy enough to be a concern.  I also had the brownish mucousy discharge at times.  My suggestion would be to call your doctor and talk to them about your symptoms.  You might also try a home pregnancy test, just to be sure.



Source(s):



Mom of three and one-to-be!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks a bunch to you and Kass. I will test asap.



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Your ovulation depends on your cycle.  If you have a 28 day cycle you should ovulate sometime around day 14.  It really isn't as hard as it sounds since the sperm can live for several days in your body.  The best chance would probably be having sex between days 10-14 but could even be a little later than that.



</answer>

<answer from>



Sandy Lee
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 156 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Believe it or not, it sounds normal to me. Every pregnancy is different. My doctor tells me that all the time. I just tell myself, "Wow, it would figure I'd be one of the unfortunate ones". I was sick 24/7 the first 4 months of my pregnancy. I'm now 26 weeks and I'm dealing with constant aches and pains. My back hurts all the time. I can't stand for long periods. I get constant headaches. My hips hurt every morning when I wake up. I still get nauseated very easily. There's a ton of foods I can't even eat anymore. And I keep thinking to myself that if I'm feeling like this now, then I can't imagine how I'm going to be feeling in a month or two. It's definitely more than what I expected. But hey! Look at the bright side...you're almost there.



</answer>

Can I really be seeing the baby kick at 18 weeks pregnant?

It was like a tapping and stretching from within, always in the same spot and would happen every now and again, sometime a few in quick succession and then nothing for a couple of minutes.  Once I'd got used to this sensation I realised that I've been feeling a similar but lighter and less obvious sensation for a week or so just before I go to sleep.



I was watching my stomach while in the bath and whenever the baby 'kicked' I saw my stomach move up in the very spot where I felt the kick.



I'm really surprised that I would be able to see anything this early, so do you think I really am feeling the baby kicking and is it really possible at 18 weeks to see your stomach move from the kick?

This is my first pregnancy, and I guess I'm fairly average weight with a definite bump.

<answer>



Short of not having sex AT ALL there is ALWAYS a chance of getting pregnant!
If you are still within 72 hours of having unprotected sex you can take the morning after pill. Other than that you'll just have to go to your GP and see what's happened.
You should never rely on merely one form of birth control, IMHO it's just asking for trouble. You should always have a back up (not to mention you need to keep yourself safe from STI/STDs as well as getting pregnant!).



</answer>

mrsmum
Member since: 28 May 2008
Total points: 335 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You might be leaking your amniotic fluid.  Give your midwife a call.  Sometimes your waters "breaking" can just be a little trickle over a few hours.  Best just to have a check over to make sure your waters are still in tact.  If they have broken you need to go into labour within 24 hours or they will induce you to stop the risk of infection.  The waters around your baby are like a barrier to the outside world, once they have gone, you need to be kept an eye on.



Good luck hun, it sound like your baby might be on its way xxx



</answer>

<answer from>



Miss Informed
Member since: 15 January 2007
Total points: 8661 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am a mother of 2 and I had the same thing in my last few weeks. It could be from a couple of things. First of all, hormones will cause you to produce more vaginal discharge and it can be really watery. A few times I thought my water had broken with my first baby, but it was only discharge. I actually had wet spots, like water, on my undies a few times. The second reason you can be experiencing it is because of all the pressure on your bladder. No one wants to hear they might be peeing themselves, but it's true. It's one of those unpleasant little things your mother fails to mention about pregnancy. =) You may not even notice it leaking either. 
The third reason would be a slow leak in the amniotic fluid. If you have an appointment coming up soon (they should be seeing you weekly at this point), it would be a good idea to tell your doctor about it. They can do a test where they take a strip of paper and dip it in the fluid. If it turns a certain color they can tell if it's amniotic fluid or something else. 
If you're not contracting or bleeding, I would go with the first two reasons. Just wear a panty liner. It's not long now!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



kimberly b
Member since: 10 December 2007
Total points: 1908 (Level 3)

Jessica W
Member since: 04 October 2007
Total points: 9150 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had the same thing with all three of my pregnancies.  It is just related to your hormones and changes your body is going through because of the pregnancy.  However, if it is thick or a bad smell, get it checked out.  It could be a simple yeast infection, or something else.  They have inserts that will take it away, and it won't harm the baby. I went through that too.



Edit - Bearcat the normal time to carry a baby is 40 weeks.



</answer>

<answer>



Hmm...it sounds like you may be leaking amniotic fluid. What does the discharge look like? Is it clear and watery? If it is, you need to call your doctor sometime today, they will want to induce you if you are leaking amniotic fluid for a long period of time without going into labor.



The only other possibility I can think of is that you're leaking urine, but (sorry, this is gross) urine has a pretty distintive smell so I think you would have noticed.

<answer>



Bearcat, women are pregnant for 10 months, not nine. So she's right on time.

First of all, congrats and best of luck to you and your baby!
1) The baby sits smack dab on top of your bladder, so the pressure may be weighing down on your bladder.
2) There could be a slight tear in the amniotic sac, leaking amniotic fluid. In this case (unless extremely near the due date) you should call your doctor and discuss the possibilities. Leaking amniotic fluid could be potentially very bad for the baby. 
3) The viscous squiggy stuff that women leak out before their water breaks often slowly leaks for a few days as the baby nears birth.. It's somewhat of a grey color, but I guess that all depends on you.

Ahh. I'm so excited for you!



</answer>

<answer>



It could be a combination of pee, vaginal discharge or a slight chance could be your water breaking. As long as it's not pinkish or have a foul odor I wouldn't worry about it too much. Also as long as there is no cramping associated with it then you should be fine. Mention it to your doctor at your next appointment and they might be able to give you more specifics. I was like that the last 2 weeks of my pregnancy. It was definitely no fun but nothing to be concerned about. Good luck

<question from>



Steph35
Member since: 06 March 2008
Total points: 511 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



My doctor's reaction to spotting?



I went in Monday for my doctor's appointment, and told him about the spotting that's been going on the last couple of weeks.  His reaction?  Nothing.  Basically, it's the same situation as last time when I miscarried.  Wait it out and see, because there's nothing they can do to stop it.  I'm not having a blood test until October 23, to measure my HCG levels, and my ultrasound is scheduled for December 20th!  So now I'm almost 8 weeks pregnant, and just waiting for whatever happens next.



I live in Canada, (New Brunswick), where we have a doctor shortage, so it's almost impossible to get another doctor, so I'm stuck.  Oh, and also, knowing I was spotting he gave me a pap test!



Just wanted to know what you guys think about this.



</question>



<answer from>



M Kerr RN L&D
Member since: 04 March 2007
Total points: 48109 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Pap test won't affect the pregnancy either way, they are 100% safe to get.



Basically for the rest hes right, there isnt a thing that can be done if you are having a miscarriage, BUT, it's also common for spotting to occur in early pregnancy.  I wouldnt panic just yet, unless the spotting turns bright red bleeding, period like with cramps chances are you having a normal pregnancy with some spotting.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kim -due Feb O9 :)
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 301 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



you're doctor should have done more- if you really feel there is something wrong please go to the hospital and ask for a check as now they can see from an internal whats going on in there...



but its different here in UK - we can go free and whenever so dont know how it works out with you guys



good luck xx



</answer>

mamma

132

<answer>



Sorry to hear. I know the wait and the not knowing is terrible. But the doctor is correct, there is nothing you can do. Even if you were able to get a scan right away, you cannot prevent an imminent miscarriage. </answer>



<answer from>



Canada Baby, 24 weeks :)

<answer>

mattz_gr...
Member since: 24 June 2007
Total points: 2776 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I believe I'd still be doing whatever I could for a second opinion. I've never had a miscarriage, but the same thing happened to me at about 8 weeks. I began spotting one weekend, so I immediately contacted the doctor's answering service. He called me back in a matter of minutes and had me go to the hospital that day for labs. I'm 32 weeks now, and everything is going just fine. It's just scary and you want that reassurance! October 23 is a long time to have to wait for that. I hope everything turns out alright for you and your little one!



</answer>

Pregnancy & Parenting

<question from>



l h
Member since: 28 November 2007
Total points: 2316 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



What is the pregnancy walk and when do you get it?



I've heard about how pregnant women walk differently. I'm 32 weeks and I don't think I do!



How do they walk different, and why? When do you get this walk?



</question>



<additional details>



I'm not carrying small - I'm carrying as though I'm 33 weeks.



</additional details>



<answer from>



GivPerf
Member since: 31 May 2007
Total points: 2177 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You probably do walk differently, and just haven't noticed it.

It's a sort of waddle, or side-to-side walk... and it's caused by your center of gravity shifting. It starts the minute your stomach starts to pop out a bit, and gets more exaggerated over time. If you're carrying very small, it's possible you don't do this yet.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kathy S
Member since: 07 June 2007
Total points: 4597 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Once your baby's head is fully engaged, I think you will find out!



Source(s):



Mother of two



</answer>



<answer from>



DippyD
Member since: 07 February 2008
Total points: 5655 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Som women tend to waddle later on in pregnancy this is because they are large and find it more comfortable to walk this way! i started to waddle in the last couple of weeks when i was very big!



</answer>



<answer from>



Devrie S
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its more of a waddle-ish walk.I'm eleven but my mom did it when she was around like 5-6 months.it really depends on how big up are.



Source(s):



um close observation



</answer>



<answer from>



littlemu...
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 2036 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The pregnancy walk is not so much of a walk as a waddle.  I do it now at 20 weeks a bit as i have a small bump but am compensating from some lower back pain.  Your centre of gravity shifts which makes it difficult to walk upright without doing the side to side wobble thing.  Its quite funny but I'm trying not to do it at the moment, its just too early lol



Source(s):



mother of 4yr old and 20 wks with #2



</answer>

Good luck! Happy waddling!!

<answer from>



kade*

</answer from>



<answer>



some women do it others dont. its not a symptom of pregnancy. it depends on the women n how able they are to shift their weight.

u may notice pregnant women 'waddle' like a duck from side to side.

im 38 weeks pregnant n im not massive but ive added a good 2st to my pre pregnancy weight n i dont do it.

is a question of balance, i notice i walk slighlty different when the baby pushes down n i feel like ive got a ball between my legs or if she shifts from one side to the other it puts ur balance out, but dont worry if u dont do it....its not a requirement ha ha.

best of luck xx



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Scan in late pregnancy measuring 1 cm smaller then last week is it normal to scan?



can you see a lot of the baby in there what possible reason is there for this scan i will be 37+2 weeks when i have the scan (tues)

they have told me its to check the babys growth, as i measured 1 cm smaller then the week before i thought 2 cm either way was ok

are they telling me the truth or could something be wrong with the baby they are not telling me
i did ask the midwife/doc 3 times and they said because of the measurements

please help worried



</question>



<answer from>



Shannon J
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 200 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It sounds pretty legit.  It would be ok if you were off on measurements a bit but not ok if you are smaller than you were before.  They have to determine if the baby is at a point where being outside would be more beneficial to him or her.



Source(s):



Nursing school



</answer>



<answer from>



Daisyhil...
Member since: 23 June 2007
Total points: 26092 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dont worry...my measurements varied a bit too...it sounds like you have very good care. They dont keep stuff back from you..it wouldnt be legal...if they suspected something wrong they would tell you.



</answer>



<answer from>



littlemu...
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 2217 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



They could not know that something was wrong with the baby without doing a scan so it is unlikely that is the reason.  It sounds like they are telling you the truth, they will just be checking on the baby's growth if your measurements have gone down.  At this stage it is better to be safe than sorry which will be why they are checking how your baby is growing.  If your baby is smaller than it should be it could be because the placenta is not functioning as well as it should be and in this case your baby will need to be delivered a bit early (not a problem at all at this stage).  In any case you have nothing to worry about.  Good luck!



Source(s):



mother of 4yr old boy and 22wks with baby girl!



</answer>

<answer from>



sftballg...
Member since: 14 July 2006
Total points: 1217 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well it depends on where you are in your cycle. If you are ovulating at the time of sex then the risk is very high. Ovulation usually occurs 14 days after the first day of your period.  Also, just a little FYI, you can get pregnant from precum.



http://www.revolutionhealth.com/calculat...
 If you go to this website they have an ovulation calculator. If you want to use it.

Hope this helps! Good luck



Source(s):



Nursing Student & Mommy
http://www.revolutionhealth.com/calculat...

http://www.teenwire.com/ask/2004/as-2004...



</answer>

<answer from>



adrian
Member since: 10 February 2007
Total points: 1802 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The morning-after pill — a form of emergency birth control — is used to prevent a woman from becoming pregnant after she has had unprotected vaginal intercourse. Morning-after pills are generally considered safe, but many women are unaware that they exist.



Here's how the morning-after pill works. Human conception rarely occurs immediately after intercourse. Instead, it occurs as long as several days later, after ovulation. During the time between intercourse and conception, sperm continue to travel through the fallopian tube until the egg appears. So taking emergency birth control the "morning after" isn't too late to prevent pregnancy.



The active ingredients in morning-after pills are similar to those in birth control pills, except in higher doses. Some morning-after pills contain only one hormone, levonorgestrel (Plan B), and others contain two, progestin and estrogen. Progestin prevents the sperm from reaching the egg and keeps a fertilized egg from attaching to the wall of the uterus (implantation). Estrogen stops the ovaries from releasing eggs (ovulation) that can be fertilized by sperm.



The morning-after pill is designed to be taken within 72 hours of intercourse with a second dose taken 12 hours later. Side effects may include nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fatigue, dizziness, menstrual changes and headache. According to the manufacturer, the morning-after pill is more than 80 percent effective in preventing pregnancy after a single act of unprotected sex.



Morning-after pills aren't the same as mifepristone (Mifeprex), the so-called abortion pill. Emergency contraceptive pills such as Plan B prevent pregnancy. The abortion pill terminates an established pregnancy — one in which the fertilized egg has attached to the uterine wall and has already begun to develop.



Plan B is available to women 18 years and older without a prescription at most pharmacies. Women must show proof of age to purchase Plan B. For women 17 years old and younger, Plan B is available only with a doctor's prescription.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sparkling Diamond..
Member since: 20 March 2008
Total points: 179 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Firstly you did the right thing by getting the emergency contraception!

The "morning after pill", emergency contraception, works up until 72 hours (3 days) after the unprotected sex. However the sooner the pill is taken the faster it will work and the more efficient it would be.

The emergency contraception pill is very sucessful and only has a failure rate of about 2% (the failure usually occurs when the pill is taken after the 72 hour period).

I hope this has helped.
x



Source(s):



Myself.



</answer>

<answer>



It can take up to 12 weeks for your body to get back into some sort of pattern - I wouldn't be concerned yet.



See your Dr if still nothing in 4 weeks.

If you are having unprotected intercourse - which the withdrawl method is...you might also want to take a pregnancy test now - you don't have to have had a period bleed to get pregnant again.

Try condoms or something safer in the meantime.



</answer>

<answer from>



Seafret1...
Member since: 30 April 2008
Total points: 1090 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Every woman is different, but initially, a large amount of women get swollen or sore breasts, and some get morning sickness.  They exhibit no other major symptoms, except for lack of periods (not all women get this, but hoorah for small mercies). You may start to crave certain foods, or smells and some things will turn you off that didn't necessarily before.  You will want to drink more fluids, feeliing dehydrated if you don't.
As your stomach starts to swell, you will notice that it is not like being fat, it is firm and hard, however, you will still not initially feel movement, some women don't feel their first until they are well over 20 weeks, breasts will grow and some lucky women report better hair, skin and nails.



After 12 weeks, a lot of women loose the morning sickness and breast pain, and report they feel better or start glowing.  You may experience a heightened sense of smell which apparently harks back to the day when we needed to be wary of foods that would poison or upset us so strong smelling foods like onions and fish may linger with you far longer than they did before.
In your last 3 months, you may experience heartburn, as the womb is pressing upon the stomach, you may actually loose weight, but may not think it because your bump is still growing.  The breasts also grow more.  You may develop a waddle, which is tragically not sexy.  You may want to go to the toilet a lot.  In the last couple of weeks, your heartburn may go as the baby moves down.  You will be tired by then end, and feel anxious about your due date and labour.



It's all worth it, and just to prove it, I'm doing it again, got six days to go.
Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



ebony 23
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<answer from>



Jackie
Member since: 31 December 2006
Total points: 438 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am going through this exact thing..and I am only 8 weeks along. These helped me a lot. I raised the head of my bed onto blocks of wood 4-6 inches and I sleep on my left side. Maalox is safe when you are pregnant. Stay away from spicy foods, chocolate, soda, fried or fatty foods and spearmint and peppermint.  Don't eat 3 hours before laying down for a nap or going to bed. Eat slowly and chew thoroughly. Try eating six smaller meals a day instead of 3 big ones. Don't wear tight clothing around the waist or chest (it helps me to go without a bra) And try to avoid gaining too much weight it puts pressure on your stomach. I got all these from the What to expect when you're expecting and I have almost eliminated my heartburn and acid reflux.
If none of those work talk to the Dr about giving you some more ideas or some medicine. You CAN take Zantac or prilosec OTC. My Dr told me to take zantac all through my last pregnancy and everything was fine. This time they told me to take either that or the Prilosec..but ask your Dr. what they think is best. Good Luck..you are over half way there..hang in there :)



</answer>



<answer from>



maginty
Member since: 17 November 2006
Total points: 455 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

also, if you try and eat little and often it can help keep it at bay.

Sometimes it gets worse when you are hungry so graze rather than scoff :)

good luck

im a mum of three

I called my doctors office but they were closed... the emergency line sent me to another office... that was closed... I eventually got a hold of someone who claimed to call the on call doctor.  She said he didnt answer, so she paged him and said to call back if he didnt call me.... He didnt call and when I tried back there was no answers... 4 times...

I have been feeling ok... other then cramping and slight nausea... But I am still bleeding...

Do I go to the ER? or wait to see a OBGYN tomorrow?



</question>

<answer from>



euphgirl...
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 231 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



How heavily are you bleeding? Is it light bleeding or heavy like a heavy period. How many pads/hour are you going through. If it is light bleeding, then I would say wait until tomorrow. There is nothing the ER can do for a miscarriage. They only do supportitive care for the mother (making sure she does not loose too much blood). If you are only 5 weeks along, then chances are you will not loose too much blood. However, if the bleeding is heavy, then you need to be checked out. Good luck and hopefully this is a false alarm.



Source(s):



ER nurse



</answer>

<question>



Are they braxton hicks??



wot does braxton hick feel like??
and is it anythn to worry about

i keep gettin pains in my belly back & chest...like loadz of litle sharp pains...lasting a bit then stoppin...wondering if this is it??
im 27weekz pregnant 1st pregnancy



</question>



<answer from>



Hayley B
Member since: 16 June 2008
Total points: 582 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



braxton hicks are exactly as you described sharp pains that just get your body ready for labour they are nothing to worry about and completely normal. So yes i would def say you are experiencing these uncomfortable braxton hicks



</answer>



<answer from>



Sara*18weeks,due in january*
Member since: 25 April 2006
Total points: 580 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Braxton hicks arent anything to worry about.Last night i experianced sharp pains in my back and stomach,and it was worse then regular pains i get.So im guessing thats what i was experiancing.If it is,your stomach will feel really tight.
Does yours when you have the sharp pains?

Good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Kayla C
Member since: 27 November 2006
Total points: 2132 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



lil sharp pains sound like round ligament pains, esp. cuz u say they are in your chest as well. round ligament pain is nothing to be worried about, this is ur first pregnancy and you are at a point where you are stretching much further than your body has ever stretched before! they shouldnt ever get really bad though, so if they do, call your doctor immediately and have him/her check everything out!



</answer>



<answer from>



kassyrn
Member since: 24 August 2007
Total points: 208 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



What you are describing does not sound like braxton hicks.  A braxton hick contraction is not sharp and you should only be able to feel it in your abdomen.  Your stomach will get tight and you will feel uterine pressure, like your baby is pushing against your stomach really hard.  You will be able to feel your abdomen tighten and relax with your hand as well.  Being a first pregnancy, 27 weeks seems pretty early for braxton hicks.  It could be nerve related.  Be sure to mention this to your doctor at your next visit.



</answer>



<answer from>



Stephanie T



&lt;3
Member since: 19 July 2008
Total points: 862 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i read that BH are painless, but i think its crap bc mine hurt. but they are normal. no worries.



</answer>



<answer from>



kass ♥
Member since: 05 May 2008
Total points: 2595 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



They could be. Just watch them and make sure they dont get a pattern to them. Like if they start coming every 8 minutes... or every 20 mins... like clockwork. I f they do, you might want to go get checked to make sure your not in labor.



</answer>



<answer from>



C B
Member since: 19 June 2008
Total points: 553 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Braxton Hicks don't normally hurt.  Cause discomfort, yes, but hurt, no.  Sounds more like round ligament pain from all the stretching happening in your midsection.  If the pain continues without any relief and is accompanied by anything suspicious at all - an increase in discharge, fever, vomiting, spotting, etc, call the doctor and take yourself to the ER.  Also, give your doctor a call tomorrow morning no matter what, just to put your mind at ease.

Congrats and good luck!



Source(s):



28 weeks baby #1



</answer>



<answer from>



A L
Member since: 17 June 2007
Total points: 250 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



jacq
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Braxton Hicks can start after the 16 week of pregnancy, they are not supposed to be painful but sometimes they can, i found in my first pregnancy if they were uncomfortable it was helpful to have a warm bath, true contractions remain in the water, braxton hicks disappear.
Its also useful to change what you were doing, if you were walking, then relax and vice versa.
Dehydration, tiredness or straining yourself can trigger these contractions. 
If your still worried and are finding the pain unbearable go see your doctor, thats what they are there for.

Goodluck



</answer>

<answer>

i know i cant blieve it - knowing at 16wks because there muscles are developing they can make some faces - able to squint, frown and open its mouth and kick you - i dont know how any normal person with a healthy baby could end its life :(

<question>



Im so nervous about ultrasound?



Im having an ultrasound done tomorrow morning and Im so afraid. My last period was July 1st, Aug 2nd my HCG levels were 97 my dr said that I was very early in my pregnancy, Aug 4th they were 283, then Aug 11th they were 3301. My dr hasnt measured them this week. The reason Im so nervous Is I have had 2 previous ectopic pregnancies and Im so afraid to find out tomorrow that this one is also an ectopic. Im not having any pains, no spotting. Just normal pregnancy symptoms. What are my chances of having another ectopic and will I see anything on the ultrasound, they are doing a vaginal one. Thanks!!



</question>



<answer from>



Leesa T
Member since: 20 May 2007
Total points: 5807 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Your levels look great. It's natural to worry and given your past you have every reason to. Just because it happened before does not mean it will happen this time. I had 3 miscarriages and my pregnancy with my son was very scary. I am 16 weeks along now and it's still hard even after having a healthy baby. I have to remind myself that good things will happen for me and this baby is for keeps. This baby needs you now everything you've wanted for so long is inside you at this very moment. Breath free girl it will work for you soo many women have loss and go on to have a healthy pregnancy about 80 present. You have a higher chance of things working out than you do of having another loss and that is a fact! It will be okay like I said I know it's hard but try as hard a you can tell yourself it will be okay. Hope does not disappoint us having hope is never a bad thing. I can't wait for you to see your baby's little beating heart tomorrow.



Source(s):



mom of 9 month old and 16 weeks along with #2



</answer>

A vaginal ultrasound will tell you exactly where baby is located & you will be able to see a tiny sac but not always a heartbeat because it is still very early ( & very tiny).

<question>



Smoking while pregnant?



My sister has told me that she and her husband are trying for a baby, and i am thrilled.
Now she smokes and has done for over 10 years but said that she definatly wont smoke while pregnant, but when i suggested that she give up now, while trying to conceive she was kinda mad at me.

I just wondered if people on here smoked while pregnant, or gave up while ttc and what your views are.

I realise that it is my sisters choice whether or not to give up smoking its just i think why wait until your pregnant why not stop now while your ttc-
Her argument, is that i dont know what its like as i have never smoked (which she is probably right)



</question>



<additional details>



Please dont leave nasty comments about my sister regarding this question, i am looking for peoples views and smokers who gave up while ttc or while pregnant.



Just wanted to say thank you to everyone who has answered so far, its nice to get positive comments and advice from people.

Sometimes people say really hurtfull things on here, when theres no need.

So thank you everyone!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Graham's mommy
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 1733 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Once I found out I was pregnant, I quit smoking. I didn't even have the desire to smoke, and I'm able to have enough control to not smoke when I have cravings. Just because I don't want it to hurt my baby. 
My pregnancy wasn't planned, but if she's trying to conceive, she really should stop smoking. It could interfere with her getting pregnant too. Along with drinking, etc. But I'm sure she knows that. You're right. She needs to start quitting now.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks to everyones response, but i chose this as the best answer because i completely agree with it.



</asker's comment>

I see it as being quite selfish to smoke while pregnant. It's just 9 months out of your life, and surely the baby's welfare is the most important thing.
Why take any unnecessary risks?

<answer>



It is your sisters choice to smoke or not but she might find conceiving more difficult if she continues to smoke. 
As long as she gives up when she becomes pregnant things should be okay but if she doesnt her child could be born underweight and with other health issues. 
Try to convince her to give up now for her own long term health.

<answer>



I got pregnant and have smoked for a little over 10 years.  I wasnt really trying to get pregnant, and my husband smokes too.  When I found out I was pregnant, I slowed down to between 2-4 cigarettes a day from almost 1/2 a pack.  Needless to say, I miscarried at 10 weeks.  So now when I try to conceive in the upcoming months, my plan is to stop before trying... Hope this helps...



</answer>

<answer>



My friend went to the doctor and got help to stop smoking before conceiving.  Smoke can cut off oxygen to the baby and is very dangerous.  Alot of woman can just give it up for the baby when they find out they are pregnant.  But damage can already be done, because you can be 5-6 weeks along before you find out your pregnant.  Maybe doing some research and maybe passing it on to your sister.  Because even second hand smoke affects the baby, and if her husband smokes also, he can harm the baby.  But they should really stop before trying.  It's hard to quit, but it needs to be done before a baby.



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



My mother and several aunts smoked while pregnant.  We all turned out OK.  It's not a death blow to the baby.



But it IS a risk factor for several problems, including low birth weight.  And this carries a whole raft of problems with it.

I suspect that your sister knows that she should quit, but she's afraid of how hard it will be, and she's afraid that she won't be able to do it while she's pregnant.  Your comments brought that fear out in the open.  Instead of harping on her about it, try supporting her.  Tell her that you're willing to help her quit now, by exercising with her, encouraging her to cut back until she can quit, and cheering for her when she makes progress.



</answer>



<answer from>



Hoping for a girl this time
Member since: 17 July 2008
Total points: 454 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i smoked with my first 2 kids, but was able to drastically cut down.  Quitting is very hard, and i was kicking myself the whole time.  Both were born healthy.  I am 8 weeks along with #3 and have almost been able to quit (down to 6 a day).  It is sooo hard to quit after smoking for so long. (12 years for me).  I give your sister credit for commiting to quit when she gets pregnant, although it may be easier for her now, because if she needs a prescription she cannot take them, or use the patch while pregnant.



</answer>

<answer>



Giving up does increase the chances of getting pregnant - ask anybody who has been through IVF. Ideally both she and her partner should give up while ttc as it has an impact on both the sperm and the egg.
I agree giving up isn't easy but if your sister thinks it will be easier once her hormones start changing she is fooling herself. I would say try to give up along with the tiredness, sickness and hormone changes of early pregnancy isn't going to make giving up any easier.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jill
Member since: 05 May 2007

Contributing In:



Health Care



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Research on this issue is pretty clear - smoking puts you at higher risk for miscarriage, preterm delivery, small birthweight, etc.

The sooner she stops, the healthier her pregnancy will be.



I think all smokers aren't stupid and ignorant to this fact, they just don't like other people getting preachy with them because they already know they shouldn't be doing it. Smoking is just a tough addiction to battle, quitting is not as easy as people (non-smokers who have never dealt with addiction) seem to think it is.

HOWEVER, despite the risks that research has detailed, in the grand scheme of things, there have been many women who have smoked throughout their pregnancy who have had healthy pregnancies and healthy babies. If she smokes it's not a given that bad things will happen. Some doctors even frown upon quitting cold turkey as the stress on the body can actually be just as bad for a pregnant woman and her child.

It's your sister's business, and you already said something to her about it once, so leave it at that. The ball is in her court, and she will do what she wants, whether anyone approves or not. Fighting with her over this issues is not what you want to do.



Good luck to you and her.



Source(s):



RN



</answer>

It's better to quit while she's ahead.

This is a touchy subject now days.  I had my kids over 15 years ago and I hate to admit now , but I did smoke then. ( my kids are all normal, I have on child in Gifted and Talented classes and the others are in Honor Roll )



Up until the 90's, there were still pregnant people smoking and it wasn't looking down upon as much because we didn't know the dangers.  I am not saying its OK to smoke.  If I had to do it over, I wouldn't do it.



Talk to her and tell her your concerns, but don't push her to stop.  ITs her choice and only she can stop.

Smoking isn't good for anybody. It isn't good for the smoker, it isn't good for those around the smoker and it most certainly isn't good for the unborn baby. In the end it is just selfish on their part. If you are going to smoke that is fine but it should be somebody's choice. The unborn baby didn't ask for a cigarette.



As for your sister it would be much easier if she was to gradually quit now before getting pregnant. It only makes sense that stopping now would be better than finding out she is pregnant and then trying to quit when she could have withdrawals which isn't good for the baby.

<answer>



I didn't have a problem concieving while I smoked. HOWEVER... I did smoke for the first four weeks of my pregnancy, not knowing that I was pregnant. I found out the fifth week that I was pregnant and quit immediately. It was hard but it will be worth it. I also went to the doctor and found out my baby's placenta had a tiny tear in it. I read that smoking can cause these tears and they have dangerous consequences, even miscarriage. The doctor told me I had nothing to do with the placental tear but I think I did and feel so bad about smoking but I didn't know. Soo..my OBGYN told me that since I have stopped smoking, the placental tear will heal itself as it continues to develope. My suggestion to your sister is to stop smoking now because she won't know right away when she is pregnant and the same thing may happen to her. I do not suggest smoking while pregnant because that is REALLY dangerous for her future baby. The sooner she stops smoking the better! Good luck! =)......and just fyi the smell of smoke makes me sick now! lol go figure



Source(s):



Experience



</answer>

<answer>



To Ghosthuntergirl: Yeah, they're fine...for now. That's the problem with ignorant people.

Anyway...

To answer your question: I am a smoker, BUT I did indeed quit smoking as soon as I found out that I was pregnant with both of my babies. This is your child. They don't ask to come into this world. They have a choice whether to smoke or not to. It's not fair to inhale all the chemicals that you so choose and send it directly to your unborn child via umbilical cord. My sister smoked during both of her entire pregnancies. I hated it. I couldn't believe that she would do that. Knowing how much I loved to smoke, but yet had the common sense and willpower to stop smoking. THEN she had these babies and breastfed them. Yeah, it was absolutely a disgrace. On one hand you're trying to give them the best head start in life with the most incredible nourishments that formula can't duplicate, yet she's smoking. Completely defeats the purpose.

Oh well, sorry for the rant.



</answer>

<answer>



I smoked until I found out that I was pregnant.  It is very difficult to quit.  I tried many times before I was pregnant, but I couldn't get it to happen.  The worst part for me was people bringing it up all the time.  I quit almost a year ago and people still bring it up all the time.  It doesn't help for people to constantly talk about it.  Your sister will quit when she is ready and that will probably be when she is pregnant.  It is something that she really has to want to do for herself and for her baby.  The biggest hurdle is the mental and emotional connection to smoking.  It is a powerful addiction.  Just let your sister know that when she decides to quit that you will be there for her and try not to push her. It is something that you can't force someone else to do.  I know if she is a responsible person she will make it work for 9 months.  Hopefully once she has that much time behind her, she will quit forever.  Tell her good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



I had seven children, I smoked with six of them, and went off them with one while I was pregnant because it made me sick.  And out of all my children the one I didnt smoke with was put on inhalers from one years of age, which now that she is ten dosent need any more. I stayed off them for near enough three years, but now have got hooked on them again.  And am still trying to give them up.

But I have been a smoker for many years and did try to go off them, even before I was pregnant, but it is hard.  Especially when you really want to.....

I do regret not being able to quit while I was pregnant, I didnt even think of quitting before I was pregnant because they were all surprises if you know what I mean, but it would be better if she could quit, but if she is finding it hard, she will need all the support she can get, from everyone, and it will of course be her decision.

But stick by her, whatever her decision will be.

Honey

Total points: 5177 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I didn't quit smoking until my pregnancy was confirmed by a doctor. My husband and I conceived at the end of December, we weren't trying to though. I began feeling syptoms around the second week of January. I had taken like 5 different over the counter pregnancy tests which all came out positive. All this time, I had been smoking. I was smoking about 3-4 cigarettes a day, no more than 6 in one day. The first week of February, I went to my doctor and my pregnancy was confirmed. At the time, I was a bit overwhelmed and smoked a cigarette when I got home.



I have not smoked a cigarette since then. I'm about 33wks pregnant right now. I chose to stop smoking cigarettes because I felt that all the chemicals in cigarettes would be dangerous for my baby. In addition to what my doctor told me the possible result could be, I found numerous articles on the internet that confirmed all he told me.



On the one hand, I can understand your sister's reluctance to quit right now. She's probably very aware of the fact that conception may not happen right away, possibly for years, and she doesn't want to stop if there's no immediate reason. If your sister is at all a responsible person, I'm sure she'll stop smoking while pregnant. It won't be easy and she'll need a lot of encouragement- not bashing. Even though she doesn't feel an immediate need to quit, I'm sure that she'll do what's best for her baby. Most moms do. Even if she continues smoking after she has the baby, while she's pregnant, she'll probably quit. I did and it wasn't at all difficult.



</answer>

<answer>



I smoked during all 3 of my pregnancies, and I have 3 big and healthy babies. The Dr. suggested I cutback from my pack and a half a day habit, to something smaller. So I cutback to 5-7 cigarettes a day. Cold turkey could stress you out, and that's not good for the baby. You can ween yourself off, but don't go cold turkey.



</answer>

<question>



Hip pain at 32 weeks??



Last night I had a sharp pain to the inside of my left hip bone - as though I'd pulled a muscle.  It came in waves of pain, but I didn't take painkillers for it. It only went if I laid on my left. If I laid on my back or right it hurt.

Any ideas?



</question>



<additional details>



I'm not sat in a position where it bothers me. But I know that if I were to shift position or lie down, then it would.



Baby's been shifting around a lot yesterday - I've had various part of her body in my ribs, and what I can only describe as what feels like Baby punching through jelly down below.



</additional details>



<answer from>



DevineFe...
Member since: 22 March 2008
Total points: 4440 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



at that far along the baby starts to lay on you in ways that can pinch nerves. its usually nothing to be worried about. ask your doctor about what you can do to relieve the pain or to avoid it. they may prescribe some safe drugs, or exercises or other things to relieve the pain.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cristyn
Member since: 04 May 2007
Total points: 784 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm 31 weeks. Im getting that too. Maybe our babies stuck their fists in there..



</answer>



<answer from>



amanda N
Member since: 09 July 2007
Total points: 189 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



if its more toward the front, probably round ligament pain.  harmless but uncomfortable.  if more toward your back on the inside, could be your kidney.  could be just how the baby was positioned at the time.  is it still hurting?  getting worse?  are you running a fever? was your belly getting tight while this was happening? (might be contractions) best to monitor it and if still bothering you today, see or call your doc.



</answer>



<answer from>



JNS
Member since: 02 December 2006
Total points: 5251 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is the ligaments in your hips stretching to accommodate the upcoming arrival of your baby. Do not take pain medication, sitting on an exercise ball and walking will help relieve the pain.



Source(s):



RN and mother of three



</answer>



<answer from>



Halo...as in Angels have them
Member since: 06 September 2007
Total points: 1167 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



JNS just about says it all.



There are so many different pressure points baby is laying on.  You also have ligaments that are stretching and getting tired.  When you lay on your right side or back, it is stretching them farther than they want to go...so they tell you so by the pain.  If you don't have a workout ball, try squatting a little, or try some pelvic tilts.



Good luck!



Source(s):



Mother of 5

<answer>



Be supportive of her. When she tells you she is fat and isn't feeling attractive, reassure her that you still love her. When/if she wants to diet or try crazy things to get thin and inshape again remeber that she isn't just doing it for herself, she thinks she's doing it for you too. It's really hard to feel good once you've had a baby. If this is the 1st and she was in pretty good shape before she got pregnant, in my opoion, it's easier to get a lot closer to that point. After my 1st I was back into pre baby clothes with in 2 months, after the 2nd one however, and it's been almost a year, I'm still sitting at the weight I was when I came home from the hospital. I go through bouts of depression where I feel fat and unattractive. It's not easy on us and we make it that much harder on you. The fact that you are on here asking for advices shows alot. Tell her you love her, do things that you did before she got pregnant, remember the the little things-like just because flowers and cards, tell her you find her attractive. Most of all show her that she is still number one and always will be. She will thank you and even though she'll probably bursh it off, she won't forget what you said or did, even though she probably won't agree with you.

<question>



During Intercourse just 3 hours before Condom was teared, I am feared of Pregnancy, please suggest me ? ?



During Intercourse just 3 hours before Condom was teared, I am feared of Pregnancy, please suggest me ? 
what steps is necessary to avoid pregnancy ? 
Note  : Last Friday is Completion of PERIOD



</question>



<answer from>



joyce_21...
Member since: 24 July 2008
Total points: 167 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



to avoid pregnancy, you and your partner must have sex 1 week before and 3 days after your period... the rest of the days is considered unsafe because it is your ovulation period...

also, to avoid pregnancy, you have options to choose:
your partner in need to wear a condom 100% effective
take contraceptive pills 100% effective
abstinence 100% effective
withdrawal 98% effective
calendar method (must be carefully observed) 98%



</answer>



<answer from>



westtexa...
Member since: 20 July 2008
Total points: 881 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



having any sex is a way to be pregnant.

<original file>index;_ylt=AtBYLbc1Tupcx_tkAqPDLBggBgx33cf.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk40878.txt</current file name>



<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Pregnancy



</category>



<question from>



♥Pink Princess♥
Member since: 07 July 2006
Total points: 1982 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Why are the midwife/doc sending me for a scan @36 weeks, am i worrying for nothing?



I am under the doc and midwife at the hospital instead of my local midwife as my iron level has been dropping (was 9.1 then 8.7 on iron tabs)

i went to see them yesterday and she said i mesured 36 weeks correctly last week but this week i only measured 35 weeks (i am 36+4days)

why are they sending me for a scan? they said it was to check the babys size and there is nothing to worry about as different people would measure me different

if thats the case why not let the doc who was in the room at the time measure me too why send me for a scan

i have spoken to friends and family and they said its normal to sometimes be 1 cm out so why are they scanning me im very worried there is something they are not telling me 
please help me cause i cant stop thinking theres something wrong

heard the heartbeat etc all was ok but they have also given me a form to fill in everyday to count babys movements this seems very strange to me

please help very worried mom to be



</question>



<additional details>



they said baby is head down, and is 4/5 engaged



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It is common and no worry for you to measure plus or minus 2 weeks from how far along you are, because every baby will develop differently. Plus like you said they mentioned, different people will measure differently. Measuring is not at all perfectly accurate anyways. There are a lot of reasons why you should not even worry about this. They do scans now and then just to double check that everything is okay, but not necessarily because things aren't okay. They just want to confirm that all is as it should be. I had an extra ultrasound at 31 weeks because they thought I was measuring 3 weeks ahead (so 34 instead of 31). They wanted to make sure the baby didn't have any abnormalities and they wanted to make sure I didn't have too much amniotic fluid, as that can signal a problem. Turned out everything was just fine, and the ultrasound showed the baby only actually being about 1.5 weeks ahead - still bigger, but within that 2 week range. And since all was well, even if she had been measuring 3 weeks bigger, it would just have meant I was having a bigger baby and they probably would have moved my due date back a little bit.

My point is, you should try not to worry because the overwhelming chance is that things are just fine! I know it is hard not to worry, but do your best. The scan is just a precaution :-)

Congrats and good luck!



Source(s):



Mom to 18 month old, 36 weeks pregnant with #2.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



firstly, everyone does measure differently and one person can measure  you 35cm and another 38cm. They likely just want ot make sure of the growth as a safety precaution rather than anything else. 
Also, you should be feeling around 10 movements from the baby in a 24hour period. If you had mentioned reduced movements or they were seriosly worried about the baby you would have been sent for a ctg trace of the baby straight away. 
Try not to panic and talk to your midwife about your fears. That is what she is there for. use her



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Ask the doctor or midwife but don't worry its a normal thing they do, its just to check baby is thriving ok and maybe they think it will be a small baby, remember when labour starts get the epidural. Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Are you mid 30's? If so they check more regular. Nothing to worry about.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Please dont panic! at 36weeks IF there was anything they were really worried about that could jepordise you or your baby they would look into induction, as they are not and have reassured you i wouldnt worry to much. i was booked in for a scan at 36 weeks, ( but didnt get that far had littleun at 34 weekds) they called it a growth scan because i was measuring large, my midwife told me the over the belly measurement are not idealy accurate and they can get a better idea through a scan. i hope this reassures you, all the best



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



To check that the baby is not sitting breach (feet down and head at the top), and possibly to check if the baby's head has "engaged" (moved down into the pelvis) yet.  Don't worry it's perfectly normal.

They can also send you for a scan to check the amount of amniotic fluid as towards the end of pregnancy the amount reduces.

Try not to worry!!!



Source(s):



Had lots of scans!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



i had a scan at 36 weeks..it was just to see how big the baby was..its nothing to worry about



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



DONT STRESS... its not doing you or your baby any good.



I had a scan at 36 wks too and that was because he was breach. but then he also wouldnt' engage anything.. he was classed as an 'unstable lie' he would swim around to his hearts content.. prob with that is if my water broke the chord would slip through .. contract.. and cut circulation off to him prematurely.. SO that was my dilemas with that.. it all worked out in the end.. i had my birthing story to carry on for yrs.. 
Now with your iron levels dropping thats ok.. your body will go up and down on that scale depending on the day you have had and the meals you had prior to each test. I was at 4 at one point and had a healthy baby boy.. 9lbs.. and early!! i was a little relieved that i had a c section as his head was quite large too lol.. (hated the idea at the time and was really angry at the docs for making me have one.. but i got over it as soon as i saw his sweet face)
Measurements are always going to be out a little.. dont panic your family is right. think about when your not pregnant your belly changes size all the time.. from bloated feeling to skinny when you haven't had enough water or you had too much water and you puff up.. you cant help that its a natural thing your body does when it wants to.. same happens when you have a baby.  You may find next week you go back and your belly is 3 times as big as its suppose to be for 37wks because the baby took on more because he/she was a little more hungrier this week.  same thing happens after child birth.. some weeks they pack on the weight some times they wake longer than normal and work it off.. 
Heart beat was fine - thats the main thing..
it has been a bit more of a 'cover their ***' thing to get mothers to monitor baby's movements. its good for you to be aware of them too but is not something to scare you in particular. a lot of women i know since i had my son 9yrs ago have been told to monitor movements. that also sends them scared too but if you arent aware of this and you baby does stop moving and you carry on then you could end up worse for wear.  A lady i knew who was due 2 wks before had a still born at 39 wks as she wasn't aware to monitor movements.. she nearly died herself. 
The dr did NOT intend to scare you in particular. its something they do now.. so please calm down and just enjoy the last few wks before your life is turned upside down!! (in a good way)

Oh.. i just remembered.. did they do a pelvic exam on you? they may be monitoring how big you baby is to see if you will be able to have a vaginal birth.. if bub is big for your size they may be calling in back up! Don't panic on this one.. its good for them to know if they need an extra nurse or two to help with your delivery. 
Remember every birth is different and no mater how it happens it is YOUR story to tell and it will be unique and memorable and one of the most talked about things you will ever do.. 
Take care.



</answer>

no answerer details

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



i was a house with my first, often people asked how many 2 or 3 and i always replied only 1,

my gosh if the 2 survived i wouldnt be able to get through the door,

i went from a 10/ 12 to a 18 / 20 my bump was massive

i slept alot or tried to anyway, bathed most of day as i got bad pains due to the size of me



i could barely walk but just got on with it, as i had to often move from bnb 2 bnb nearly each day until i was over due and on the night i moved in i dropped



oh the relief it felt great to have the bump gone.

i dropped down to 14/16 after birth and pretty much stayed around that going as low as 12/14 at times.

but those days i was tired always and wished the days by as i was in pain and had housing issues it was crazy and i was only 17, i had him just a few days after my 18th b day and funny enough the second just days before my 20th

second was easier and smaller but the bump still fairly large,



they probably call you in for another scan and see what the dates are or see how well the baby  is developed or if baby needs more time or is baby stressed.

good luck anyway relax when you can as it is not easy to when they are here, rest as much as possible as the early mornings and late night calls will start.

congrats too sweetie xxx



</answer>

<answer>



Due to my severe adema which is excess swelling of the body and fluid retention I was massive - I put on 6 stone, 3 of which was fluid, 1 stone was baby, amniotic fluid and placenta and 2 as a general gain. I spent the last days doing as much housework as I could to help have less to do when you get home. I also cooked meals and froze them so we had home made ready meals ready for when I got home to - they were a god send! my spare time was spent on the net and reading a few books. You really dont have long to go and your classed as full term anyway which is anything over 37 weeks so if your fed up - here's some labour vibes for ya ;-)

<answer from>



BC
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 712 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Honestly, you may not think you're ready, but once a baby is born, you mature very quickly. I was 18 when I first got pregnant, 19 when he was born. I was living with my fiance at the time, but, we were hardly making ends meet, bills were always late, etc. Shortly before he was born, the parenting instinct kicked in and we not only got back on our feet, but, we're doing pretty well for ourselves. Schooling isn't that big of a deal, parents go for schooling all the time, even with young children. I'm currently a "stay at home mom" (ie, unemployed by choice) and pregnant with our second (planned). I'm hoping to go for nursing school after the second baby is born, and my husband (yeah, we married three weeks after our son was born) is working a "factory job" making a nice pay.
I've heard of people who've had abortions who regret it so much later down the line. Some have even had accidents where they weren't able to have children later. In the end, it's your decision, but, as a young mother myself, I can tell you that our son made our miserable lives blossom into something worth living.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dana S
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi. I'm also 19 and I have a 3 year old. You sound like you have a good head on your shoulders and know what you want to do with your life. I understand your fear of the poorer lifestyle, working dead end jobs to just barely pay the bills. It's understandable. I am not an expert in anything like this, but when I was 14 I got pregnant, and I had an abortion at 12 weeks. I knew for a fact that I was NOT ready to be a mother, I couldn't even take care of myself. You sound like if need be, you could take care of a child, despite your financial situation. I think you and your boyfriend should sit down and really talk about this, it'll change both of your lives, no matter what decision you make. If you feel that it would be best for the abortion, than you should do it. If you honestly feel that it would be better off without continuing the pregnancy, then go make your appointment, before it's too late. Making the decision will no doubt be very hard, to this day I still think about what i'v'e done, and how my life is for the better now. I know it's a sin against god to get an abortion, but I am not saying that and I am not judging you. Just do what is in YOUR best interest and remember that you will have to deal with this decision for the rest of your life.

I hope I helped a little bit.



Source(s):



Mommy of a 3 year old.

<answer>



sounds to me you know what you want to do.  its one of the hardest decisions you will ever have to make.  if you decide to terminate the pregnancy, you are doing what you feel is best for your situation.  do not be too hard on yourself, or concern yourself with 'what people would think'.  only you and your bf have to live with your decision.  termination of pregnancy is pretty common, very safe, and an acceptable option in your case.

whichever you choose, stay true to yourself.

<answer>



Abortion is not as bad as some people make it out to be. If you are not in a position to give your child a good life, don't have it. Wait until you can provide for a child. If you keep it, you may be resent your boyfriend and your child. That is no way to bring up a baby. I had an abortion when I was 21. I don't regret it for a minute. There was no way that I could have been a good mother at that point in my life. It was the best decision I ever made. I got my partying and traveling out of the way, I found a great man and now I'm 29 and a happy mom of a beautiful baby girl.

<answer>



I find this a very hard question to answer.  I had an abortion when I was 19... it doesn't hurt, as others have said, but it is a very upsetting experience, obviously.  At ten weeks you need to make your decision fast, because the further on you are, the more unpaletable the decision gets (in my opinion).

You do sound like you want people to tell you it's ok to get an abortion - only you can decide that.  On a personal view I can say that I've never doubted that I made the right decision - I would have ended up another single Mum statistic in a grotty flat in some city.  The child wouold have no future and neither would I.  On the flip side I look at my two beautiful boys now and constantly wonder what my first child would have been like.  I know I couldn't do it again, now I'm married and in a lovely house and village we would just have to cope if I fell pregnant again, but at 19... I think making the decision to terminate for both your sakes is actually a very brave and sensible decision to make.



</answer>

<answer>



I  am very pro choice, and that why i not going to tell you what to do! I will not judge you. However; I think you need to go to plan parenthood.. I am not telling you to have an abortion I just giving you the facts! The choice is yours. i got this off their website. I hope this helps! 
Abortion



Abortion is a safe and legal way for women to choose to end pregnancy. There are two kinds of abortion in the U.S. — abortion procedures and the abortion pill. 
Abortions are very common. In fact, more than 1 in 3 women in the U.S. have an abortion by the time they are 45 years old.



If you are trying to decide if abortion is the right choice for you, you probably have many things to think about. Learning the facts about abortion may help you in making your decision. You may also want to learn more about parenting and adoption.



Only you can decide what is best for you. But we are here to help. A staff member at your local Planned Parenthood health center can discuss abortion and all of your options with you and help you find the services you need.



www.plannedparenthood.org



</answer>

sepulved...

</answer from>



<answer>



My wife wants to answer this one for you (she is 19 weeks pregnant). Here's what she says:
I have felt this way with each of my pregnancies. Its not just physical - its hormonal, so it's really hard to just "get up out of the slump". But for most women, including myself, the second trimester is easier. In the next few weeks, you should get your energy and vitality back (just don't forget to rest!) and the nausea *should* subside. Try ginger for nausea, although not very tasty, they work pretty good for temporary relief. (Ginger Altoids are good.) Also peppermint tea, iced or hot.

I hope some of this helps. Getting pregnancy or parenting magazines might help give encouragement on the hard days also.



Wishing you well on your journey to motherhood...



</answer>

<question from>



Couture x
Member since: 28 July 2007
Total points: 465 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Question about first ultrasound?



I'm not pregnant myself, but I'm writing a story about a 19 year old girl who is. I originally thought that the first ultrasound was at 12 weeks, so I wrote it into the story that way.



Now I've heard that the first should be at 8 weeks. Is it completely unrealistic if I keep the 12 weeks ultrasound as her first?

Btw, any other things that I should add into that part of the story, feel free to give me input :)



</question>



<answer from>



Chel
Member since: 19 November 2007
Total points: 4315 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



In my first pregnancy, i had bleeding, so i needed an ultrasound. It turned out to be a miscarriage.

In my second pregnancy, they tried timing it for 12 weeks, but i turned out to be 11 weeks, and i needed to go back.

My third pregnancy, i had cramping and pains, so i needed an ultrasound to make sure it wasn't an ectopic pregnancy. That was at 9 weeks, 6 days.



It depends on your history, and what doctor you have. You're the one paying for the ultrasound, so you get to say if you want one at 8 weeks or not.

The only reason they have one at 8 weeks, is so they can be sure when you're 12 weeks, because there's only a small window that you can have the down syndrome test done. If you miss that, you don't get it back, and it's between 11-13 weeks.

It's not unrealistic to keep writing your story that way. I know of people that haven't had one until 19 weeks.



You could write the first ultrasound as an accident that it was so late. Maybe she thought she wasn't as far along. 
Not many women have morning sickness, and a few have regular bleeding for no apparent reason. You could try writing that into your story too.

Good luck.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

cutemomm...

<answer>



It really depends on your doctor. Some drs will only do one ultra sound the whole pregnancy, to determine a more accurate due date and make sure the baby is growing accordingly. That ultra sound is done at the 12 week mark, so you are correct. Some drs however, will do an ultra sound once a month to check on baby or if you are high risk they do that...but not all do that because ultra sounds are expensive.



</answer>

<answer from>



AnswerMa...
Member since: 04 August 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My wife and I have two girls that are 17 months apart, which is very close to what your children would be if you are pregnant.  We were not expecting our second, but have been extremely happy with the experience.  Our kids are great companions and we found that taking care of two that were close to the same age seemed easier than we think it would have been if they were further apart and needing very different types of care.  Either way, you sound like the kind of person that will do a terrific job whether raising one or two at a time.  Good luck!



</answer>
