<answer>



Yes there is in fact a pill you can take if it has been less than 8 weeks from your last period, it is called a medical abortion. It is taken by 2 pills within 3 days of each other. Here is some information that might be useful.



Best of luck!

Medical Abortion with Mifepristone and Misoprostol
What is the Medical Abortion?

Medical Abortion (brand name Mifeprex) is a form of early abortion caused by the combination of two medications, mifepristone and misoprostol that is an option for women who are 8 weeks pregnant or less. Also known as RU486 or medication abortion.



During the first appointment at the clinic you receive the mifepristone pill to take orally. Then 24 to 72 hours later, in the privacy of your own home, you take the the second medication, misoprostol. Misoprostol causes contractions resulting in a miscarriage. When used in combination, mifepristone and misoprostol are 95-97% effective within two weeks. Mifepristone and misoprostol are FDA approved.

How Does It Work?

Mifepristone blocks the hormone progesterone needed to maintain the pregnancy. Because this hormone is blocked, the uterine lining begins to shed, the cervix begins to soften and bleeding may occur. With the later addition of the second medication, misoprostol, the uterus contracts and the pregnancy is usually expelled within 6 to 8 hours.



Because the woman chooses when she takes the second medication within the time frame of 24 to 72 hours after the first medication, she has some control over the timing of when she expels the pregnancy and experiences the side effects of bleeding and cramping. Some women choose the Medical Abortion because of the privacy it offers. Some women feel empowered by taking an active role in the process.

Use

At your first appointment at the clinic, an ultrasound is performed to confirm you are less than 8 weeks pregnant. You then speak with an experienced counselor who explains how mifepristone and misoprostol work and makes sure you get answers to all of your questions. Your health history is carefully reviewed and if you meet the criteria, the doctor will give you the mifepristone to take orally. You are also given one bottle containing four tablets of misoprostol to be used 24 to 72 hours after taking mifepristone. If this first dosage fails to induce a miscarriage, please call the clinic to receive instructions on using your back-up misoprostol tablets.

What To Expect

Upon taking mifepristone at the clinic you may begin to bleed. As each woman's body is different, bleeding varies from woman to woman. Some may experience light bleeding much like spotting towards the end of a menstrual period. Others have heavier bleeding like their regular menstrual period, or like a heavy period. Some women do not experience any bleeding until taking the misoprostol.

Upon taking the second medication misoprostol tablet, cramping, bleeding, and clotting may begin as soon as 20 minutes. Within the next 6 to 8 hours, most women will miscarry. Cramping may come in waves with increasing and decreasing intensity. You can expect bleeding heavier than a menstrual period with large clots. During this time, you will pass the embryo although you may not see it since it is very small. The amount of bleeding when using the Medical Abortion is greater than with aspiration abortion.



Aftercare

A follow-up exam is scheduled for two weeks later to make sure the process is complete. If you have not yet miscarried, we will perform a aspiration abortion. A very small percentage (5%) of women do not pass the pregnancy tissue and need a suction procedure to complete the process.

Side Effects

Most of the side effects when using this early abortion option are caused by the second medication, misoprostol. Side-effects may include heavy bleeding, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and heavy cramping.



Risks

Vaginal bleeding with medical abortion could be extremely heavy. In rare situations it could require a aspiration abortion and very rarely, a blood transfusion. You will be given our 24-hour hotline number to call if you have any problems. Medical staff are on call at all times to answer your medical questions and concerns.

If pregnancy is continued after taking these medications, there is a high risk of fetal deformities.

Criteria

Abortion Medication may be an option if you:

Are less than 8 weeks since your last menstrual period. 
Are willing and able to give informed consent. 
Have the support you need such as access to reliable transportation and ability to communicate with the clinic by telephone. 
Live no more than 2 hours away from emergency medical care (a hospital). 
Are able to come back to the clinic for 1 to 3 follow-up appointments. 
Agree to have a surgical abortion if the misoprostol does not induce termination. 
Your Health

Due to the risk of serious health problems, mifepristone and misoprostol may not be recommended if you:

Have had a blood clotting problem or are taking anticoagulant medicine. 
Have severe anemia. 
Have adrenal failure. 
Are taking long-term systemic corticosteroids. 
May have an ectopic pregnancy. 
Have a mass in the tubes or ovaries. 
Have inherited porphyria. 
Have an allergy to mifepristone, misoprostol or other prostaglandin medicine. 
Have severe diarrhea. 
Future Fertility

According to studies of the FDA (Food and Drug Administration) and the National Abortion Federation, there are no known long term risks associated with using mifepristone and misoprostol. Therefore, women may pursue another pregnancy whenever they feel the time is right after having a Medical Abortion.

Other Options For Early Abortion

If you are at least 6 weeks by ultrasound, you can choose to have a surgical abortion, in which the cervix is dilated and suction aspiration is used to remove the tiny pregnancy.

Another option may be a chemical or medical abortion using Methotrexate. Ask at the clinic about your particular circumstances.

No Confusion

Do not confuse Medical Abortion with the "Morning After" Emergency Contraception Pills (brand name Plan B). They are completely different medications taken for different purposes.



Source(s):



http://www.fwhc.org/abortion/medical-ab....



</answer>

<answer>



Hi there, well first of all ignore the negative comments as that wont get u anywhere! first of all before u stress yourself out, take a preg test to make sure ur pregnant, u have got to do this, terminations or abortions get treated for different stages of the pregnancy, go to the gp and tell them ur preg they do a test. if its positive then you ask the doctor to refer u for a termination, he then writes a letter to the local hospital nearest you and they send you an appointment for a consultation where a nurse then a doctor examine u and give u an ultrasound scan to see what stage ur pregnancy is at and how many weeks it shows on the scan, thats the first part, at this stage ur better NOT looking at the screen as a baby has taken shape at around 6 weeks and is visible, I know Im a mother of 6! then u get taken back in to talk to the doc who will then make sure that in ur own mind u are 100% positively sure that u want a termination, if u decide that is what u want they will give u an appointment righth there to come into a day ward, when u arrive a nurse will hand u a small yellow tablet for u2 take, once taken u can go home, u then return to the hospital to take a 2nd yellow tablet and they will insert pessaries inside ur vagina to loosen the cervix and u stay in the hospital until they have seen that the foetus has passed away, if u find it painful they give u strong painkillers to take but they will try and make u as comfortable as possible whilst ur there,what I will say is do not look into the bedpan thats on the toilet when u feel anything is about to pass as its not and never will be a pleasant sight! after the foetus has passed a family plannung nurse will visit u to ask u if u would like them to give u a method of contraception whilst ur in there and they will go thru all methods available to u, what they do, and how effective it is. To get the tablets you must be between 6-12 weeks pregnant if you go over that then you will have to get a medical termination but again this is only from the period from 12 weeks to 6 months pregnant after that they tend to give u the yellow pills again and u basically have to give birth to the baby to pass it which is definitely a horrendous thing to see and I would imagine quite traumatising for the person. what I will say is this though if u do decide to take the pill that the hospital give you and decide after you have swallowed it that you wish you hadnt gone through with it, it maybe too late to change your mind as these pills are designed to simply soften everything in the hope that the foetus will pass itself before u go back to take the 2nd tab, I had decided with my 6th child that I couldnt cope with another one when I found out I was pregnant with him, I took the first yellow tab at the hospital and went home....I had bad pains all that night but nothing happened no bleeding nothing, 2 days later I went into hospital to take the second one and I didnt feel right so I asked for a scan, I asked to see the scan and asked them if my baby was dead they told me NO his little heartbeat was visible and I could see him moving about I felt so guilty that I jumped off the scanning bed and ran out! I went on to have a beautiful baby boy totally healthy in every way, the pills dont kill the foetus or harm it in anyway its only designed to soften ur womb etc, so bear in mind that when u take the 2nd ones and get the pessaries inserted there is absolutely no way back!once ur cervix opens and everything contracts the foetus will be expelled out into the bedpan hopefully and when it does bear in mind that it would still have been alive , sorry for being so blunt but thats the reality of it! I hope ur test is negative and please be more careful next time u have sex as this is not a pleasant experience for anyone, good luck and I hope this helped you Gilly x



</answer>

Brunette...

<answer>



An abortion pill. This is for pregnancies up to nine weeks old and involves taking two drugs – called mifepristone and prostaglandin – 48 hours apart. These have the effect of causing the womb to contract and shed its lining so that the embryo is lost through the vagina. This can be painful and some women feel sick or have vomiting and diarrhoea with these drugs.

Unfortunately its not as simple as taking a pill then having a heavy period, i read a magazine article about this form of abortion, the women discovered once the foetus had expelled from her uterus, that she was actually 16 weeks pregnant. women who take this pill have to miscarry the baby into a metal tray, once it's out the baby is examined by the doctor, to check that everything is out.

There is no easy way out of pregnancy, i had a surgical abortion (put to sleep, then the baby is sucked and scraped out)  when i was 15 at 13 weeks pregnant, it was horrific and truly awful, its not something i would recommend.

The easiest thing to do is to abstain from sex all together until you are mature enough to cope with the consequences. If you don't have the willpower then use protection, because abortion is not contraception.



good luck and I'm hoping your not pregnant, being a parent is hard work and you have the rest of your life to look forward to.



WHY THE HELL DID I GET THUMBS DOWN, ALL I WAS DOING WAS OFFERING MY KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERIENCE TO TRY AND HELP THE GIRL!!



</answer>



<answer from>



sam h
Member since: 29 December 2006
Total points: 1159 (Level 3)

I won't lie to you, it was painful, but without justifying myself on here, it was nessesary, and not a regret that I beat myself up over.
Good luck to you. Stay strong x



</answer>

<answer>



I was 14 1/2 weeks pregnant when I woke up with HEAVY bleeding. It turned out to be a huge blood clot in my uterus. My baby was fine. So you are not necessarily having a miscarriage.

<answer from>



Caligirl...
Member since: 25 July 2008
Total points: 252 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am 6 weeks along with my second and had bleeding as well. My doctor also told me to stay off my feet for 2-4 day and wrote me off work. They did a pelvic exam and said my cervix was closed which was a good sign of not having a miscarriage. He also told me that it is perfectly normal for you to bleed sometimes. It can be caused by sex, stress, and a number of other things. Some women have a period the first few months of pregnancy.



As far as the dizziness and fainting goes, I had that with my first and again with this one. It's just one of the joys of pregnancy. With my first I could barely make it through work, school, or even grocery shopping without having to grab something cold to drink and sit down on the floor (yes even in the grocery store....my baby was more important that the weird looks other people gave me lol). Try carrying a candy bar and cold ice water with you everytime you go somewhere. I found this helped out a lot.



Good luck!



Source(s):



im a nurse and a mommy with number 2 on the way!



</answer>



<answer from>



Hoping For A Little One♥
Member since: 01 May 2006
Total points: 4359 (Level 4)

its good that its brownish and not bright red. bright red can be serious. many women have some sort of spotting in their pregnancy. im sure the scan will be fine :)

Everyday's the same again...
Member since: 08 May 2007
Total points: 3430 (Level 4)

<answer>



I got back from A+E about an hour and a half ago. We'd been there since 6.30. I have been bleeding since Thursday afternoon, a dark brownish colour. There's not a lot - but more than spotting. I also had a missed m/c in April - so I'm kind of "searching" for symptoms this time.

The dr has booked me in for a scan on Tuesday (2nd early scan already) and will check then - but he also reassured me by saying that 30% of women who have full term babies had bleeding in the first trimester. he also mentioned that his friend's wife had bleeding for THREE weeks - but was ok.

Bed rest for now is good, but no: it doesn't mean that you will m/c. 
Good luk with your scan. I hope when you choose a best answer you give us an update so we know you're ok.



Source(s):



me - third pregnancy - 10+4 today.

if you are pregnant with twins the cramping you are feeling could be your uterus stretching form the babies. It gets uncomfortable at times.



Also at one point if you do not excersize regularly the elasticity of your abs deminishes so they can't hold shape as long as they use to. this can account for the early showing.

littlelo...

</answer from>



<answer>



Getting bigger sooner could be twins or you might be further along, or you could have a bigger baby this time around or it could just be because you already have kids.  I would definitely discuss the cramps with your doctor, because cramping can be an indication of miscarrying but not necessarily mean you are.  You could be constipated.  You know it is funny, doctors can examine you or do an ultrasound and tell you that you are constipated, even if you don't feel it.



Source(s):



I showed real soon with my second one, and we hoped for twins, but they said it could be twins, or I could be further along, or I could be having a big baby.  FYI:  I didn't have twins, I wasn't further along, and whereas they said he would be about 8 pounds, as soon as he was born I laughed because just by looking he was smaller than my other one who was 7 lbs. 7 oz. he was only 6 lbs. 10 oz.



</answer>



<answer from>



SydneyMu...
Member since: 13 February 2007
Total points: 13610 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Sorry I can't really give you much advice I'm afraid.

You might be pregnant with twins - but then again you might not be.  The only way to tell for sure is to see two babies on an ultrasound, or deliver two babies at the end.  Other "signs" like your size or, hCG levels are not definitive.

As for the miscarriage issue, again, nobody can really say.

Just try and relax - what will be, will be.



Source(s):



RN Midwife, IVF Consultant and mother of 7



</answer>

<question>



C-section question......?



How many people will be present in operating room for c-section of premature baby (32 weeks)?



</question>



<additional details>



Its my sisters baby that is being delivered tomorrow - she has pre-eclampsia.  She quite worried about everything and I've been finding out loads of info on condition and c-sections, but just wondered how many 'staff' would be in there too....



</additional details>



<answer from>



love me longtime
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 414 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



u and one other person



Source(s):



had 1 c section



</answer>



<answer from>



Mandee TTC#1
Member since: 27 December 2006
Total points: 1068 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I DONT KNOW ABOUT DOCTORS CAUSE IT DEPENDS ON WHATS WRONG WITH THE BABY BUT FOR YOU ONLY 1 PERSON CAN GO IN.



</answer>



<answer from>



LittleLu...
Member since: 18 April 2008
Total points: 813 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Quite a few. There will be your support person if you have one, your OB/GYN/Surgeon (usually 2 of them are there) a respiratory therapist, an NICU nurse, sometimes your delivery nurse, and sometimes a pediatrician depending on the baby's needs then there is the OR staff which usually has an anesthetist, a scrub nurse/circulating nurse.



Source(s):



Been there as L&D nurse



</answer>



<answer from>



Rhonda
Member since: 24 October 2006
Total points: 2413 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<answer from>



luckigin...
Member since: 08 January 2007
Total points: 4312 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



My twins were born at 34 weeks.... I'm sure we had more in there because there were 2 babies but lets see.... 2 ob/gyns, 4 pediatric nurses, 2 nurses.....  So for one baby I would think that you'd have the 2 ob/gyns, 2 pediatric nurses, 2 regular nurses, and the anesteisiologist (sp?)

You're only allowed one support person for yourself.

With a premature baby, depending on how bad the health is, you may not even get to hold the baby.  They just give you a quick peek over the curtain and whisk the baby to NICU.



My husband got to hold one of the twins but not the other :(  I didnt even get to hold S till he was 2 days old and W till he was a week old :((



</answer>

picky

</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on the circumstances or on the possible unforeseen complications. Anesthesiologist, surgeon, pediatrician, nurse/s, possible your husband.
I had an emergency c-section, as far as I can remember I counted at least 5 people not including my husband. 3 people covered me with warm blankets, one was doing spinal anesthesia, another one was at my head asking questions about what I feel or what I don't feel.



</answer>



<answer from>



ironbark...
Member since: 04 April 2008
Total points: 2300 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



There will be a medical, anaesthetic and nursing team for your sister, and a paediatric nurse and paediatrician for the baby at the very least.

At 32 weeks gestation the birth will likely be treated as an emergency, just in case, so she may not be able to have a birthing partner present.  If she is having a general anaesthetic and not a spinal anaesthetic, then she definately wont be able to have a birthing partner with her.

I had an emergency C-section 26 years ago at 27 weeks gestation when my pre-eclampsia turned into eclampsia and my blood pressure shot up to 250/190 and I started to seizure.  My son is now married, fit and healthy, and in the Air Force.  Try to stay positive, and best luck to you, your sister and her baby.



</answer>



<answer from>



seksi-st...
Member since: 09 June 2008
Total points: 179 (Level 1)

<answer from>



ashendar...
Member since: 08 June 2008
Total points: 1823 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



She should "push" the midwives.  They won't know she's upset unless she tells them!  Simply call and ask when they are rescheduling the sweep for.
(Honestly, If she found her midwife unhelpful, she should have changed doctors earlier in the pregnancy.)

Midwives know (and most modern doctors know) that 40 wks is an estimate, and it's healthiest to wait for the mother to go into labor.



Last of all, I know it's tough, but induction is really not a good way to go.  If she can just hold out until her body/the baby is ready she'll be a lot better off.  The best you can do is sympathize with her and tell her she's tough and can do it.



Source(s):



2 pregnancies, one induced, one not



</answer>



<answer from>



Sunshine M
Member since: 24 May 2008
Total points: 698 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The midwife may be wanting to avoid the potential side effects of induction, especially if your sister wants to have a home birth. Stripping the membranes may or may not start labour. If it does, great. Contractions are usually more intense after the water breaks, as the head makes direct contact with the cervix. If it doesn't start  contractions, then she will have to be induced with pitocin within 24- 48 hours.



Induction, and early water breaking, are not the most pleasant. Both situations make labour more painful earlier in the process, increasing the chances of debilitating exhaustion, fetal distress, needing medication, delivery intervention, and c-section.



Pregnancy can safely be continued into 2 weeks post-due date. Remember, the due date is a guideline. Some women go longer, some go short, and very few deliver on the date.



</answer>



<answer from>



onelove1...
Member since: 04 March 2006
Total points: 270 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<question>



How does a pregnant woman's body decide what hormones to bathe a child in to make the child male or female?



</question>



<additional details>



I understand gender is caused by whether or not the child is bathed in certain chemicals, but what determines whether or not the woman's body will release these or not?



</additional details>



<answer from>



considering having a baby
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 358 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



it is not the woman who decides it the man a woman only has X chromosomes (genes) whereas a man has X and Y so if the sperm contains an X chromosome it will be a girl and if a Y a boy.
Men- XY
Women- XX
Hope i helped!



</answer>



<answer from>



MUFFY
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 435 (Level 2)

<answer from>

Member since: 25 April 2007
Total points: 2005 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



the sex of the baby is decided by the sex of the sperm that meets the egg, the womens bnoddy has no say in the matter.



do you know about chromosomes?



a girl has xx chromosomes and a boy has xy
as both the egg and the sperm only contain half of what is needed the chromosomes are divided and as there is only x's in a egg only an x can be passed on
as a man is xy half the sperm contain an x and half a y, if a sperm with a y meets the egg then it will be a boy, if a sperm with an x meets the egg then it will be a girl



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 15 June 2006

<answer>



it's the males sperm that decides baby's gender.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mama to be
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 4293 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



That's not quite how it works.  The womans body carries the X chromosom, and the male sperm has both some X sperm and some Y sperm.



When an X sperm comes together with the X egg you get a girl :  XX chromosome.



When a Y sperm comes together with the X egg you get a boy: XY chromosome.



The womans body does nothing to chose the sex of the baby, it is all dependant of which sperm fertalizes her egg.



Source(s):



Biology.



</answer>



<answer from>



celtic.p...
Member since: 09 February 2008
Total points: 2464 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The fetus has either XX or XY.



Until about week 6, we are gender neutral. The fetus puts out different chemicals depending on whether it has XX or XY, and those send back more hormones.



Read more on chromosonal abnormalities if you want to understand how it works.



Source(s):



http://www.gender.org.uk/about/04embryo/...
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turner_synd...



</answer>

THE.WA...

little_b...
Member since: 20 May 2006

<answer>



ok, i have very mixed feelings about your question.
first of all, this is a site where people are free to ask questions, whether you find them idiotic or not.
secondly, there are ligitimate times when people are concerned.

my last cycle started july 20. i'm 2 weeks late. negative hpt's. yes, i'm smart enough to get a blood test, the results are not in and won't be until tomorrow. however, i have asked on here if anyone experienced negative hpt's and positive blood tests.

the people on this site have been wonderful. i have not talked to any friends or family about my possibility, because i don't feel it is necessary to cry wolf when it may just be a late period. however, the fact that it's a possibility is on my mind a good bit. 
it was nice that i was able to hear other people's experiences and opinions. whether they will be correct in th end or not.



what makes me sad is that there are people out there, such as yourself, who feel that it's necessary to be condescending when you are not aware of everyone's situation. i understand being aggravated at questions asking if one is pregnant but haven't had sex. i can even annoyance with questions where people claim they've had a period but want to know if they could still be pregnant. i've read many questions (hoping to gain insight for my own situation) and there is no background. someone will say they are late but won't say how late and give no background information. you are right in some aspects; there are some ridiculous questions.

try to take a few minutes and realize that there are still those out there, like myself, who are thinking, maybe i am, maybe i'm not. if there are people like me, there is absolutely no point in mentioning anything to friends or family if it is a false alarm.

if there is a small amount of advice that is gained in the "question asker's" eyes, then i think it's an accomplishment, no matter how stupid other users may see the question.



</answer>

<question>



What does a ripe cervix mean?



Is that good or bad?



</question>



<answer from>



fubby_gi...
Member since: 30 June 2008
Total points: 204 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's the softening of the cervix.

It needs to be like this to induce labour during pregnancy.



</answer>



<answer from>



gumbi204...
Member since: 12 September 2008
Total points: 137 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well I have been reading up on this as well because I am TTC my first.  Anyway, from what I can tell. . .when you are in fact pregnant your cervix should be high and "ripe" or soft.  People on the internet describe it as ripe like a plum.  But if you are not pregnant it will be lower and more firm. . .like the tip of your nose.  But this is not an accurate sign of pregnancy because everyones cervix changes at different times.



Hope this helps!!



</answer>

Member since: 14 June 2006

<answer from>



becca
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 1804 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Actually go by the start of last period and count 12 to 14 days in! This is an estimate and not a for sure date. Since your cycle is so long it is likely that you don't ovulate when most women do! if your wanting to know how far along  you are and your due date its better to go by the start of your last period. In fact I don't know of any doctors that go with a conception date because for one thing conception can happen anytime from 24 to 48 hours after sex! Check out these sites!

http://parenting.ivillage.com/pregnancy/...

http://www.medcalc.com/pregnancy.html

http://www.babycenter.com/pregnancy-due-...

http://pregnancy.about.com/cs/pregnancyc...

http://www.americanpregnancy.org/duringp...



</answer>

<question>



Hi Iam 34 weeks pregnant..I was wondering if caeserian is easier or normal delivery?



how long do they keep you in hospital after caeserian in london?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Normal delivery is easier because the healing time is less. The hospital stay for Cesarean is usually 5 days it may differ if their are complications or not.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi there
I hate to tell you but there is no ideal "easy" way to give birth (after 5 in the past 8 years, I'm an expert LOL!)  As my nan used to say, "it's 6 of one and a half dozen of the other"  cos, if you have the natural birth, you're doing all the hard work during labour but have a far quicker recovery rate; by going the C section route, you have a relatively work-free labour but a hell of a job to recover afterwards.  Your baby will be prepared to be born with the vaginal way too because the labour lets them be born in their own time rather than be "taken" all of a sudden.  Good luck with whatever you choose - you'll have your gorgeous bundle of joy no matter which way you decide!! xxx



Source(s):



Vast experience of labour!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



My mother did both and didn't remember the c-section being harder, but she also had her tubes tied right after the vaginal delivery, so that might have contributed to it. Over all I hear that c-section has a lot more recovery time which you don't want when you are having to get up at all hours and take care of your new baby.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Normal delivery is better for the baby and easier to recover from.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Normal delivery is way easier to recover from.  That is the reason that (at least in the USA) you are in the hospital for 4 days after a c-section and only two after a vaginal delivery, and why you get 6 weeks off from work for a vaginal and 8 for a c-section.  A Cesarean is major surgery.  A vaginal deliver is a perfectly normal process.  If a c-section becomes medically necessary because of an emergency situation, then definitely do it for the well-being of you and your baby, but if it is not necessary, then try to avoid it.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Cesarean may seem the easy way out - but the recovery is a lot harder than recovery after a normal delivery. Also, if you plan on having more children - you should know that if you have a C-section now, there is a good chance you will need to get it again with your next child.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details

<answer>



Yes everyone is different, I had a normal delivery with my son but it was a really horrible experience.
He was not breathing when he was born and had to be recusitated and I was cut and also split from giving birth.
I was induced and it took me over an hour to push him out, he was 10lb born over 2 foot long and his head was 15inches around.
I was not the same for about 6 months as I had so many stiches (half hours worth)/
I had a c section with my daughter at 37 weeks, and although the scar is quite long it only takes 4 days before you can take the pressure bandage off. It hurt far, far less than my sons birth and I resumed sex within 6 weeks quite happily and with no pain.
Lots of girls are doubled over with a c section and complain that they cant walk, I walked the next day and had very little pain.
If I had a choice I would have a c section again as my daughter never suffered in anyway and my son was virtually stillborn ( he was recusitated and is healthy now).



</answer>

<answer>



I had a hard labor, but I am SOOOO happy to be getting another c section! 3 days and everyone I know that had a normal c section were sitting indian style comfortable as can be on the floor. There is barely any bleeding, and while I got an infection due to the nurse not knowing how to accurately do her job, as soon as my infection was gone I was able to do anything I did before. I was working out with a personal trainer 4 weeks after my c section, Doing sit ups, running, hard workouts for 2 hours a day, I felt fine. After having a c section I wouldn't try to deliver vaginally. After seeing my sister and my aunt and my other aunt able to do anything and everything after 3 days I am ready for the c section this time! I would vote for c section! Oh and my baby girl is now 6 months old and perfectly happy and healthy she had no health problems, nor did my sisters son who is now 2 months. I don't see why people say it takes so long to recover, I had a massive infection and it only took me a week to recover and feel like I could do anything. I guess everyone is different, so I am giving you a different point of view, I think c sections are great. I was in the hospital for 3 days and I went home the 3rd day. It takes a very short amount of time, You can pick the day, you know when it will happen, and if your anything like anyone I know you'll feel fine in a few days. I literally know about 10 people that have had c sections in the last year and they were all the same, feeling fine after a few days. Good luck whatever you choose!

Edit. and they make pain medicine balls now that they put in after a c section, which make it so you don't feel the pain at all, I know 2 people that have had them, so you really only have to feel like 1 day of pain. and my incision scar is way below where a bikini would go and is teeny tiny, You would never see it no matter what I was wearing.

<answer from>

</answer from>



<answer>



Vaginal birth is easier.  No brainer there.



(Really, think about it for a minute.  You can go through 12-18 hour or so of labor [and most of the pain can be relieved by medication, if you need it.]. Nothing is expected of you; you can ***** and complain all you want, and you just have to focus on giving birth.  After baby is born, you are a bit sore and tired for a few days, but pretty much back to normal, as you take on the job of caring for your newborn.

OR ... you can have major surgery.  No pain during the surgery, and it's over with in an hour or so -- but then you have weeks of post-op pain and  a long healing process -- all made that much more difficult by the need to care for a newborn, breastfeed every couple of hours,  entertain guests and visitors, get up for night feedings.  Why would ANYONE think this was the easier choice?



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I had 3 normal deliveries with my kids - 2 were great - 1 was bad.  But all 3 resulted in beautiful healthy children who I would do it every day for.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



i would go for a normal delivery. Ceasserrean takes longer to heal and is more painful in the long run. I know someone who couldnt even climb up the stairs becos it was too painful. You stay in hospital for about 3 days and you will miss ur babies first few moments in life because you will be under sedation Youll also be left scarred for a long time it probably takes years for the scar to heal completely and fade away. A normal birth is probably painful for that time being but after you forget about the pain and you heal quickly and get back to normal. and theres also drugs the doctors can give you to make it more easier for you.



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



A vaginal delivery is going to be much easier for you. Sure it may hurt during the process but the healing time is so much quicker. I don't know about London but I'm in the US and had to stay 3 nights for my C-section and then it also took me a good 2 weeks to feel "better".

You're not able to hold your baby right away with a C-section. I didn't get to see my little guy until an hour or so afterwards. Plus, after you go home, you aren't able to fully care for them as you should. I felt totally helpless. Unless you absolutely NEED a C-section then try for a vaginal delivery first.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I had 3 cesarians in 3 years, not because I was too posh to push but because I had no choice.
It is not the easy option it is major surgery.  Both me and my baby were very ill after the first one, I made it my son wasn't so fortunate.
5 days in hospital may seem like a good idea but look at the bigger picture.



Your baby needs vital immune building organisms in his/her gut that only natural birth can stimulate.
For the sake of your baby if not yourself if the natural option is possible then take it.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I have had both and I believe a normal delivery is better for both you and the baby, the recovery time is shorter and you have the satisfaction of doing most of the work to bring your baby into this world.  The c-section was easier during the surgery, but was more difficult to recover from, allthough I had more energy after the c-section (didn't push and use that energy.)  Although if you choose a c-section, you can't change your mind afterward and do it naturally, it is very dangerous to do a VBAC (Vaginal Birth after Caeserian) to both you and the baby.  I would suggest trying it natural first and then if you have another one, you can do a c-section if you choose.  (I would rather have had both naturally, but both my life and the baby's life were in danger after 3 days of labor.)



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



The caesarean is easier at the time, but takes much longer to recover.  It also isn't as helpful for the baby.  I personally wouldn't do it by choice.  It's not fun picking up a baby who cries all night when you've been cut from hip to hip!
I spent five days in hospital after the birth of my daughter - it was exhausting.  I never slept at all - too many babies, too many exhausted mothers.
I've done both, and unless you've got major help at home, go for the natural birth.  Not only is it better for your baby, but you recover much quicker.



</answer>

<question>



Only for mothers......?



I am almost 18 weeks pregnant with my 3rd child and I  don't feel it move but maybe a couple times a week! Both my girls were very active and I carried them in the front. I actually had to have an ultra sound last week because the doctor couldn't find a heart beat. The baby is fine but apparently I am caring it low and towards to back. I have a lot of pressure on my cervix and lower back pain.  It is making me really nervous not feeling it move around or kick. I know its early but I felt my girls move by 14 weeks. Anyone else had this kind of pregnancy?



</question>



<answer from>



Gina
Member since: 19 August 2008
Total points: 325 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



18 weeks is still early to feel tons of movement and every pregnancy is different.  I understand how you feel though, try not to worry.  My ob always has a hard time finding a heartbeat because my son is always moving around but I didnt feel him moving at first.  Also, while you are walking and busy during the day, your baby gets rocked to sleep.  Try resting your hands on your belly when you lie down to sleep and you may feel more movement.  They usually wake up while we are trying to sleep!



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



My wife is 6 weeks pregnant and our 1st baby, what are those preparation to take?



</question>



<answer from>



1 due in Feb :)
Member since: 14 June 2008
Total points: 352 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Go buy prenatal pills, take those on a daily basis, call your insurance to see what doctors are on your insurance list, once that is done, call an obgyn and get in for a pre-natal visit. Once there they will ask you lots of questions and get you started on your pregnancy journey. You probably won't have an ultrasound for awhile but they will check your levels and take lots of blood.



</answer>

<answer from>

<answer>



First off, you are in an abusive relationship and need to get away immediately for your health and your baby's health. Here are a few things you can do:
1. call a domestic abuse hotline, they can walk you through getting out of this situation step-by-step by providing you with shelter and contacts to support you finding, medical and emotional help, and help with employment.
2. look up a legal aid in your area. they can give you free advice about custody of your child, but so will the domestic abuse hotline.

take care of yoursefl



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, he can. I was told to get a police record on him. It will hold up in court and give you favor. The next time things get heated to the point of physical violence Call the police and put a restraining order on him.

With a violent record it will be easier for you to get custody. Now you need to prove that you are capable of providing for your child. You need a new place to stay, and a job asap. There are womens shelter's to help you. The phone book and planned parenthood have the information on shelters.

When he slammed my head into the bathroom mirror and forced me to pay for a new one, i knew i had to get out. He WILL get custody, unless you are proactive. when answering this question pls act like adults and not be smart and besides i am not scared of being preg just want to know what you think thanks

<answer from>



Angelic
Member since: 12 July 2008
Total points: 616 (Level 2)

<answer>



No. It is highly unlikely that you are pregnant. First of all, when on your period, you're not ovulating. Second, you would have no symptoms right now. Your period would not be affected.



</answer>

<question>



29w high ketone level?



i dont get it and the dr didnt explain it. my glucose test was clear and i eat and drink alot. but i have a high ketone level. should i be worried? the dr sent my urine off for a culture to make sure is giving me the right meds that i have to pick up tomorrow. i dont know, im just kinda confused on the subject. i googled it and it just made me even more confused bc i dont have diabetes and im not starving.

<answer from>



Lacy's due NOV 20th!
Member since: 11 November 2006
Total points: 2770 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Ketones can be sugar in your urine that your kidneys didn't filter.  Or dehydration.  Also oculd be a sign or infection.  You don't have to be diabetic to pass sugar in your urine.



</answer>

<answer>



Yes it could be the start.  When I went into labour it was lower back pain and cramping almost as if I had to go the bathroom. A few days before I did go to the bathroom very frequently, I guess my body was preparing.

Not all your labour is going to be extremely painful and intense, it works its way up to that.  So, you've probably started ... mind you it could take hours or weeks before baby decides to make an appearance.

<answer from>



mias_mum...

</answer from>



<answer>



wow, you are experiencing exactly what I experienced a couple of days before my waters broke! I was aching really bad around my whole middle region, I could barely walk, and I was having cramps. I also did not have a show, I didn't have a nesting instinct, and I never got diarrhoea (all books/website will tell you these are the most common signs of impending labor).



This stage is called pre labor so you aren't really in active labor yet, so it's probably too soon to go into hospital. If you're worried call the hospital and describe what you're feeling and they will be able to help.

Good luck!



</answer>

<question from>



mommy200...
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 335 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Post eating disorder/eating habits?



Before I got pregnant, I had an eating disorder for about 18 months. After getting help for it my eating habits changed dramatically, I'm not sure if it was because of the eating disorder or maybe just because I had grown out of the soda and junk food phase.



At any rate, to give you an idea of where I started to where I ended up here are what my Body Masses were:

Before eating disorder - 21.9 (normal is 18.5-24.9)
During eating disorder - 17.7
After eating disorder - 18.8

So as you can see after the ED, my eating habits changed to the point that I didn't gain that much weight afterwards.

I probably ate about 1400 calories per day after the ED. Not on purpose, but just because when I ate, I ate salad with no dressing and cut up grilled chicken, carrot sticks for a snack, all I drank was water, had cheese occasionally, only ate whole grain bread once in a while, etc. So when I did eat, there was really nothing to it, and obviously I was eating too little. But the doctor was happy that I was eating, had gained 7lbs, and was taking vitamins. Overall, I was healthy to her again.



Even though I have had cravings for foods with more substance while pregnant, I'm afraid that afterwards I'll go right back to those eating habits, like I just won't crave Taco Bell and Chocolate milk anymore!



So my question is, how badly (if that happens) is it going to affect breastfeeding my son? I know you're supposed to add on an additional 300 calories (?) for breastfeeding, but I'm afraid I'm just not going to be eating enough for the baby, and I'd really love to breastfeed.

Ok I know that was probably the most off the wall story/question, but I was just wondering if I could get advice OUTSIDE of my doctor, because sometimes even doctors don't have the right answer...

Thank you in advance!



</question>



<answer from>



stephanie n
Member since: 05 September 2006
Total points: 2993 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



you do need a little more  when breastfeeding ,but if you eat healthy ,make sure you get enough of everything your body will take care of the rest ,you can get milk type supplements that might help things like malted milk power added to your cereal or something to make sure you get enough calciam.



</answer>



<answer from>



SydneyMu...
Member since: 13 February 2007
Total points: 13610 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



You haven't given us any idea of your age, actual weight or height - a BMI measurement only gives very limited info.

But lets assume you are avergae - only eating 1400 calories a day is  under the average woman's basal calorie requirement - that is, the very least amount of calories needed to maintain your normal bodyweight.

An average woman of 130lbs (about 60kg) with an average lifestyle needs at least 1800 a day.



If you consistantly eat below this you will lose weight, unless you are already very underweight.

A pregnant woman should ideally aim for about 2300.

A breastfeeding mother does need additional calories, but the advice of eating a specific number of extra calories every day assumes that she is already eating at least the normal amount of calories, not below the requirement.

Please note that your body will actually use about 750 calories just breastfeeding.



So a breastfeeding mother should be reaslistic looking at consuming about 2500 calories a day.

Note that eating WAY below these calorie levels WILL NOT help you lose weight.



For a start you should not actively try and lose weight whilst pregnant.

Secondly if you eat way below the required calorie levels when you are breastfeeding all it will do is lower your milk supply.

A human body is designed to offer itself protection from starvation.  When you don't eat enough at times when the body is placed under demand (like breastfeeding) your body will assume it is starving and your metabolism will slow way down and this will PREVENT you from losing weight, because your body will try and hang on to it's fat reserves and will burn off all the new nutrients it is taking in for energy instead of burning fat reserves.

You are right on the borderline of being underweight as it is now.

I know you've said you aren't craving junk food and chocolate, however only eating undressed salad and vegetables, a little chicken, and cheese and bread only every now and then and drinking only water is very extreme.  What do you eat for breakfast?



You MUST try and eat properly.  EVERY DAY you need a mix of fruit and vegetables, protein, calcium, and carbohydrates.  You won't fiind these in junk food but you will find them in yoghurt, milk, cheese, eggs, fish, chicken, lean red meat, pasta, bananas, apples, grapes, oranges, tomatoes, carrots, peas, spinach, mushrooms, wholegrain bread and cereals.



Bottom line - if you don't eat enough it will have a very negative effect on breastfeeding your son.



Source(s):



RN Midwife, IVF Consultant and mother of 7



</answer>

Total points: 1588 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Maybe. It depends.
If it is close to the time of your period then if could just be the start of an early period, which could be normal since your not on the pill.

If not near the time of your period then maybe. Some women have implantation bleeding when they get pregnant, but not all. I have actually heard that it is rare.



Don't worry to much though just wait a couple weeks and take a home pregnancy test. Or go to a doctor and get a blood test, that is the best way to detect early pregnancies.



Hope this helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



PennyLan...
Member since: 11 May 2007
Total points: 248 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



i really don't think you are pregnant because if you got your period (even if it was lighter than usual) then that means your body is shedding the egg and lining of your uterus that was NOT fertilized.



Although if you want to be 100% sure, take a pregnancy test

If you are this worried about getting pregnant maybe you should consider going on the pill in addition to condoms. Sex is a big responsibility, and there is always some chance you could get pregnant but you can lower that chance the more precautions you take.



</answer>

Second birth I had to be induced because my son kept turning breech and before he moved around again I was induced so I could have a vaginal birth and that was only 6 hours of labor and 3 big pushes and he was out. With my son I had an extremely fast first stage - I didn't realise I was actually in labour until I had had a show and was pushing, but then ended up pushing for 7 hours before he was born by ventouse with a very large episiotomy - ouch!  (My pelvic floor muscles were too tight from going to the gym till I was 30 weeks pregnant!) I ended up back in hospital at 5 days with cellulitis of the episiotomy wound and then at 9 weeks had to have a d&c for retained products.  With my daughter I was a bit worried about an unplanned homebirth because of the really fast first stage last time but she ended up turning breech at 35 weeks and couldn't be turned back as her bottom was engaged - so I ended up with a caesarian at 39 weeks.  But yet again even though I had had a caesarian I ended up having retained products at about 8 weeks again!  I would say as you had had an extremely fast birth last time I would be prepared for another this time!!

<answer>

<answer>



Most women do not feel movements until they are 17 - 20 weeks.  If you're feeling them this early that's wonderful, but you probably can't expect to feel them everyday.  Midwives don't recommend tracking movements until at least week 24 because it can be so inconsistent.  Enjoy your flutters when you get them.  I started getting mine 2 weeks ago at 19 weeks!  So fun!!!



</answer>

<answer>



it is doubtful that what you are feeling is your baby.  that baby is still just the size of a pea.  however, if it is the baby and what you are worried about is that you didn't feel it today. don't be.  normal fetal movement shouldn't be calculated or relied on until 18-25 weeks.  your baby is so so tiny in their and they have to be right up near the skin to be felt.  so i would wait awhile before having any concern.  a baby does start moving around 9 weeks...but like i said...they are too tiny and not yet strong enough to be felt.

<question>



Would there be any pain having a miscarrage ?



OK this is Not about me i have suffered a loss but a missed miscarriage this is about a family member with a know talent for being a liar!



If someone hasn't had a period for 8 weeks which isn't unusual for them and then bleed very heavy again is normal for them, but they have no pain BUT they are saying they think they have had a miscarriage would that person be in pain and how much if at all ??



and she says a Dr came out and said pop to me in the morning maybe scan you surely if your having a miscarriage they would wisk you in there and then ?



</question>



<answer from>



Ruth - 12wks!
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 648 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes generally you would be sent to the er. if she had a missed miscarriage, there wouldnt be any bleeding or very delayed weeks after the baby stopped growing. she would need a d&c to remove the embyo otherwise she could end up with infection. if a woman is miscarrying and bleeding, yes there is always pain. it is severe (way worse than a period!) there are clots (tissue) in the blood and the contractions come like labour (ie regular intervals)
hope that helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



chilenit...
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 349 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i had a miscarriage at 7 weeks, and no, i experienced no pain, though everyone is different. the doctor did send me in for an ultrasound straight away as i was bleeding. she is either lying or that doctor doesnt know what they are doing! she wouldnt have been sent to the E.R at that early stage of pregnancy though like i said they would have sent her for an ultrasound straight away!



</answer>



<answer from>



Dabuchic...
Member since: 06 September 2008
Total points: 253 (Level 2)

<answer>



From personal experience, yes, there is a lot of pain with miscarriage at 8 weeks. When I suspected something was wrong, I went to see an OB (was in another state when this happened so not my regular doctor) and he did a vaginal ultrasound that day to verify that it was a pregnancy and that I was indeed losing it. He also did a blood test to confirm that I had been pregnant.



I can't say whether or not your family member would experience pain. It felt like the worst menstrual cramps of my life.



</answer>

buschchi...

<answer>



well it all really depends...early on in the pregnancy my doctor told me to go home after the ultrasound and if it got heavy (filling a pad every 5-10 min) then come back, because there is nothing that they can really do but monitor it and I don't like the thought of a D&C unless absolutely nescessary...it really depends on how far along they are as to how much pain there would be....When I had a very early miscarriage there was no pain, but a friend of mine had a miscarriage at 6 weeks and was in ALOT of pain and felt like she did when she gave birth to her two previous children

<category>

<question from>



Aren W
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 357 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Caffeine free sugar free sodas?



Alright. I'm 36 weeks prego and I cut out caffeine a long time ago and started drinking more milk and water, but I still drink caffeine free soda. When I went to my doctors appointment on Monday, my doctor still got pissed and said I had to only have soda once a week. But I hate milk and I didn't drink a lot of water before pregnancy so its hard for me to cut out soda completely. So anyways, I went to the store and ran into a bottle of caffeine free sugar free sprite zero...Do you think that's ok as long as I'm still getting some milk and water in there? I'm assuming the sugar is why he's so anal about me not drinking soda, but if you think otherwise let me know.



</question>



<additional details>



He said the baby is measuring 2 weeks ahead. Like he is where he should be in 2 weeks. And I'm trying so hard with the milk. If its ice ice cold I can drink a 64 oz cup of it, but I have to guzzle it in about 2 seconds or I won't finish it and then it leaves that milk taste in my mouth and the only way to get rid of that is drink something else flavored. I can't win. lol



</additional details>



<answer from>



debbie
Member since: 08 June 2007
Total points: 1706 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I have to say I NEVER drink diet (sugar-free) sodas (like Sprite Zero) because most artificial sweeteners are far worse for you than sugar (the debate is still out on Splenda - seems safe so far but aspartame and most others have been proven unsafe.) I don't know why your doc would freak out about drinking regular soda unless your glucose test results are giving you a reason to cut back - and in that case you would know, right?



And actually caffeine is considered safe during pregnancy, just don't overdose - no more than 200mg a day when I think a can of coke has like 55mg? My midwife actually recommended having a little something with caffeine if tylenol doesn't work for headaches - and it has helped me even though I was never a big caffeine drinker so it wasn't a withdrawal thing.



If you are seriously drinking a ton of soda every day then yeah it IS a good idea to cut back, especially in the long run when you're not even having to worry about a baby inside you, but just to generally be healthier... I don't usually have more than 1 can a day, usually less than that - but I'm a big water drinker. Just get used to drinking more water and it's as easy as a craving-filled adjustment period.



If you are having problems with the sugar tolerance thing which your doc's should have told you after your glucose tolerance test, some fancy soda brands like Hansen's and I think Blue Sky (both are in the natural/organic section of my supermarket) have regular cane sugar in them instead of high fructose corn syrup. While I don't think it's a whole lot better for you cuz they are still both processed sugar, high fructose corn syrup is one of the worst sugars out there for you in how your body processes it. And ask your doc why he's so anal about soda - if it's just sugar then he should have told you to cut back on juice and other flavored beverages as well.



By the way I don't drink milk! I get it in my cereal and I have other dairy like cheese and stuff but I don't like to drink milk unless it's in a nice chocolate milkshake or something - don't force yourself!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Baja181
Member since: 05 June 2008
Total points: 435 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you go into the alcohol area of a supermarket, look for the carbonated water. I used to drink alot of soda but figured out what it was that I actually liked was just the carbonation. You can add a little lime/lemon/crystal lite to any can of carbonated water and it tastes great, has bubbles, and is fat/calorie/sugar/caffeine free! Even try some crushed up mint in it with a squeeze of lime. Very good and HEALTHY!!!! The Albertsons brand carbonated 6 packs are about $1.50.



</answer>

Holly Wolly Got a (+)!

<answer>



To the person that said all root beer has no caffeine- wrong. Barq's root beer (regular, not diet) has caffeine. It's the caffeine they're talking about in the commercials when they say "Barq's has bite!". Also, Sunkist orange soda has caffeine, and diet Sunkist has MORE. I broke one of my pregnant friends heart when I told her her diet Sunkist was worse than Mt Dew.



Diet Barq's has 0 caffeine, but then you're ingesting artificial sweetners which aren't a great idea either.



In reference to the above answer- just make sure to not get tonic water containing quinine, it is NOT recommended for pregnant women by some doctors. Ask yours before you drink any.



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



You know what I agree to her statement, Women who have gone through abortion are facing a lot...anyway here's an article that I hope could answer your questions



After Abortion



After an abortion, you may experience a wide range of emotions. For many, having an abortion causes feelings of intense loss and grief. These feelings may occur immediately after your abortion or may occur several years after your abortion. If left untreated, these negative feelings can progress into what is called Post-Abortion Syndrome. It is a good idea to seek counseling if you experience any of the following signs of Post-Abortion Syndrome:



* Refuse to talk with others about your abortion



* Unexplained anxiety or irritability



* Outbursts of anger or rage



* Anger or bitterness with people who where involved with your abortion



* Disturbed sleep



* Nightmares, flashbacks or hallucinations that remind you of babies



* Irrational fear of loved ones being hurt, injured or killed



* Withdrawal from relationships or family members



* Difficulty with relationships, particularly with the opposite sex



* Avoidance of children



* Disinterest in activities that you once enjoyed



* Lack of desire to care for yourself



* Sexual dysfunction



* Suicidal thoughts or tendencies



* Increase in drug or alcohol use



* Eating disorders



* Depression, anxiety or physical discomfort around the anniversary of your abortion or the due date of your aborted pregnancy



* Personality shift, you are not the same person you were before the abortion



STEPS TO HEALING



If you are experiencing grief after your abortion, even if it happened years ago, emotional healing is possible. Even though you may regret past actions, you can begin to make healthy choices now that will help you heal and cope. Emotional healing is a process that takes time and usually requires assistance from a counselor or support group, but you can get started on your healing by taking one or more of these steps:



* Find a support group or counselor



* Admit the truth about your abortion



* Admit any feelings of remorse or guilt



* Allow yourself to grieve the loss of your child



* Talk about your experience with others



* Honestly explore your feelings about your abortion



* Honestly explore your feelings about the people involved with your abortion



* Accept God’s forgiveness



* Forgive others who were involved with your abortion



* Forgive yourself



* Reconcile relationships that have been affected by the abortion



* Let go of your lost child



* Find creative outlets that allow you to express your feelings such as writing, music, drawing, etc.



* Spend time with others on the anniversary of your abortion, don’t stay alone



* Pray



Source(s):



http://www.lifechoices4states.org/aftera...



</answer>



<answer from>



llh703
Member since: 30 December 2006
Total points: 171 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm 57 and have 2 grown daughters. When I was 18, it was the 70's and abortions just became "legal". I was scared and alone..and that at the time seemed like an easy way out. Lots of girls was doing it. New York was the only State to do it at the time. I flew up there myself, with money I borrowed.



Since it was a new proceedure..when they did it I was surrounded by a crowd of doctors. Ya I was pregnant, but I was shy and this was horrible. Half way thru the proceedure, I awoke , was drossy, but could see what was going on ..and I'll spare you the gorey details.



Afterwards I was put in a room with other girls and was told I needed to leave. I walked to the front desk, cramping, and called a cab and went back to the hotel and sleep for days.



Its been 37 yrs. and I STILL cry on the anniversery of that day. I STILL think about it..alot. Me...I killed a baby..thats what I did..some people make it sound simple and uneffecting..but Im here to tell you,,itll always be with you..and someday I'll have to face God with what I did to one of his children.



</answer>



<answer from>



diamond gal
Member since: 02 March 2008
Total points: 343 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Honestly til this day I am struggling majorly because I didnt think it was going to be that emotional for me so I kinda brushed it under the carpet and my whole life wound up becoming out of whack because of it. I do not regret my choice in any way shape or form but I do regret that I didnt prepare myself for how emotional I would have been. If I could go back in time I would have saw a therapist from the very day the procedure was done. Til this day (7 months later) I am still not the same. I am not religious.



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



What are some symptoms of pregnancy ? ?



I know it differs between people, but i was just wondering what are the main symptoms and when do they start to show ?



Also when do you start to show ?



thanks



</question>



<answer from>



Zander due in December....
Member since: 12 April 2008
Total points: 1719 (Level 3)



</answer from>

</answer>



<answer from>



loopylad...
Member since: 31 July 2006
Total points: 245 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



your stomach gets big



</answer>



<answer from>



Bella
Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 562 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Implantation Bleeding:
Implantation bleeding can be one of the earliest pregnancy symptoms. About 6-12 days after conception, the embryo implants itself into the uterine wall. Some women will experience spotting as well as some cramping.



Other Explanations: Actual menstruation, altered menstruation, changes in birth control pill, infection, or abrasion from intercourse.



Join our pregnancy forums to discuss your symptoms & more



Delay/Difference in Menstruation:
A delayed or missed menstruation is the most common pregnancy symptom leading a woman to test for pregnancy. When you become pregnant, your next period should be missed. Many women can bleed while they are pregnant, but typically the bleeding will be shorter or lighter than a normal period.



Other Explanations: Excessive weight gain/loss, fatigue, hormonal problems, tension, stress, ceasing to take the birth control pill, or breast-feeding.



Swollen/Tender Breasts:
Swollen or tender breasts is a pregnancy symptom which may begin as early as 1-2 weeks after conception. Women may notice changes in their breasts; they may be tender to the touch, sore, or swollen.



Other Explanations: Hormonal imbalance, birth control pills, impending menstruation (PMS) can also cause your breasts to be swollen or tender.



Fatigue/Tiredness:
Feeling fatigued or more tired is a pregnancy symptom which can also start as early as the first week after conception.



Other Explanations: Stress, exhaustion, depression, common cold or flu, or other illnesses can also leave you feeling tired or fatigued.



Nausea/Morning Sickness:
This well-known pregnancy symptom will often show up between 2-8 weeks after conception. Some women are fortunate to not deal with morning sickness at all, while others will feel nauseous throughout most of their pregnancy.



Other Explanations: Food poisoning, stress, or other stomach disorders can also cause you to feel queasy.



Backaches:
Lower backaches may be a symptom that occurs early in pregnancy; however, it is common to experience a dull backache throughout an entire pregnancy.



Other Explanations: Impending menstruation, stress, other back problems, and physical or mental strains.



Headaches:
The sudden rise of hormones in your body can cause you to have headaches early in pregnancy.



Other Explanations: Dehydration, caffeine withdrawal, impending menstruation, eye strain, or other ailments can be the source of frequent or chronic headaches.



Frequent Urination:
Around 6-8 weeks after conception, you may find yourself making a few extra trips to the bathroom.



Other Explanations: Urinary tract infection, diabetes, increasing liquid intake, or taking excessive diuretics.



Darkening of Areolas:
If you are pregnant, the skin around your nipples may get darker.



Other Explanations: Hormonal imbalance unrelated to pregnancy or may be a leftover effect from a previous pregnancy.



Food Cravings:
While you may not have a strong desire to eat pickles and ice cream, many women will feel cravings for certain foods when they are pregnant. This can last throughout your entire pregnancy



It's different for every woman and every pregnancy. Also consider the size of the baby and the way your body is carrying it. Some women start showing at 4-6 months



Source(s):



http://www.americanpregnancy.org/getting...



</answer>

<answer from>



LMinSA
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 1325 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You won't see very much.  Basically the doc will check that the gestational sac is in the right place (i.e. in your uterus and not in one of your tubes) and you might see a tiny blob inside the gestational sac.  that is called the fetal pole.



It is probably too early to see a heartbeat, but you might get lucky - depending on the doctor's equipment.



Best of luck with your pregnancy.



Source(s):



17 weeks pregnant



</answer>

<answer>



Yes there is a chance.  Breast feeding is supposed to reduce fertility but the bounce back effect from the hormones of pregnancy being suddenly absent can make you super fertile.  Use contraception.

Personal experience,  14 months between my two sons

<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



azmom85
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You could request a blood test or an ultra sound.



However, you could also be experiencing a false pregnancy. Women who desperately want a baby can trick their bodies into thinking they are pregnant. This is known as Pseudocyesis. It goes as far as breast tenderness, morning sickness, periods stop, craving foods, the abdomen can grow larger, and your breasts can grow larger.  Often, the only way to reverse this is to prove to the women that she is not pregnant through an ultra sound. Counseling is also recommended in treatment of this.



Source(s):



http://www.womens-health.co.uk/false_pre...



</answer>



<answer from>



Merricks Mommy
Member since: 23 August 2008
Total points: 207 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It all depends on when you took the test&gt; is your period late? and if so, how late?  I went to the hospital when i was pregnant with my son and i was already 6 weeks.. they did a regular urine test..but no blood test and it said that i was NOT pregnant.  I didn't find out until I took a blood test. The same with the one I'm pregnant with now.. I would get a blood test taken if I were you.  Good Luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Maars
Member since: 16 June 2008
Total points: 10927 (Level 6)

momsey

<answer>



If you had a negative blood test, then most likely you are not pregnant.  If you're nauseous and fatigued, you could just be sick.

<answer from>



Stephanie M
Member since: 22 March 2007
Total points: 3781 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Throwing up and sleeping a lot can be a sign of MANY things.  It doesn't mean you are pregnant.  If you've taken a test and it's negative, you aren't pregnant.  It is very common for women to mistake symptoms of other things for pregnancy symptoms, especially if you want to be pregnant.  The mind is a powerful thing and plays tricks easily.



</answer>

<question>



How many people got pregnant while ON Birth Control?



What kind of Birth Control were you using?



</question>



<additional details>



I mean NOT statistics of the world, lol.



I mean personal experience, from people who are pregnant RIGHT NOW (or have a child that was conceived while using some form of Birth Control.)



I mean PERSONAL EXPERIENCE .. not 'my friend did' etc.



YOU. YOURSELF. =]



I got pregnant on the pill (with my 14 month old son) and my friend got pregnant on the Depo shot (her son is 6 days older than mine.)



It just seems SO common. I'm soo worried it's going to happen again.
I'm BACK on the Pill ..



</additional details>



<answer from>



wildblon...
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 3073 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I did!!!
I had an IUD!!!
I was lucky, because it didn't cause harm to my son!!!  He was born just fine and is in Texas right now helping with the Hurricane 'cleanup'!!!



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

<answer from>



CuriousG...
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 362 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, I got pregnant on the Depo-Vera Shot.  It is the same medication that the birth control pill has.  So, I must tell you, I had my shot early November and conceived the end of December.  I'm not one of those that had the Depo shot and then it expired and I didn't get it right away and said well, it was supposed to really be good for up to 4-5 months.  No, that is BS and I don't think people should be saying they got pregnant while on the Depo if they didn't take it as directed by doctors.  I was a true case and the doctors said I am very rare.  The only birth control they could recommend for me that was long lasting was the IUD.  I had that taken out in June and conceived in August.  It does happen. I was happy with the IUD.  My doctors just said I am really fertile, but it does happen.



</answer>

<answer>



I really feel for you. Your body won't know any different, but your mind might, somewhere right at the back of things you have tried to bury.



You will always feel some regret and sadness for what has happened, but you have to remember that you had your reasons for doing what you did, and it cannot be changed now. All you can do is try to ensure you do not find yourself in that situation again until you are ready, to save yourself from any extra heart-ache.



There is no point in anybody judging you on here, because, you've already said you regret it and are sad, so probably nobody can make you feel any worse, or be a harsher judge of you, than you are yourself.



I think talking to somebody about the way you're feeling might help you come to terms with what happened. You will never get over it, but it will get easier with time.

<answer>



Condoms are not 100% effective. There is still a chance they might break or have some other sort of defect in them.



However, it does also depend on what you mean by 'safe.' If anything, you can be asking if it would be okay for you to be using a latex condom if you're allergic.Obviously not, but i'm just stating the obvious(:



Nonetheless both female and male condoms are generally safe. Just don't wear two at once, or use them together.



</answer>

<answer from>



johnnyje...
Member since: 08 May 2008
Total points: 332 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, hormones can trigger all sorts of things.



But it is common knowledge that you are "slightly" (depending on the person I guess?) more fertile when you've just quit the pill.



So, I'd just wait to see the testresults, and even when they are positive, go see a doctor afterwards.



</answer>

Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 125 (Level 1)
