<answer>



So long as you're not nauseous, drink orange juice or find some vitamin C tablets.  You want to strengthen yours and the babies immune systems as much as possible and vitamin C is the best way to do it.  Try to get the right nutrition and drink LOTS of fluids.  I know it's hard to have to pee even more when you're already pregnant, but the more liquids go in, the more germs they take out.  Best of luck, get all the rest you can, take good care of yourself, and enlist someone to make you a great big pot of chicken soup, none of that canned stuff.  Hope you feel better soon!



</answer>



<answer from>



jancoetz...
Member since: 05 September 2007
Total points: 2363 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Try drinking chamomile tea, eating lots of oranges and lemons, keep yourself hydrated,get lots of rest and keep the faith...



A pot of chicken soup is also supposed to work wonders, although I've never tried that during pregnancy...



</answer>

<answer>



I feel so bad for u honey.
I have been ill twice now with the flu and i am 25 weeks pregnant and both times i just wanted to die.
Its a pain in the bum that after all these years they still havnt come up with something for pregnant woman to take when it makes u feel worse that u cant do anything about it.



Just wait till the headaches start from blowing ur nose and coughing at the same time - thats when ur defo going to need them paracetamol tablets.



If i was u, i would go buy urself now a V Shaped pillow for sleeping with, i didnt have 1 the first time i was ill and i was ill for 3 weeks with it cause i couldnt sleep at night laying flat with blowing my nose all the time with it being blocked and coughing - but when i was ill 2 weeks ago with the flu i had my pillow and slept better cause i was sort of sat up in bed so made breathing alot easiser for me.



Thinkings to give a try to help u cope till the flu goes away:
1) V- Shaped pillow.
2) Keep warm at all times.
3) Try having a bath/shower first thing in the morning - the warm water will heat ur chest up to make ur day easier for blowing ur nose and getting everything up off ur lungs.
4) Drink hot water with a tea spoon full of suger in it.
5) Get urself some vapour rub for ur chest.
6) Get some olbas oil and put some on some tissue and carry it around with u.



If u have a sore throat aswell - get some Merocaine.
They are safe for pregnant woman to use - i couldnt of coped without them both times.



Hope u feel better soon honey.
Love Manda xXx

25 weeks pregnant with first baby and been ill with flu twice.

Second time i was 23 weeks pregnant and ill for 6 days cause i knew what to do second time around and got better faster.

<answer from>



EG
Member since: 04 June 2007
Total points: 432 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The only pill that I think you're thinking of, is the morning after pill.  This can only be taken up to 3 days after you've had sex.  The normal pill won't do anything if you suspect that you are pregnant.



Pregnancy tests can't tell you with total accuracy if you are expecting or not, it's harder for them to give a good reading if you take it soon after sex (there are many different brands as well).



Do what a couple of the others have suggested, go to your GP for a second opinion (go with a urine sample), also they can give you confidential advice.  If you're a bit worried about it all, take a close friend just to be there for you.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lilly
Member since: 21 January 2008
Total points: 4030 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Once you are already pregnant, there are no birth control pills you can take to make you un-pregnant. The method in which you are talking about is only effective to stop implantation of the egg into the uterus. This usually happens within 72 hours. So at 13 weeks you are well over that threshold. Once the egg has implanted it has no effect. There is nothing you can do at home to control your pregnancy at this stage - only a doctor can help. Blood tests will be accurate at this stage, your doctor will take them



IF you are not pregnant, then make sure you take your birth control regularly and on time from now on so you do not get into this situation in pregnancy.



</answer>

<answer from>



Stephanie M
Member since: 22 March 2007
Total points: 3785 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Having a waterbirth is known to decrease the pain.  It helps ease contractions and because you float in water, it helps to make you feel "lighter".  The water can also make it easier for you to stretch, making it easier for your baby to come out.  Water is a wonderful thing for birth.  Not that it will take all the pain away, but it can be tremendously helpful.



</answer>



<answer from>



musicimp...
Member since: 12 December 2005
Total points: 14251 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Being pregnant and giving birth is not for the weak of heart. That's one reason I never did it. If you really hate pain, keep taking your birth control because there is some pain no matter what, from the onset of morning sickness through the birth, and afterward too.



Water births help take the edge off the pain and stress for the mother but mostly they make it easier on the baby being born. Midwives can offer this service but not sure if you can have a water birth in a regular hospital.



If you work with a midwife you pretty much agree to not having any painkillers but they focus largely on prenatal care so that you have a healthy pregnancy and labor. They also teach you all kinds of things to get relaxed and get through the pain, and so do Lamaze classes.



If you have an epidural, well...you get dulled from the waist down but you are still awake and feeling enough to push.



These are all pain management strategies for delivering the baby...you get full local anesthesia if you have a C-section because this is officially surgery.



</answer>



<answer from>



djembemu...
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 320 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am planning a water birth. I had one on a bed 3 years ago and cannot do that again. I have heard the warm water does take the edge off the pain, helps you relax, helps your perineum stretch, and helps you stay in a good position for longer.



</answer>

<question>



Is plan B reliable? Im taking it, a day after the brake in the condom.?



My boyfriend and i had sex, we found a brake in the condom after, but when he was cumming he pulled it out. but since the break was still there, some still most likely got inside me. This was on the 2nd of oct., and im going to take plan b, on the 3rd of oct. Is that good? Will it be affective? help please, idk what to do.



</question>



<answer from>



Due March 15th 2009 :) with #1
Member since: 09 July 2008
Total points: 1011 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It should be fine i believe that you have up to 48 or 72 hours to take the first pill.



</answer>



<answer from>



funn1bun...
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 159 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Every hour counts! If taken as directed within 72 hours (3 days) of unprotected sex, Plan B reduces the chance of pregnancy by up to 89%. About 7 out of every 8 women who would have gotten pregnant will not get pregnant. And it works even better if you take it within the first 24 hours after unprotected sex. The first pill should be taken as soon as possible, and the second pill 12 hours later.



So that added to the fact that he pulled out, you have a very slim chance of getting pregnant. You most likely won't because pulling out is 70% effective, and if he knows how to pull out, you have nothing to worry about because that makes it higher than just 70%.



</answer>



<answer from>



StupidKu...
Member since: 27 April 2007
Total points: 1118 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hurry up and do Plan B. Don't be one of those girls that wait several months to abort a baby and become a child killer.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kristin B
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 931 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hello, you have 72 hours to take the Plan B pill. It is 75% effective if taken right away. The longer you wait, the less effective it will be. Take it right now :)



</answer>

<answer>



Your blood pressure was very high at the start, but there is nothing wrong with having a low blood pressure, my blood pressure during my second pregnancy was 80/60 and perfectly normal, it was only when i was 30 weeks and it jumped up to 140, that it became dangerous. Don't worry yourself, a low blood pressure can cause headaches, so take things in your stride and only worry if it is high.
Look after yourself

<answer>

Despite all the problems with the blood pressure being too low there was never any problems with the baby, the risk was more to myself then to them. Just make sure you keep hydrated, don't overheat or stand for too long.

<question>

PLEASE REFRAIN FROM JUDGING



I know this is a controversial subject and everyone wants to have their say on it, but I ask that only women who have had an abortion respond to this question-  I thank you for your consideration.



What were your honest feelings after the abortion? Did you feel relieved? Guilty? Did you feel confident that you made the right decision?



And also, can you tell me about your religious background?  Were you raised in a religious family?



</question>

<answer>



I dont really know what to say to u babe other then u really shouldnt be having unprotected sex at any age unless u and this person have both been tested and been together for a long time.
Ur only a baby urself and still growing up.



If u did a test 2 weeks ago and only had ur period the start of this week then clearly the test would stay u wasnt pregnant cause clearly u wasnt pregnant, at that time u was ovulating.



Please dont take this the wrong way honey but u really need to have someone sit u down and teach u about ur cycle.



U have a 21 day cycle - The cycle starts on the first day of ur period and 14 days later u ovulate and 14 days after that ur period starts and the cycle starts all over again.
When ovulation starts in the middle of ur cycle u have a 2 day window on both sides where ur at risk of becoming pregnant.



Love Manda xXx



Source(s):



I am 25 weeks pregnant with a planned baby.

<answer>

<answer from>



answerth...
Member since: 17 March 2007
Total points: 5121 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm surprised your doctor didn't advise you to use some sort of birth control after the miscarriage since it is usually recommended that a woman waits at least one cycle before trying to get pregnant again.



I suspect that you're already pregnant and that you're ovulating just fine.  It's not too early to use a home pregnancy test since the new tests are much more sensitive and accurate than previously.



I suggest taking a in home pregnancy test and if it's positive, make an appointment with your gynecologist as soon as possible.  If the test is negative, consult with your doctor about what to do next.  Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



lakmii
Member since: 09 September 2006
Total points: 1420 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



sorry to hear about your miscarriage



it sounds like you might well be pregnant



don't worry a miscarriage is not going to make you unable to ovulate, miscarriages are very common in the first 10 weeks, how many weeks were you? when the egg and sperm are fusing together and chromosomes are replicating etc it can often go wrong, it has nothing to do with your ovaries



have you actually been trying for a baby? i.e. having unprotected sex, cos then in that case i would say you  are almost definitely pregnant :)



good luck!!



</answer>

Congrats!



The earlier you take your folic acid the better - preferably before you are pregnant but I would start now, dont wait around for a doctors appointment. There is nothing wrong with taking it as early as possible!

<answer>



Pretty much any rounded prenatal vitamin should be ok for you to take. I started taking CVS pharmacy brand and my ob-gyn was perfectly happy with that. Folic acid is a very important amino acid you need to take- and most docs would suggest starting taking this when trying to conceive since it can improve conception and embryo health from day one. Once your doc does the blood tests and urine test it will say if your lacking anything the vitamins aren't giving and from there he can prescribe a better one for your body or reccomend one over the counter. Anything is better than nothing so start taking one that makes you feel good ( no agida nausea or heartburn as some might do) and you should be ok! Best of luck and congradulations!!!!!!



</answer>

<question>



What size diapers should I get?



I have "newborn" and "1" just in case...its hard to believe a baby would fit in the newborn ones. what size did you baby fit into once you brought him/her home?



</question>



<additional details>



i'm really hoping i dont have to get a c-section, not cuz im scared just because i think i'd get sick knowing they're moving my inside around haha I am going to be breast feeding and when I was born I was almost 10Ibs and my mom gave a natural vaginal birth so hopefully everything goes well like it did with her &lt;3



</additional details>



<answer from>



jackmatt
Member since: 17 December 2007
Total points: 10359 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Most babies will fit into newborn, but I would not buy a bunch of them at first. If you want to stock up on diapers before birth, then buy more of the # sizes or save receipts so you can take back excess diapers that baby can no longer fit in.
OB/GYN RN & mom



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you it helped out alot :)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Mother of 2
Member since: 31 January 2008
Total points: 154 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Both of my children were born full term.  My daughter weighed almost 7 pounds, and my son almost 8.  The newborn size, seemed to be big on them for first week, but they soon grow into it, and very soon grow out of it.  My daughter moved to size 1 at 3 weeks, my son at 4 weeks.



The newborn diapers are designed with a special notch, to prevent from covering the end of the umbilical cord, which will come off in about 1 to 3 weeks after birth.



Good luck to you.



Source(s):



Personal Experience.



</answer>



<answer from>



e_forcuc...
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 205 (Level 1)

mine were in preemie but were able to wear the newborns at 4.5 and 5.8 lbs so really the newborns are supposed to fit up to 10 lbs and now that they are over 8 the 1's actually work even if they are slightly big... and for your sake i hope your child isn't that big.. cause man that seems like it could hurt or they might possibly have to do a c-section... Not to scare you about the section, they are nothing.. I had a c-section and i actually felt nothing till the next day and as long as you aren't breast feeding they can give you some mighty nice drugs ( not that i'm saying you shouldn't breast feed, i know its better)

<answer>



If she's registered, definitely buy her something of the registry. I got almost everything off my registry and it helped sooo much! <question>



What are the chances of this couple having a blue or green eyed baby?



Baby's Mom:
Dark brown eyes, Japanese, and everyone in her family has dark brown eyes



Baby's Dad:
Blue eyes, German/Scottish, his dad has blue eyes and his mom has light brown eyes.



</question>



<answer from>



35 wks w/ #2*
Member since: 14 August 2008
Total points: 2031 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Canada Baby, 24 weeks :)
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 1581 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



there's a chance but not likely.



</answer>



<answer from>



usa.doa8...
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 118 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<answer from>



anna j

</answer>



<answer from>



Michelle R
Member since: 25 November 2007
Total points: 8955 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Religion & Spirituality



</answer from>



<answer>



Unless the mom has a non-brown-eyed ancestor, then there's pretty much no chance.  The baby can't benefit from a chromosome that isn't there.



But his or her children (your friend's babies, when they grow up) will have a good chance of having non-brown-eyed children, if they marry someone who has it in their background.



Source(s):



In the same boat - blue eyed and married to a guy with all brown eyes in the entire family, and hoping against hope that someone way back in his family tree was an exception ;)



</answer>



<answer from>



Mel
Member since: 31 March 2008
Total points: 143 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on Mom's genotype for eye colour, which is determined by two gene contributions. Brown is the dominant gene, whereas blue is recessive and would be masked by the brown in phenotypic expression.



If Dad has blue eyes, then he is homozygous (both genes are the same) for blue eyes. He can only contribute a blue eyed gene.



Mom may have brown eyes, but it is possible (although it sounds like slim if no one else in her family has blue eyes) that she carries a recessive gene for blue eyes.



If Mom is heterozygous, than the chances of blue are 1/4. If she is homozygous for brown, than there cannot be blue eyes.



Green eyes are, if I recall, somewhat more complicated, and I cannot answer to that part, but if Mom is homozygous for dark brown, then it seems unlikely.



Source(s):



genetics class



</answer>



<answer from>



Deborah H
Member since: 30 January 2007
Total points: 221 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Brown eyed people can have blue eyed children - I have 2 of them.
However, the brown eyed person must carry the recessive gene in order to not dominate their partner's genes.



If everyone in your family has brown eyes, then it is unlikely you will have anything but brown.  That is, unless the recessive gene has been passed on through your family without a match for generations.



</answer>



<answer from>



sparkle
Member since: 25 September 2007
Total points: 8191 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



most likely brown eyes,one of my children has pale green eyes,despite her father and i having brown eyes,but both her grandfathers had blue/green eyes,therefore husband and i carried a recessive gene for blue /green eyes,giving us a 25% chance of a non brown eyed child.her three siblings are brown eyed



</answer>

<question from>



Kaitlynn Starr due 12/12/08

<question>



If you tend to get depressed during your pregnancy is that a sign that you'll have postpartum depression?



</question>



<answer from>



Baby Boy Due 10/17
Member since: 05 August 2007
Total points: 805 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



not necessarily but it is possible, during pregnancy and after your emotions and hormones are all over the place



</answer>



<answer from>



Bag
Member since: 26 June 2007
Total points: 11202 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not necessarily. Pre-natal depression and post-natal depression are different illnesses.



If you do have pre-natal (partum) depression, it would be best to work through that before the baby is born to try to avoid post natal depression.



</answer>



<answer from>



rosieang...
Member since: 28 September 2008
Total points: 268 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



it could be my sister was depressed during her pregnancy and went on to have post natal depression go and see your doctor and  tell them they might be able to nip it in the bud sooner rather than later



</answer>

<question from>



Jodi
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



100% STD/Maternity Leave?



Does anyone get 100% pay through STD?  If yes, for how long and who is your insurance provider?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I believe it is a federal law that insurance companies can only pay 65% of a persons gross weekly income on a Short Term Disability policy. Also be careful, in most cases income from STD is non-taxable, unless the premiums were deducted before taking taxes out of your pay check. If taxes were deducted after subtracting your STD premiums, then the benefits received from the policy is/are taxable.



</answer>

<question>



Pregnancy Questions: Part II?



Hi again, I'm continuing my study on life during the prenatal years and came across other questions:
1) If x-ray is a form of teratogen that pregnant women should not be exposed to, why then do pregnant women conduct an ultrasound?
2) Is it safe for newborns to drink milk themselves while lying in their cribs? If not, what impact if any could this cause?



Thanks again!



</question>



<answer from>



Lou
Member since: 27 August 2008
Total points: 756 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



1) An ultrasound is not an x-ray.



2) It really isnt safe to leave a newborn alone to drink their milk on their own. They could choke really easy and die, or they could just stop breathing.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thx



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



granny5
Member since: 03 July 2008
Total points: 6958 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



ultra sounds are not the same as x-rays! the source that comes from ultra sounds are milder in the imagining of thr baby while x-rays can cause pregnant women to miscarry, because of what makes up x-rays;no, a newborn should not be dinking milk in a crib, it usuaaly is breast-fed, it a newborn(could hold a bottle in which I doubt), it would choke to death, because it could not digest it.



Source(s):



thoughts from granny 5



</answer>



<answer from>



2nd baby due march 4th!!

</answer from>



<answer>



an ultrasound isnt anywhere near as much (if any) radiation as an x-ray...and i dont see how a new born could drink milk by itself since most new borns cant hold a bottle on their own...i dont know if it is safe, but i wouldn't do that...id think they could spit up and choke??



</answer>



<answer from>



Kimberly A
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 3120 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are two very specific waves that these use



here are the facts



x-rays use electromagnetic waves, No medium and accelerating electric charges



Ultrasound use longitudinal mechanical waves and elastic medium



</answer>

So she is making me an appointment to c the doctor in 3 weeks time to check the baby size should i be worried about this its my 1st baby.



</question>

<answer from>



MRS. J. BURNS
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was told with my last child he was very small and sent for a scan 2 weeks before he was due... everything was normal on scan and he was born a healthy big 9lb 4oz naturally.



my sister in law was taken for an emergency c section 1 week before due, being told the baby was very very small, around 4lb and would be taken to nicu! he was deliverd a healthy 6lb 8oz and was alloud home the same day.



they dont always get it right.



dont worry too much but if you start to panic then ring her up and ask to be sent for a scan asap.



BEST OF LUCK CHICK.XXX



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



So, I've been on birth control consistently for 4 years, Just this past month I started spotting 17 days?



before my period was due (or 11 days after my last period, whichever way you want to look at it). It was a brown spotting, and was usually very light, and was on and off for the whole time up until my period. (Some days there was no spotting and some days there was a little). I was due for my period 9/30, I have what I believe may be my period but its pretty light compared to other periods. I'm not sure why this could be happening. COuld I possible be pregnant? (I took two tests, they were both negative) Also, My BF and I don't use another form of contraception and I have never missed a pill (take it the same time every day)



sorry if this is long, anyone with this experience, or who could know possibly what my deal is, would be a great help! Thanks!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



It could be hormonal imbalance or it could be cysts or something. It would be best to consult a gynaecologist. Do not wait too long. If it is hormonal imbalance, than you would only need some pills to treat it but if it something else like cysts or etc, then you better have it looked at



Source(s):



Personal experience



</answer>

<question>

has anybody ever had a negative urine pregnancy test after their period was due but still think there pregnant and have symthoms?



</question>



<answer from>



badgrenc...
Member since: 02 February 2006
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



NO



BUT I THINK U NEED 2 GO SEE THE DOCTORS.



</answer>



<answer from>



CuriousG...
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 393 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I took two, one at 5 days before the missed period and then one 1 day before the missed period and both of them came back negative.  So, I just figured I wasn't pregnant.  Then I spotted about an hour or so and thought it was just because I had my IUD taken out recently and my system is out of whack.  After about 10 more days, I decided to test again and I was pregnant.  It just didn't show up early.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mummy of 1 1/2 angels**
Member since: 30 July 2008
Total points: 994 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yep, I know of loads of people this has happened to, including my mom who never got a positive urine result during her entire pregnancy with me or my sister. We were undetectable!
I think they just don't work for some people, and for others, they should try again in a week or two when their HcG levels are likely to have risen.



</answer>

<question>



Did any of you ever just "know" what your baby's gender was before you actually found out? ?



I'm having a baby in March and I just "know" that it's going to be a girl. I mean I'm only 11 weeks so I obviously don't know for sure, but I just have this gut feeling. I can't explain it. Everyone does, all of my family and my husband's family thinks it's going to be a girl. We all even call it "she" and "her" without even thinking about it. So, In other words did any of you get a feeling, woman's intuition, a dream or anything? Were you right?



</question>



<additional details>



With my first one I didn't have a really strong feeling either way, I wanted a girl which is strange because I always wanted a boy to be my oldest, I just had a sudden craving for a girl. I got a boy (very glad about that for several reasons). With the second one I wanted a girl again because I hadn't had one yet, I had a slight feeling that it was going to be a girl and it was. But, I'm not sure if that was just bacause I wanted one so bad. Now, that I have one of each and it doesn't really matter what I have, so I don't have feelings clouding my judgement, I'm getting a REALLY strong girl vibe.

<question from>



lena_lan...
Member since: 30 May 2008
Total points: 221 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



My doc says im measuring low?



i went to the doc today, i am 32 weeks and 3 days pregnant and he  said that i was measuring low. he said it could be my size, i am only about 5ft and was about 105-110 lbs before pregnancy. other people i have asked say that i just might be having a small baby, but should i be worried? this is my first baby so of course i am more worried about things.



</question>



<answer from>



Yvonne
Member since: 04 September 2006
Total points: 4087 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I started measuring 2 weeks small at 32 weeks and my doc said it's probably because I am so small...5' and 95 lbs pre-pregnancy. Her head has been down since at least 30 weeks which can cause you to measure "smaller" than you actually are too. He actually said it's kind of a good thing, he doesn't want me trying to push out a 10 lb baby lol. My son was 3 days late and still only came out at 6 lbs 6 oz but he was perfectly healthy.  There is no need to worry.



:)



Source(s):



Due yesterday w/ #2



</answer>



<asker's comment>



comforting to read this answer,  really set my mind at ease.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



krob8008
Member since: 03 September 2008
Total points: 1657 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



What are you measuring? Mine never tells me what I am measuring. She just says, "You're not measuring too big." And, I feel like I am smaller with this pregnancy than my last for some reason. But, at 36 weeks, I had an ultrasound that estimated his weight to already be 6 lbs. 8 oz!
So, I know he's not small. I am also right below 5'1. So, it might also be the position of your baby/uterus....It seems like if your doctor was concerned, you'd be in for an ultrasound soon.



Source(s):



Boy # 2 due 10/24



</answer>



<answer from>



LiL' Momma
Member since: 10 August 2006
Total points: 1859 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



My doctor said the same exact thing when I was pregnant with my daughter two years ago. They did an ultrasound and said I was just going to have a small baby. They said she would be no more that 7 pounds..... She came out 8lbs 6oz. lol.



I'm gonna say you don't have anything to worry about. She's probably just tucked in there really good like mine was and it's hard for them to get accurate measurements when the baby is like that.

<question>



38 weeks and 5 days pregnant?



I'm 38 weeks and 5 days today and ive noticed a clear slimey liquid everytime i go to the toilet and ive been told to stop taking my iron tablets and i am still going for poos quite alot but not diarrahea and i never usually poo alot. I have also been having really nasty pains in my back sometimes i have to grab the bed and use my arm strength to pull me over as i can't move i don't understand if these are contractions there usually in my lower or the middle of my back what is this?



</question>



<answer from>



TexasPro...
Member since: 19 June 2008
Total points: 287 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



being that far along it might be the braxton hicks.... which is false labor.... or it could even be labor...  a lot of women have back pain when they are having their babies...



but if you are having concerns it is always a good idea to talk to you dr. about any problems you are having. he is going to be the only one that will know for sure since he is the one that has been seeing you and has your charts...



</answer>



<answer from>



NavaehRo...
Member since: 14 August 2006
Total points: 1694 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



you can have back labor that would cause pain in your lower back Id call the doctor and tell them about it. Good Luck and Congratulations



</answer>

<question from>



Ejr
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Has anyone ever been induced with pitocin? If so, what did they think about it? ?



I am supposed to get induced in a few days using Pitocin. I am nervous, but Have been in so much pain and am not dialated at all. They baby's head is not even all the way down and my due date is in 7 days. I cannot eat or sleep anymore and have the worse integestion that i cannot get rid of.



</question>



<answer from>



2 in the oven
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 13993 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was induced and they inserted cervadil (sp?) the night before and that's a 12 hour process. Then the next morning since I started dilating they used pitocin. I was okay with it. The pain wasn't as bad as people talk about. The nurses were great offering pain meds before I felt I needed them. I think I had the meds in my system and that cut down on the pain before it started. Then I went for a spell of no pain meds and the doc was delivering twins so the epidural was on hold also. That was a 20 minute period where I was bad-but I didn't lose it or anything. Pushing lasted 45 minutes, and 15 of that was waiting on doc and NIC to be ready.



It was a good experience, we had a healthy baby and I like things being planned. I'd do it again and in fact nurse mentioned it yesterday at my first appointment since my second is due within 2 days of my daughter's birthday.



</answer>



<answer from>



28weeks* *#3* *It's a GIRL*
Member since: 21 February 2008
Total points: 17791 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Parenting



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



I was induced via pitocin drip both times. I loved it! I'm hoping for a 3rd induction this time as well. Short easy labors, and the pain wasn't horrible until about the last hour as the baby was decending to crown.



Labors were:
8hrs45mins, pushed 2 times (slept 6 hrs of that)
5hrs20mins, pushed 3 times (slept 3 hours of that)
No epidural. I had Demerol pain meds with my first, which worked great on taking the edge off.
I had Nubain meds with my second, which did nothing but pass to the baby and cause his stomach to be pumped at birth.



I will be attempting no meds this time....we'll see how that goes!



</answer>



<answer from>



M Kerr RN L&D
Member since: 04 March 2007
Total points: 48544 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



I was induced with my 1st with Pitocin, and was the most horrific labor that I ever had to endure!



I had pre-eclampsia so I was induced at 36 weeks, he refused to drop into my pelvis, so no epidural for me as his head was too high up on my spine, after 19hrs of pitocin induced labor and pushing for 2hrs, I finally got my OB to agree to a c-section.



If you dont have to be induced, don't its horrible IMO



</answer>



<answer from>



Luv2Answ...
Member since: 03 July 2007
Total points: 13247 (Level 6)

<answer>



My water broke at 9 in the morning but contractions never started. I got pitocin at about 2pm and the baby was born at midnight. Everyone says that it makes contractions stonger. If that's true then people who don't get it must have a really easy time of it because with the help of an epidural I did just fine. I'm sure that what you are going through now is worse than just getting on with it.



</answer>



<answer from>



laceandc...
Member since: 24 March 2007
Total points: 13166 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was induced with Pitocin.  At 7am started IV.  Nothing happening.  1pm doctor broke my water.  Nothing, no labor pains.  6pm first labor pain.  8:01pm, she was born.



</answer>



<answer from>



wendy080...
Member since: 25 April 2007
Total points: 7261 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was induced with Pitocin two years ago because my water broke, but I didn't go into labor.  I went from having no contractions to having very hard very painful contractions.  I had planned all along on having an epidural, but found out that they wont give you one until you are at least 4 cm dilated.  People who have gone into labor both ways say that natural labor was much more comfortable than being induced was, so I'm hoping to not need to be induced this time, but for now I can only tell you that the pitocin induction was very painful.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ethel
Member since: 05 September 2007
Total points: 8608 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



When my water broke without labor they put me on pitocin.  I never got pain relief, so I was doing labor on pitocin with no help (none of the two epidurals worked, bloody doc poked me 10 times with each try, guess she wasn't used to a 6' tall woman in labor).  Not the most awesome ever thing to do.  If you get a good epidural, it's fine - the big thing about pitocin isn't that it hurts more it's that the contractions come close together and take longer so it's like you're in transition for HOURS.  There is a chance that your uterus will be overstimulated and you will not dilate as well with pitocin, and you'll head off to c-section as I did.



Just make sure that you have a chance to get pain relief before it gets too bad.  Labor normally is painful, pitocin is a ***** - did a VBAC with my 2nd, labored naturally and got an epidural after 16 hours of labor, just before transition, never as painful as pitocin labor.  If you're ready to deliver it's great, but without careful administration it can be a bad thing.



</answer>

<question>



6 weeks pregnant and low hcg levels?



I am almost 6 weeks pregnant and my doctor called yesterday morning and would like to retest my hcg levels because they were low. This has me worried because I really have not felt pregnant other than my breasts seem to tingle and little but no other real signs. This is my third pregnancy I have two boys and I am hoping no signs means this is a girl! LOL I was sick with both of my boys! Just wondering if anyone else has had this problem!



</question>



<answer from>



debbie r
Member since: 16 November 2006
Total points: 1746 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Don't get your self all stressed out over it. I know it's hard not to worry, but try to relax. It could be lower than normal because you could of conceived later than the doc or you thought. Hopefully he is getting you in there soon so you don't have to stress over it all weekend. Good luck and I hope everything works out for you and your baby.



</answer>



<answer from>



Princess...
Member since: 31 March 2006
Total points: 2170 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi There. I had a similar issue when I first found out I was pregnant my hcg levels just weren't doubling like they should and the doctor ordered blood tests every other day. Unfortunately my pregnancy ended in a miscarriage. I don't want to freak you out but since your going to the doctor you may want to ask her/him what low hcg level means and if there is a vitamin or supplement that you can take to help boost your hcg levels. Also remember that some women have low hcg levels there entire pregnancy and go on to deliver healthy babies. Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



CuriousG...
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 397 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



They just want to be sure the HCG levels are going up and not down.  As long as they are increasing, you are ok.  I was sick with my first two and the whole pregnancy with both..  But, I had a boy and a girl.  So, this time, I'm not vomiting as much, but I just feel nausea.  I don't think that matters so much.  But, we can send girl vibes your way!  Smile.  Best of luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



jenzito
Member since: 16 April 2007
Total points: 3161 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



i dont wanna scare you but , i have 2 boys too, but when i got pregnant the 3rd time, my levels were o.k. till the 5th week, and i had sore breast, heartburn, but NO morning sickness, and sadly miscarried at 7 weeks,i thought no signs means girl, but i had low progesterone levels, just stay positive , everyone is different, some don't even have any signs, and have a healthy pregnancy, but talk to your doctor and see what you hcg levels are-good luck



</answer>

<answer from>



dangle
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 1746 (Level 3)



Contributing In:

<answer>



That's fairly normal. Some babies "drop" earlier, and others don't drop until labour actually starts. Enjoy being able to breathe better for a while :-) (countered by the fact you probably need to pee every 5 mins).
He may not stay there though - at that stage they do move round quite a bit. At 24 weeks, I feel like I'm getting kicks to the cervix, as well as having my ribs played like a xylophone!
All the best for the last couple of months xx



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 16 November 2006
Total points: 1746 (Level 3)

<answer>



Yep that is normal. Unless you have cramping that is hurting you or bleeding I don't think it's anything to worry about. Try changing positions and see if that helps any.

<question from>



Stephine R
Member since: 20 February 2008
Total points: 227 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Am i or am i not pregnant??



ok it's hard to tell if in fact i am pregnant.........I'm afaid to take a test due to my BF already having 3 kids of his own and he doesn't want any more. i myself am unsure if  i want or even can have kids. I have been feeling sick and like i'm gonna throw up....i get tired and my moods are out of wack.



</question>



<additional details>



I also have pcos. It's a hormone disorder in women that can cause a women to not have kids or have a lower risk.



I do pee alot.....my breasts so far arn't sore.



I understand the need to take a test.........however i would perfer not to rise a worry if i didn't have a......high mind set that being pregnant is possable.



the thing is i don't have my monthly.........well i don't have it monthly.....more like once a year if that.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Baby Wood ETA 30/05/2009
Member since: 17 January 2007
Total points: 504 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It is scary hun but the only way to know for sure is to take a test!!!
Good luck



</answer>



<asker's comment>



TY for all your answers.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Amber - Due 11/24/08
Member since: 29 July 2008
Total points: 1177 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You really haven't given much information, but the generic answer for this question would be to take a test. While I understand you're scared, you can't decide what to do without knowing. Being tired and moody isn't always a sure sign of pregnancy, and if you haven't missed your period yet the chances of having symptoms this early are slim. Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Yvonne
Member since: 20 November 2006
Total points: 109 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hey.. You should take a pregnancy test for you to be able to know if your pregnant or not. Coz, If your not going to see the reality.. You'll just becoming more paranoid, and acting as if your pregnant or not. The case that your experiencing, it may just cause of the stress that you feel.. So, get up and take the test.



</answer>



<answer from>



LMinSA
Member since: 15 May 2008
Total points: 1331 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Even women with PCOS ovulate once in a while.  What makes it difficult for women with PCOS to have children is that they don't know when they ovulate or when they may have a period, so they cannot time sex in order to conceive.



You may have ovulated.  If so, you could be pregnant.  Time to take a test!



Source(s):



17 weeks pregnant



</answer>



<answer from>



C B
Member since: 18 October 2007
Total points: 3718 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would suggest that you go to your family doctor and ask him/her for a pregnanct test.  The consultation is completely confidential and then you can confront the situation when you know for certain.  Whether or not your are nervous about your bf reaction you still need to know.



Good luck



</answer>

<answer>



The whole reason people say dry crackers is because women keep them at their bedside to eat before they get up. I get sick if I get up to fast or do not eat right away. Sleeping is still not eating for 7-8 hours. A pregnant woman needs food every 2-3 hours. I would try eating something like cereal before bed, and have something ready to eat in bed before you wake up.



I had morning sickness for 2 months. I am over that part now. I wanted to cry because I was so tired of feeling that way. This is my third pregnancy so it was much harder on me. I hope you start feeling better soon. You can also ask your doctor for a prescription, but the pills will make you very sleepy. Its not worth it!
Congrats!



</answer>

<answer from>



Cindersa...
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 487 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had bad morning sickness, especially with my first pregnancy. All day/all night and lost 15 pounds in the beginning. I got tired of crackers pretty fast. You can only eat so many of them. Bland food seems to work the best. Somethings that I could eat...



Scrambled eggs
Hot pretzel
Baked potato
Plain chicken breast
Coke or Pepsi with the fizz stirred out of it.
Toast with light butter.
Plain cookies like Ginger snaps or just vanilla wafers.



Tums can help a lot. Take a tums before you eat. It helps the food stay down. Also try to eat something every 2 hours instead of regular meals. Having something in your stomach actually helps. Let water warm up a little rather than drinking it right out of the fridge or with ice.



Hope you feel better soon.



Cindy.



</answer>

<question>



How does mirena work?



how do they put it in? what are the side effects? what is the percentage of protection against pregnancy? etc.



</question>



<answer from>



iluvjdee...
Member since: 07 June 2007
Total points: 2144 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I always caution around these new and improved medicines.  I don't know the side effects etc, but if you google it, I'm sure that it will give you an answer.  Just be careful.  I trust the old stuff better.  I know it works and is safe for me.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dark Angel
Member since: 25 April 2007
Total points: 2005 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Mirena is a plastic/hormone gadget that is placed in your ueterus through your cervix.  it can stay in place for 5 years.  it realeses hormones to the local area that work like the pill, only you dont have to take a pill everyday.
it is usually inserted towards the end of a period, the doctor uses a speculum to open the vagina and inserts a rod through the cervix.
then the doctor pushes a little lever thing which leaves the T shape mirena in your uterus.



it can cause some discomfort and bleeding for a little while while the body gets used to it. but then you can forget about it for 5 years.



lots of women find the added benefit of not getting a period or a very light period while they use it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Wilmalov...
Member since: 03 January 2008
Total points: 1355 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is a slow release contraceptive.
I have heard of many women suffering heavy bleeding and other complications as a side effect but with most things these days there comes the risks.
I would not use this myself personally as I think it may cause some kind of permanent damage and I would not like to be infertile just yet.
You need to weigh up the odds and make a decision before using this.
The only totally safe bet against pregnancy is - no intercourse.
I fell pregnant while on the pill and bled for like six months of my pregnancy.  So be careful with whatever you do.



</answer>



<answer from>



PATRICIA L
Member since: 20 October 2006
Total points: 1054 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had a Mirena put in 3 yrs ago and after 6 months it changed my life! It does hurt a little bit when its put in and I bled for about 2 wks afterwards, although not much and it took a while to settle down but it was worth it in the end. Its basically the same as having a smear test but takes a little longer to do. I don't know of any side effects once its in there. As with any other contreception, it's not 100% proof but it must be at least 98% and you don't have to remember to take it every day. I actually forgot mine was in when I went for a smear a few months ago!! Got told off cos I forgot to mention I had one lol. Before you have it inserted, take a couple of painkillers 20 mins before and have someone with you to take you home, even if you can walk home as being on your back, not moving, can make some feel faint.



</answer>



<answer from>



Melissa W
Member since: 21 August 2007
Total points: 1228 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



They insert the mirena through your cervix into the uterus. You may have more spotting for the first six months. Then some women have no period at all or very light. They usually require you to have had at least one pregnancy so your cervix is open a little. I got one before I had been pregnant and wouldn't suggest it. They had to dilate my cervix to insert it and it did not feel good. I can't remember the exact percentage of protection, but you need to be in a stable monogamous relationship because with the device in place std's have an easier route straight to your uterus which could lead to a bad infection. Hope this helped.



Source(s):



worked in OB/GYN



</answer>

amysmumm...
Member since: 22 July 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



Hi,



I'm 16 weeks and was advised that colouring these days is ok, but most people try to avoid the first 12 weeks.  My hairdresser advised me to just get highlights using foils if in doubt - that way your scalp only gets minimal contact with hair dye.  That's what I did and it made me feel much better about my grey hairs.  It also means that you can go longer without looking like your roots need to be done :-).



As for after the birth, I'm not aware of any issue with colouring your hair, in fact it was one of the first things I did when I felt able to escape the house to the hairdressers for an hour of pampering.  Perhaps best to check with your midwife if you are breastfeeding, just to be on the safe side.



Wishing you all the best!



</answer>

celtic.p...

</answer from>



<answer>



It really depends on the reason for the tear....



If it's likely to happen again, then definitely hospital.



If it's possible, then birthing centre.



If not, then home birth.



As long as you don't have any problems, and the baby doesn't have any problems, a home birth can be perfectly safe.



Ask the consultant if you're likely to tear again, and discuss what you want with them.



Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 25322 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Whichever one you prefer.



A third degree tear should not rule out a home birth for you -- most severe tears result from the mother being made to push while lying flat on her back, or are an extension of a previous episiotomy.  If you are allowed to push in an appopriate position, you shouldn't tear.  And if you do, the midwife can repair it.



I'd talk to a midwife.  If you DO have risk factors that would make a home birth  unsafe for you (including lack of back-up for complications) she will tell you so, and not take you as a client.



In the abcense of specific complications/risk factors, a home birth IS safe (safer than a hospital and at least as safe as a birthing center)  -- so whatever you feel most comfortable with is right for you.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lucky♥



2nd Bun in the Oven
Member since: 31 March 2006
Total points: 14202 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's not advisable if you had a 3rd degree tear the first time.  You are likely to tear the same this time around, and as you know that requires an immediate surgical repair.



If you give birth in a birthing center, half the time you'll end up being rushed to the hospital anyway.  To me, that sounds more stressful than anything and would only prolong the birth experience.



</answer>

<answer>



Homebirth is statistically SAFER than hospital birth. My son was born at home on the living room sofa (by choice), we had TWO dedicated midwives at all times, The Carpenters playing softly in the background under candlelight (until the big moment). I heartily recommend it!

wendy080...

<answer>



I've known people who have had really positive experiences with both, and one person who almost had a really tragic experience with the home birth (I should add that she went on to have 5 successful experiences with home birth after the first one).



While I personally am way to paranoid and nervous to ever even consider it, if I were inclined that way, I would go with the home birth since you live that close to the hospital.  Two of my friends who  used birthing centers the first time are pregnant again and both plan to do home births this time.  The midwives that they are working with have told them that they bring the same equipment out to the house with them that they would have available in the birthing center.  One of them told me that the birthing center sent her home 2 hours after delivery (2:00 AM) after her son was born.  I personally was horrified until she explained to me that that was what she actually wanted.  If they are going to send you right home anyway, then you may as well just have the baby at home.



Best of luck to you with whatever you decide.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tia
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 137 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have had a homebirth, and it was absolutely wonderful. I found a midwife with excellent statistics (1400 babies and not one death). She knows her patients (of course, all low-risk patients) so well because she meets with them once a month for a full hour, and she knows when a transfer to the hospital is needed well before the situation has become a dire emergency.



I get very heated about how everyone makes birth out to be a hugely scary and dangerous thing. Birth is not dangerous in a low-risk woman. Midwifes practice very safe and effective care. As a matter of fact, The Netherlands has far better birth outcomes (more babies survive) than we in the US do, and 70 percent of babies there are born at HOME with midwives! Only the high-risk women are seen by obstetricians.  There is a lot of literature out there that proves homebirth to be as safe or safer (there are risks at a hospital, as nobody seems to realize) than at the hospital. Hospitals can also create problems in the birthing women with the "routine" interventions that they make mandatory for women.



It seems like everyone is here to make you nervous, and I wanted to stress the fact that homebirth can be a safe option for you and you don't need to rule it out, even if you had a tear last time around - in fact, you are probably less likely to tear this time because you have already had a baby and have been stretched.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jessica
Member since: 11 May 2007
Total points: 5689 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had a waterbirth at home.  It was a great experience.  I was 6 days overdue and VERY ready to have him!  At 2 am on Saturday morning I woke up with contractions that were irregular and crampy like period cramps.  I had them off and on all day and everyone said that it wasn't likely anything.  At 8:30 pm that night we went for a walk and got ice cream.  My contractions were a little more painful, but still irregular.  When we got home we thought that nothing would likely come of them and settled down for a movie.  At 9:30 pm they started to come regularily and I made my husband time them.  at 10:15 pm I called my midwife and told her.  She wasn't really concerned and wasn't going to come.  After three contractions in 10 minutes on the phone with her, she decided she would.  She and the student midwife and my doula arrived at 10 to 11 pm and my husband started the tub up because contractions were 3 min apart.  I got into the tub at 11:30 and my contractions were coming at 2 min.  I started to feel like I wanted to push about 10 min later.  After the first two pushes, the midwife called the second midwife.  (She told me earlier that when they call in the second it's generally 1/2 hour til the birth).  I was shocked and asked in the middle of a contraction, "Do you think he'll be here that soon?"  I started to get excited but freak out at the same time.  I was all natural and I was starting to feel more pain and a burning feeling down there.  The second midwife showed up at 12 pm and at 12:18 (only 5 pushes!) my son was born.  LESS than 3 hours.  I would DEFINETLY go with a home birth again!  Especially in water.



I have also heard that birthing centers are kind of like home away from home.  I've also heard that they are very nice.  I never liked the hospital and I loved to have my baby at home.  Everyone left within two hours and I got to sleep in my own bed and move around my own house and take care of my baby without all the nurses poking and proding me every few hours and doing things to my baby.



EDIT:  Just a statistical fact for those that say homebirth is unsafe:  MORE than 90% of the people in the world are BORN at home!  It's only in the Western world, Australia and some of Europe where women ACTUALLY go to a hospital to have a baby.



Source(s):



Hospital birth with Phoenix Alexandria, 23 months.
Home water birth with Carl Edward John, 10 days.



</answer>

<answer>



Only your doctor would know for sure.  You haven't had any cramping so that's good, but you need some blood work and possible an ultrasound to know for sure what is going on.  If you had a miscarriage it would be heavy bleeding-like a heavy period.  Spotting does not necessarily signify a miscarriage.  Call your OB so you know for sure. Good luck!

<answer from>



usi_gal
Member since: 07 June 2006
Total points: 2440 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to contact your OB's office. When I miscarried at 7 1/2 weeks it was nothing like a period or spotting. I woke up in severe pain. It felt like someone was repeatedly stabbing me in the stomach and I could barely even walk and I couldn't stand up straight. I went to the bathroom and as soon as I looked down I noticed there were pools of bright red blood and tissue everywhere. I was bleeding through a heavy pad in less than an hour for over 8 hours. My husband took me to the emergency room where they did an exam and saw that my cervix was open and an ultrasound that showed that the baby indeed did not have a heartbeat and that I hadn't passed everything on my own. The very next morning I had to have an emergency D&C to clear my uterus and control the bleeding and pain.



With my current pregnancy I started having severe cramping and heavy bleeding at 5 1/2 weeks and I thought for sure I was miscarrying again. I didn't take any chances and I immediately called my OB's office and he told me to come in right then for an ultrasound. At that point they saw the gestational sac and the yolk sac and it measured perfectly to 5 1/2 weeks. They measured my HCG levels for a week or so and did another scan at 6 weeks and 1 day where we saw the baby and its heartbeat.



Just because you are spotting or bleeding some it doesn't mean that you are miscarrying or are going to miscarry, but it does mean that you need to get checked out as soon as possible.



Good luck to you.



Source(s):



36 weeks and 6 days with baby girl after 1 previous miscarriage at 7 1/2 weeks.



</answer>



<answer from>



Juice XxX
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 131 (Level 1)

Just try not to worry chick!

Susan86

<answer>



If you just had your period and it was heavy, it is unlikely that you are pregnant unless something went wrong with the pregnancy and you had a miscarriage. Stress can also affect your body, these symptoms do not necessarily mean that you are pregnant. If you have medical problems, you should go see a doctor and they can give you an answer. In theory, you can take a pregnancy test after your period is missed but this wasn't so I don't think it would show much. If your symptoms get serious, go to the doctor.



</answer>



<answer from>



edℜos...

well the pill is usually 99% safe if you use them correctly, thus take them more or less at the same time every day... please be aware that if you had been having diaroerah or vommiting then obviously the pill also might lose effect if it didn't stay enough in your system.

now stress from not getting your period might result in the delay of your period itself...



head aches bloatedness and heartburn are also common symptoms in side effects of the pill.



your last period wasn't even 2 weeks ago.... so might be early to tell.... make sure you didn't miss a day when you started taking the pill again after the break...

<answer>



Pregnancy lasts for 40 weeks. However the baby could arrive 2 weeks before or after your due date - this is absolutely normal. Conception is somewhere between January 15 to January 23, 2008. Go to :-
http://www.baby2see.com/conception_calcu...
And work it out hun x. Good Luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Military Family
Member since: 20 August 2008
Total points: 177 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



38 weeks prior to your due date.



In the United States, Dr's consider a pregnancy to be 40 weeks.  They go back 2 weeks prior to the date of your conception, so the dating is typically from the first day of your last period (it's just an old school method that has never changed).  So, you actually get pregnant 10-14 days after the first day of your last period; THAT is when conception occurs, hence the subtracting 38 weeks from your due date.



From what I calculated, your conception was on 1/19 (give or take a few days, because sperm can live inside for a while before fertilizing)



Source(s):



8 month old son, and 16 weeks pregnant with boy #2!!



</answer>



<answer from>



SydneyMu...
Member since: 13 February 2007
Total points: 14966 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



It's the due date minus 266 days.



Source(s):



RN Midwife IVF Consultant and mother of 7



</answer>

We are both worried about miscarriage and the risks that flying may potentially increase the chances.

<answer>



You are fine to fly. I am flying at 36 weeks (that is the latest I can fly without a doctors certificate)



</answer>



<answer from>



Anita
Member since: 07 August 2007
Total points: 241 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your fine...I wouldn't think twice about flying during my first trimester. Just realize that she may get more motion sick than usual if she is having morning sickness to start with. Also you can not take Dramamine or other motion sickness pills. When I have flown while pregnant I use sea bands, the little wrist bands that put pressure on your wrist to control nausea. They work great for me. I have flown twice while pregnant in my second and then again in my third trimesters. If you are too worried talk to her doctor but I am sure he/she will encourage you to go ahead with your plans and enjoy your trip. Also for pregnant women the risk of blood clots is always elevated so it would be wise for your wife to make a few trips up and down the isles just to get the blood circulating. Good Luck. Have fun and don't stress the real stress is yet to come...like when you fly WITH the baby!! LOL



</answer>



<answer from>



M J
Member since: 18 March 2008
Total points: 181 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The best thing to do is consult your wife's doctor. Every woman is different and her pregnancy is different. I had plans to fly in my third trimester, which the my doctor said was fine at the beginning of my pregnancy. But I developed pregnancy induced high blood pressure during my third trimester and had to cancel my trip. So, you just never know.I've had friends who flew in both their first and third trimester with no problems at all. Your doctor can help give you the best assessment. best of luck to you...this is such an exciting time in your life..enjoy every minute!



</answer>

<answer from>



rd
Member since: 13 October 2006
Total points: 335 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Flying while in the first trimester shouldn't be a problem but it is important for your wife to keep really well hydrated and wear flight socks. She should also try and walk around on the flight as pregnant women are at a slightly higher risk of developing a blood clot.



The other thing you both need to think about is if something were to happen, are you happy with the health services of the country you are flying to?
Hope this helps and you have a nice time.



</answer>

<answer>

With this one , #2, I've been so sick and had so many different aches & pains that I've been fairly miserable this whole pregnacy.  I actually don't have any swelling this time, and I look way better than I did with #1, but I feel like crap most of the time.  I don't think I could give you a date when it actually started, but I'm sure it was around the time I realized that my morning sickness was going to last well into my 2nd trimester this time around rather than ending at 16 weeks like it did the first time.  It has been down hill since then.  As much as I am so glad to be having this baby and can not wait to hold him in my arms, I will never go through this again, and if my first pregnancy had been like this one, my first born may have been an only child.

<answer>



With my first pregnancy I was sicker than a dog for the first 3 months and then felt great until about 2 months before I gave birth. I had trouble sleeping because I could not seem to get comfortable and I also had bad headaches,  swelling in my feet, and felt like I was not going to stop leaking urine and having to go to the restroom. With my second pregnancy I was not sick once, felt great the whole time. Did get uncomfortable at the end because of not being able to sleep and the urine irritation. I would say probably the last month or two you should be feeling different, less comfortable, more irritated with your uriation and bowel movemnts, and feeling super fatigued. Your feet do swell, but mine didnt with the second pregnancy because I was very active, is what I think it was. It may all hit at once or it may take its time and one thing will hit then another. Good luck to you!

<answer from>



VixenMom
Member since: 13 June 2006
Total points: 2027 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



In another 3-4 weeks (at about 35 wks) is when it started getting bad for me.  You start getting bigger in the belly due to the baby putting on weight (and if you're a thin person, it becomes uncomfortable because you don't think you can stretch any more).  The peeing was my worst part.  Seemed like every 15 minutes, I had to go... only to get a couple of drops out... and then it would all start again.  The worst is at night when you're trying to get some sleep and have to keep getting out of bed to go pee (Brrr... especially during the winter months).  The baby gets less and less room to move around, so all the jerky jabs sometimes hurt.  My son barely bothered me... but my daughter was like an alien and kicked me in the ribs alot.  People would see her moving in my belly and were shocked... but it made for interesting conversation.
Sleeping can be very rough... I recommend lots of pillows to put between your knees, behind you to prevent from rolling back, and one to hug in front of you.  I slept with 4-5 pillows every night to keep me snuggled and in one position.
I never had any swelling of the feet... but did experience knee pain from varicose veins.



At the end of the day... all the discomfort you'll feel is nothing compared to the breast pain you'll go through when your milk comes in.  That too shall pass.  Don't be scared about any of it, because it always sounds worse, and you can drive yourself crazy trying to anticipate what and how and when.  You'll deal with it when it happens... and you'll eventually realize that it the whole scheme of things... all this discomfort is nothing compared to how crazy they'll drive you when they're out and walking and talking.
I delivered both my kids drug free and always chuckled that the labor was more tolerable than the few weeks before giving birth.  I had both of my kids 12 days early... and it wasn't soon enough for me.



Good luck... and try to make the best of it.  There's not much you can do to change what will happen (and no, it doesn't all hit at once... thank god), but it's how you choose to deal with it that makes the difference.



</answer>

<answer>



The best thing you can do right now is to back off and give her some space.  Two months isn't a very long time for a relationship, especially when you suddenly add an unexpected pregnancy when you've hardly had time to get to know each other.  You may like her a lot, but she is trying to come to terms with the fact that her life has officially changed forever.  She has to come to terms with the fact that you and she will always have a common link through that child even if the relationship between you two doesn't work out in the end.  She is probably also processing things about you that she may not have cared about when you two were just going out but which change everything when she has to think about the well being of the baby.  So give her space, give her time, and let her set the pace for your relationship for now.  You still need to be there for her, emotionally and possibly financially, but meanwhile, just give her time.



</answer>

<answer>



If this is her first child, she is having to cope with a lot of emotions at this point. Not to mention she may not be feeling too well, along with being extremely exhausted and of course feeling somewhat stressed. You should definitely give her time and space to work it out for herself, so she can decide just what kind of support she needs from you.



My husband and I went through something similar with our first son, and I discovered that for a first time mother, it's not always easy to properly communicate the variety of emotions your experiencing, but it truly helps to listen and make sure she understands that you're here for her, whenever and however she needs you.



Things will get better as long as you both keep communicating honestly with each other and always remember why you came together in the first place! You're bringing a new life into the world, and that baby's health and well-being is the most important factor, so the less stress for her is all the better for the baby.



Good luck!

bubbaboo...

<answer>



If you had a miscarriage at 8 weeks preg you would know and have to visit the hospital or see a doctor.
Maybe you weren't pregnant at all and just thought you were cuz you missed a period?
The blood test you are taking ...whats it for?  you say everything but truthfully the doc will only mark certain things to be tested for and pregnancy might not be one of them
Ask the doc if they check hcg.
It depends if you did miscarry or not, you can still have some bleeding during pregnancy and be ok, the test if it's 2 weeks from now may not show it.
The hormones decrease every 48 hours, when I miscarried I had to be retested every 48 hours to be sure that they went down and it was a miscarriage consisting of all of the baby



Good luck!



</answer>

But to answer your other question... my hormones (hcg) did not return to normal until almost one and half months afterwards.  The numbers took that long to go back down.

<answer>

<answer from>



Boo Bear
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It could be quite possible that you did pass the baby. I have had three miscarriages and after the first time I had one my doctor told me that in most of the early miscarriages the baby disappears back into the uterus and is then undetected on ever being pregnant or that you will pass the baby and it will look that of a blood clot. Sometimes you can be told that you were pregnant after miscarriage sometimes you can not. I would go to a doctor and have them valuate the situation. Some woman do bleed during their pregnancy like they were having their period.



</answer>



<answer from>



cp04
Member since: 24 May 2008
Total points: 934 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Before I had my miscarriage I had spotting, then a few days later I had brown blood every day for like 2-3 days, then I started losing blood clots, (the actual miscarriage).  Miscarriage is different from a period, because you lose blood clots (decent size ones).  When you go for your blood work in two weeks it won't show up, as long as it was actual miscarriage.  The only way it will show up is if you didn't lose the baby and you are still pregnant.  Normally they have you come in in two weeks after a miscarriage to test, to make sure you aren't still pregnant, especially since there have been cases of people losing a twin, but one baby is still fine and healthy.  But to say the least, if you truly had a miscarriage then there is still a possibility that it will show up.  Just because every person is different, and the amount of time you were pregnant and hcg levels (how high they were) and how slow they drop make a difference.  So it could show up.



</answer>

Mrs. Mendoza

</answer from>



<answer>



I've seen the drano test done at babyshowers...someone other than the pregnant woman should always do the test for you AWAY from you!  This is because it is very toxic.  Basically you pee in a cup and then someone adds about 1tbsp of drano crystals.  Based on the color and the amount of foam they'll predict the gender.  Of course its only about 50% chance it's correct.



At one baby shower, my mom did it for 3 pregnant women there.  One of them had results that for sure indicated girl so the mom went out to buy all kinds of girl and pink stuff.  Turns out it was a boy.



I'd say have someone do it for fun, but don't rely on it.



Source(s):



Personal experience.



</answer>
