<question from>



Kel..will be a mommy on Sunday!
Member since: 30 October 2007
Total points: 4548 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Why does everyone say an induced labor is worse?



They still offer you the same pain medications right? I'm planning on having an epidural and being induced Sunday.



</question>



<answer from>



Kitty
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 270 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



b/c sometimes your body doesn't react the way they want it to and it could cause a c-section and or a long drawn out labor.  they still offer the medications but you have to dialate more before taking them i think, b/c they can slow the process down alone



</answer>



<answer from>



Adriana's Mommy
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 1651 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



I was induced with my daughter. The reason why it is so much harder is the drug Pitocin that they use to induce your labor. The contractions are much harder and you often do not have a break in between. I had as many as 4 contractions in a row. Yes, you can still have an epidural. I had an epidural and it didn't take, so I ended up having natural childbirth. Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



trynitis...
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 207 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



nothings wrong with it. i was induced and it was all normal. Relax, and good luck:)



</answer>



<answer from>



Starsfan...
Member since: 19 January 2007
Total points: 9926 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The big difference is that it labor progresses faster generally with induction.  So your body has less time to adjust to the faster increasing pressure.  Induction don't make your contraction harder, they just tend to feel more painful because of this faster paced labor.



You can get an epidural and everything just like natural labor.  So you shouldn't need to worry.  However, you might want your epidural a little sooner than a person going into labor naturally.  Congratulations on your up coming bundle of joy.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kaylee
Member since: 04 June 2008
Total points: 340 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes. its just not the natural way.



</answer>



<answer from>



Emily E
Member since: 22 August 2007
Total points: 6458 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because anytime you force the body to do something, it doesn't always work right.  Contractions come on hard and fast unlike natural contractions.  Your body doesn't kick in its natural reactions to labor and delivery as it is not a natural delivery.  Usually pain medications slow down or stop an induced labor, then they have to give you more medication to override the pain meds!  Your body just isn't given the time it needs to do all that is does during labor.  And often times it puts the baby into stress, low heart beat, and then you have to do a c-section! It is a mess and best to go natural when you can!



</answer>



<answer from>



Due February 22nd ♥
Member since: 14 March 2008
Total points: 6372 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Because it's not your body going into labor naturally, it's being forced to.. the contractions come at you much harder then they would if labor was naturally progressing.



Source(s):



http://guideonpregnancy.blogspot.com/
Great site for us pregnant women, those TTC, and those who are just curious!



</answer>

<question>



12 days late on my period,negative tests, but have symptoms?



neg blood test, but I have pregnancy symptoms, if pregnant, I would be almost 6 weeks so I am sure that the blood test would pick up hcg if I was, but the weird thing is that I am never late and I have the same symptoms as I did with #1, mild low back pain for 3 days now and mild cramping, dishcharge and sore boobs, doc said to take another blood test next week.  Also last night during sex there was a burning feeling down there, afterwards it was a bit sore and when I wiped I saw very little light red blood.  I have no idea what is going on with  my body.  Pregnant? Uti? So confused, almost 6 weeks since last period.



</question>

<answer>



you just described all the symptoms of PMS...pregnancy tests are usually pretty right on. Test in the morning when you wake up. the box says to do that. a late period and symptoms like that could just mean you're not giving your body enough TLC...eat right, stop stressin', exercise, sleep well, these things keep your clock right. If you don't get it in another week and keep testing negative go to the doctor again.



peace.



</answer>

<answer>



It's very possible. But don't worry, there isn't anything a labor and delivery nurse hasn't seen... They'll whisk it away before you even realize it's there.



One way to get around it is to take an enema when you realize your in labor. They used to be routinely given in the hospital when a laboring mom came in, but the practice is going out of style. And it doesn't mean you won't end up "pooing" anyways.

Doula and in nursing school to become a midwife

wylde95



A.R.T.
Member since: 31 May 2007
Total points: 13933 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Like everyone else said, yes it can happen. But that's not why they don't let you eat solid food. The reason for that is so you don't vomit, if you need pain meds or an epidural these things can make you nauseous. Also if you end up needing a C-section, they don't want you eating just like before any surgery. So the not eating is preventative for other reasons.
And as for getting diarrhea befor labor, well I was actually constipated, and they gave me an enema. Not only so I wouldn't poo, but because being constipated would have made the labor more uncomfortable.



</answer>

<answer>



In the UK, that would considered direct sex discrimination.  An employer cannot under any circumstances fire you for being pregnant.  If you are in the US however, I don't know.  I can only imagine that it is also illegal given that you have good employee protection laws there too.



Also, what a horrid guy he must be.



</answer>

<answer from>



violet
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 6314 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Teen & Preteen



Parenting



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



It is usually illegal to fire an employee because she is pregnant. But in some jobs, there may be exceptions.  If the job involves physical risk to a pregnant woman, the employer is supposed to reassign her to different duties, but that isn't always possible.



If pregnancy is treated the same as any other physical condition that prevents an employee from doing their job, then it may not be illegal.  For instance, if an employer would let someone go because they broke their leg and couldn't work, then I believe it is also legal to do the same in case of pregnancy.  It depends on the job.



The other issue is whether you can prove that pregnancy was the reason why you were fired. If they can document any other reason, such as poor work performance, absenteeism, or insubordination, they may get away with it.



If you feel you were discriminated against, it would be worth consulting an attorney who specializes in employment cases or going to your local equal opportunity office (if one exists).  Most attorneys will give you a free initial consultation, and then you can decide if it's worth pursuing a lawsuit.



</answer>



<answer from>



witherin...
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 1454 (Level 3)



</answer from>

<answer from>



Due December 1st With A Girl~*
Member since: 13 May 2008
Total points: 1942 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeah, he can't do that. You need to call the Better Business Bureau; if you look in the phone book, it should be there. If you can't find the number, you need to look online, or look online for your local unemployment agency and file a claim with them. How long have you been at your job? What kind of a place was this, a factory? A store? If you haven't been there long enough to draw unemployment benefits, you can still get him in trouble and probably get some kind of monetary compensation. This is very unfair and you've got to do something to let him know you are not going to just let him fire you over being pregnant; that's illegal and it's discrimination!



</answer>



<answer from>



kat
Member since: 07 June 2006
Total points: 13288 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



He cannot fire you for being pregnant.  You can sue him for discrimination if he does.  What reason did he give you for firing you, and does he have any documentation?  Most of the time an employer will need to have some sort of written documentation.  For example if you are consistently late to work, or miss work and they have called you in to talk about it they should have put something in your personnel file showing that there were problems and that you were aware of the problems and that you did not remedy the problems.  Or if they have told you that you need to increase your sales by 25%  by a certain date and you didn't do it.  If you really think that he fired you because you are pregnant and he didn't give you a good reason then you should talk to a lawyer about it.



</answer>

<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



hi even i hv missed my period for 3 months....... i still got pregnant about a month ago..... its better to wear a condom.......... but as far as i know........you dont hv to worry coz the sperm will die in 48 hours n it was not ur ovulation period too........any how better you do ur pregnancy test if you miss ur period next month......tc bye



</answer>

thanks



</asker's comment>



<comments>



lola



there is always a possibility of getting prego. always use protection. good luck



</comments>



<answer from>



kiwigirl...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Probably not. Obviously, as you got your period, you are not now pregnant.



Most people have a ripe egg (called ovulation) about fourteen days after the start of their last period. For 3-4 days either side of that Day 14, you're highly likely to conceive. Before and after that time you're technically safe, but absolutely not guaranteed!



Probably a greater concern is the risk of sexually transmitted disease.



Source(s):



I am a registered nurse, with years and years of experience in a family practice.... and everyone thinks an accidental pregnancy won't happen to them!



</answer>



<answer from>



Aurorali...
Member since: 12 October 2008
Total points: 595 (Level 2)



</answer from>

for the 101th time if you have sex you could get pregnant. it does not matter what day it is you still could. And if you did not use protection your chances are higher... pulling out does not work im a mother of a 1 month old boy now because that is what i did



so please use a condom.



</answer>

<question>



I feel pregnant but the test says no, what's up with that?



Ok, here are my symptoms:



-I'm tired ALL the time
-I yell at my husband for NOTHING
-My breasts hurt, have new stretch marks and I can see the veins, and I never could see them before
-I am craving the weirdest things, especially apple juice and ranch dressing.  And the other night all I wanted was tomato soup and I hate tomatoes.
-Dispite drinking my weight in apple juice every day, I am so constipated.
-On Sunday night, I had killer cramps, which I have only ever gotten on my period
-I have heartburn
-Food , sometimes even the smell of food, makes me nauseous
-I am getting car sick all the time, even if I am driving
-I am having major headaches



All this being said, you would think that the pregnacy test would come up with a flaming "YES" in 10 seconds.  But it is coming up negative, but I have taken 2 in the past 2 days.  The one I took yesterday was a very very faint line, but the test today had nothing. (Note that I took 2 different brands.)  So what is going on?  Should I wait a couple weeks and try again or make an appointment with my OBGYN? This is my husband's and my first baby, so I have no idea what is going on.  Please help!!!



</question>



<answer from>



Brittany
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 470 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, make an appointment. Most likely they will draw your blood for more accurate results.



</answer>



<answer from>



Stephanie H
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 835 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I know what you mean, I knew I was pregnant even though I kept getting negatives.  The test you took with a faint line, if that line was one of two then you are pregnant.  It doesn't matter how bright or faint the line is, if it is there at all then you are pregnant.  Congrats lil' mommy!  Next step is to make an appointment with your OBGYN.  On your first visit they will give you another test to make sure.  Good luck!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Due June 9/09 with #4 & LUVIN IT
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 3018 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



As long as the controller line was visible, if you got a very faint line, you are pregnant. Congratulations. If you want to be positive, wait a couple of days and test again. It will come up dark. When i tested to see if I was pregnant, the line was so faint that I had to hold it in certain lights to see it. I even thought that maybe I was imagining it because it was so faint. But I am pregnant!



Source(s):



baby #4 on the way



</answer>

If you got a faint line you are def pregnant, any type of line is a positive! The line for me was so faint I almost dismissed it as me not being pregnant, but waited a few days and the line was little darker, I am now 30 weeks prego. Good Luck!

<answer>



I also had my first son on his due date at 4:21am.  My second son was born 2 days before his ultrasound due date and 4 days before the LMP due date.  After that, I had a scheduled c-section at 38 weeks and 5 days, so that doesn't really count.



I've also heard that your first baby is usually your longest labor and those after are often a bit shorter.  I think I read it in "What to Expect when you're Expecting."  Go check it out.



Good luck and congrats!

<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 30376 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



The failure rate for withdrawal is around 20%.  Which means that in 100 couples using the method for a year, about 20 will become pregnant.



By contrast, the failure rate for condoms (used carefully/correctly) is about 2%.  For pills it's about 1%.  (And if you use no method at all, about 80% will be pregnant.)



So, while withdrawal is better than nothing, it's far from a reliable method -- there are many better options available.



</answer>



<answer from>



Joey
Member since: 24 April 2006
Total points: 845 (Level 2)



</answer from>

<question from>



dma

</question from>



<question>



Getting a physical after pregnancy?



Hi,
So I had my last physical when I was 25 and everything came back great. I am 28 now and going to have my first baby in a few weeks (or sooner). I think I should go get another physical but no sure how long to wait after the baby is born and I go back to my normal exercise and eating like a non pregnant woman routine. How long did you wait?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



You should get a physical every year. Since you'll be followed up by an OB-Gyn after your delivery, I would wait about 6 weeks (when the OB-Gyn is supposed to give you a clean bill of health) and then have my physical.



</answer>

Before i found out i was pregnant my boobs where my first sign - they were hurting and they started getting bigger.



I did a test the day before my period was due but it wasnt till the end of that week i started being sleepy more.

As for ur bladder - mine didnt kick off till i was around 8 weeks - gets worse the bigger u get.
I cant go anywhere without going the loo first and even then i need to go again after i have locked the front door lol.



Hope ur pregnant hun and good luck.

<answer>



The sleepy thing usually hits you the hardest. I slept so much people thought I was hibernating. As far as running to the bathroom this early, I dont know because the baby isn't big enough to push on your uterus. Like now I'm 14 wks and the baby isn't that big, but when I drink fluids, depending on where and how I'm sitting I will go every 30 to 45 mins. That's how long it takes fluid to travel through you. Thats why if your going to get an ultrasound, you should be done way before you get to the doctor. Being hungry, yes. If your appetite has picked up more than normal, chances are you could be. Hope for the best.

<answer from>



Adriana's Mommy
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 1711 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



It is a possibility. Your hormones are going crazy in the beginning of your pregnancy. Common symptoms women have are..



-Increased/decreased appetite
-frequent urination
-constipation
-fatigue
-light headed/dizzy
-bloated
-mood swings
-swollen or tender breasts and nipples
-darker nipples.



</answer>

<answer>



There are two issues here: your mistake in not being diligent in taking your birth control pills, and his reaction to it.



Now, I have some sympathy for him on the first front - if the two of you are relying on the pills for your birth control needs (though it sounds like you're using condoms as a backup), then you are required to be responsible about taking the pills.  There are a lot of unwanted pregnancies resulting from women who "accidentally forgot" to take the pill for a few days.  He is justified in being a bit upset there.



HOWEVER . . .



Getting "really angry" and berating you for it is not exactly the behavior you'd expect from someone who (presumably) claims to care for you.  From that, he sounds like a bit of a jerk.  Whether he's a congenital jerk or was just a jerk in that one stressful moment is something you'd know better than anyone here.



What you need to do is talk to him about this - acknowledge your mistake, but make sure that he knows that you don't think his reaction was appropriate.  Don't just wait for him to talk.  And, if he really is a jerk, don't feel the need to stay with him just because you've been together for a long time.  I've seen this in many friends, and seen that staying with someone who treats you poorly is worse for your mental health than just being alone.



Again, I'm not saying that he is a jerk - you have to judge that for yourself.  If he's not, then he'll listen when you have your talk.  If he doesn't, then that should be a red flag for you.



</answer>



<answer from>



csbiup
Member since: 30 March 2006
Total points: 2920 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I did forget to take my pills and got pregnant.  I knew I could get pregnant, but somehow didn't think it would happen, and in the moment really didn't care.



My husband and I laugh now that I "tricked" him into being a dad.  Maybe I did, but we're both extremely excited for our new baby.



I guess that's what 10 years of maturity and being with the right guy looks like.



Let him know that you won't trick him and you will let him know if you've missed pills so that he can use a condom.  The responsibility of birth control can't fall entirely on you and he needs to know that it's hard to remember to take a pill every day.  You'll try your best, but there will be times you'll let him know to use a backup method.



</answer>

Are there any positive stories about labor when you get induced?

<answer>



I got induced! It was fine...once i got my epidural i flew through it...It was a long labour, but i can honestly say i have no complaints.  It was my first baby too.



It was not scary, and my boyfriend was great with me through every second of it, that made such a big difference!



I would do it again in the morning if i had to...and no, im not one of those airy-fairy hippy people who think birth is an amazing life changing thing. Im a normal girl who was scared of her life of it!



dont worry, everyone is different, dont listen to other peoples horror stories! My daughter is 4 months now..



</answer>

You must be kidding**
Member since: 08 February 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



Hi sweetheart!



I was induced with 2 of my babies and I guess, since it's the only way I've ever delivered- I don't see what's so "awful."



I didn't have an epidural with either baby, went 100% natural and yes, it was painful, but it was such a small amount of time I didn't mind it. It wasn't scary for me at all. With each of my kids, once I got the pitocin my contractions picked up like crazy and they were painful, but I don't think they were any stronger than the contractions I was having at home.



The only super painful time was right before I needed to push and during pushing...and I'm pretty sure that's going to be painful no matter what!



Don't worry about getting induced...labor is labor and it's different for everyone. That's why some women swear by epidurals and some women refuse them. Some women have 3 hour labors and some have 30 hour labors....you'll see it's not scary any way you have it. You'll be taken care of, baby will be taken care of and it'll be over before you know it!!



Lots of luck and love sugar. xxx



</answer>

<answer from>



Beth
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 987 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've been induced twice, with my 2nd son it was horrible and ended in what I completely believe was an unneccessary csection due to the induction.  With my 3rd son I wanted a VBAC but he didn't do so well on a NST so they decided to induce me the day before my due date but they did it differently this time.  The used Cervail which ripens, softens and prepares your cervix for labor, doesn't really induce you, doesn't start contractions, just prepares your body for when they will give you pitocin.  Well that alone put me into labor but they did still use a bit of pitocin and that labor and delivery went great, couldn't have been better.  In the matter of 1hr and 43min I went from being 4cm to 10 and delivering him :)



But really if possible I would try and avoid being induced medically, maybe try some at home stuff, lots of walking and sex.  If you do have to do it medically I would really ask about the cervadil first.  Why do they want you do deliver before your due date?



</answer>



<answer from>



newcastl...
Member since: 20 March 2008
Total points: 509 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I basically got induced last Friday. My body went to 4 cm, but that's as far as I would go on my own. I showed up at the hospital at 8:30 am. They checked me in and got me comfortable. I watched some TV and wrote in my pregnancy journal. Just relaxing. They started Pitocin by 10 (I had a side effect of getting the "shakes" when I wasn't having a contraction....not a big deal) and the contractions weren't that bad (my pain tolerance may be a little high from some past experiences, but really it was no worse than your monthly friend)! The epidural came at 12:30 (the most painful part of the whole experience) and they broke the bag of waters by 2. My family was in and out, as well as my hubby. Everything was completely relaxing and exciting at the same time. At 3:50 they brought the doctor in and I started pushing. My beautiful baby boy was born at 4:13. I was so scared of labor and the induction (etc) that I thought when the time came I would be a horrible mess. In reality? It was an amazing experience (my first child BTW) and I would do it all over again.......not right now though because I still feel like I have been riding a horse for a couple days! It isn't painful, just sore! I wouldn't worry about it at all. Even if it does hurt, you won't even feel a thing once that baby is crying and you get to hold it for the first time!



Source(s):



Just had my first baby boy 10/24/08.



</answer>



<answer from>



46days* ~till induction~ *YAY*
Member since: 21 February 2008
Total points: 21583 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Parenting



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



On a 1-10 scale, it was about a 7 for me. I didn't have an epidural though. It was NOTHING near as bad as I thought it would be. I didn't really have major pain until the last 1-2 hours of labor as the baby made it's way down to crown. I was induced with pitocin with both of mine, and will be this time as well. I loved it, and have no complaints at all. Short easy labors and deliveries.



Labors were from first contraction:
8hrs45mins, pushed 2 times (slept 6 hours of that)
5hrs20mins, pushed 3 times (slept 3 hours of that)



Source(s):



Will have had all 3 of my kids via induction.



</answer>



<answer from>



VixenMom
Member since: 13 June 2006
Total points: 2041 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Mine was great.  I got induced because my first child was 12 days early... and I had a fairly quick labor.  So for my second (and since my doctor would be out of town when I was due) we decided to induce to avoid the possibility that I would go into labor too fast to make it to the hospital.  So... I heard stories that it would hurt more and bla bla bla.. and was worried myself.  They broke my water at 9:00 am... and I asked not to have the pitocen (not sure if I spelled that right) to see if I would start contractions naturally.  I put in a house/techno CD and started dancing around the room... in about 10 minutes I started contracting... and continued dancing through all my contractions (of course you stop and buckle over when the actual contraction comes on and stay in that position until it passes) as best as I could up until 10:55 am when I had the urge to push.  5 minutes later, my daughter was born.  I highly recommend induction if the baby is fit to come out and you want to deliver.  It all hurts no matter what, but don't be afraid of the induction itself.  I would definitely recommend trying to contract on your own before resorting to meds... and dancing and jumping around definitely helps bring that on.  My first pregnancy, I laid in the hospital bed wrenching in pain and mangling the bed rails through each contraction... and couldn't believe how much more tolerable the pain was up on my feet and dancing around the room like I was at a night club.  I truly believe that it helped with the contractions and the quick labor/delivery.
If you're planning on using meds for pain, it may delay delivery in some people.  Everyone is different.  But it you're looking to get the absolute raw experience, I highly recommend drug free which is what I did with both my kids.  I know it hurts, but believe me... you will be able to make it through.  The best and least painful part (for me anyway) was the delivery.  Good luck and don't be scared.



</answer>



<answer from>



Delilah P
Member since: 12 June 2007
Total points: 424 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My experience wasnt that great, but i cant compare it to a natural birth with out being induced. I pushed for almost three hours with my daughter stuck. I had to have an episotomy and they used the suction too. I almost had to have an c section. I had an epidural which numbed that area but i had back labor and my contractions were so close that i did not have a break in between. I ended up having to wear an oxygen mask and my duaghter wasnt breathing right when she was finally born probably from being stuck so long they took her out of my room to care for her then once she was doing better they brought her back.



Everyone is different though. I had a healthy pregnancy and took care of myself maybe it was cause i am a rather small person and she was 8 lbs i know people have bigger but that was good sized for me



</answer>

<answer from>



_

</answer from>



<answer>



As long as the baby is healthy and your bleeding isn't crazy, you can be happy. I wanted to go home early so I could sleep in my own bed (I took some of the pads they use so you don't soak the bed with blood). YOu just have to relax and lay down at home, no one will force you to like in the hospital. If you feel like you need more care and/or aren't recovering well, I'm sure you can get help or have a nurse come to your house to check on you. I had a nurse come to my house and she checked the baby and me for signs of problems. It was also really nice to have someone come over... you start to feel like you're secluded from the rest of the world.



Try not to worry, after 24 hours you'll be very tired and want to go home. The only thing that bites about going home is that your baby has to sleep in the same place as you, you can't send them to the "nursery" at night like in the hospital. In the hospital they brought my baby in at 5 am and placed her in my arms while I was half asleep. I just wanted to return to normalcy! Good luck, you'll be fine!



</answer>

<answer>

I'm having a tubal the day after birth this time, and should be looking at another 48 hr stay if all goes well.



I wouldn't be worried.

<answer from>



Dianca H
Member since: 25 November 2007

</answer from>



<answer>



With my first child I stayed in the hospital for 48 hours. But when I had baby number seven it was much different. Three hours after I had him the nurses watched him while I ran home to check on the babysitter and the other children, I then took them to lunch before returning to the hospital. I felt amazing and the hospital stay wasn't needed.



Many women are different and in some cases like mine it depends on the birth experience. Mine were drug free which allowed me to get up and move around without being "out of it". Many women actually give birth at home these days with midwives. baby number eight will be born at home come March. For me, the hospital stay is pointless. but many women need that time and some births require it.



What is right for one woman isn't right for another. However, if you feel you might need the extra time there is nothing wrong with laying in your bed at home for an extra day.



Source(s):



18 weeks with number eight

<answer>



I would be concerned! According to the The Newborns' and Mothers' Health Protection Act of 1996 (NMHPA) you are entitled to stay up to 48 hours following a vaginal delivery or 96 hours following a delivery by Cesarean section, barring any complications.

<question>



Ok, I'm confused...when does the second trimester start?



Hi! Does the second trimester start at 12, 13 or 14 weeks? I'm really confused about that. I'm 13 weeks, so am I in my second trimester yet? And when does the third trimester start??



Thanks! :)



</question>



<additional details>



Oh dear! Everyone has such different answers.



</additional details>



<answer from>



_
Member since: 17 January 2008
Total points: 4375 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Some sites say one thing, some say the other. The first trimester is 13 weeks. So if you're 13 weeks (completed) you can say you started the second trimester. The third starts at 26 weeks.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sodas♥
Member since: 13 December 2006
Total points: 18086 (Level 6)



</answer from>

After the 12th week, so you are in your second trimester!! 28 weeks is the start of the third.

<answer from>



Dr. Diagnonsense
Member since: 08 July 2007
Total points: 20466 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



As far as I know, the second starts at 13 weeks & 1 day.



Remember that week 12 runs from 11 weeks & 1 day to 12 weeks. So week 13 is 12 weeks & 1 day to 13 weeks.



</answer>



<answer from>



darinats...
Member since: 03 September 2008
Total points: 1487 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Each trimester lasts 14 weeks for a total of 42 weeks, which is why the due date is commonly set at week 40.  So at 13 weeks, you have one more week of 1st trimester, then 14 weeks of 2nd and then 14 weeks or less of 3rd or until you deliver.



</answer>



<answer from>



Due June 9/09 with #4 & LUVIN IT
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 3219 (Level 4)



Contributing In:

yes you are in your second trimester. when you hit 12 weeks, you start your second trimester. In the book "what to expect when expecting" the third trimester starts at 28 weeks.

<answer>



13 weeks.



1-4 weeks and a couple days= 1 month
4-8 weeks and a few days= 2 months
9-12 weeks and a couple days= 3 months
It totals about 13 weeks if you add the extra days together.



My midwife and Your Pregnancy Week By Week said 13 weeks.

<question>



Pregnant bleeding, not from vagina?? TMI warning!?



Okay so I've noticed once in awhile after going to the restroom that when I wipe there is red blood on the tissue. However, it is NOT coming from my vagina...I've actually been in for spotting a few times before and everything checked out okay, so I'm wondering now if it was not coming from my vagina those times either...I plan to ask my OB since I have an appointment on Monday, but now I'm nervous to ask her since I don't want her to think all that testing was just for outer bleeding (i am a paranoid person though and will ask anyway to make sure). Since I have to wait till Monday I thought I'd see if anyone else had experienced this... Its usually either on the inside wall of my "lips" or around my clit area...and its usually after I wipe quite a few times (I keep wiping till all the discharge is gone...) so could this be what causes it to bleed? It's not painful...I'm just wondering if this is a symptom of something or I just need to stop wiping so much...also, it's not continuous, by the time I use the restroom again it will be gone. Thanks in advance, I'm already embarrassed for asking...lol. ~paranoid first time mommy~

Due February 22nd ♥

<answer>



Yes! I lost eight pounds in the beginning because I had constant morning sickness which I actually prefer to re-name, all day sickness. But.. as my first trimester ended and I began the second trimester, the sickness went away and now I am gaining weight like I should.



Source(s):



http://guideonpregnancy.blogspot.com/
Great site for us pregnant women, those TTC, and those who are just curious!



</answer>



<answer from>



shandwanda k
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes its very normal my sister is 8 months now and pretty big but at the beginning of her pregnancy she thought she wasn't pregnant because she lost so much weight but it was actually due to her hormones changing because of her pregnancy.

<question>



My periods after my second delivery started at 6months first one is normal but 2nd one is continuing for2weeks?



bleeding is little. im breast feeding my baby



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



It takes a while for your periods to become normal again - even when breastfeeding. I think mine were off for about 6 months or so. If you are concerned that something is wrong, you should call your OB/GYN just to make sure.



Take care and congrats!



</answer>

<answer from>



dma
Member since: 16 January 2008
Total points: 5315 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



totally normal.



if it helps talk to friends/family that have gone thru it. Also take a birthing class in the end of your 2nd trimester or beginning of your 3rd and get a tour of the labor and delivery floor you will be delivering on.



Read a book on what to expect if that will help, but keep in mind, EVERYONE's experience is different! Just because your friend had a great or horrible experience in no way means yours will be the same.



Relax and enjoy the next 9 months. You will be fine. Good luck



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer from>



PiNkPrIn...
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its very very nervous to think about it. To be honest, when I was getting closer to having my second child, I was even nervous about what to suspect during labor. For first time mothers, its perfectly normal to worry about it. It doesn't mean that your not "motherly" or un excited! Labor hurts and it can be very strenuous on you. Until you have expericenced it, you don't know what to expect. The channel that shows labor and delivery shows. Labor isn't always like that. Them shows scared the hell outta me, and it was nothing like that. When I was all done and my precious daughter was laying in my arms, you forget all about the pain you go through. You never forget, but its not something that's suppose to make a tragedy! You'll do great! But your not a bad mother b/c your scared or nervous about what labor is! Congrats on your new baby!



</answer>



<answer from>



tired n hungry
Member since: 02 September 2008

Oh and there is the element of the unknown which is always intimidating no matter what people say.Rregarding the maternal instinct, it will kick in when you're holding this tiny warm helpless angry little human being.
Good Luck with everything.

Congrats!!!

<answer from>



shes all that
Member since: 19 August 2008
Total points: 338 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



For baby:
- clothes to bring him/her home in (take two sizes in case your baby is bigger than expected - happened to me)
- blanket to wrap baby in when bringing home
- some disposable nappies but the hospital should have cloth nappies



For you:
- way more breast pads than you think you'll need
- way more underwear than you think you'll need and the bigger the better so they don't rub against what will now be a tender region
- notepad and pen to jot notes about babies feed times etc
- extra food (I was starving when my milk came in!)



</answer>

<answer>



Pack stuff that makes you comfortable.  Baby won't be wearing anything but hospital garb.  Make sure you pack an outfit for the ride home for the new little one.  I would'nt pack too much for the baby because the hospital is going to charge you for everything anyway, even if you don't use it.



I would pack myself a robe, plenty of pads, my OWN pillow, (maybe two), an extra blanket for myself and the usual, toothbrush, brush, make-up etc.



Congrats!  Looks like you won't be on the internet for a couple of days.  We will miss you in cyberworld!  Good luck.

<answer from>



Due 22Oct*
Member since: 04 March 2008
Total points: 611 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I know this might sound crazy, but Ive packed 3 bags!
Bag1: Labour Bag
birth plan, all paperwork needed by hospital, socks, old tshirt, lip balm, music/mp3, magazines, toiletries, cushion, labour bal, flask for ice, snacks, energy drinks, headband&pins, CAMERA/videocorder, essential oil (clary sage- helps with fear, camomile- helps with relaxation), first clothes for baby



Bag2: Hospital Bag
new sexy nighties + backup nighties, cute clothes for baby, blanket for baby, comfy flip flops/feetwear, make up, hairdryer, disposible maternity panties, maternity pads, breast pads, tissues, feeding bra, toiletries, nipple cream, cellphone, charger, socks, going home outfit



Bag3: Baby Bag
-Our hospital gives a complimentary bag with baby toiletries, nappies, wipes etc. so this is only a backup bag in case I want something extra for baby like baby oil, baby brush...



This way you dont have to pack one big bag, but can have 3 seperate ones.
Your hubby/partner can bring your hosp bag after labour, and put the labour bag in the car. The baby bag stays in the car, except for when you need something from it!



Good luck, hope this helps a bit!



</answer>



<answer from>



wendy080...
Member since: 25 April 2007
Total points: 7168 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Call  your hospital and find out what they provide first, but you will not need half of what most first time mother's bring with them (at least I didn't and will be packing much lighter this time).  Here are the things I actually remember needing and using:



1) toiletries - tooth brush/paste, lotion
2) socks - I don't know why, but cold feet tend to be a problem in labor
3) reading material - you will probably be in labor for a while before it is time to start pushing
4) bathrobe - only needed if you plan to walk around while in labor prior to getting an epidural
5) FOOD - I can't stress this one enough if your hospital is like mine and has a no eating from check-in until after delivery policy.  Not all hospitals do, but most have that policy and I had to make my husband sneak me food from the cafeteria throughout the day when the nurse wasn't looking.
6) Sanitary Pads - While you are in the hospital, you will want to use theirs because they are the super size industrial strength variety that you will still need to change every hour for the first day or two.  But you will want your own to go home in.
7) Phone/email list - Make sure you have the name and number of everyone your husband needs to call as soon as the baby comes.  Trust me, you will have too much on your mind to even remember your mother's phone number at that time.
8) cell phone or phone card - especially if any of the people from your list in #7 are long distance calls
9) Pillow - or whatever you need to rest comfortably
10) camera - to record the birth if you want that, and for taking pictures of the baby & you after even if you don't want to record the birth.
11) Going home clothing - for both you and the baby
12) Car Seat - hospital wont let you take the baby home without it.



Remind your husband to pack a bag too
1) change of clothing - you all might be there a few days
2) food - or money for the cafeteria just in case they don't feed him
3) money - parking, vending machine, etc.
4) Gift - After 9 months of pregnancy, and who knows how many hours of labor, & then pushing a water melon out of a 10 cm hole, you deserve a gift, and he deserves a smack if he doesn't get you one.



</answer>



<answer from>



4th & last, due 10/15!
Member since: 01 May 2008
Total points: 4488 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I always brought way more than I actually needed/used, so, this time, I'm packing light!



Heating pad



Squirt bottle and mini-fan. (I get hot, and these work wonders! And, keep me from fainting, while getting the epidural, if I get one, this time.)



An outfit for myself, for when coming home.



An outfit for baby's FirstPhoto, as well as an extra one, in case an accident happens. :)



Receiving blanket for baby.



My make-up... Yes, I always put it on, before leaving the hospital... Lip gloss is a must, cause my lips get chapped!



Hair tie, for when labor gets rough, and I want my hair our of my face.



A few movies to keep my kids (and myself, and hubby) occupied.



Massage lotion/oil



Deodorant



Toothpaste/toothbrush



My own shampoo/conditioner/soap.



Camera and batteries.



I think that's it! Of course, my older kids will be there, so I pack snacks for them, as well as my husband, and I bring some board games for them, too, cause they play them with their Grandmas, in the waiting room, during times they have to leave the room. :)



Good luck!! I need to pack, too...



</answer>

<question>



UTI's During Pregnancy?



Ok,  i know this may seem like an odd question but is it more common to get a UTI while pregnant?



It seems like every time I have sex with my hubby I get one!



</question>



<answer from>



Expecting in May 2009.
Member since: 09 June 2007
Total points: 3134 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, it is. Best make sure you pee right after sex and clean up with a warm washcloth to decrease the chances.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kell-o
Member since: 13 May 2008
Total points: 5816 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



They are, and you should call your dr if you think you have one.  You don't want it to get too bad.



</answer>



<answer from>



dma
Member since: 16 January 2008
Total points: 5338 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes it is more common. It is more difficult during pregnancy to fully empty your bladder, thus urine stays in there longer leading to more UTIs. You may also not have any symptoms.



</answer>



<answer from>

Everyone (female) seems to have them when they are pregnant.

<question>



Health and safety regulations in work while pregnant?



im 34 weeks pregnant and ders some road works going on outside my job, for the past few weeks at least one or two days a week we have been without water for the whole day and are expected to walk to the nearby hotel to use the loo! I really dont think i should be expected to walk over the road everytime i need to go which is a lot with the pressure on my bladder!! My company hasn even said anything to me about it and expect me to comply with this does anyone think this is totally unfair??



</question>



<answer from>



iluvjdee...
Member since: 07 June 2007
Total points: 2156 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, I think it's unfair.  How about a port-o-potty outside?  You might suggest that to them.  I wouldn't say that it's a safety issue or health.  Just an inconvenience.  Maybe it won't last long.



</answer>



<answer from>



Diann C
Member since: 11 November 2007
Total points: 7540 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



This may not be the answer that you want to hear, but they don't have to totally accommodate you.  They have to make sure that you are safe, not because you are pregnant, but because you work for them.  Other then that, they don't have to do anything extra for you.  The way they see it, you can either do your job while you are pregnant or you can't.  And if you can't, why are you there?
It doesn't sound fair, but what's to stop someone else from demanding special treatment too? Pregnancy is not a medical condition.



</answer>

<question>



Why do people ask if they "might" be pregnant?



Seriously.  Did you have unprotected sex?  Or protected and the condom broke?



Then YES, you might be pregnant!  Doesn't matter that you are on birth control or not.  I don't think that there is a single contraceptive out there that is 100% effective.  Maybe 99.9%, but no 100's.  Abstinence is 100% effective.



ok, I guess this is more of a statement then a question, but....



</question>



<answer from>



Due in May
Member since: 06 April 2007
Total points: 3786 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



LOL, you are right. If you suspect you might be pregnant than you might be. Why ask us? That's what we'll tell you is yes, you might be pregnant.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jeremy R
Member since: 25 April 2008
Total points: 5915 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer>

If you come in contact with a "peter" you have a chance of catching "peter poisoning" even if it was covered....lol.



I just don't think it sinks in with some kids--and some adults for that matter!!!

<answer from>



Stephanie H
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 835 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your ultrasound usually changes your due date, no big deal, and as for the heartbeat, you usually can't hear it until 7-8 weeks, even though they have one at 5 weeks.  What do you mean the bleeding stopped?  If there was a reason to be concerned your doctor would have talked to you about it. Good luck and Congrats!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Darcy
Member since: 22 May 2007
Total points: 12666 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Honestly at 6 weeks there should be a visible heartbeat with ultrasound.  Did they explain to you why they couldn't see one?  Why not call your doctor up and ask what this means for you?  No one can really tell you what is going on for sure, but you certainly have my best wishes.



Source(s):



Pregnant with baby boy #5



</answer>



<answer from>



Due February 22nd ♥
Member since: 14 March 2008
Total points: 6354 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't want to scare you but there's a possibility that you had a missed miscarriage. That is when a girl miscarries but the sac stays in place.. a heartbeat is lost or never detected and no more growth is continued. This is, of course, just one of many possibilities. Another possibility could be that your EDD is off.



Source(s):



http://guideonpregnancy.blogspot.com/
Great site for us pregnant women, those TTC, and those who are just curious!



</answer>



<answer from>



1st due 2nd May 2009
Member since: 25 February 2008
Total points: 273 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had a scan at 6 weeks and 5 days and you could see the heartbeat, what did your doctor say? How long have you been bleeding for, how heavy etc???



</answer>

<question>



Fact or Myth? Pregnancy and hair dye?



Is it harmful to your baby if you were to dye your hair? I it is and that it isnt as long as you dye away from the scalp.......any ideas...



</question>



<additional details>



lol  I noticed I forgot a word I meant to say



I heard it was and that it wasnt =D



wOw! Thanks for all the feedback I think I'll wait it out.



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It is perfectly ok!  However, you can not use the dyes out of the bottles, the chemicals are harmful to the baby.



You must have your hair dyed with professional hair dye.  The only time it is not good to dye your hair when you are pregnant is if you are high risk.  So make an appt and dye away!



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Answer: unknown



There’s no hard evidence to say it’s unsafe, but there’s also no way to be sure it’s completely safe. As many doctors will tell you to avoid it all together as will tell you don’t to worry about it.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It is fine to dye your hair while you are pregnant. I did it with both my pregnancies and my doctor gave me the OK as well.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I think it can be harmful to the baby because even if you dye it away from the scalp, you are still inhaling the chemicals which is the main thing that can be harmful to a baby. Not only that, I don't think the hair would look like being to different colors/tones. I think you are better to just wait until after you have the baby.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I think if you use the stuff that doesn't have ammonia in it then it's won't do anything to the baby



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



This was an issue for me as well. My doc said that there isn't any evidence about dying your hair in the first trimester, but to avoid any harsh bleaches or things that sit directly on your scalp. After the first trimester pretty much dye away, most over the counter products are a little less harsh these days. Just make sure you are in a well ventilated area. I just hit thirteen weeks and immediately called my stylist :) I can handle no coffee or wine, but I have to get my hair and nails done! Congrats!



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I have heard that dying your hair after your first trimester is typically ok. Getting highlights is better, since it's less dye and isn't put as close to your scalp. You also want to find a salon that is well ventilated so you aren't sitting there inhaling the ammonia fumes for hours on end.



The best choice is to dye hair with vegetable dye, which is entirely safe. You can call salons and see if they offer this service.



It's always safest to avoid these things during pregnancy if possible but you have to weight the potential risks against the potential benefits. I have decided not to dye my hair but have heard that after the first trimester it's ok to do.



Hope that helps!



</answer>

no answerer details

Contributing In:

Pregnancy



</question from>



<question>



37 weeks - Pregnancy induced Hydronephrosis of Kidney?



I was told yesterday my kidney infection they thought I had is not one after all and I have hydronephrosis of my right kidney.



Because I am too far pregnant for them to be able to stent my kidney, I am being induced next week.



In the meantime they have given me Panadeine Forte for the pain which is taking the edge off the pain but I am still in excruciating pain.



I can't stand, sit, lay down or anything without the stabbing pain through my right hand side. Even hot water in the shower is not working.



Has anyone had this or have any suggestion for a position to relieve some of the pain??



</question>



<additional details>



Once baby is born they will stent and and drain the kidney.



From what I have been explained, hydronephrosis of kidney is when the fluid goes back up into the kidney rather than drains, and causes the kidney to enlarge. It can cause it to go septic, cause permanent kidney damage or at worst cause renal failure.



And of course, the baby's arms and feet are all on my right side so everytime the baby moves my kidney takes a bashing!



MEPPA - Thanks... I declared my hubby slave this morning and told him that he just has to be the woman for now. The kids thought that was funny.



My son's birthday party is on Sunday so he is outside cleaning the deck & windows as we speak!



</additional details>



<answer from>



meppa30
Member since: 06 August 2007
Total points: 16996 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Oh Hun, this is turning out to be a bit of a drama isn't it.



Keep taking the panadeine fort as prescribed because it will have a cumulative effect and hopefully take the edge off that pain by the next dose you are able to take. I have no idea about what else you could do for the pain, maybe a cold compress instead of warm if your Doctor said it was ok. I wonder if deep heat or the equivalent would help, I know it isn't muscle soreness but it has a warming effect of the surrounding tissue. Take it easy and I hope your kids are behaving for you.



You need a slave to be at your beck and call just in case you do find a position to get a little bit more comfy. Maybe you could stand upside down with your head in a bucket?? lol.



Source(s):



Mum of 3



</answer>

<question>



Please answer...32 weeks pregnant,how well should baby be able to hear at this point?



Okay I know this is weird but.... I thought that my daughter at this time should be able to hear pretty well. But it worries me because loud noises and stuff like that don't startle her or anything. Does that mean that she may have a hearing problem? Because people are always saying how noises scared their baby... but she doesn't seem to react to them.... Should I mention this to my doctor.. or is this normal?



</question>



<additional details>



I think you guys are right...maybe I am just over thinking it.



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Babies ears develop and can hear from 27 weeks. However don't always react to startling noises. I found that it was familiar voices, sounds or music that they reacted to. I wouldn't worry though.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



My son never responded to loud noises and this one doesnt really either, or not that i have noticed.  They do a hearing test within a couple of days of the baby being born so i wouldnt worry about it.  A lot of the sounds in there are muffled because your heartbeat and the rush of blood and fluid around the body will be what she mainly hears (try putting your head under the bath water and getting someone to make a loud noise, it doesnt sound so loud under there).



Source(s):



mother of 4yr old boy with great (selective) hearing and 31wks with baby girl!



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



My first was a very mellow child inside and after he was born but as he's grown we have discovered he's autistic and actually has painfully hypersensitive hearing.  What I mean is that he certainly heard much more than an ordinary baby when he was inside me but just wasn't the type to react to it.  His brother and now sister on the way are jumpy sorts and you know everything they hear.  You know what my first is a sound sleeper and my second is a very light sleeper so it does tell you something just not necassarily about a hearing defect.



</answer>

<answer>



She can hear.  she is use to loud noises being inside you is not as quite as you think.  She hears your stomach grumble your heat beat all the swishing of blood and your voice.



Have you tried talking to her and seeing if she reacts or playing music. You might get more of a response to that then a random noise that was loud to you.  Because what's loud to you is not going as loud to her.



I think she is fine and you are over thinking.

<answer>



okay you maybe could be .



although your ovulation is the 26th of this month. most chances for you to get preggers. is approx 14 days after period. (first day) when the egg drops and wait to get fertilised inside.



6-12days after the 26th(ovulation) is when the egg will implant itself, meaning preggers. a blood test will be accuarate 1 week b4 the 9th of november.



sperm can stay alive for 24-48 hours inside depending on body temperture.you need to test on the 9th which is when ur period would be due.



so in few days is when you are releasing your egg, so have sex then..
there is a chance that u can become pregnant in few days.



good luck hope it makes sense for ya.

</answer from>



<answer>



Okay, relax. I've been there. Do you take regular sitz baths? Have you had your 6-week check-up yet? It is possible for those not to heal correctly, and perfectly alright for you to go see your doctor now, instead of waiting the full 6 weeks. I would recommend not to have sex until after the doctor gives the go ahead. Surgical incisions can take up to 2 months to heal, not counting any complications, which it sounds like you have.



</answer>



<answer from>



pipsquee...
Member since: 04 December 2007
Total points: 5315 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



You shouldn't even think about having sex until after your 6 week check up.



What you describe, that extra hole...red flag!  Are you having any extra/weird discharge?  Can you control your BMs?  I developed a fistula after my second child.  It was basically a part from my anus to just outside my vagina that didn't heal.  That's kind of big deal if that's what's going on.



But don't expect to be healed already.  It's a work in progress.



</answer>

MissRed

</answer from>



<answer>



I didn't have an episiotomy, however; I did tear during birth.  And the reason that they do episiotomies is because they are supposed to be less damaging than a tear and are supposed to heal better.



Since you didn't mention how far they had to go down, it is hard to say how fast it should heal - but a month definitely sounds too long.  Call your doctor immediately!!  Get it checked out, better to do that and have them tell you everything is fine than to wait and find out there is a problem.  The longer you wait the more it will heal in it's present state - and if the stitches slipped or something - it could be healing wrong.



CALL YOUR DOCTOR!!



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Darker blood during what?  During your period?



*Yes, its possible to have dark red blood during implantation.  No blood at all to heavy clots is normal.

Its normal to feel this way. Completely. Yes it is your responsibility to take care of your siblings while your parents can't , that is just a part of life. The fact that that kid wont see you much while its growing up wont matter, because of the difference in age between both of you ( 15 years) you wont have much to talk to him about, in fact you'll probably be what your dreading the most, a mother figure.



The thing is , that kid will bond and relate to the sibling closest in age, so yeah you'll love it, and yeah you'll have feelings for the little twerp but things are going to play out the way their going to play out, and life gets more complicated than this. So if you learn to handle situations like this you'll be better for it, you'll be stronger, and you'll also not be put into shock or break down in a crisis in your future.

<answer>



My mom also had a baby when I was a teenager (and I was an only child to that point). I promise it may seem bleak and it is perfectly normal to be upset about it (I cried for a weeek).



However it does get better. I actually found that my mom was even more attentive to me after my brother was born because she didn't want me to feel unloved. She tried harder and actually came to me for advice and because a friend instead of a mother. It is also scary for older mothers because they are worried they are too old to be starting over again.



If you really feel bad try talking to your mom and telling her how you feel. Also remember that no matter what she does love you and will want the best for you anyway. I'm sure it'll be ok. All your emotions are perfectly natural so don't worry to much about it.



</answer>

<question>



19 weeks pregnant is this normal?



I am only 19 weeks and lately when me and my boyfriend have sex it hurts, is this normal or should i stop? I have my doctors appointment in a week should i just ask him?



</question>



<answer from>



Sophies mommy

</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Joy
Member since: 13 September 2008
Total points: 3359 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Its normal, and you shouldnt keep having sex if it feels like this. Theres lots of blood flow down there now, so things that felt good before you got prenant might not feel good now. I felt a great deal of discomfort, including terrible terrible cramps after sex ( often I thought I was having a miscarriage). You should talk to your doctor. Just lay off the sex until it becomes pleasurable, but do keep trying. If it feels wrong, just stop.



</answer>



<answer from>



Adriana's Mommy
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 1107 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



It could be normal. When you are pregnant, things are a lot more sensitive "down there," due to hormonal changes. I know when I was pregnant, I was WAY more sensitive down there. If you are having bleeding or bad cramping, that isnt normal and should be addressed right away. I would suggest just holding off on the sex and mention it to your doctor at your next appointment.



</answer>



<answer from>



Poppy: John is due 12/19/08
Member since: 20 February 2008
Total points: 17240 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



If it hurts - don't continue. I can't imagine that being enjoyable.



I had pain during sex from around 6 weeks to about 17 weeks. My doctor told me it was probably my cervix as it can be really sensitive during pregnancy. But at about 17 weeks my cervix became more posterior and harder to irritate.



Yes. You should certainly ask.



</answer>

<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Pregnancy



</category>



<question from>



Chyna P
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 86 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Blue veins and cramping pregnancy?



I was the girl that asked about the 2 weeks thing...today i noticed i had really prominent blue veins going all over my breasts and period cramps what does that mean??



</question>



<answer from>



TC007
Member since: 27 February 2007
Total points: 336 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is all perfectly normal. I also noticed many deep blue veins on my breasts and my doctor told me it was because my breasts are getting bigger and ready to produce milk for the baby. These will go away after the baby is born.



As for the cramps it is also perfectly normal. I personally find (and sorry if this is TMI) that when I am constipated the pains are worse. It is normal as your uterus is expanding and the baby is movign and stretching everything inside you.



It is not pleasant but in the end it is all woth it!



Good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



platinum
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 1019 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



i got blue veins on my boob in the start of my pregnancy and now all over my tummy , take a test if you miss your period



</answer>

<answer from>



CMomma

<answer>



I'm 22 wks pregnant and I feel everything everywhere. Babies are ruling right now . they can toss and turn however the like cause they have more than enough room to roam around. <answer from>



Kellabud
Member since: 16 November 2007

</answer from>



<answer>



She could very well be running out of room in there. And that may be a hand or an elbow or even her head you're feeling. My baby was right side up (breech) until about 36 weeks and I always felt "kicking" in my ribs. Hiccups are totally normal. And, some days I know it'll feel like she's doing somersaults! Just have your doctor check to see where the cord is and make sure she's not getting tangled. My baby was born with the cord around his neck and shoulder, and he had turned purple by the time he was out! He's totally healthy now, just ask your Ob/Gyn. Good luck to you and your new little one!



</answer>



<answer from>



Jay
Member since: 03 April 2006
Total points: 995 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



hi i'm 21 weeks n i know what u mean about it feeling like baby was stuck in the same place however my midwife said its just that where baby was kicking was more sensitive n it was actually kicking n figiting all over the place

I have the BEST kids EVER!!!

</answer from>



<answer>



I have had 3 children, 2 came on their own and 1 was induced.  And to me, being induced was far less painful and a whole heck of a lot quicker.  With my first pregnancy I was in labor for 21 hours, he came on his own, with my 3rd I was in labor for 17 hours, and she came on her own.  Now with the one I was induced with, I got my pitocin around 9am, felt my first real labor pain around 11am, got my epidural around 1pm, and had her at 417pm.  The only thing I had with her was my epidural, no other pain meds.



</answer>



<answer from>



dawn
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 240 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It can make your labor more intense, and last longer. But everyone is different!



I was almost 2 weeks overdue so was induced with Pitocin (sp?) at 6am on a Monday morning.  I had my daughter 38 hours later on a Tuesday night!  I did not get an epideral until after about 30 hours... Don't ask me why!!  The labor got extremly intense after about 4 or 5 hours after being induced.



Even though you will not want to walk, do it.. it really does speed things up.



Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



You have to be at LEAST 38 weeks for a doctor to induce for any reason othet than the health of you and/or the baby.  After that, its up to the doctor.  It cant hurt to ask but at the same time, every pregnant women feels the way you are right now.  The last couple weeks are always the worst but you stick it out for the baby.  Yes, he would be healthy if born right now but the longer he "bakes" the better for him.  Maybe your doctor would induce you a couple days early, say two days before your husband has court.  That would make you about 39 weeks, but again its up to the doctor.  i had three different doctors during the course of 3 pregnancies, none of them induced unless there was a risk to the mothers or babies health or if the baby was 2 weeks overdue.



Good luck hun.



</answer>

<original file>887.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk83239.txt</current file name>




<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Pregnancy



</category>



<question from>



linkinxx...
Member since: 18 December 2007
Total points: 103 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



So, am I pregnant? :)?



Yes a lil redundant as a question, but I'm going to ask anyways. My boyfriend and I made love 2 days before my period which was Sept 29th, 2008. After that, I've gotten mood swings, and my uterus has been getting bigger by the week, my breasts have been killing me for almost 3 weeks before my period, I'm slightly nauseous, and my heartburn is really intense. I've also have been extra sleepy, like I'd sleep all day, and I'd still want to sleep in, and I've also have been getting headaches. Just to be known my next "supposedly" period is October 28th, and my symptoms started 3-4 days before my birthday which was October 8th. I NEVER get bloated, and I get my mood swings right on my period, my boobs would normally hurt at around a week or less before my period, I never gotten heartburn on a daily basis, nausea, or headaches like I do now. And if I recall i haven't slept this much ever. I hope I'm pregnant, after all of this happening to me, right? Oh, and to add, my sister is 8 months pregnant, and she got pregnant on her period. She tells me that you're most fertile then, but I'm also told on the 14th day...ugh I'm so confused! lol Please help me! :D



</question>



<answer from>



Blue Jean
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 17610 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Given a regular 28 day cycle, a woman is most fertile between day 8 and day 16 inclusive, if day 1 is the start of her period.  However there are always exceptions.  Teenagers and young women should consider themselves fertile anytime, since their bodies are still developing their rhythm.
I'd say you are pregnant given the long list of symptoms.  Use a home pregnancy test if your next period doesn't show up.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks to everyone for their answers, and I'm not rambling FYI I'm pregnant. There's a difference. Anyways, Thank you for the answers. It's a big help!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Samantha Kay
Member since: 03 September 2008
Total points: 283 (Level 2)

<answer from>



telltell98 *36wks w/baby#3*
Member since: 28 December 2006
Total points: 6254 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm not sure about chicken hearts, but here is what I found about chicken livers (copied from the marchofdimes.com)



Should a pregnant woman eat liver?
There is some concern about consuming liver during pregnancy. Liver is a good source of protein and is rich in certain vitamins and minerals. These include:



The B vitamin folic acid, which helps prevent certain birth defects



Iron, which helps prevent anemia



Vitamin A, which is needed for normal fetal growth and development



However, in the case of vitamin A, liver may contain too much of a good thing.



Some studies suggest that high doses of vitamin A may cause birth defects. According to the Institute of Medicine (IOM), the recommended dietary allowance (RDA) of vitamin A for pregnant women is 2,565 IUs (international units) per day (7). In a 1995 study, women who took more than 10,000 IUs of vitamin A daily (nearly 4 times the amount recommended by the IOM) in the first two months of pregnancy had more than double the risk of having a baby with birth defects (8). Other studies have suggested that doses under 30,000 IUs daily probably do not cause birth defects, but the lowest dose that may cause birth defects is unknown (9).



The body makes its own vitamin A, when needed, from substances such as beta carotene, which is found in yellow and green vegetables. This raw material for the vitamin is completely safe and healthy during pregnancy. However, much of the vitamin A consumed is the preformed vitamin (retinol) which, in excessive amounts, may cause birth defects. Preformed vitamin A is found in many vitamin supplements and some foods, including meats, eggs, dairy products and fortified breakfast cereals.



Liver is the only food that provides very high amounts of vitamin A. For example (7):



A 3-ounce serving of beef liver may contain 27,000 IUs.



A 3-ounce serving of chicken liver may contain 12,000 IUs.



A pregnant woman who eats liver regularly may consume enough vitamin A to pose a risk to her baby.



Though it is not proven that eating liver causes birth defects, the safest approach is for pregnant women to minimize their consumption of liver. A pregnant woman also should be sure that her multivitamin or prenatal supplement contains no more than 5,000 IUs of preformed vitamin A. Some prenatal vitamins contain no preformed vitamin A, substituting beta carotene or omitting vitamin A entirely. She should not take any vitamin A supplements beyond that amount (10).



</answer>

perth2cl...
Member since: 28 December 2006

<answer>



you can get pregnant on the pill even if using a condom sometimes these things just happen.  The best thing to do if you think you are pregnant is to go to the chemist and get a preganancy kit I use the crystal clear digital ones from friendlies chemists.  then take the test first thing in the morning as this is when your hormones are the strogest.  if it comes back negative wait one month then take another one(you usually get two tests in a box).  if this comes back negative then you are not pregnant.



if it comes up postive then you need to go to your Dr who will do another pee test and then if this comes up postive then you will need a blood test to confirm.



good luck.



Source(s):



mother of three with one on way fell pregnant with this one as I was not taking pill correctly and did not even know I was pregnant until I went to the gyno to get a tubuligation.

LOVER ♥

<answer>



I have that also. Try hot tea. A lot of people intake too much food or drink with too much acid. I can have a powerade or gatorade and a coupl hours later I have acid reflux and it burns.

<answer from>



SE
Member since: 08 December 2006
Total points: 4712 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I never had acid reflux / heartburn until the beginning of my third trimester - about 2 or 3 weeks ago. Now it's a regular occurrence. ugh.  I found that the following things help me quite a bit:
- eating small amounts at a time, but more frequently
- limiting heavy or greasy food
- limiting spicy food (even if you really like it)
- not eating too close to bedtime



- Drinking milk - the calcium in milk helps neutralize your stomach acid
- limiting intake of acidic foods like tomatoes and citrus fruits
- limiting carbonated drinks, even ones without caffeine
- Always keeping Tums on-hand!



Calucim-based antacids like Tums are safe for pregnant women, and they seem to work well for many people. Zantac didn't work for me but Tums works nicely. You might want to try another antacid and see if you have more success.



Hope you're feeling better soon!



Source(s):



30 weeks with baby girl.



</answer>
