<answer>



Call them back and tell them your concerns.



When I was having some issues in my early pregnancy they wanted to have a 10 or 13 week scan done to make sure that everything was progressing well since I had issues in the beginning.... they were going to send me to a specialist to have this done.



I would call them.  Tell them you want to have an ultrasound to be sure everything is okay.  IF they do not do this for you, and you are concerned it is time to see out someone else who will help ease your mind and will do what YOU want.



Pregnancy is not a time to be stressed out and they should do all in their power to help ease your mind.



</answer>

<answer>



Hi sweetheart!



I was induced with 2 of my babies and I guess, since it's the only way I've ever delivered- I don't see what's so "awful."



I didn't have an epidural with either baby, went 100% natural and yes, it was painful, but it was such a small amount of time I didn't mind it. It wasn't scary for me at all. With each of my kids, once I got the pitocin my contractions picked up like crazy and they were painful, but I don't think they were any stronger than the contractions I was having at home.



The only super painful time was right before I needed to push and during pushing...and I'm pretty sure that's going to be painful no matter what!



Don't worry about getting induced...labor is labor and it's different for everyone. That's why some women swear by epidurals and some women refuse them. Some women have 3 hour labors and some have 30 hour labors....you'll see it's not scary any way you have it. You'll be taken care of, baby will be taken care of and it'll be over before you know it!!



Lots of luck and love sugar. xxx



</answer>

<answer>



I've been induced twice, with my 2nd son it was horrible and ended in what I completely believe was an unneccessary csection due to the induction.  With my 3rd son I wanted a VBAC but he didn't do so well on a NST so they decided to induce me the day before my due date but they did it differently this time.  The used Cervail which ripens, softens and prepares your cervix for labor, doesn't really induce you, doesn't start contractions, just prepares your body for when they will give you pitocin.  Well that alone put me into labor but they did still use a bit of pitocin and that labor and delivery went great, couldn't have been better.  In the matter of 1hr and 43min I went from being 4cm to 10 and delivering him :)



But really if possible I would try and avoid being induced medically, maybe try some at home stuff, lots of walking and sex.  If you do have to do it medically I would really ask about the cervadil first.  Why do they want you do deliver before your due date?



</answer>

newcastl...

Total points: 509 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I basically got induced last Friday. My body went to 4 cm, but that's as far as I would go on my own. I showed up at the hospital at 8:30 am. They checked me in and got me comfortable. I watched some TV and wrote in my pregnancy journal. Just relaxing. They started Pitocin by 10 (I had a side effect of getting the "shakes" when I wasn't having a contraction....not a big deal) and the contractions weren't that bad (my pain tolerance may be a little high from some past experiences, but really it was no worse than your monthly friend)! The epidural came at 12:30 (the most painful part of the whole experience) and they broke the bag of waters by 2. My family was in and out, as well as my hubby. Everything was completely relaxing and exciting at the same time. At 3:50 they brought the doctor in and I started pushing. My beautiful baby boy was born at 4:13. I was so scared of labor and the induction (etc) that I thought when the time came I would be a horrible mess. In reality? It was an amazing experience (my first child BTW) and I would do it all over again.......not right now though because I still feel like I have been riding a horse for a couple days! It isn't painful, just sore! I wouldn't worry about it at all. Even if it does hurt, you won't even feel a thing once that baby is crying and you get to hold it for the first time!



Source(s):



Just had my first baby boy 10/24/08.



</answer>

<answer>



On a 1-10 scale, it was about a 7 for me. I didn't have an epidural though. It was NOTHING near as bad as I thought it would be. I didn't really have major pain until the last 1-2 hours of labor as the baby made it's way down to crown. I was induced with pitocin with both of mine, and will be this time as well. I loved it, and have no complaints at all. Short easy labors and deliveries.



Labors were from first contraction:
8hrs45mins, pushed 2 times (slept 6 hours of that)
5hrs20mins, pushed 3 times (slept 3 hours of that)

<answer from>



VixenMom
Member since: 13 June 2006
Total points: 2029 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Mine was great.  I got induced because my first child was 12 days early... and I had a fairly quick labor.  So for my second (and since my doctor would be out of town when I was due) we decided to induce to avoid the possibility that I would go into labor too fast to make it to the hospital.  So... I heard stories that it would hurt more and bla bla bla.. and was worried myself.  They broke my water at 9:00 am... and I asked not to have the pitocen (not sure if I spelled that right) to see if I would start contractions naturally.  I put in a house/techno CD and started dancing around the room... in about 10 minutes I started contracting... and continued dancing through all my contractions (of course you stop and buckle over when the actual contraction comes on and stay in that position until it passes) as best as I could up until 10:55 am when I had the urge to push.  5 minutes later, my daughter was born.  I highly recommend induction if the baby is fit to come out and you want to deliver.  It all hurts no matter what, but don't be afraid of the induction itself.  I would definitely recommend trying to contract on your own before resorting to meds... and dancing and jumping around definitely helps bring that on.  My first pregnancy, I laid in the hospital bed wrenching in pain and mangling the bed rails through each contraction... and couldn't believe how much more tolerable the pain was up on my feet and dancing around the room like I was at a night club.  I truly believe that it helped with the contractions and the quick labor/delivery.
If you're planning on using meds for pain, it may delay delivery in some people.  Everyone is different.  But it you're looking to get the absolute raw experience, I highly recommend drug free which is what I did with both my kids.  I know it hurts, but believe me... you will be able to make it through.  The best and least painful part (for me anyway) was the delivery.  Good luck and don't be scared.



</answer>

<answer>

<question>



Alcohol during first month of pregnancy?



I have a friend (I know how that sounds but it really is a friend!) who is pregnant with her first child.  She suspected pregnancy when she missed her period, but tested negative (after the missed period) so she felt it was safe to have one margarita with dinner.



She is really nervous about the effects (if any) it had on the fetus.  Her first doctor's appointment is next week, so I wanted to find out some information to try and calm her nerves before then.  Is it possible that the small amount of alcohol at about 5 weeks pregnant caused any harm?



</question>



<answer from>



TTC w/ #1
Member since: 07 March 2007
Total points: 1378 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The chances of any defects are slim to none. Many women drink within the first month of pregnancy without even knowing that they ae pregnant. Unless she was drinking all day everyday, doing drugs and what not, i think she will be ok, but she can always ask the dr and they will reassure her. As long as she doesnt continue to drink, everything will be fine.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for the information.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



trixylov...
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 235 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was in the same boat as your friend. Before I found out I was pregnant, I went out drinking with my friends.. like getting drunk drinking. Afterwards, I was worried that it might have some effect on my baby. The doctor told me that since the first month of pregnancy is the baby attaching to your body and not developing, there's a slight chance anything could happen to it. I've had my testing done,and she's perfectly fine. You should just ask your doctor about it when you go in.



</answer>

<answer>



It most certainly sounds like this is your mucus plug.
This can be white, and may lead to a pinkish or brown discharge afterwards.



Ooh, you lucky girl, bet you're not 2 weeks overdue like I nearly was with my second, after having to be induced with my first.



Although your mucus plug has come out, this does not mean that you will instantly go into labour, but, it means your cervix is obviously ready for dilation and delivery, so don't go anywhere remote and off the beaten track in the next few weeks!  Lol.



Make sure your bags are packed, all is ready and I think you will go in the next couple of weeks - let us know the good news!!
Good Luck.
x



</answer>

<question>



What has your experience with a VBAC?



I'm still waiting to find out if I am actually pregnant with my third baby. But that aside, I am a the type of person who likes to be informed and well prepared.



I've had 2 children already. The first was nearly a textbook pregnancy and birth. I was in labour for 24hrs and I delivered vaginally with an epidural. no problems.



The second was great until the end when it was discovered that she was breech. I was scheduled for a version and was told that my fluid levels were critically low and instead of trying the procedure, I was scheduled for an urgent c-section that day.



I was extremely sad when I had to have the section but in the end I was happy that my baby was going to be born without complications and was healthy.



If it turns out to be certain that I am pregnant, I am almost dead set on having a VBAC but am also not a huge risk taker and will do what is best for my baby and myself.



I am wondering what your experiences have been with a VBAC? did you go the midwife route or the doctor route? were they supportive?  Was there complications after or during? did you feel like you were being selfish wanting a vbac rather than another c-section?



any input would great and will help to make up my mind....
and hopefully my sore boobs are really indicating that I'm pregnant.



</question>



<answer from>



Proud mommy and army wife! ;0
Member since: 16 April 2008
Total points: 126 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I actually just had a successful VBAC and i wouldn't go back (if i could) and change my decision you see my first i went in thinking and in hopes of a natural birth but after being in labour for 24 hour bubs heart rate dropped and they had to wheel me in for a c-section. That was 18 months ago and i just had a baby 6 weeks ago, that was a successful VBAK that i went in route with a doctor that was very supportive, this is the way god intended for baby's to come into this world so no i didn't feel selfish when i choose that route. If anything  would have felt selfish having a planned c-section. I didn't have any complications during or after i felt like i was a pro after bubs was born as if i had done this before. This decision is truly up to you go with what your heart tells you and good luck in whatever situation you end up choosing.



Source(s):



Experienced a sucessful VBAK

<question>



Conceiving directly after miscarriage?



I lost a pregnancy exactly 4 weeks ago - a "missed" miscarriage. We discovered at our first appointment at almost 10 wks that there was no heartbeat, and three weeks later I lost the pregnancy naturally at home.  Our doc recommened that we wait two cycles before trying again and we had a brief discussion about going out to buy some condoms, but neither of us did, and we were not really all that careful.  Yesterday I all of a sudden felt super hormonal and have been noticing extra sensitivity in my breasts (until this week though, all pregnancy symptoms from the miscarriage had disappeared). I figured I was about to start my period, but got to thinking and decided to take a preg test - it was positive.  My question is, what is the liklihood that it was detecting residual hormones from the miscarriage, vs. hormones from a new pregnancy.  And, if I do have a new pregnancy, is there any big reason medically (I realize the emotional implications of another pregnancy so soon) why this one would be at a much greater risk for miscarriage being so soon after a loss? I have read tons online about this and the info is widely varied. I know there probably is not a cut and dry answer - I guess what I am looking for are some stories from people about their experiences with this.



</question>



<answer from>



Amanda!!
Member since: 22 July 2007
Total points: 9220 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



That's a hard one because the pregnancy was pretty established when you miscarried so you would have had a lot of HCG built up. Did you take any pregnancy tests during the past 4 weeks that have been negative? I miscarried but very early on and I was still taking HPT's (to check) and they were negative and then gradually started to go positive again. That is how I knew I was pregnant again because we didn't wait to start trying again either. I would say just keep taking tests every couple of days and check if the positive result is getting stronger or weaker as that should indicate whether HCG is dropping or not. In regards to the increased risk of a second miscarriage, I did a bunch of research after mine too because I was concerned about losing this pregnancy, when I asked people on a forum there were a bunch of them who DID lose their following pregnancies which I think was more than just a coincidence, this doesn't mean that you will though, all you can do is hope. I am 33 weeks pregnant now and conceived about 3 weeks after my miscarriage. Good luck to you and I am sorry for your loss.



</answer>



<answer from>



786
Member since: 19 September 2007
Total points: 4179 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I doubt that the hormones are from your last pregnancy. The reason is b/c you have a natural miscarriage at home, and when you lose the baby/blood, all the hcg hormones go to 5 or 3. I had experience a miscarriage b4 as well, and right after i had a miscarriage at home, i took a pregnancy test to see if it wa spositive or negative and it was negative.



I am sorry for your loss, but i think you might be pregnnat again, you will never know until you find out from taking a blood test..Congrats!
After I miscarried my doc told me to wait a month, and try the next month but it took me  four more cycles to get pregnant. I t hink you should be fine, once a miscarriage does not mean that you will always have a miscarriage. Every pregnancy is different. I think the last miscarriage you had wasfrom chromosonal abnormaltiy which is the major cause for one..



</answer>



<answer from>



Mrs Fike♥
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 409 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, in April of this year I miscarried at 6 weeks. I knew when it happened (it happened immediately) loads of pain. I was completely devastated because me and my husband wanted a baby soooo bad! I had the bleeding from the miscarriage and then missed my next period. I however did not get a positive home test. I got a blood test done a week later when my period didn't come because I was well obsessive I guess lol. But no pregnancy. Since my miscarriage my periods are always late and I haven't ovulated since I miscarried (besides this last month). So I guess what I'm saying is that I had the 6 weeks worth of the pregnancy hormone and I didn't get a positive test the next month when my period was due. I had absolutely no pregnancy hormones left 2 days after miscarrying. Yours could be different but I have heard of A LOT of people getting pregnant immediately because the hormones are so high. The reason they say not to try so soon is because your body has to get back to normal.  It has to recover. Someone I know has had 3 miscarriages and 3 babies brought to term. Each of her three kids were conceived directly after a miscarriage and she didn't have any problems. I would recommend that you call your doctor and have them do an internal ultrasound. That will tell you for sure if your pregnant again. From there your doctor can help you with what to do. Good luck and God Bless♥ I hope you get everything you want!!



Source(s):



Miscarried April 4th 2008



</answer>



<answer from>



bad...
Member since: 27 December 2006
Total points: 2591 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, from experience here. You are most definitely pregnant again there. So, first of Congrats to you & your other half!!! Okay heres the deal with the HCG issue first. When your baby is not alive inside you, they HCG level decreases by half everyday. So, 4 weeks later there would have been no trace of the hormone. And, when it comes to conceiving again so soon, its for you more so then your body. We seem to be more prone to conceiving again within 6 months of a miscarriage. Dont know why, but its true!



My sister & I have both been cursed with spontaneous miscarriage here. She lost 11, & myself 8 here. And I inquired why they give you a time constraint on getting pregnant again. My doctor told me, its so your hormones can settle down to normal again & to sort of grieve some too. It never easy & as women when we lose a baby, we subconsciously want another to replace this lost one. I know it sounds odd, but if you ask any woman that has lost a pregnancy, they will tell you, they have never felt complete till they had another. Theres like a piece of us missing. But then on the other end there, try being set in your ways so much so that you are done having babies & finding out your expecting. I was waiting for my period to get my tubes tied here & guess what, period never came! Instead a beautiful son did! This was scary for us, with my history as I told you & it was just difficult the whole time, the worry, the not wanting to get excited till the end! It was hard for us! Myself I lost most in the first & second trimester. But one of my babies was stillborn at 7 months. So, I really couldnt get excited till the very end here! And come to find out, he was a scheduled c-section, but the cord was around his neck... the doctors never told me- till he was 2 weeks old & a nurse slipped up & said something! I freaked!!! Knowing that I could have lost him also! But I didnt & I love him to pieces!!! Anyways, thats it. Have a wonderful day & take it easy there!!!!



</answer>

<answer>



There's a great saying which says "life happens while you are busy making other plans".



The same applies to trying to fall pregnant. Stressing about falling pregnant and having sex as a chore to become pregnant can actually stop you falling pregnant.



Instead why don't you sit back, relax and enjoy sex and you will be surprised how quickly the baby will come! Good luck and keep trying!



</answer>



<answer from>



Michelle S
Member since: 18 July 2008
Total points: 2042 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You only have about a 25% chance of conceiving in any given monthly cycle.  And that is assuming that both partners are healthy.  It's not uncommon for a healthy couple to take 6-12 months to conceive.  The best thing is to continue charting your cycles and baby dancing at the right times.  If it doesn't happen after 12 consecutive months of trying, ask your doctor for a referral to a fertility specialist.



</answer>



<answer from>



Katie
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 426 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Actually yes, you can get pregnant on the first try... THe lady up top is wrong. With all three of my pregnancies it was on the first try, but it may be next month for you to get pregnant... or few months later. Don't stress, it'll happen



</answer>

<answer from>



Wo ist der Flughafen?
Member since: 07 November 2007
Total points: 971 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



From BabyCenter.com : Severe itchiness in the second or, more commonly, in the third trimester can be a sign of intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy, a liver problem that affects less than 1 percent of pregnant women in the United States.



They say to call your caregiver immediately because if it continues it can cause problems for you and your baby.



Good luck!



Source(s):



babycenter.com



</answer>



<answer from>



srhgreco
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 595 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi you should call your doctor as bad itching on your arms and hands can be a sign of something called obstetric cholestasis, which is something to do with the liver and need to be treated it could be nothing but best to get checked this link might help



http://www.bbc.co.uk/health/conditions/o...



I know there is more symptoms than itching but that is the main one and somtimes all you get



</answer>

<answer>



i had this with my first baby - on my shins, i used to scratch so much they bled and i have scars now - i bought myself some eczema cream and smothered where i itched in it - it took off the sensation to scratch, but not much, i was told by my midwife that this can happen due to hormones, but if you start to scratch on your hands, feet and face, see your doctor asap, it can be a serious liver condition...

<answer>



Yes, there is and you will unfortunately have discharge throughout your whole pregnancy.  You can have milky white discharge and you can have clear discharge.  I was warned about the white milky disharge but not the clear.  My panties were wet every day and I would look online and get paranoid, I thought I was leaking amniotic fluid.  Finally, I got over my embarassment and asked the doctor who told me yes that it was normal and to invest in pantyliners and cotton panties.

<question>



Induced labor's hurt more?



Im going to be induced next thurs and im being told that it hurts a lot more then if labor was to come on its own. also im being told that an induced labor causes more problems?



Im asking because im starting to feel as if i've waited for my son to be born and now that he will be here soon that all im hearing is bad news.



</question>



<additional details>



induced labors cause c sections. my cousin was induced and didnt have a c section when she had my cousin.



</additional details>



<answer from>



nonsense...
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 442 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



doesnt necessarily hurt more or even cause any problems (I was inducted labor twice), just makes all the contractions happen sooner, and not so gradual as compared to going into labor on your own.  think about it, you are combining hours of labor and contractions into a smaller time frame.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Riyen's Mom
Member since: 03 February 2008
Total points: 5824 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



First off, why are you being induced?



Unless it is for preeclampsia or low fluid levels I would suggest you to not be induced.



Induction hurst much more because it jump starts contractions to be strong strong strong , since you haven't had time to build up to this pain level it is hardly managed without the use of an epidural.  You should be dialated to a 4 before they do this.



First of all they will insert something into your cervix to soften it and then 2 days later they will probably induce you with pitocin.



Don't worry about it, usually there arean't very many complications, a lot of women have had perfectaly healthy, safe deliveries but me myself had a bad one ending in a csection.



You should be fully informed as to why you are being induced and possible complications, you can get a list from your doctor and if there is anything you are too worried about they should be able to guide you to the right direction.  Good luck, and reguardless enjoy this special and happy time!



</answer>



<answer from>



Baby Joel is due 12/22/08
Member since: 03 July 2007
Total points: 6453 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, pitocin, the chemical used to induce labor, causes very strong and harsh contractions.
So, most women I know who wanted a drug-free labor who ended up being induced opted for an epidural VERY easy on.



And yes, being induced does make it more likely for complications, and more likely that you'll need a c-section.



but really, inductions are so routine these days, doctors know what they're doing.
I wouldn't worry at all.



Good luck and congrats!



</answer>



<answer from>



Julie-An...
Member since: 11 November 2006
Total points: 5034 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes it does. the reason?



PITOCIN  (I call it the medicine of the devil and I ABSOLUTELY REFUSE to have this the second time around).



Dont expect to go without pain meds or an epidural.  You will likely need it with being induced.  I had pitocin at the very tip end of my labor, started screaming bloody murder and didnt even know where I was.  It made me turn into a monster.  BUT I had NO meds and NO epidural.. Sorry to scare you, but if you have to do this, insist on an epidural right away.



My labor was very very regular before this, every 1-1/2 minutes like clockwork for 22 yrs, pushing took 4 hours.  The pitocin was given to me at the last hour (plus the 4 hrs of pushing) and I turned into a monster.  I even apologized to the nurses afterwards.



Source(s):



pregnant with #2, 10 years later!



</answer>



<answer from>



Jeeves
Member since: 01 December 2006
Total points: 585 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It does hurt more because it is not natural, your body wasn't 100% prepared to go into labor. The pitocin, the chemical that starts labor, will be injected into you causing labor and you hit the floor running. Your body didn't naturally trigger the chemical to start labor so its kind of like Whoa! whats going on? So its harder and faster.



If you have the option to do a natural birth and let nature run its course, then do it. If the Doctor recommends the induction, of course your health care professional knows whats best for you.



If you are simply having the induction to get it over with, I suggest you wait. Everything comes in due time.



Congrats and good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Waiting for Baby
Member since: 20 February 2008
Total points: 5013 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Don't listen to people who try to scare you...



Induced labor doesn't hurt any more than regular labor. My doctor and I had this discussion, because i'm getting induced on Tuesday. I said, "Doesn't the Pitocin cause harder contractions?" and she told me that Pitocin doesn't cause abnormally hard and painful contractions, just regular ones instead of sporadic ones. She said that you can ask your nurse to ease up the Pitocin if they get too close together for you to handle and you need a break (that is, unless the baby is coming out and your body is doing it, not the pitocin)



</answer>



<answer from>



jackmatt
Member since: 17 December 2007
Total points: 11829 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Induced labors are more likley to end up as a C/S when compared to labor that comes on naturally. And theoretically, yes they should hurt more b/c an external source (the medicine Pitocin) is being controlled by your Nurse to increase & strengthen your contractions (they increase the dose every 20-30minutes). However, pain depends on the individual's pain tolerance.  Your concerns are normal & natural. You still have time between now & next week to go into labor on your own, so don't worry too much, just start cleaning, walking, have sex, etc LOL
OB/GYN RN & mom



</answer>



<answer from>



Trissh
Member since: 12 October 2008
Total points: 479 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I can't compare the 2 but I can tell you about my own sons birth of which I was induced.  My waters broke at 5.30am, I went to hospital at 10am with no pain, I was induced at around 11am and by 1.20pm the same day my little boy was born.  Doesn't sound like a horror story does it ?? That's because it wasn't. And this was my first baby.  From what I have heard being induced just means that the contractions come quicker and faster than normal labor so your body does not have as much time to adjust, but I honestly didn't feel any difference in the intensity of the contractions from start to finish, all I needed was the gas and I didn't use that for the pain but to take my mind off it. I rated my labor pains as a 2 out of 10.  Don't stress yourself about it hun, you are about to participate in one of the biggest miracles of life, lay back, relax and go with the feelings you have. You will be fine. NOTE: I also found that kneeling up with the bed in a sitting position and my belly into the chair easier as I was comfortable and was working with gravity. Good luck :) Bubs needs to come out and if being induced has been recommended then that is what will be best for both of you.



</answer>



<answer from>



Love♥
Member since: 18 December 2007
Total points: 21067 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, there are risks associated with it. The doctor's don't always tell you what they are or what the differences are. I don't want you to go into labor being scared, but I want you to know that if there is no reason to induce labor... No high blood pressure or gestational diabetes and you're not overdue then you should really think about some things. I was told this all by my midwife...



*Induced labors only work 1/2 the time, the other half ending up in c-section after many hours of painful labor. They are longer, the contractions are harder and longer, so there's little break to breathe in between.*
Birth is an amazing experience and you do not need to dwell on negative experiences of others. People will tell you everything negative and it will scare you to the point where you panic during labor and you need to just block out what everyone else says. Even me if you don't like what I say. ***It's your call to say how you want your birthing experience to be!***



</answer>

im not sure what your labor plans are...but i was scheduled to be induced  jan.3rd.of2007..i went into labor at 4:00 in the morning on jan1st...they put me on pitocen and i got my epidural...my epidural did not take and i screamed and cried till 5:00 that evening...thats when i started pushing...she came out at 6:02....my second child was induced on may 14th2008...i was put on pitocin at 6:00 and got my epidral at 8:00, also they broke my water at 8....i was shaking uncontrollably at 11:00 they said my body was working so hard getting ready...but i didnt feel anything except a little pressure in my lower back...i literally sat indian style in my bed with makeup, hair fixed,laughing and joking all through it till 12:00...they have a button to push in most hospitals for your epidural medicine every 30 minutes if you want too...trust me i did...they got ready for me to have the baby and after 7 minutes of pushing out she popped....it was wonderful....it was completly different than the first ...so if you are in any pain if you get an epidural  tell them and they will fix it.. also my nurse said i would have the baby at around 12 because they can predict the time since they are pumping the pitocin..i had my daughter at 12:23

<question from>



Missy -x-

<question>



How early on in a pregnancy can you miscarry, and what are the symptoms?



??



</question>



<answer from>



Canadian girl
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 3572 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Some women miscarry before they know they are pregnant, could be very early.  Symptoms are bleeding and pain/cramping.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bag
Member since: 26 June 2007
Total points: 12439 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can miscarry from the point you conceive. It can happen at any time, but becomes much rarer after 12 weeks.



The symptoms are bleeding and cramping or neither.



</answer>



<answer from>



naughtyg...
Member since: 02 May 2006
Total points: 680 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



it varies from pregnancy to pregnancy...but bleeding, cramping, and a sense of just not normal...but be careful it could also be an ectopic pregnancy



</answer>



<answer from>



Me
Member since: 20 November 2007
Total points: 3028 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can miscarry anywhere from 4-20 weeks but with every week that passes, the chances of a miscarriage are less. Most people miscarry around 4-8 weeks. Normally if you make it past 12 weeks, you're out of the danger zone. I miscarried last month at 6 weeks and miraculously I'm now 6 weeks pregnant again. I thank God everytime a week passes.



</answer>



<answer from>



Baby boy due in Feb. 09.
Member since: 25 December 2007
Total points: 3413 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can miscarry as soon as the egg gets fertilized, in which case you wouldn't even know you were pregnant because you wouldn't miss your period or even get a positive pregnancy test. If you miscarry after that then you would most likely have a late period but it would be heavier and you would be in more pain then a normal period, you would also pass clots but really tiny ones. If you miscarry after you already miss your period then it is even worse, you would bleed A LOT and  be in a lot of pain and probably bleed longer than a normal period. Those are usually the early miscarriage symptoms.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sourkand...
Member since: 20 May 2007
Total points: 993 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's possible to miscarry anytime after conception, some women can have this happen even before they know they are pregnant.  Symptoms would be relativley the same as getting your period, bleeding (possible with clots), cramping.  If you were pregnant and miscarried even this early it would be detectable by a pregnancy test (maybe not a home one, but by bloodwork) because your body starts producing the hormones immediatly and it takes days-weeks after a miscarriage for the levels to go back to normal.



</answer>

Apryl S

Total points: 185 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can miscarry at any time during your first trimester and it is most common to miscarry in the first trimester.  I had a miscarriage on September 5th, I was 7 weeks pregnant.  Some signs are bad cramps, back pain, and bleeding, clotting.  Unfortunately, I learned that you don't have to have all those signs to miscarry.  I had no warning, I woke up that day went pee and there was a little blood.  I became really worried and went to ER because I never had any bleeding in my first pregnancy.  The bleeding by that time stopped and they did an ultrasound and couldn't tell because it was early and tested my HcG levels.  They told me some women bleed a little during pregnancy. I went home and later that afternoon I had more bleeding, still no cramps at all.  By Monday morning I was passing very large clots but still no cramps and my HcG levels increased.  Anyways, it was a miscarriage.  So again you can have all the symptoms or just one. If you think you are having a miscarriage, go to your doctor.



Source(s):



OB/GYN



</answer>



<answer from>



brielle_...
Member since: 29 January 2008
Total points: 1224 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can miscarry anytime during pregnancy, although it's more common in the first trimester.  You can miscarry before you even know you are pregnant.  And may not have any signs at first.  Or period like symptoms very early on.  My friend miscarried at 10 wks. she went in for her first apt and found that the baby had passed a week earlier.  So they did a D and C because It could take up to a month for her body to miscarry the baby.



</answer>



<answer from>



HooKooDo...
Member since: 12 September 2007
Total points: 12689 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



In addition to what everyone else is saying, studies have indicated that about 50% of all pregnancies end in miscarriage, most before the woman ever knew she was pregnant.  The miscarriage could happen so early that her period isn't even late, and for others, they never notice anything be a period that's a little late and MAYBE a little heavier than normal.  But unless they took an HPT and got a positive result, they have no clue they were ever pregnant.



Once pregnancies are detected after 4 to 5 weeks (basically once you've missed you period) there is statistically a 10% - 15% of miscarrige.  Of those, 90% will occur during the 1st trimester (hence the reason miscarriage odds go way down after 10 to 12 weeks).



</answer>

<answer>



Ok, it is very possible that she is pregnant. It is also possible that it's someone else's child. The only reason she would have an ultrasound is to confirm pregnancy, and also to figure out due date. Ask for a picture from the ultrasound. They almost always give the mother a picture. Find out the due date. (If she had an ultrasound, they will have told her the estaimated due date.) Speak to an adult female, and get them to help you work out how far along she is, or if she does show you a picture, it will be written on it. It will say 3/40 for example, which is 3 weeks out of a forty week pregnancy. Hope this helps. Good luck.

Jen

</answer from>



<answer>



She may indeed be pregnant--but most likely not with your child.  It would depend on when she last menstruated.  A strange question to ask a girl, to be sure.  It is possible, though.  Just not likely.  If she was expecting her period on, say the 21st or slightly before, then she could have been ovulating and gotten pregnant on the 10th...but if you used protection?  I guess it depends on what kind of protection you used.  Some are more effective than others.  Not even the pill is 100%, but condoms, foam, gels, etc are even less effective.



Another question would be how effectively did you use the protection?  If you were at all under the influence (maybe had a few beers, etc) you could have made a mistake in applying the protection.



I would have a serious conversation with the girl about this, and make sure she realizes how important it is that if she's pregnant she tells the correct father.  Also tell her that if she's sure the baby is yours, you'll be with her through the pregnancy, but that you are planning on getting a paternity test once the baby is born.  That way if the child is yours, you didn't make the mistake of not being part of the pregnancy and birth.



When the baby is born, you can ask for a paternity test if you are not married at the hospital, and if the test results confirm that the baby isn't yours, she would be responsible for paying for the test.  You can also sign your right to a test away.  If the baby is confirmed as yours, however, you are responsible for paying for the test.



Hope this helps.



Source(s):



Mommy of three, and a nursing student (R.N.)



</answer>

<question>



About how long after you pass your mucus plug will your water break?



According to the first ultrasound we had done (@25weeks) I am 37 weeks and 2 days pregnant.  For 2 weeks now I have been at 2 cm and 50% but the doctor can feel the baby's head.  The day before yesterday, I went for a walk around our block and that night around 8pm, I passed part of my mucus plug.  Around 8 am yesterday morning, I passed the rest of it.  I was having some spotting and very intense vaginal and abdominal pains yesterday also.  My dad is an EMT and so he has been monitoring my blood pressure.  It was very elevated last night so I just took a warm shower and went to bed.  This morning, we checked it again and it is only slightly elevated but I am still having some spotting and my lower back and tailbone hurt.  At what point should I be concerned enough to go to the doctor?  Should I just wait for my water to break?  I am not having contractions that I know of but I didn't feel most of the contractions with my first son and they had to break my water with him.  Any advice would be appreciated.



</question>



<additional details>



My blood pressure has been normal throughout the entire pregnancy.  120/74 range.  It was the same with my first pregnancy.  Towards the end of my first preg. my blood pressure started to rise (133/88) so my doctor induced at two days later.  I was 38 weeks then.  I never lost my plug with my first pregnancy.  Last night my BP was 131/97.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Katie
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 426 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It was two weeks after I started losing my mucus plug that I went into labor... Water never broke by its self.



</answer>



<answer from>



HouseMom
Member since: 09 January 2007
Total points: 1236 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm not so sure the loss of mucus plug is a sign - it can happen in bits and pieces or all at once during the pregnancy within the last few weeks. I lost one with my first after the last internal exam and with the second, I think it was just some here and there. Some women never even really form one, so it's different for everyone.



I would be more concerned about your BP and it's great that your dad can monitor you. Has your doctor been concerned about it throughout your pg? SOmetimes labor can start with contractions and no water breaking; sometimes the water just breaks and they start, and sometimes it breaks and nothing happens. Once your water does break though, you should head to the hospital at least within 24 hours due to the elevated risk of infection.



Source(s):



Mom of 2, 19w with #3



</answer>

<question>

<answer>



I would have the baby. I would let my ex and the new man know what's going on. If your ex decides to step up and take responsibility, great. If the new man decides to leave you, then it just wasn't meant to be. This situation could turn out a number of different ways. Your ex may decide he doesn't want to be a father and the new man may decide to step up and take responsibility for the child. Either way, this is not going to be easy. The longer you wait, the harder it will be for you. Please don't have an abortion. I'm not 100% against abortions because I believe that certain situations arise in a woman's life where this is the only choice, like in a case of rape or incest. But you had unprotected sex voluntarily and you knew what could happen and you decided to take that chance. At 10 weeks this baby already has a heartbeat, eyes, and ears. I had an abortion at 17 (I'm 23 and married now) then a miscarriage last month. I now realize how precious childbearing is and how blessed we are to be able to carry a baby. I'm  pregnant now again and I pray everyday that nothing goes wrong with my baby. I regret the miscarriage I had when I was young, dumb, and felt like my situation was too complicated to handle. God bless you and I hope you make the right decision.

<answer>



Whichever path you choose, it's going to hurt, no matter how you sort it out. If I was you, I'd talk to your ex and see what his view is. I'd also talk to your new man, and see what his view is. But remember, no matter what they say or want you to do, you don't have to do it.
Also, talk to your parents or anyone else in your family that you can trust, maybe your sister,  as you're so young. Find out who would be willing to help and support you if you do decide to keep the baby.
From there on, it's your choice. Think about the current place you live in, the amount of money you have, if you'd be willing to give up Friday nights down at the club for your baby. I personally disagree with abortions, but that doesn't mean they're wrong. It depends on the conditions that the baby will be living with.
Having an abortion can haunt you for years, (not trying to put you off) but sometimes it's the best you can do. I had my youngest around your age, and she's five now, and I don't regret keeping her, but you might.
I wish you the best, don't let anyone force you into anything you don't want to do.



</answer>

<question>



Safe dosage of tylenol during pregnancy?



I am 31 weeks pregnant. A few days ago, I suddenly developed severe lower back pain which is preventing me from doing anything (sitting, walking, going to work) without dissolving into tears. I called my doctor and she recommended ice, the belly belt, and Tylenol. When I asked her what a safe dosage would be, she said to take 2 pills 2 times per day. Here's the problem- my husband has been to several drugstores and no one sells regular Tylenol; it is all extra strength. I looked up the milligrams and regular Tylenol has 325 mg/pill while extra strength has 500 mg/pill. With the dosage she recommended, that would put me at 1300 mg/day for regular Tylenol. I'm trying to figure out if I can take 3 extra strength spread out through the day, which would put me at 1500 mg, only my doctor's office is closed today through Monday. Has anyone spoken to the doctor about this that can pass along some info? Also, anyone know how many days in a row I can take this safely? The dr. told me "only as long as you need it" but I am afraid that will be for awhile. Thank you so much.



</question>



<additional details>



To clarify, she said 2 pills 2 times per day (not 2 total.) I would much rather take nothing at all, but at this point the pain is absolutely horrific so I'm afraid I need it for the moment. Thank you for the suggestion about the generic- that is a great idea!!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Baby boy due in Feb. 09.
Member since: 25 December 2007
Total points: 3413 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



extra strength is regular Tylenol and is perfectly safe during pregnancy. You can take the regular dosage it says on the bottle and you and baby will be fine. Good luck and don't worry!



</answer>

<answer from>



Pops
Member since: 10 May 2007
Total points: 763 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



So she recommended 2 325 mg pills.  That's 650mg.



Try one 500mg tablet and see if that works.  If it isn't enough, cut a 500 mg into quarters (125 mg per quarter) and take 1 500 mg and 1 of the quarters for a total of 625mg.



The absolutely safe amount?  Zero.



Tylenol is very tough on the liver, but not usually a problem at this low a dosage.



I recommend considering accupuncture for the back pain.  No drugs and very effective.



Source(s):



Life



</answer>



<answer from>



Me
Member since: 20 November 2007
Total points: 3036 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Extra strength is ok, that's what I take. But what I do is take 1 to see if it eases the pain. If not I take another in about an hour. I have taken 2 at a time before though, my doctor said it's ok.



</answer>



<answer from>



Calijess
Member since: 07 November 2007
Total points: 769 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I guess every doctor is different.  Mine has said that 5 a day (500mg each) is fine, but not to take any more than that.  I have been having extreme back pain in the middle of the night since I was 20 weeks which doesn't let me get back to sleep and he has said that the three I treat it with plus 2 Tylenol PM before bed are fine.



I manage to not do the 5 very often, if ever and many days lately have not even needed any but I think it is good to know the "safe" zone so you don't have to worry.

<question>



Brown blood spotting 8 days after ovulation, then light red spotting on AF day what does this mean?



I ovulated from the 14-18 of october, the brown spotting started on 10/27/08.  The next day nothing, then it happened again on 10/29/08.  My period was expected today 10/31/08, but it is light bleeding not like my normal flow, what does this mean?  Helllllpppp, scared to death.



</question>



<answer from>



Baby boy due in Feb. 09.
Member since: 25 December 2007
Total points: 3413 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well it could be from implantation or your period coming only starting off light. I would take a test today to see and if it is positive then it from pregnancy, you shouldn't worry though if it is just spotting. If it is accompanied by pain and it gets a lot heavier go to the E.R. If your test is negative then it is probably just your period only it is lighter. Good luck!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Angellov...
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 2073 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



could mean your pregnant could mean your not, im not sure im not a doctor but take a test and then maybe call your doctor and tell them whats going on.



</answer>



<answer from>



carogato...
Member since: 03 May 2008
Total points: 571 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This could be implantation bleeding. I went through the same thing and assumed it meant I wasn't pregnant, so I was very surprised to find out that I was. What I would do if I were you is go out right away and buy a home pregnancy test. Try one of the ones that says it will detect pregnancy up to 5 days before your missed period, because I think those may be a little more sensitive to HCG, the hormone that is present when you're pregnant. Good luck!



</answer>

<answer from>



carogato...
Member since: 03 May 2008
Total points: 571 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, that is normal- don't worry a thing about it =). This is my first pregnancy and I didn't feel any flutters (let alone kicks) until 22 weeks. From then on, they would happen a couple times per week, but they definitely didn't happen every day. I asked the doctor about it, and it turned out that I have an anterior placenta, meaning that the placenta is facing the front of my uterus instead of the back. The doctor said this happens in about 10% of pregnancies, and while completely harmless, will cause you to feel the baby's movements later and less strongly than moms whose placenta is located toward the back. The mom's weight is supposed to be another factor, but I am average weight and I still didn't feel it too early on. Now, at 31 weeks, she's much more regular and I can feel definite "awake" periods, although the movement is stronger some days than others. Ask your doctor, but I think she will tell you what you're experiencing is pretty normal at this point. Good luck!



Source(s):



Personal experience, reading a kajillion baby books



</answer>



<answer from>



m.i.a08
Member since: 27 November 2007
Total points: 843 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Please don't worry! It could be that your placenta is on the front of your uterus, which cushions any movement. Otherwise first time mums usually feel movement later than 2nd or 3rd time mums. Maybe try having a drink of orange juice or something and lay down in bed in the quiet and just rub your belly for a while. You might get a kick or something. Sounds weird but a midwife told me to do that and it worked for me. But other than that id say in the next couple of weeks you will definitely start to feel it.



</answer>

<answer>



Those flutters that you felt were the baby. I remember with my first child I felt flutters at around 20 weeks and I didn't know that it was my baby moving.  Then with my second child I felt flutters in my 16th week and I knew it was the baby. Some people feel their baby move at different times.  My theory is that it also has to do with how big the baby is.  My first baby was born at 6'4, but my second baby was born at 8'4 and they could tell at about 8 months that I was going to have a big baby just because of where the feet were.  You are just fine!

<answer>



I would either call your doctor or get an over the counter pregnancy test.  They aren't expensive, but they are effective.  It is possible to become pregnant on the pill--I did, and I took my pill like clockwork!



Switching pills may have opened a window of opportunity there, too.  I got pregnant when I went on a slightly lower dose pill, since I was having such a terrible reaction to my other higher dose pill.



Source(s):



Mommy of three, and nursing student.

<question>



How high are the chances of getting pregnant one day after her period finished.?



Condom was used but broke. She took the morning after pill eight hours after it happened.

Member since: 27 October 2008

<answer>



the chances are very high that is the point where you are most fertile is before and after your period, but if you took the day after pill it will probably work right. just relax and wait to see what happens



</answer>



<answer from>



carogato...
Member since: 03 May 2008
Total points: 571 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If her period just finished, there is a pretty low chance that she will get pregnant because she just expelled all of the lining that the baby would implant it. Since she also took the morning after pill, it is kind of a moot point though.



</answer>



<answer from>



Katie Lou 84
Member since: 09 October 2008
Total points: 478 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



shes most fertile after her period - but if she took the morning after pill within the required time  then i wouldn't worry, the chances of pregnancy are very slim



</answer>



<answer from>



Sourkand...
Member since: 20 May 2007
Total points: 988 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Morning after pill is highly effective if used within 72 hours of unprotected sex.  Not to mention the chances of conceiving the day after her cycle would be almost impossible.....She would have to ovulate (release an egg) in order to get pregnant which usually happens around 14 days after the start of her period.  I think your in the clear.



</answer>

Member since: 20 October 2008

<answer>

<answer from>



bookmom
Member since: 17 October 2006
Total points: 10560 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



A woman is NOT most fertile after her period---some of these responses are incorrect.



You are less likely to conceive the day after your period because a woman's body usually doesn't release an egg until days later. BUT it is possible. Sperm can live a few days and if the egg is released early....



If she took the morning-after pill then I would think it is darn near impossible.



</answer>



<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 30500 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



That's not a very fertile time, AND she took the morning after pill. So the odds of pregnancy are very low.



</answer>

<question from>



soccerch...
Member since: 13 July 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Trying to get pregnant...rubella?



My hubby and I are thinking about trying for a baby. I went to the doctor over the summer and she said that before I even consider trying that I have to go get blood work done to see if I am immune to rubella. I know I had the shot years ago when I was a kid. Is this something everyone has to do or is this a new thing? She said that if it turns out that I am no longer immune that I will have to get the shot and then wait three months to try because it is a live vaccine. I feel like I would be more nervous about accidentally getting pregnant around the time of the shot than I would about contracting rubella. If I ignore the doctor's advice then I'm afraid she will judge me and think I'm irresponsible. Should I just do it? I'm kinda wary of doctors/pharmaceutical companies, etc.



Sorry if this posted twice but it didn't show up the first time?



</question>



<answer from>



Piaz
Member since: 28 December 2006
Total points: 3864 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



This never occurred to me when I got pregnant, and my husband didn't either. I had gotten the shots as a kid!  At my first appointment after pregnancy, they tested me for the rubella vaccine, and I wasn't immune!  It was such a surprise.  They couldn't give me the vaccine as I was already pregnant.



I did receive the vaccine after I had the baby, and I was told by the OB's nurse that some people have natural resistance to the vaccine, and that I would never have to receive the shot again in the future, because now either I am immune or I am not immune because it wouldn't take and it would never take if that was the case.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

I've heard if u are resistent to the vaccine, no matter how many times they give it to u, u will always be resistant so what's the point? I'll get the test though to be safe.

<answer from>



jackmatt
Member since: 17 December 2007
Total points: 11829 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



First of all, go get the blood test done that tells your immunity. if you are "immune" then you don't even have to wait to TTC, but if you are not immune then you can make a decision then. Chances are that you are immune, but contracting rubella during pregnancy can cause miscarriage or severe birth defects. This test is often done at the first prenatal visit, but nothing can be done about it once pregnant except avoiding sick people (who might have it) & getting revaccinated after delivery
OB/GYN RN & mom



</answer>



<answer from>



Isabeu O (Finally a mummy!)
Member since: 02 January 2008
Total points: 15931 (Level 6)

Well, I can't speak for you doctor, however I fell pregnant, not knowing that I too was not immune from Rubella anymore.

I was told to avoid people with German measles like the plague!



If it weighs on your mind, I'd get the test! I wouldn't have risked it if I knew for sure I wasn't immune!

More than likely you are FINE if you've already been vaccinated, so you won't even have to worry about it.  If, on the off chance, it turns out that you aren't immune... well, three months is not a long time to wait.  You will just have to be diligent about your birth control during that time.

<answer from>



harchick...
Member since: 04 February 2008
Total points: 10314 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Homework Help



</answer from>



<answer>



If you're going to have a baby, you're going to have to get over your fear of doctors.



Even if you use a midwife to help you deliver your baby, a midwife can't operate to reattach a broken growth plate on your child's elbow after she falls from the monkey bars, as mine did.  You'll need to trust a doctor to do that, and then again when it's time to operate to remove the wiring that kept it in place for 11 weeks.



Here are the risks:
*** If you don't have the test, and your immune system is no longer strong against rubella, and you come across it while you are newly pregnant, you could miscarry or your baby could be born deaf.



Odds of having a miscarriage?  Who knows?



Odds of having a deaf baby?  Not high.



But why take the chance on either one when you can be certain to prevent it altogether?



Source(s):



About deafness from rubella - http://pregnancy.about.com/od/diseasespr...
About growth plate fractures - http://orthopedics.about.com/cs/pediatri...



</answer>

<question>



Do i get to choose how my labor is induced?



im 39 weeks pregnant and my due date is tues and my doctor said if i don't go into labor by thurs (thurs is my doctors appointment) then i will be induced. I was told that he can ether break my water or give me something in a iv. do i get to choose how im induced?

<answer from>



C B
Member since: 19 June 2008
Total points: 3650 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Why do you need to be induced only 2 days after your due date?  Most doctors will let a woman go 2 WEEKS past her due date before inducing, unless there is a pressing medical reason why the baby shouldn't stay in there longer.



You have every right to ask for, accept or refuse ay procedure.  Just know that inductions have a 40% higher rate of failing and leading to c-section than allowing your body to go into labor naturally.



If they break your water and your body isn't quite ready for labor, it most likely won't do much.  It will, however, increase your risk of infection.  It will also make the doctors watch the clock and if you don't progress within several hours, they WILL send you in for c-section because then it becomes an "emergency".



If they give you pitocin through an IV and you are not already amply effaced and dilated, you also may not progress and the same scenario will happen.  The contractions wtih pitocin are much stronger and are more likely to send your fetus into distress.



I hope that you ask these questions of your doctor - mostly 'Why do you want to induce me so soon?'



Best of luck!



Source(s):



LOL at thumbs down!  This is scientific data, people.



</answer>

Geanine
Member since: 10 October 2007
Total points: 392 (Level 2)

<answer>



Ohh you are soo sweet. First of all, you are an angel for taking care of your brothers while pregnant.



Remember that teenage years are very difficult to deal with... I'm sorry that you feel guilty about yelling at the boys. The nine year old may feel neglected because you are turning all the atention to the older brothers and the younger one... so if the 9 year old is expected to do what he needs to do, he will be prone to be more forgetful than the other ones.



I will tell you what works for my family: for my 10 year old son (who tends to "forget" common basis personal tasks)  is to give him a Checklist. It works. I have an AM list and a PM list... he's old enough to get ready so all I have to do is to drop him off in daycare and all I have to say in the morniong is to remind him of the "checklist" The checklist includes basic tasks such as making his bed, brush his teeth, put his homework in the backpack etc.) Believe it or not, kids his age enjoy having responsabilities. PRAISE him when completing the tasks every day... this checklist has save me a lot of time and has kept me sane.



As far as your teenager brothers... my advice is for your husband to talk to him man to man. The 18 year old will be out of yoru house soon and make sure he understand that he needs to get a job, join the military etc. etc. because the free ride ends when he graduates from HS. If he decides to stay, then tell him that he will be paying rent. I know this sounds harshm but he is an adult. As far a sthe other teenager, make sure that your husband TALKS to him --- man-to-man. When I talk to my 10 year old son it seems like he is not listening to me... but my husbands talks to him like a man and he complies immedietly... my husband never screams or yells at him...he simply talks to him like an adult and my son responds instanteneoulsy. Also, it seems like your brothers are bored and are getting on your nerves to entretain themselves... may I suggest a project! can they build a fence? Join the YMCA or the Boys and Girls Club...they have age appropriate activities for teens in a positive enviroment (they have a scholarship program for families in your situation)  let them join a SPORT league, learn to play the guitar...something where they can challenge their energy and keeps their minds occupied. If they are still more than you can handle, it's ok to ask for the help of social services. Tell them that yoru two older brother will have to go temporarly or permanently while you deliver and have a newborn. I know this is harsh, but it's better than to lose yoru mind. Make sure that your brthers are calmy inform that if they do not shape up by X day, they will be going to a foster home and make them know that they will be a baby in the house and that they can choose to help or move out. Reassure them that you love them and that you really want to make things work, but that you cannot do this alone without their cooperation. I'm sure that your brothers have suffered enough too  and that treats are not working anymore. **hugs for everyone**



Good luck in your pregnancy and I hope everything goes well..



God bless!



PS/ You are a better person than me . I truly admire you.

<answer>



As an older sister myself, I think the issues you're having with your brothers-18 and 16- are completely normal.  They don't want to listen because you're their sister, they know how far they can push you, and they're teenagers.  I think God makes teenagers somewhat irritating so you're ready for them to leave when it's time.  lol.  If I were you, I would get the 18 and 16 year old to sit down with you and your husband and talk to them like the adults they're about to be.  Tell them what they're doing that's bothering you, how you expect them to help, etc.



As for the 9 yo, I would talk to him too, but be encouraging.  When he wants you to do something for him, remind him that he needs to be learning to do things himself.  Maybe you could even encourage him to help the 4 yo as they say "teaching is the best way to learn."



One last thing, the pregnancy hormones-whether you realize it or not-are playing a huge part in all of this.  They're making you more irritable and easily annoyed.  I've been pregnant five times myself and by the end, I'm so sure everyone is walking around doing the most annoying things just to get on my nerves. lol.  By the time you're done being pregnant and have the new baby, you'll feel so much better and things will likely calm down a bit.

<answer from>



brendasm...
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 1980 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have seen a similar situation in a friend's family.  They took in three nephews after their parents (the wife's sister and the sister's husband) both died.



I think that what was going on psychologically is that those boys were still unsure they would be unconditionally loved and accepted.  So they began testing to see how far this "love" and "acceptance" really went.  In other words, they had to find the breaking point where their new family would throw up their hands and say, "That's it!  We can't deal with your behavior any longer!  You're going to have to go to some other place!"  What they failed to realize was that it was their aunt and uncle who were breaking.  Their aunt really does love them and is still committed to keeping them.



But she has become ill with cancer, and their marriage has come very close to falling apart from all the stress.



The best way out of your situation, I think, would be to consult a professional psychologist specializing in issues with children and adolescents (not merely a "counselor").  He or she would be in a position to explain to all the boys, in words of one syllable, what their behavior is actually doing, and what consequences could follow.



You have the right to send your brothers into another foster care situation, if it's crucial to do so to save your health, your sanity, and your own family.  You had this problem wished on you -- you did nothing to make it happen.  You could still keep in touch with them and see them when you wished.



Certainly you love them.  They're your own brothers, after all.  But if their behavior keeps getting worse and worse, it will tear your family apart, while they get to act out all their psychological hangups.



</answer>

<answer from>



stefs05

Total points: 1679 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is hard to say. Usually girls don't ovulate until about 14 days after the day their period starts, but that can vary - so don't count on that. Also, sperm can live in a girl for up to a week, so it is possible that she could be pregnant. There isn't a terribly high chance - even couples that are trying to get pregnant only have about a 20% chance of conceiving every month. But, there is a chance. For now, just try and relax and help her relax (stress can delay a period even if she's not pregnant). If her period is late in November, buy her a test.
Most likely she's not pregnant, but try to be more careful especially since this isn't the first time this has happened.



</answer>

<answer>



braxton hicks contractions are normal after 25 weeks until labor, but if you have them for more than 4 times and hour you need to call your doctor and make sure everything is ok, they shouldn't be too frequent.  he may give you tips on how to keep them down to a min, like walking when they come around until they go away, or relaxing in a warm bathtub ( not hot )

<answer>



I've read in my books that more than 4 in an hour are cause for concern (ie: pre-term labour)



I'd check with your doc. Take it easy. What works for one woman - doesn't work for the other! I'm almost 27 weeks and CANNOT walk while I have one - I need to sit or lie down. Some women can "walk them off"
To be safe - i'd check with doc - never be afraid to check with your doc - this is your child!!! but if it's been on going for 2 days and not letting up after relaxing - I'd get checked. They'll be able to tell you in Labour and Delivery wether they are real or not - with those handy little moniters they have.
Best of luck

<answer from>



Jayah O

<answer>



You are meant to get BH at this point for sure. If you get them often make sure you are not dehydrated. Drink a few cups of water, 3-6 I would say, lay on your left side and see how you feel. <answer from>



Poppy: 7 weeks left!
Member since: 20 February 2008
Total points: 18023 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



I've been having them frequently since 22 weeks. My doctor gave me a guideline. If I have 6+ an hour with increasing intensity I need to call. That was after I kept calling and going to L&D because I was having 4+ an hour (sometimes 10+ an hour). I told them I was going crazy - because each time it was a false alarm. The doctor said some women frequently get them (I was diagnosed with an irritable uterus). So, the rule for her is if they do not increase in intensity they are false contractions - not real ones. So, I've gone by that rule and it's worked out. Kept me from visiting the hospital so frequently.



But, since you are just beginning to experience this and they have not done any tests (like they did on me - I had a cervical exam, I was on a fetal monitor and had a fetal fibronectin test) I would call your doctor to be on the safe side.



Source(s):



33 weeks



</answer>

<question>



I had sex 14th 15th 16th of my cycle and still see white creamy carvical mucus on the 21th of my cycle?



i had sex 14th 15th 16th of my cycle and still see white creamy carvical mucus on the 21th of my cycle. am having abdominal pains and breast tenderness, can i be pregnant?



</question>



<answer from>



Due June 9/09 with #4 & LUVIN IT
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 3018 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



could be. take a test if you miss your period.



Source(s):



baby #4 on the way



</answer>



<answer from>



GMarie
Member since: 08 May 2008
Total points: 704 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are probably ovulating, have sex now!



</answer>



<answer from>



sue
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I"m not sure why you think the discharge you're having would be related to pregnancy, but the other symptoms (abd pain & breast tenderness) can indicate pregnancy or pms.  Having a vaginal discharge and abdominal pains can indicate an infection as well.  Seven days from conception to actual pregnancy symptoms is stretching it a bit, it usually takes longer for that (remember conception actually takes place in the falliopian tube and it takes several days just for the ovum to reach the uterus, then longer yet to implant in the uterine wall, and the hormone changes are gradual).  I'd have the discharge checked out to make sure it's not an infection and if you miss your period & the breast tenderness continues & becomes more noticeable, you might be pregnant.  You'd have to take a test to be sure.



</answer>

<question from>



BJ
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Is it possible to have two false negative pregnancy tests?



I am 24 years old. I am already the mother of a two year old and the pregnancy test i took with her was positive the first try. I am late on my perios and have some symptoms of pregnancy. I have taken two pregnancy tests which were both negative. What should I do? Could they just be false negatives?



</question>



<answer from>



Susan B
Member since: 24 June 2008
Total points: 1602 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



They could very well be false negatives if your body isn't producing enough HCG yet, which I'm sure you know.  It depends how late you are.



If you're more than a week late for your period and still having negative HPTs, try again in a few days.  If the final test comes back negative, chances are you aren't pregnant.



Either way, test again in a few days to be sure.  A blood test with your doctor would be the most accurate way to find out, but since you're already a mother, I'm sure you know that too.



Best of luck, I hope your dreams come true!!



Source(s):



14 weeks pregnant, baby #1



</answer>



<answer from>



Me
Member since: 20 November 2007
Total points: 3036 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It could just be too early to test. Wait a few days and test again.



</answer>



<answer from>



Trophy Wife
Member since: 19 September 2007
Total points: 5996 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it is possible for you to get a false test and still be pregnant.  Some tests are not as sensitive as others.  The early predictor tests require the least amount of HCG to come up positive.  Wait 2 more days and test first thing in the morning with an early predictor test.  I personally like First Response, but everyone has their own brand they go to.  Let us know what happens!



</answer>



<answer from>



Kristin B
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 2451 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's not likely they are inaccurate, but you can go to your doctor and have them do a blood test. Those are more accurate than urine tests and can pick up a smaller trace of HCG.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lb.
Member since: 24 May 2007
Total points: 444 (Level 2)



</answer from>

best make an appointment with your doctor to be 100% sure!
