<question>



38 weeks pregnant... water break?



I am 38 weeks pregnant with my second child. This morning I was laying in bed and I don't know if I peed the bed or if my water broke a little. I got up and went to the bathroom.. still had to pee.. and then layed back down in bed. I had about 2 contractions in that time. Awhile after I layed back down a little more came out. Now I'm up and about, but I haven't really been having contractions. In your opinons/experiences, do you think my water may have started to break or do you think I just may have wet the bed?! Yes, I do have a pantyliner on to watch. And yes I have tried calling the nurses at my clinic, but they are so busy they took down my name & number to call me back. By the way, as of Tue. I was 1-2 cm. dilated, a little effaced (I don't remember how much), my cervix was very soft and the baby was really low. Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



Valerie
Member since: 05 June 2008
Total points: 1314 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sounds like it may have.  If the nurses don't call you back within a few hours, you should take your bag & head to L&D.  If your water has broken, you need to deliver within 24 hours to reduce the risk of infection.  They will test the fluid at the hospital to see if it is indeed amniotic fluid, and then they will induce you.  Good luck!



Source(s):



My water broke at 39 weeks with no contractions.



</answer>



<answer from>



Trophy Wife
Member since: 19 September 2007
Total points: 5996 (Level 5)

<answer>

Calijess

<answer>



During my pregnancy class they talked about water breaking in two ways- one is the way you hear about a lot - the flood of fluids, etc.  The other sounds very similar to what you are describing, where you kind of spring a leak.  They said that sometimes women who this happens to don't know.  And that women wonder if it is wetting the bed or water breaking.  They said to DEFINITELY call in if you had these symptoms.



Keep an eye on when it started and what it looks like, they will ask you all of those questions.  If they don't call you back and you are uncomfortable, you may want to call/go into your hospital.  My hospital has a triage unit I can call with things like this if my drs office is busy.



Good luck on your new baby!



</answer>

<answer>



My water broke the day before I was due at 5:30am with my first.  I wasn't sure that it had.  It felt like I really had to pee super bad and I almost didn't make it to the bathroom.  Throughout the day, at various times, a little more fluid would come out.  I still wasn't sure it had broken as I hadn't had any contractions at all.  At 5:30pm, I finally went to the hospital with my Mom.  Still no contractions.  ETA: Oh, and it did break that morning.



If I were you, I would definitely tell the nurse when she calls back that you think your water may have broken.  It sounds like it could have and it's definitely better to be safe than sorry as waiting too long could cause infection.



Good luck!

baby #4 due 5/20

<answer>



Congrats Girlfriend!  I believe your water has broken.  Good call with the pantyliner.  Depending on where your amniotic sac ruptured (if on top, then it is usually a little trickle at a time), then you may not get the "big gush."  If it is clear and continuing to come out, then it is most likely your water.  Also if it has a sweet smell, as opposed to an ammonia smell indicating urine, you probably broke your water.  Make sure they see you today.  You shouldn't go too long after breaking your water.  Good luck and congrats on your new addition.

<answer>



you don't want to know. although every situation is different, before I got pregnant, my boss got fired, and we got new boss. she was a ***** who was like 40 with no kids and didn't like kids, ( from what we could tell, if you had a child's event to attend she wouldn't be happy about you leaving work for it )  anyways needless to say I was about 3 months pregnant and decided to tell work I was.  a week later they fired me for a stupid reason.  i applied for unemployment and was granted it by the state, they said they had no good reason to fire me.  then my employers company appealed the courts decision and we had a date to go to court over it, i got a lawyer. when the company found out i hired a lawyer they dropped their case against me and let me collect my unemployment.  i was out about a month and it was nice actually b/c i had real bad morning sickness. i had a totally different job now that is better for me and my baby and this job has no stress, i can be out for my doctors appointments no problem, and can be late or leave early when i don't feel good.  I LOVE MY BOSS!  anyways, the fact is it may not affect you at all or it might for some stupid reason.  mine was very stressful but i mad it through and now i thank god, b/c i might have lost the baby with the job i had before, it was highly stressful and not very safe.  just pray!!

<answer from>



violet
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 6377 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Teen & Preteen



Parenting



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



New management can and often do make changes in staff.  Quite a lot depends on the kind of organization in which you work, whether you have a contract, with whom, and what provisions for termination are spelled out.



It's true that they can't discriminate against you for being pregnant, but it they are laying off others, then you may not be able to make a case for being singled out.  I think you should talk about your concerns with your new boss, if that person is already there, or with your current boss, if s/he has not yet left.  Read your contract, too.  Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Emma due 11/30/08
Member since: 29 April 2008
Total points: 2871 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on what your position is and if it is only needed when your old boss was there. Really no matter if you are pregnant or not, they can find a reason to let you go. I got let go when I was 5 months pregnant and there was nothing I could do about it. I even tried to apply for unemployment but they found a way to get around me getting approved. Not that that will happen to you, I found out I was working for crooked people after the fact that screwed over all employees. They ended up shutting their doors completely about a month after I was let go.



Just talk to someone and try and get a feel for what might happen so you get an idea of what to expect. Sorry and good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Dr. Diagnonsense
Member since: 08 July 2007
Total points: 20483 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



You’re only protected from being discriminated against for being pregnant.  Basically your employer can’t let you go just because they’re pissed you’ll have to take leave in a few months.



There’s no law stopping them from letting you go if you’re just honestly not needed. In my experience, a large corporation might be reluctant to let you go if you’re expecting just for the simple fear that you would claim discrimination and sue, but if they’re letting other non-pregnant people go too, you’re really not protected.



What you can do is to bust your tail and make yourself as valuable to the company as you can. You’ll keep your job as long as you can show you’re a necessary part of the organization.



Believe me, I understand the fear. My own employer has laid off more than 200 people in the last month just in my region. It doesn’t sound like a lot, but it’s a ton for a company that has never really done a mass lay-off before. I’m grateful for every day that I remain employed.



</answer>

And she has plenty of other interesting toys to play with. She's a very unclean cat and gets litter everywhere and even plays in her water dish and then jumps in the litter box and tracks litter everywhere. My husband hasn't been very good lately with cleaning the litter box everyday. So Im annoyed about that. I am really worried about catching that parasite cats can carry which can cause brain damage, deafness, and blindness in babies. Should I be worried or maybe take the cat to a friend's house so they can take care of her for a couple months? We only had her for a year and she's my first pet cat so I'm more than likely not immune to toxoplasmosis. Anybody run into this problem?

Is that normal? should its be so watery? do u think my water broke and im just leaking?



Those of you who got this done did it help you any to start stronger contractions? did is help you start labor?



i got a week to go, im anxious but i know i can wait another week ...i hope lol. im 2 cm dialated i got a long way to go, just share with me your experiences and some advice. thanks.



</question>

i noticed stronger contractions but they are tolerable, i can still talk through them, and they are irregular.

<answer from>



Babystep...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 117 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Stripping the membranes does hurt (Ouch). I had it done with my middle daughter, and went walking immediately after wards. Yes, the brown discharge is normal (at least it is what I had). I went into labor about 6 hours after having them stripped, but I am sure it was because I went walking. The more I walked the stronger the contractions got, and eventually I couldn't walk anymore! I would have died if I had to stay pregnant one more day. I was miserable.



</answer>

<answer>



I'm not sure about anyone else, but I was told that your waters were supposed to be clear and transparent, not dark brown.
I know my waters were clear!



It is however quite possible that you are experiencing your 'bloody show'.
If your contractions are still irregular, wait for some regularity before going off to the hospital, however it wouldn't be a bad idea to call your doc/midwife about the dark brown discharge.



</answer>

<answer>



It sounds like early stages of labor. My doctor stripped my membranes, or as she called it "helping me along", ay 3 pm and I went into the hospital ay 11 pm.



Since it does sound like you are leaking fluid, I would go and get it checked. They will test the fluid with a piece of paper to see if it is amniotic. You don't want to wait past 12 hrs if it is, due to an increase in infection rate.



Source(s):



Good Luck!

I would say if it is continuing go to the hospital.  if it has stopped and you are not having regular contractions Wait and see what happens.

Easy as this.. Don't have sex until you are ready to have kids. If you aren't ready to have kids, you aren't ready to have sex. You can get pregnant on any day... it doesn't matter. I'm sure there are days that are "least likely" for you to get pregnant, but you can still get pregnant no matter what day it is.



</answer>

<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 30512 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



There is a birth control method called Natural Family Planning.  It uses your own personal fertility signs to help YOU determine when you ovulate, and what days are safest for you to have sex with little risk of pregnancy.  Used carefully and properly, Natural Family Planning (which is NOT the same thing as the old 'rhythm method') is about as effective as most other methods.  (95-99% range.)



Here are a few links to get you started:



http://familydoctor.org/online/famdocen/...



http://www.irh.org/nfp.htm



http://www.bygpub.com/natural/natural-fa...



</answer>



<answer from>



Cassie M
Member since: 11 June 2008
Total points: 231 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

OR



Dont have sex! It's the most effective birth control around. :)



</answer>

<question>



For the mothers who had to have a planned c-section, what?



did you pack in your hospital bag since you knew you'd be there for about 3 days?



Thanks in advance :-)



</question>



<answer from>



Kristi is 11 weeks!
Member since: 29 July 2007
Total points: 6344 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



I packed the same things you'd always pack, just a little more.  I brought breast pads, night gowns, extra socks, slippers, robe, some magazines (I have trouble focusing on anything after a c-section for some reason), nursing bras, personal care items like deodorant, toothbrush/paste, and shampoo.  You get the idea.  I also brought some extra things for the baby like blankets and sleepers, the coming-home outfit.



I hope that helps.  Good luck!



Source(s):



baby #4 due 5/20, 3 c-sections so far



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 22 May 2007
Total points: 1522 (Level 3)

<answer from>



mookiemo...
Member since: 15 September 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



Congratulations! I had planned c-sections with both my children. I just took soap, shampoo, deodorant, nightgowns (some hospitals let you bring your own, if you want to), a robe, slippers, socks, maternity bras if you're going to breastfeed,  and a change of clothes for the trip home. The hospital usually provides a certain kind of underwear (for post-surgery care), pads for you, extra blankets, and everything the baby will need, diapers, wipes, formula, etc.



</answer>

Member since: 04 February 2008

If you need anything extra (extra clothes,  books etc) you can always get your partenr / a friend / your relatives to bring them in.



</answer>

<answer from>



Blue Jean
Member since: 06 April 2006
Total points: 18330 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



If your last period was Oct 12th, your most fertile days would have been 19th to 27th.  Ovulation might have occurred on the 25th.  There's a chance you might have become pregnant during that time, but you won't have symptoms for another two to three weeks.
See your doctor ASAP because you might still be able to get the morning after pill.  It works best if there has been less than 72 hours since the "event".
Always use condoms.  Pulling out or knowing when your "non fertile" days are is not an effective way of preventing pregnancy.



</answer>



<answer from>



April B
Member since: 22 June 2007
Total points: 146 (Level 1)

<answer>

Waterbirth is definitely safer. (And that IS a 'natural birth .. using natural methods rather than meds to help cope with the contractions.)  Cheaper too.



I'd go for a waterbirth.  If you find that it's not enough, you can request an epidural at any time and the hospital staff will be happy to oblige you.



</answer>

<answer>



You can start out with a water birth and change your mind and have the epidural later on. I would keep your options open because you don't know how you will tolerate the pain.



I am on my third birth (hopefully any day) and I have had an epidural both times before, I have put down in the hospital notes that an epidural is my preferred method of pain relief. But as far as I am concerned, you will be giving birth and you need to try and do this the way you want to try and do it.

<answer from>



I'd rather be at the beach
Member since: 28 May 2008
Total points: 2650 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You're going to have to decide that when the time comes.  You can have your plan, but things can change!  I did a 100% all natural childbirth (even after 25 hours of labor).  There are a lot of pros for having a natural childbirth -- you're able to walk around, get in the jacuzzi, feel when you need to push (usually there's less tearing because of that), you're able to walk around after wards, no catheter, etc.  But be prepared for anything.



Water births I'm leery about.  They don't seem quite safe to me, although they seem like an amazing idea.  I started pushing in the water, and I'm sure I would have been more comfortable in there (our hospital doesn't allow water births).  But if you're in the water, and comfortable -- go for it.  My friend had an amazing water birth.



Good luck to you!  Early congrats -- cute name!!



Source(s):



mother of a 15 month old



</answer>



<answer from>



E&L
Member since: 12 January 2008
Total points: 7748 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I could see you comparing water-birth and natural . . . but an Epidural is totally at the other end of the spectrum.  If you even have that one as an option than I'm not sure you are prepared for natural childbirth.  It's not really what is better, but what you can tolerate.  A water-birth may be more calming and relaxing . . . but only for the woman who can tolerate the level of pain that comes with childbirth, especially the first.  The amount of pain will be the same, but how tolerant you are to it and ability to tune it out and focus on the outcome is the real deciding factor here.



</answer>

<answer>



I had my son a year ago and insisted that I was going to do it all natural. After 30 hours of labor though, I ended up getting some Demerol. It didn't take away the pain, it just took the edge of, which was exactly what I needed. My son was born about 10 hours later.



I have little to no pain tolerence, but I did it without meds for so long because I wanted what I thought was best for me and my baby. And ultimately that is what you have to decide. Unexpected things do happen in labor and delivery so don't be too set in your plan. You never know what that little boy is going to decide to do.

14 wks along with baby # 4~
Member since: 31 December 2006
Total points: 1692 (Level 3)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



I had all three of my boys naturally at the hospital and I plan a natural with this one. I have never had a water birth so I can't help you there. I'm too scared of an epidural. You don't take meds all through your pregnancy to keep the baby safe. I personally just don't think it is a good idea to put a bunch of meds in your body when you are giving birth just for pain relief. It isn't natural. The pain is intense, I won't lie. I just had to keep telling myself that I would be ok, it would be over soon, and that no ones dies from the pain from childbirth. Besides the fact that more and more studies are linking pitocin and epidural meds. to autism. It makes sense too, look at all the cases of Autism nowdays and more women are having epidurals and being induced. Just about 6 months ago we had a story here where we live about a young lady that was given too much medication in her epidural and was paralyzed. Just not worth the risk for me. Everyone I know that has had an epidural now has headaches and back pain that they didn't have before. I was in the delivery room with my sister when she had her epidural. It slowed her contractions way down, she couldn't feel to push the baby out so that took forever, and when she wanted to pee they had to put in a catheter. I believe natural birth is better, baby's have been born that way since the beginning of time and if it was that horrible, women wouldn't have more than one child..lol. Once the baby is out, the pain is over.  Women that do opt for pain meds are not wimps or weak. Everyone is different and it is a personally choice. Best wishes to you and your little boy :)



Source(s):



Mom of 3 and 1 on the way :)



</answer>

Louise

<answer>



that depends do you want no pain or slightly bearable pain or unbearable pain.



No pain = Epidural. i had no pain in my epidural i realise though that some people can still feel something but for me i felt nothing.



Slightly Bearable = water birth. i have not had a water birth so not sure what it is like but i do know what it feels like to have warm running water while in labour and you get some nice relief from that however you can still feel the pain.



Unbearable = All natural. the pain is horrible but i was able to do it with my second and now i am able to believe that it is acheivable( i had no choice though. I was unable to have en epidural or gas or anything because the babies head was not far down enough and they didn't know how long i was going to be in labour for).



Well hope this helps good luck.

Member since: 20 February 2008

<answer>



My doctor didn't talk about a weight restriction with me. He said you can continue doing what you have been doing. Therefore, if you have been lifting your child you can continue to do so. But, if you haven't lifted anything you shouldn't go around and lift 40lb objects.



If you don't feel comfortable lifting him I wouldn't. I'd also check and see what your doctor says. I know doctors often say different things on the same issue.

<answer>



this is what my doc said.....(i have a 26 lb 2 year old and a 30 lb 3 year old) that i shouldnt try to to lift them often and if i do lift with legs not back, cause it will strain my muscles that are already strained, and instead sit on the couch and let them come to me, and sit on my lap....that being said, i still carry my kids, sometimes both when i need to get them where they need to be, and yes my back is aching, but sometimes you just have to.  I try to sit down and let them sit on my lap. Like you i dont want my kids to think i dont want to hold them cause i am having a new baby.  So hope this helps.

brendasm...

</answer from>



<answer>



A lot depends on whether he climaxed, and where he was if that occurred.  If there was seminal fluid released near your opening, sperm cells could possibly work their way up into your uterus, although that's not very likely.  Pregnancy can even happen without a climax, if some seminal fluid seeped out while he was inside you even a little.



If you miss your next period by several days, it will be time to take a pregnancy test.  The most likely outcome in this case is that you've been lucky and your period will come.  From now on, though, don't do anything intimate with your boyfriend until you have obtained reliable birth control for yourself (I'm talking about the Pill).



</answer>



<answer from>



Kristin B
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 2459 (Level 3)

<answer>



If he was sure he would have told you for certain. On our level 1 ultrasound at 20 weeks the penis and testes were visible even to me. I didn't need to wait for the technician to tell me. I pointed at the screen and said: "Isn't that testicles?"



But at 16 weeks the external genitals are still forming, so even if your baby was going to sprout a penis, it might not be visible, especially with poor positioning.

<answer>



I wouldn't be worried if I were you since you're not bleeding.  I am 21 weeks and I still have cramping and discharge.  As some women get further along in their pregnancy they have more discharge.  The cramping is due to your body adjusting and growing due to a living little person inside you.  My back has hurt the whole time through the pregnancy.  If you really think something is wrong then you should go ahead to the doctor but I am almost positive everything is fine as long as you're not bleeding.  Every mother has their worries about having a miscarriage.  Trust me, it is always in the back of your head but you need to enjoy your pregnancy and not stress over it.  Good Luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Knocked Up
Member since: 07 March 2007
Total points: 533 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My advice is to just calm down. First of all, nausea, back aches, and discharge are completely normal. I don't know who told you increased discharge was a sign of miscarriage but they should be smacked for worrying you. I cramped SO badly for the first few weeks after finding out I was pregnant. The doctors said it was just stuff being stretched around to accommodate the baby. I also had bleeding and went to the ER. Turned out everything was okay and it was just some old blood. I say as long as you're not bleeding, you're fine. BUT if you just can't stop worrying, try and get to a clinic or even go to the ER if it would settle your nerves. I don't know what kind of insurance you have though, so be careful not to rack up too many bills. If you start bleeding though, I would go to the nearest clinic or emergency room. BUT stop stressing and I'm sure everything will be fine. Everyone is worried about this during their first few weeks!



</answer>

<answer from>



FLmom3
Member since: 22 January 2007
Total points: 7481 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Please don't worry- as long as you are not having any sort of bleeding or brown discharge, I would just take it easy, relax and enjoy your pregnancy! If you do have bleeding, it is NOT necessarily a miscarriage- there are many explanations for bleeding during pregnancy. I have a friend who bled during her entire pregnancy and had a completely healthy baby. An increase in discharge is normal as well. But just remember- all women are different and each pregnancy is different. I have been pregnant 5 times, and each and every one has been completely different. Good luck to you!



</answer>



<answer from>



jstrong2...
Member since: 17 February 2006
Total points: 435 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



All of your symptoms are completely natural.  If you have worries, call your doctor's office.  If you have stomach pains and are bleeding, then you should call the doctors office immediately or go in to the emergency room.  The urgency status of pregnant women are elevated and so your will be seen a lot faster than normal.



Just keep in mind that the cervix becomes very fragile during pregnancy and bleeding can occur and still be normal.  Bright red blood is not always a bad sign, but it still should always be checked out by a doctor or midwife as soon as possible.  Dark blood (brownish in color) is very very normal and should be expected.  If you have a good doctor, she/he should be there to answer your questions or assuage your worries should you have any.



Good luck and remember... take those vitamins :)



</answer>



<answer from>



smiley1
Member since: 31 May 2006
Total points: 227 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer>



Calm Down!

Relax :)

<answer from>



mommy2be
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 376 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Don't be scared of miscarrying! I know it's hard but don't stress. Nausea is common, back pain is not so normal but it could have been the way you slept. Cramping is probably coming from your morning sickness, and I had the same issue with the discharge, unless its like a weird amount (like a Lot!) then I wouldn't worry about it.



when I was 7 weeks, I woke up one morning and my waters had leaked...I called the doctor and he told me to come in right away and I went in and he told me to go home and relax and I would have a miscarriage any day. I was devastated but kept positive, I stayed on bed rest and tried to stay calm. When I went back to the doctor after two weeks of tests and no miscarriage, he was stunned and said he had never seen this happen, 9 out of ten women would have lost their baby in this situation and I didn't. Im now 37 weeks pregnant with a perfectly healthy baby girl.
I wish you the best of luck and just remember to stay calm.



</answer>

Member since: 28 March 2008

She's a very unclean cat and gets litter everywhere and even plays in her water dish and then jumps in the litter box and tracks litter everywhere. My husband hasn't been very good lately with cleaning the litter box everyday. So Im annoyed about that. I am really worried about catching that parasite cats can carry which can cause brain damage, deafness, and blindness in babies. Should I be worried or maybe take the cat to a friend's house so they can take care of her for a couple months? We only had her for a year and she's my first pet cat so I'm more than likely not immune to toxoplasmosis. Anybody run into this problem?



</question>



<answer from>



Kitty
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 424 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



my husband too isn't very good with the litter box, and all cats are messy when it comes to the litter, mine does play in her water dish but doesn't jump in tthe litter afterwards so i just get water everywhere.  one thing, is it an indoor only cat? if so you are less prone to getting that bacteria they talk about b/c it mainly comes from them eating mice and other rodents. although you should take any chances and still stay away from the litter box!  youcan wear gloves and help with the mess but don't scoop it by no means.  talk or yell at your hubby whatever it takes for him to realize that you CANNOT do this he needs to for your baby's sake, he needs to grow up and take charge of the litter box correctly, everyday i ask my husband... did you scoop it today?  it needs to be cleaned out again...( i have 3 indoor cats )  he knows i can't do it, and husbands can be childish more than they realize.  i don't think they every grow up!

<answer>

<answer from>



Knocked Up
Member since: 07 March 2007
Total points: 533 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



First of all, you really only have to worry if the cat goes outside because they get toxoplasmosis from eating mice and birds. That being said, if you're like me you're going to worry about it regardless. I have a cat that's never set foot on dirt, and I still don't touch the litter. Talk to your hubby about cleaning it better. If that doesn't work, call your  mom or a friend and see if they would mind coming over once a week to do the maintenance. And if all else fails you can do what I do...when he throws poo out of the litter box I vacuum it up. Not the best thing for the vacuum, but my baby is more important. If you must clean it yourself invest in some gloves and paper face masks. Clean it, throw the gloves and mask away, and scrub your hands in hot soapy water. Hope this helps! I'd hate for you to have to get rid of your kitty!



</answer>

<answer from>



Dr. Diagnonsense
Member since: 08 July 2007
Total points: 20505 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I can relate. One of my cats likes to bolt from the box when she’s finished going, only sometimes she’s not quite done and leave a treat on the floor. :-)



My husband was always horrible about dealing with the cat box before I was pregnant. While I’m not normally a nagger, I will bug him about the cat box as often as needed. Not only am I not touching it, I can’t stand the way it smells if dirty. Feel free to remind him when it needs to be cleaned.



I’ve learned that the vacuum cleaner is a great tool for dealing with liter box messes. It gets loose litter off the floor and the hose attachment should have no trouble picking up your cat’s nasty “toys” for you. That way, you don’t actually have to touch anything. Also wash your hands regularly after you’ve been around the box, and obviously before you eat.



One other suggestion is an electric cat box like the Littermaid. We have one. They’re not 100% maintenance-free, but they’ll scoop up most of the waste within 10 min so unless your kitty plays with fresh poo, there won’t be anything left in the box for her to mess with.



Don't get rid of your kitty though. You made a commitment to her, and there are plenty of ways to make this work.



</answer>



<answer from>



Due 1/24...it's a boy!!!!!
Member since: 20 March 2008
Total points: 1532 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Does your cat go outside? If not, then she almost certainly doesn't have toxoplasmosis...they get it from hunting. Also, the poop has to sit in the box for 48 hours before it becomes communicable. So if you clean the box every day (as you should...cats HATE a dirty litter box, that could be why she's tossing the poop out) you shouldn't have an issue. I clean the box for 5 cats every day, have since I became pregnant, and I am careful to wash my hands thoroughly with antibacterial soap after I'm done. Please don't give your cat away just because your husband is lazy...seriously. Tell him he HAS to do it, every single day. Or, if he's a total deadbeat and doesn't care, you'll have to do it yourself. Just be mindful of washing your hands, and keep up with the box every day, and you'll be fine.



Source(s):



2 Dr.'s and a ton of internet searching.



</answer>

<question>



How to check hormone levels?



I am around 4 weeks pregnant and recently asked a question about early scanning as I have previously had two miscarriages. Somebody said to keep checking my hormone levels as this indicates things are going well. How would I do this?



</question>



<answer from>



sunny day due oct 30th
Member since: 24 January 2008
Total points: 2618 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



ask the Doctor for a blood test that will show how high your hcg levels are, then they test you again 48hrs later to make sure they are doubling, only the doctor's can do this good luck



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks :-)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



lingtan1...
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 424 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You have to take a weekly blood test to test for HCG. I had a previous miscarriage in August and got pregnant 1 month later. Doctor also suggest that to me to monitor. But i didn't go for it because i feel it's a waste of money. The alternative is to take horomone pills and injections. I'm taking pills 3 times a day and injection every 3 days till I'm 12 weeks. I'm 12 weeks pregnant now and the baby is healthy but i have low laying placenta. I have stop the injection since last week but still taking the pills



You can read more at my baby's blog http://joanna-shawn.blogspot.com/



Source(s):



http://www.americanpregnancy.org/duringp...



</answer>

<answer>



the doctor needs to do this by taking blood tests, they will take 1 blood test, then another 3days later to see if your hormone levels are doubleing



or you can use regular pregnancy tests, take one the same time everyday (same brand) id just use really cheap ones like from poundland, and if the line starts to fade then its bad news 4u, but im sure it will stay the same :)



gd luck

<question from>



Viran Abeysiriwardhana
Member since: 24 August 2008
Total points: 376 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How Does High Sugar Affect a Baby in a Mother's Stomach?



I Just Wanna Know What Happens. Don't Give Idiotic Answers Like "I Don't Know". I'll Call Them IDIOTIC DUMBO lol.



</question>



<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 30532 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



Babies aren't in their mother's stomach.  Babies grow in the uterus.



And sugar doesn't have any direct effect on the growing fetus.  It's only of concern if mother takes so much sugar that it leaves less room in her diet for other, healthier foods; or leads to excess weight gain which can cause problems for the pregnancy.



</answer>



<answer from>



smiley1
Member since: 31 May 2006
Total points: 231 (Level 1)



</answer from>

i can answer that question  while the baby is in utero what happens is if you are having high sugars it send the message to the unborn child pancreas to secret more insulin in which if a child is exposed for long periods of time it cause thickness in the heart and when the baby comes u\out it may suffer from real low blood sugars because it is not in your body any more its very  dangerous for you and the baby

<answer>



Stress, gaining weight, losing weight can cause your period to be off. If you are truly a virgin (oral and anal sex count, too. Anytime you fool around and semen gets ANYWHERE near your vagina, you risk getting pregnant. It's not a high chance, but the risk is still there.), then there's no way you can be pregnant.



If your period doesn't come in a few weeks, talk to your mom. As long as you're not sexually active, you should have nothing to hide from her, but you do need to talk to a doctor to rule out anything out of the ordinary.



</answer>



<answer from>



c'estmoi
Member since: 26 January 2006

<answer>



If you did not have sex, or have a penis anywhere near your vagina opening, then you are not pregnant.



At your age it is normal to skip a month as your body is still developing.  All sorts of things can make you skip a month, have two in a month, skip a few months, have a LONG period, etc... stress is a common cause of a cycle than is running amok!



</answer>

<question>



More morning sickness, less likely to have a miscarriage? Is that true? Have you heard it?



I was browsing around online yesterday and I caught a brief snippet that said something about if you're having nausea it's a good sign b/c doctors have linked this to decrease chance of miscarriage. I had to close down the website really quick b/c my boss was coming and now I can't find the website. I searched the topic and I did get some statements stating this is true but they were from people in blogs, not any medical websites stating that. It would make sense to me though because if everything's not forming properly, hcg levels will be low, if hcg levels are low, not enough to cause sickness. I had a m/c last month and I'm pregnant again and I'm so worried about this baby but one thing I did notice is last time I had absolutely no sickness. This time, I'm sick everyday. I know sickness doesn't mean every things ok and lack of sickness doesn't mean everything's not ok. But if th ere's any truth to this theory, it will put my mind at ease.



</question>

<answer from>



Nik's mom
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 213 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I did not have a lot of morning sickness, and I had a very healthy pregnancy.



I think people are more likely to suspect miscarriage when your pregnancy is proceeding in a way that is really different for you.  I have a friend who has been through many pregnancies and always had a lot of morning sickness.  Then she had a pregnancy that she wasn't sick at all, and she did lose that baby.  The doctors said that she probably didn't have the morning sickness because her pregnancy was not progressing normally, since morning sickness was normal for her.



</answer>

I know this doesn't help.



I just wanted to let you know that experts say that sickness is a good sign, but it's not a guarantee.



Best of luck!



Source(s):



mom of 3 year old, 1 Mc and 7 month old



</answer>



<answer from>



Poppy: 7 weeks left!
Member since: 20 February 2008
Total points: 18039 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



I heard that and I asked my doctor. The thought is women who have morning sickness have HCG and progesterone levels high enough AND rising to support a pregnancy. I was all freaked out because I never got it. However, I had high HCG and high progesterone that was rising. Not all women react to hormones the same. He said just ONE pregnancy symptom (tender breasts, fatigue etc) indicate adequate hormone levels. But it's not a guarantee one way or the other.



Source(s):



Here is some good info on it:
http://parenting.ivillage.com/pregnancy/...



"There is no medical documentation that proves that women who have nausea, as opposed to any other symptom of pregnancy, are more or less likely to carry their babies to term"



</answer>



<answer from>



mum_2_ma...
Member since: 21 September 2006

<answer from>



G Dahl
Member since: 10 June 2008
Total points: 16904 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Myth. Best, G



Secrets on Natural Remedies for Morning Sickness



New research has found that because women with morning sickness don’t feel like eating or drinking, they may find themselves dehydrated, which could be compounding and creating the symptoms of morning sickness and impairing prenatal health. Proper hydration is critical to every system and process in your body. At the first sign of morning sickness, nausea or vomiting, increase your fluid intake of water throughout the day. Morning sickness is a thirst signal of both the mother and the baby. Be sure that you are drinking water throughout the day and evening.



The next top remedy for morning sickness is to reach for a high protein snack to eat as soon as you feel nausea coming on. Protein and water are the two top building blocks for pregnancy. Morning sickness is a signal from the body that more building materials are necessary for baby. You can have a protein snack and a glass of water before bedtime to eliminate morning nausea.



Source(s):



http://web.mac.com/pregnancysecrets/Site...



</answer>

Could be true. However that wasn't the case for me. With my second child I had no morning sickness at all it was a perfect pregnancy. I think every ones body is so different. I have 4 kids and each one was different the weight gain, the cravings, the heaviness, sickness, the way the belly was shaped, the size of the baby. Man some people have some HUGE babies. So to answer you question I think the only one that can really answer that question is our creator himself.

<answer>



When I was pregnant, I was very sick. I went to my doctor and complained of throwing up a lot and she said "Good. Women who throw up a lot rarely miscarry." There are never any guarantees, but I just thought I'd pass on these words she gave me. If you aren't sick, that doesn't mean you will miscarry. I've known plenty of women who felt fine and had healthy pregnancies. Best of luck!

Member since: 15 October 2008
Total points: 924 (Level 2)

<answer>



I was awake for my c-section and I felt the tugging. It didnt last for very long though. Is anyone going to be in the room with you? Hope this helped and good luck!

<answer>



I had twins via c-section, one came out with no tugging and the other required a lot of tugging (up under my ribs).  I was awake.  It did not hurt it just was odd. <answer>

<answer>



I was awake for my c-section and honestly felt nothing. I was terrified and shaking. They had to tie my arms down because the medicine was making me shake. They said that's normal. I didn't even know they had started. I also heard it's common to throw up during the surgery. Luckily, I didn't. I did after it was over. I promise I felt no pain at all, but I was really scared. Good luck!

<answer>



Talk to your parents first...



Are you financially ready for a baby?
Are you physically ready for a baby?
Will the father stick by your side and not leave you?
Are you willing to give up a little bit of your social life and lose a few friends along the way?
Are you ready to stay up all hours of the night with a screaming baby?
Will your family help support you?



If you answered yes to all those questions, then I don't see a problem keeping the baby, rasing a child is a difficult job and not as easy as it seems, sorry if those questions were bit harsh...you just really need to consider that first. Talk to your doctor about your options as soon as you can! good luck with everything :)



</answer>

<question from>



*baby #1 due 06/21*
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 338 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Question on Delivery!?!?



okay i have a question on delivery, when i was 17 years old which im 20 now i got into a very bad motorcycle accident. we were going around a 20mph curve and the guy driving was going 90mph i flew 2 football fields and landed in a ditch well he died instantly and suffered plenty of broken bones. which one was my pelvic bone. well i guess my question is, since i broke it and its healed now, do you think that there is a chance that i can a vaginal delivery. this is my first baby. or do you think that they will have to a c-section. what do you think? sorry that its long. just been concerned since i have became preggo. haven't been to the doctor yet but i just thought that i would ask. thanks



</question>



<answer from>



Lisa
Member since: 14 January 2007
Total points: 15473 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



If it healed properly then I see no reason that you couldn't deliver vaginally.  However, this is a question best asked of your doctor since he would know your medical history.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mrs. Arnold
Member since: 13 December 2007
Total points: 3240 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its hard to say. They may just let you labor for a while and see how you progress. But I knew a lady who was in a motorcycle accident and her hips or something were broken and she had to have C-sections with her babies. But she also had a metal rod in her hips, so I dont know. But it would definetly be something you should talk to your doctor about.



</answer>



<answer from>



Erin2009
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 1419 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would discuss it w/ your doctor.  They can do some tests to measure your pelvis and gauge whether or not it is big enough for the baby to come through.  They also do this when baby's are breech, for women who want to attempt a vaginal delivery w/ breech presentation.



Any time there is trauma to a bone, it is always weaker than before.  So it may cause you more pain and discomfort.  But again, it would be best to talk it over w/ your doctor.  Unless the doctor feels you are at risk attempting a vaginal birth, more often than not they will let you try.



Good luck



Source(s):



30 weeks w/ #2



</answer>

</category>



<question from>



*Waiting for my lil man* 11/21!
Member since: 12 January 2008
Total points: 1874 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



GD & stillbirth? How common? Why?



What causes stillbirth due to Gestational Diabetes? What is the percentage that this actually happens? Wouldn't you have to have had uncontrolled blood sugars since you had it, say, in the 200s or something from day 1 of being diagnosed, or could the ending week or two do it? My sugars have been getting a tad bit higher, not too bad, but I'm still scared. I see the doctor again Monday. I have twice a week NSTs to monitor him and he's fine on those. They have not measured him via u/s at all. (Which I hear is inaccurate, anyway..) But if my sugars are up for a few days .. would this cause my baby to be stillborn? It's only Thursday, so four days until I see the doctor and they do not consider this an emergency to talk to him now.



</question>



<additional details>



Yes, I do have GDM. I was diagnosed around 29 or 30 weeks and I am now 37 as of tomorrow.



Forgot to mention, I'm 100% diet controlled, no insulin whatsoever.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Sodas♥
Member since: 13 December 2006
Total points: 17980 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



My sugars were up a bit, I took a second test and waiting for the results but if you are being monitored there is nothing to really worry about. Your baby is fine, you only worry if you don't get treatment for it--IF you even have it. I'ts normal to have higher numbers, they just repeat a test.



Source(s):



Mom of 1, 30 weeks with #2



</answer>



<answer from>



nightyni...
Member since: 10 July 2006
Total points: 3255 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Lots of risks with Diabetes babies.



First one is that they tend to be very large for their gestational age.  It's not unheard of for a woman to deliver a 37 week baby that weighs 9 pounds.



The big risk with stillbirth is because the placenta begins to deteriorate faster with diabetes babies.  Not sure why, but if baby isn't getting the oxygen and the nutrients it needs, it won't survive very long.  Fortunately, this doesn't happen nearly as much as it used to.



It's not unusual for you to need more insulin as your pregnancy progresses, just adjust accordingly to stay in really tight control.



Good luck to you!



</answer>

<answer>

<answer from>



SE
Member since: 08 December 2006
Total points: 4714 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nope. The only thing that determines the sex of your baby is whether the sperm that fertilized the egg has an X or a Y sex chromosome. The baby's sex is set as soon as the sperm fertilizes the egg.



Source(s):



30 weeks with baby girl; background in genetics.



</answer>



<answer from>



Due February 22nd ♥
Member since: 14 March 2008
Total points: 6406 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



No!! The sex of the baby is determined long before you even know you're pregnant, beacuse the dad determines it in his sperm. His sperm is filled with XY (female) and XX (male).. whichever gets hold on your egg is what you will have!



Source(s):



http://guideonpregnancy.blogspot.com/
Great site for us pregnant women, those TTC, and those who are just curious!



</answer>

<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Pregnancy



</category>



<question from>



Jessica
Member since: 28 November 2007
Total points: 85 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Is it safe to drink black or blue cohosh at 28 weeks pregnant?



</question>



<additional details>



Its not alcohol..Idk where you got that from, Im not stupid and I would NEVER drink alcohol during my pregnancy-Please read the question carefully before you go and judge me.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Expecting in May 2009.
Member since: 09 June 2007
Total points: 3134 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes. It's often drank more towards the end, since blue cohosh is more for uterine toning and helps labor. BUT it can also cause spontaneous miscarriage if drank early, since it causes contractions.



http://www.sisterzeus.com/BlueCoh.htm



As far as black goes, it's said to help induce labor, so I would hold off on that... ALSO this site cautions against it.



http://nccam.nih.gov/health/blackcohosh/



EDIT- I wonder if these people realize it is an herb and not alcohol......



</answer>



<answer from>



elaeblue
Member since: 17 February 2006
Total points: 45250 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Noo read up on that stuff before you try it . It has been known to cause miscarriage!!! Dont take it.



go to black cohosh under Yahoo!health



Omg. its not alcohol!!



</answer>



<answer from>



cp04
Member since: 24 May 2008
Total points: 931 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would check with you ob/midwife first, just to be on the safe side.  There are many herbs that you shouldn't take during pregnancy, even though it can be used for pregnancy doesn't mean it won't have some nasty side effects.  Like castor oil persay, it is considered safe, but yet can cause some babies to pass meconium in the uterus, which if they ingest can cause major health problems such as breathing problems if it gets into their lungs.  So to be safe, talk to your doctor first or at least do some heavy duty research to make sure there is no harsh side effects, or any that can potentially hurt your baby.  Best of luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Kim B
Member since: 24 October 2007
Total points: 4331 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



First it tastes like a stick why would you want to and second can cause miscarriage or early birth.. no safe... try a rasberry or green tea, rasberry is a uterine toner, and helps when labor comes but wont cause labor, and green tea just tatses fantastic.



</answer>

<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting



Pregnancy



</category>



<question from>



mommy to be!
Member since: 21 March 2008
Total points: 1409 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



I am 24 weeks and  5 days pregnant and I was wondering?



my baby did not move really at all today only like one little kick In the morning.. is this normal and  also is there anything I can do to make her move just to make sure she is ok?



</question>



<answer from>



lani
Member since: 22 March 2007
Total points: 2870 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Try drinking something cold and sweet (like oj).  After about 15 minutes, lie down on your left side and see if you feel more movement.  At 24 weeks, their movements are still irregular, but you should feel them.  They just aren't as predictable as they will become after 28 weeks.  If you are in doubt and worried and the movements seem to be a marked decrease from what you are used to, call your doctor.  Better safe than sorry.



Also remember, the more active you are, the more the baby will sleep.



Source(s):



ob nurse
32 weeks pregnant



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you



</asker's comment>



<comments>



Betsy88



There is nothing wrong with your baby but see your doctor if you are in doubt. I am 32 weeks pregnant and he is moving all the time. I think he sleeps a bit then wake up and start beating. GOod luck with that.



</comments>



<answer from>



nitrofat...
Member since: 09 April 2008
Total points: 486 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it is totally normal, no worries
I am 32 weeks pregnant myself and he still has days when he won't move much.
Just remember, they are more active when you are still (going to bed, just waking up, kicking your feet up) when you walk around a lot you are rocking your little precious right to sleep.



Try this, I have noticed that after I eat my little guy seems to be having an arena fight in my tummy!  After you eat a meal take a few minutes to lay down for a bit and I guarantee your baby will move



Source(s):



personal experience
My own doctor's advice



</answer>



<answer from>



snykiaw
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 108 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



She should be fine, babies don't always constantly move. When I was pregnant I went a whole day without my baby moving and it scared me to death but nothing was wrong and she came out fine.



You can GENTLY press your stomach in different areas to try and get a movement.



Now if she doesn't move for a few days then you should go to the doctor's.



</answer>



<answer from>



mythough...
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 148 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



This may sound weird, but here goes.  When I was PG, I use to listen to music a lot, and when I listened to faster music, and started patting my tummy softly, I would get these little movements.  At night I played quiet music and also patted tummy softly (but much slower), if movement, and asleep she would go. I found what I thought was her little bottom, but was not real sure, so softly I would pat.  When she was born, all I had to do to get her to sleep, was put on the soft slow music, pat her little bottom and asleep she would go.  So maybe some faster music would get some movement going.......



FYI - now my daughter is going to college to do Music Videos.



</answer>

<question from>



Wild Orchid
Member since: 23 September 2008
Total points: 537 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



If I have been taking my pill and want to take a pregnancy test, will that affect the results?



</question>



<answer from>



Angellov...
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 2078 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



no



</answer>



<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 30547 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



If you are pregnant, the hormones in the pill will not cause a false negative.  (Nor will they cause a false positive if you are not pregnant.)



</answer>



<answer from>



Tia P
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 595 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



the only thing that would affect your test is medications containing pregnancy hormone.the pill does not contain this so your fine.



</answer>



<answer from>



kiki
Member since: 11 September 2008
Total points: 146 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



no, pregnancy test will detect a "pregnancy hormone" regardless.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dr. Diagnonsense
Member since: 08 July 2007
Total points: 20521 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



No



And you can Google the topic for the same answer from reliable sources.



The hormone the pg test is looking for is not found in bc pills.

<answer from>



Betsy
Member since: 17 December 2006
Total points: 37277 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



You should be weighed at EVERY visit. Vaginal exams are unnecessary and may pose more harm than good. So it depends on WHY you're high risk on that one really. But normally, a PAP is done at the very beginning and many doctors start checking for dilation during the last month. Most do not discuss the other things unless YOU bring it up.



**edit**Dialtion is completely irrelevent as to when labor will begin...that's why many don't bother checking..it only introduces a risk of infection. If you have been havign regular ultrasounds, and it sounds from your added comments that you have, they can measure the length of your cervix that way as well. During my second pregnancy mine was measured that way several times. It will shorten before any real dilation takes place.



Source(s):



3 high risk pregnancies...all for different reasons....the first and second 12 years apart



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 29 October 2008

</answer>



<answer from>



HouseMom
Member since: 09 January 2007
Total points: 1244 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Here in the US they weigh you to watch for excessive weight gain, which could be a sign of gestational diabetes or other problems. A vaginal exam in early pregnancy determines you're pregnant and how far along, and towards the end they'll see if there's any progress. You can always refuse them, however. They also do an internal to test you for Group B strep. They normally do a breast checkup early on to check for lumps and other oddities.



I find it strange - there are many women on here from the UK and Europe who post medical questions and it sounds like they don't do anything over there. I mean, sometimes I'll agree that in the US, pregnancy is often 'medicalized' or treated like a disease, but our doctors tend to be very proactive. There is also the lawsuit issue if something should happen. Don't UK doctors do anything? Just curious.



Source(s):



Mom of 2, 19w with #3



</answer>



<answer from>



Little 'ole Me
Member since: 04 February 2008
Total points: 4118 (Level 4)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>

I am in the UK and was weighed at my original appointment,  I have never had a vaginal examination for this or my last baby,  nor did I have my breasts checked.

<answer>



It bothers some people but not others. Think for a second: that same organ (your uterus) that is going to give you a round belly later is already growing. If you lay on your belly, it’s going to put pressure on the organs behind your uterus. Of course it’s going to be bothersome at some point.

<answer>



if it makes you feel this way then you shouldn't do it. The reason you feel that way when you do is because you are putting pressure on the baby and your expanding uterus. <answer from>



Vera Gabriele
Member since: 24 February 2008
Total points: 28934 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Etiquette



Psychology



</answer from>



<answer>



Morning sickness occurs in 50 to 80% of new mom's to be. It's unfortunate that for many, the morning sickness will strike all through the day and not just in the morning. Most cases of morning sickness start between the 4th and 6th week of pregnancy and lasts until the 14th to 16th week. An easy way to calculate this would be 5 or 6 weeks from the first day of the last menstrual period.
The morning sickness can be accompanied by other signs of pregnancy like backaches, constipation, darkening of areola (breast nipple), excessive salivation, exhaustion or feeling sleepy, food cravings, frequent urination, headaches, increased sense of smell, lower abdominal cramps, and/or tender or swollen breasts



When my best friends sister got pregnant..  she didn't feel sick yet.. the first sign that she was pregnant.. she started ''spotting again'' meaning her acne came back.. she was working in a shop and an elderly gentleman said to her '' back to puberty?'' after that she went to see her doctor...and yes she was pregnant.. My mom had flu like symptoms.. and a lot more appetite than usual.. she went to the doctor.. thinking this was the flu.. her family physician could tell her .. ''if this is the flu.. you got 7 more months of it ahead of you. You are 2 months pregnant... she had cravings for certain foods and she got sick at the sight of the colour red in drinks...



</answer>

<question>



Sex/period questions? ez 10 pts?



1. Is there a reason (besides you're pregnant) that you wouldn't get your period for a month?
2. If you use a condom, is it still possible (just not very) to get pregnant or is it for sure that you won't?
thx



</question>



<answer from>



JeremysM...
Member since: 15 October 2008
Total points: 924 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Stress can cause a missed period.
No birth control is 100% effective. If you used a condom and it didnt break or fall off, you're most likely NOT pregnant.
Good luck and I hope this helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



lostlitt...
Member since: 19 October 2008
Total points: 892 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



well question 1 yes there is many reasons, stress, excessive weight gain or loss, diet, diabetes, menopause, and for question 2 yes it's still possible to get pregnant with a condom just not very likely, nothing is 100%



</answer>



<answer from>



Deanne S
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 159 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



1. If you are on the pill, the hormones may affect your monthly cycle.  Stress can also affect your cycle.
2. It is still possible to get pregnant using a condom.  They are only 99.9% effective.  The only 100% way to not get pregnant is to not have sex.



Hope that helps!!



Source(s):



Mommy of a 13 month old, 19 weeks pregnant



</answer>



<answer from>



KKingS
Member since: 20 December 2006
Total points: 21986 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



1.  There are TONS of reasons why you wouldn't get your period.  Some are of no concern...some could indicate problems.



2.  No birth control is 100%, so we can never say "for sure."  However, if the condem is the right size, used correctly, doesn't have a tear, etc....it is fairly safe to say you won't be pregnant.



</answer>

ha ha for me its goodnight!!  With both my children the first symptom even before missing a period was sore breasts especially nipples and maybe peeing a little more frequently but besides missing a period not alot else till about 6 weeks to the day both times when the nausea started - although I never got it that bad.  The worst symptom for me was the extreme tiredness but that also came after 6 weeks -  there was quite a few times especially in my first pregnancy that I felt like I must have been dreaming the whole thing and would keep checking the pregnancy test just to make sure it was actually real!!  LOL - you will probably look back at this in a week or so's time and think oh no what was I worried about in between feeling incredibly tired and sick!!  All the best with your pregnancy!

BellasMo...

</answer from>



<answer>



Have you ever spotted during pregnancy? If you have, it might be normal for you but DEFINITELY CALL YOUR DOCTOR RIGHT AWAY!
It could be that sex caused it, it also could be that your spotting and could have lost your mucus plug and could be labor onset. I miscarried, actually, gave pre term birth late in my pregnancy, and I was barely spotting, it wasn't lots of blood, but I knew it wasn't right for me. Insist on going in and having a sonogram, make sure there is no leak, and make sure the sonographer looks well!



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Prescription drugs are very dangerous even fatal for a embryo in development. And also take a drug to get it in your system it takes about three days. So taking it once in awhile will not stop anything. And about the pregnancy test i would wait until your next cycle if you can not wait you can usally take it about 3 weeks about the unprotected sex. And i would bet you are not pregnant because the conceiving cycle does bot start until one to two weeks before your monthly cycle. The egg travels down you fallopian tubes into your uterus and then it waits to be fertilized and that takes about two weeks give or take and when it is done waiting that is when you period comes. So i hope that help and good luck in the future.



</answer>

<question from>



Carson's mommy! :)
Member since: 02 March 2008
Total points: 204 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why do women find it scary to have a baby with Down syndrome?



Why do women find it scary or so wrong to give birth to a baby with Down syndrome? Do you think the majority of women choose to abort their baby after finding out the chances of their baby have a chromosomal defect, do it because they're superficial and selfish? I mean, I understand that anybody would be concerned after finding it out, but why not educate yourself and prepare for the arrival of the child you've been blessed with. My opinion is that they're superficial and selfish, but of course, it's just my opinion and many people would BEG to differ. But what do other people think about this? And please NO complaints about precious taxes going to poeple with down syndrome. I thinks it's money better spent rather than on some lazy people receiving government checks. I've read a lot of comments to other questions about people with DS, and comments about tax money always pops up, it's annoying.



</question>



<additional details>



Yes my son has Down syndrome. Just before I asked the question, I was reading some other questions and comments dealing with Down syndrome, and a lot of the comments were so absurb and very hurtful, that I had to ask "Why"?



I think it becomes a scary thing after you read and hear about how so many people feel about it. And doctors aren't any better either, many of them encourage terminating the pregnancy by scaring women into thinking that there's no hope for these children.



By the way, NO, just because I have a child with DOES NOT mean I think it's okay for everyone to have one. That is not part of my question...I'm asking why are people scared. It was not a biased question, it's open to any educated answer or opinion.



But, with that said, I really think it's inappropriate to post ignorant comments like that female who said it's abnormal. The comment was just uncalled for and ridiculous.



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I denied any tests for the down syndrome. What do they expect me to do abort the baby if there is something wrong with it. I think some people are scared that they just might not be able to take care of a baby with so many extra special needs. I wouldn't do anything but love that little baby just as much as I love my other children.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you had a baby with DS? or been told your baby has it?
I have 2 friends with DS babies (one who was only 18 when she had her first daughter so its not an age thing)  Her daughter was in and out of hospital with serious heart defects which were part of her condition, she didnt walk until 7 and is still haivng issues with alot of things as part of the condition, my other friends daughter is 4 and she had some serious issues as a baby, trouble feeding, and with her eyes, but shes doing very well in kindergarten and will most likely be in a public school as her condition isnt as serious



Im not sure what exactly it is you are asking. Down syndrome can be a big deal for some people, especially older couples who find out when therye 40+ that their baby has this, some DS children NEVER live on their own, or get jobs, it does depend on the severity of the condition as it can vary greatly.



I have also worked with DS adults, and most of them are just lovely, I personally have never had the worry of one of my children having DS, but I decided decades ago, when working with them, that if I ever did find out I was pg with a child with that condition, all I would do is educate myself and do the best I can



But of course that is me. and everyone is different. And if faced with it in reality Im sure most people would be shocked to say the least



Source(s):



Mum of 5



</answer>

<answer>



I think your correct, that many couples or mothers will abort thier children that have possible defects becaue they are scared and selfish. Meaning if they know that something is going to be wrong with their child, rather then educating themselves about it, they take the easy way out and abort it. My psychology teacher was telling us the other day that she would abort the baby becaue she wouldnt want her child to go through everyday struggles with having Down Syndrome. To me I was shocked to hear her say this. My mouth literally dropped. I guess I could see her stance in this, but children with DS can get the help they need and can be treated and function like "normal"  children( I know that is politically incorrect). I would rather give my child a chance at life than aborting it because their life may be a little harder. I am a firm believer in everything that happens, usually happens for a reason. God gave you a child, a child that is yours for a reason, and you must love it not matter what the circumstances are. Meanwhile there are thousands of couples out there whom are dying to have children that are infertile, and these mothers are just aborting thier child from chromosomal defects. I know if my child were to have a choromosmal defect, I would love it no matter what and learn how to deal with and what to expect. Good Question! Has my mind thinking at 1:30 a.m. but that is good! Thanks for sharing!

<answer>



Well, as you probably know, a big part of the reason is that their information about Down syndrome is scary because it's way way out of date or just plain inaccurate.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



It is scary... because most people are dealing with an "unknown" and have their own misconceptions and have never personally been around people with DS. look at it this way...not long ago if you gave birth to a child with DS the parents were told to institutionalize them and that they would never be productive or lead "normal" lives. to bring a child home and care for them even 30 yrs ago was rare.  well those misconceptions are still visible today...not just in DS but in the way we look, what jobs we have, what religion we are....and so on. You and I both know how special our kids are, but for the "general public" they really have no clue. To some  our kids are considered less than perfect...little do they know what wonderful kids we do have. It all boils down to awareness and changing people's attitudes about something they have little information on. I could stand at the top of a mountain and yell that my son is just like everyone else...he still loves, learns, plays and enjoys life to the fullest....some may choose to listen while others may not...it is their choice. If someone is willing to abort a child because of DS...well in my mind they better make an informative decision and not one based on how it will "look"to other's to have a child with DS. Raising a child with down syndrome can be difficult at times...but it is in no way impossible and people need to see that. there are so many programs nowadays that are there to support parents and help their children become productive members of this sometimes screwed up society.



</answer>

<answer>



1st of all people are rude!As you said why not educate your self?Education requires work and a brain and many people are lacking those things now days.I don't know why a woman would choose to abort a child bc of a disability,why not adoption?There are SO many people who are unable to have children that would love these children exactly as they are.I had something called a "triple test"done when I was pregnant with my 2nd son they told me most likely he would be born with DS,we meant with a genealogist,had a step 2 ultra sound,and prepared for the worst.My son was born  perfectly normal.I thank god for that but either way he is still my child and I would've loved him either way.



I have 2 uncles that are DS and they both have touched the lives of any one they have came in contact with in a profound way.I think ALL people with DS are truly beautiful and are ANGELS,they are sent here for a reason.



SS I agree 100% with Autism's Beautiful Face I feel sorry for your children or future children.Shame on you!



Carson's mommy good luck.Your son is a gift and really is adorable.Good question.

<answer>



I would imagine that alot of it has to do with how Down syndrome is portrayed in our society these days. Movies, TV everything, I have seen so many terrible jokes about people with down syndrome that it makes me sick!
Being the mother of a 7year old with Downs, I will certainly admit that when my daughter was born I was shocked and a little horrified... mostly scared for her and what her life would be like. One thing that I have learned (among the many many many) is that downs kids are the most loving and lovable.... they just shine a light... indescribable.
I had went to a class for kids with downs with my daughter several years ago when I was pregnant with my second child, there were two other mothers that were pregnant as well. They would talk about having the amniosintesis to determine if their new baby would be likely to have downs as well. I heard them refer to their lovely children as "flukes" because it was just a thing that happened. I had genetic testing done and it was found that 30% of my cells carry the extra chromosome for down syndrome, and I refused the amnio. I would have 100 more children with down syndrome.



So... in answer to your question, I blame society... get out there people, go to the Buddy walks (find one in your area), meet these people, they are amazing and can do so much more than so many people try to allow them to do.



</answer>

<answer>



I would probably choose to abort the baby (i dont plan on having kids) unless i was with a supportive responsible partner who i know would stick with me and the child and i felt that i could deal with it. I dont think i would do it for superficial reasons but i dont think id be capable to caring for a healthy baby let alone a child that needed extra attention and special care.



I would be worried that if i had the child i would resent it or not give it as much love as it deserved (i have a history of depression and self abuse).



I cant say what i would do unless i was faced with that situation really but I cant say i wouldnt rule out having an abortion. I would much rather prevent any pregnancies through contraception in the first place.



I dont believe that abortion should be illegal under any circumstances but it shouldnt be used as contaception either.



Source(s):



17 years old, Australia.



</answer>



<answer from>
