</answer from>



<answer>



It's scary to some women because they realize that the difficulty of caring for a DS child will likely be much greater than the difficulty of raising a normal child.  And they know this child is unlikely to grow up and be ready to leave home and live on his/her own in 20 years.  This child will need much extra care and work to teach basic skills as well as academic skills.  And will probably need support throughout life, never becoming totally independent.  The parenting required for a DS child is far more than that required for a normal child.



There are people willing to adopt DS babies and lovingly raise them.  From what I've seen (and I've seen hundreds of mentally handicapped kids) if you have to have a mentally handicapped child, a DS child is the best of luck.  They really are typically very loving and kind hearted.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I personally wouldn't terminate but I guess why people wouldn't want to deal with DS.....Theres other health problems like serious heart issues and weight issues dealing with a DS baby, I think that its scary for anyone whether baby is DS or not. Also people invision their kids growing up, going away to college, having successful carreers and living on their own and having their own families one day. Tho DS people are capable of having jobs and living on their own its not as early as someone with out, also their chances of having their own family are slim to none. The thought of having to care for your child day in day out without rest many times is scary, when your a parent your a parent for life but a lot of people don't realize that and don't accept that. Bless anyone who has a DS child, its not an easy road but in the end it is worth it~



</answer>

<answer>



I agree with you.  When I went for my 17 week scan, they found white dots on my daughters heart.  The doctor told me that could mean a chromosomal defect.  He suggested to me that he does an amino so we can be sure that there is nothing wrong, but there was a chance I could miscarry.  I looked at my husband and at the same time we said no amnio.  Then the doctor told us to get the AFP test done before 20 weeks so if we wanted to terminate the pregnancy we could.  I was shocked that this doctor said that to me.  I was so upset when we left there, because one, there might be something wrong with our baby, and two the doctor was talking to me about terminating my pregnancy which made me think it was something bad.  We got in the car, and I looked at my husband and said, I'm not getting the amnio, I'm not getting the AFP, whatever our baby comes out as, we will love her regardless.  He looked at me and said, I am so happy you said that because I agree.  To me, regardless of what special needs she could have been born with or any special needs she could develop, she is still my daughter, a piece of me, we wanted her, special needs or not, we love her.  She was born 2 months ago perfectly healthy, and so far she has had no signs of any special needs.



</answer>

<question>



If you were obese to start your pregnancy, did you gain or lose weight?



In my first pregnancy, I started at 205 lbs and gained 30-35 lbs total. I'm 5'9. With my second pregnancy, I started at 260 but have gotten down to about 238 lbs (at 20 weeks). I had a lot of nausea the first 2-3 months. I'm just wondering how much weight I'm likely to gain by 40 weeks. Did you gain much weight? Did you just lose weight? My doctor said since I'm very healthy other than being obese, I should gain about 10-15 lbs total. So far I haven't gained any, and really hope that I don't gain much, so it'll be easier to lose afterward. Thanks!!! Please only answer if you were obese or pretty overweight before getting pregnant.



</question>



<answer from>

<answer>



yup, i was there and still am.  please no one make fun of me for my size... but keep in mind I am 6'1 in height so i carry my weight pretty well,  or at least did lol



I started weighing at 275 when I got pregnant,  I too had bad nausea for the first 5 months!  I had only gained like 5 lbs by 5 months and felt good about that.. then the nausea got better and wasn't sick as often.  my lovely food choices and lack of exercise has caused me to gain weight quickly now that i'm not throwing up 8 times a day.  BAD NAUSEA!!!  I felt good to keep food down I wasn't watching my weight. Well I am 8 months now and weighed in at 321 on the doctors scale. :( But my baby is healthy and gaining weight too :) so that makes me feel better.  It is going to be hard for me to lose the weight but I am going to, I already have the exercise equipment ready.  my advice to you is to watch what you eat.  the nausea should ease up sometime or another and then your food will stay in your stomach.  so watch how many calories you consume so you won't turn out like me, it is too late for me now lol Good Luck



</answer>



<answer from>



MomOfAd
Member since: 17 July 2008
Total points: 202 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I started out at about 239 (5'7"). I gained maybe 6 pounds the first 20 weeks. I was pretty nauseated the first tri, and didn't eat a lot during the day. After the 20-week mark, weight started coming on more. I ended up gaining about 25 pounds for the whole thing.



My doc had said at the beginning that she'd like my gain to be only 10-15 pounds. When it went past that mark, I asked her about it. She said that because the weight was going on so slow, she had no concerns at all.



I ended up losing all baby weight by my 6- week post-partum checkup.



Good luck!!



</answer>



<answer from>



Kaylee is Here!
Member since: 22 February 2008
Total points: 1080 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



My pre-pregnancy weight was about 230, I am 5'11". I lost 20 lbs in the first trimester, I had morning sickness untill my 5 month.I didn't start gaining weight untill my 7th month and I gained 3 lbs. The most I gained between dr appts was 9 lbs.  then gained a total of 18 lbs throughout my whole pregnancy. Two weeks after birth I was down to 205. It has been 6 weeks since I gave birth and I have not weighed myself since the last time but I am positive I have lost some more weight. Best of luck and congrats!



BTW, this is my first child



</answer>

<question from>



louise loves thomas.

</question from>



<question>



Pregnancy blood testing?



Ok so i've got my doctor appointment tomorrow and they'll put me forward to see a midwife, i miscarried before and i think this time will be ok, it seems to be going better even though i'm only 6 weeks along but my fingers are definitely crossed. anyways, back to my question. i've never had my blood drawn before, i know it can't be that bad but i'm still scared of getting it done, nothing against needles just a vein phobia, when i see people getting it done i feel as though i'm gonna faint and feel sick so i was wondering do you think my midwife would allow me to get it done for the first time at my doctors surgery as i feel safer there and would prefer my first time being there? Any other tips to try and stop myself feeling as though i'm gonna die when getting it done? thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



Due February 22nd ♥
Member since: 14 March 2008
Total points: 6406 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, sweetie, you have to get used to being poked and prodded with needles since you're pregnant, people are going to have to check things often. Also, you should really let your midwife do it since you're going to be with her for these 9 months and should really get to know her, get used to her, and enjoy her company. Honestly, you're not going to die.. if you have any piercings, try to think of it as a piercing except much less painful then one.



Source(s):



http://guideonpregnancy.blogspot.com/
Great site for us pregnant women, those TTC, and those who are just curious!



</answer>



<answer from>



Kell-o
Member since: 13 May 2008
Total points: 5796 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Just concentrate on something really hard and you will hardly feel it.  I get light headed and dizzy and very very nervous every time I go in for a blood draw - but after a minute or 2, I feel ok again.  It is just the nerves that get me, not the actual poke!  You will be fine.  Just let the tech know you are nervous and they should be extra careful.  Good luck!



</answer>

<question from>



Ashl3y
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Is there any chance I could be pregnant?



Im 18 years old and had sex with my fiance over the weekend. We didn't use protection, he just pulled out as usual but straight after he put it back in again. My understanding was that once the sperm entered normal air it died. However I have woke this morning to find myself having spells of dizziness, feeling sick/nausea and bad headaches. i came off my period around two weeks ago which I have read recently that this is the most fertile time. I am unsure of whether this is true or not.



Is it possible I could be pregnant and if it is will I have to wait until my period is due to take a test and find out?



Thanks



xx



</question>



<answer from>



Labsci
Member since: 20 September 2006
Total points: 17713 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Two weeks after your period is a very fertile time.



Yes you could be pregnant, as what was left in his penis after ejaculation is more than enough to get you pregnant.
Sperm does not die on contact with air; it survives until it dries up, or uses up its energy source (seminal fructose).
If you are sick now, then it is unrelated to your pregnancy, but it could be stress-related because you think you might be pregnant.



Serum human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) can be tested for and will be sensitive enough to pick a positive pregnancy about 5 days after conception, so if you got pregnant on Saturday, the hCG may be positive by the following Thursday. You do not need to wait till your period is due.



Good luck.



And remember-



1. Ignorance is never bliss. The more you know about something, the less accidents will occur.



2. "Hoping" is not a contraceptive technique.



3. If pregnancy occurs, it's the girl who ends up with the baby and the stretch marks.
.



Source(s):



I work in a laboratory in a Women's Hospital.
.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Really helpful and put some great thoughts in my head :)



Thanks



xx



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Dirty Blonde
Member since: 07 February 2007
Total points: 954 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is always a possibility that you could be pregnant because you have had unprotected sex.



It is highly unlikely that you are experiencing early pregnancy symptoms this early though.



If you do not want to be pregnant I would suggest you get an appointment with your doctor or local family planning clinic and request the morning after pill (they will only do this a certain number of times) and discuss birth control measures with them.



Withdrawing is not regarded as a safe method of preventing pregnancy.



</answer>



<answer from>



NotAChan...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Although i wont offer a professional opinion on this, I am pretty sure that the nausea that you are experiencing is more than likely not at all related to whether or not you are pregnant. These things take a lot more time than you would think to kick in...



For more detailed information from people who actually know what they are talking about, just google "Am I Pregnant" and follow some links to professional opinions.



Hope this helps!



</answer>

If you had unprotected sex... you can be pregnant.



It's really that simple.

Start testing 5 days out or until your period comes.

Signs of pregnancy do not come on this fast.  The sperm can live up to 5 days inside of you before fertilizing the egg or dying.  Then it takes 19 days after conception in order for an accurate test for pregnancy.  You may have low blood sugar or high blood pressure..if it persisits for more than 3-4 days you should call your doctor.  Good luck and God bless.

<answer>



If you are breastfeeding you could start tomorrow (though it would be VERY unlikely) or not for another 2 years ... or anything in between. (The 'average' is 9 months.)



If you are not breastfeeding, you should have a period within the next month or so.

<category>



Pregnancy & Parenting

<question from>



Waiting on Abbie Mae*1*6*09
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 7922 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Marriage & Divorce



Pregnancy



</question from>



<question>



Stomach pain or stomachache? 30 weeks pregnant?



I really can't tell if its just at typical stomachache or if my stomach just hurts from stretching. I feel as if I'm growing so much daily and I've been in a lot of pain all day along with back pain so I thought it was just form my stomach stretching but now I feel like I'm on the verge of getting sick so I'm wondering if its normal for your stomach to ache? Its sore on the inside and out. Thanks. I'm 30 weeks pregnant. Should I just take a TUMS and see if that helps?



</question>



<answer from>



Chimichanga to go please!!
Member since: 20 January 2007
Total points: 12324 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



When you are pregnant, it is very normal and common to feel stomach aches and pain and even nausea later on in your pregnancy because there IS stretching of ligaments and your body's organs are being pressed upon a bit by your growing baby.  Still, anything that doesn't seem or feel just right to you is something worth just calling your doctor's office for.  Most of the time, if you call them with your concerns, they can tell you if your problem is something that warrants an office visit or not and if it doesn't warrant an office visit, you will often be told what signs and symptoms to watch out for to let you know when you do need to be seen by a doctor.  I hope you get to feeling better and I wish you and your baby all the best.



Source(s):



Mother of 2 and experienced this myself.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

<answer>

Tts McGee

<answer>



Yes ma'am it is possible. After a miscarrige you get pregnant faster then anybody else. I had a miscarrige in April 08 and found out i was preg. again in June 08. The problem with that is if you get pregnant right after a miscarrige sometimes (not always dont panic) you miscarry again because its too soon. But if you take progesterone then you should be ok. As far as the tests, your body could still be producing HCG and making your test come back positive even after a D&C. But its still a large possibility that you are pregnant again. Hope everything goes fine. Hugs!



Source(s):



2 miscarriges in 2008



</answer>

<answer from>



Mark M
Member since: 02 June 2008
Total points: 131 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Porn can become an addiction, that goes even beyond just filling emotional needs. It's like trying to fill a bucket with a big hole in the bottom, and each time you try to fill it with porn, the whole keeps getting bigger and the 'appetite' bucket will never be filled. You might have even noticed that about your own appetite for it... that the more you watch, the less satisfying it is, and you always need more.



How do YOU feel it affects your relationship, if at all? In his mind, your husband is probably confused by the double standard. Porn is ok, but it's also not ok. He probably justifies it by himself because you've said it's ok when you're there. This is probably very confusing.



It seems that it would be difficult to ask him to stop looking at it by himself, unless you also stop looking at it as a couple.



Can you see any benefits to your relationship being 'porn-free'? The two of you might need to decide what sanctity you give to sex, and explore how the porn is really effecting your emotional intimacy, beyond just pleasure in the moment of watching it together. It would seem to me that watching it together really brings a personal enjoyment of the moment more than increased emotional intimacy as a couple. What do you think? This is just my guess, forgive me if I'm off.



What if you had a special date night and re-read your marriage vows, to each other or something special like that? Is there anything in your marriage vows about "forsaking all others...", etc?



You never want to say, "You're not living up to your marriage vows..." but rather, if you are so compelled, "Honey, I feel like what I've been doing has not been keeping our marriage vows. I feel like I've been undermining my vow to "forsake all others and keep myself only for you" [for example] by encouraging us to bring porn into our sex relationship.



Hopefully you know what I'm getting at. I just think that, even if you've expressed your desire that he not watch it on his own, he has got to be VERY confused in his mind that it's OK in some circumstances but not in others. Because it is SO addictive, being linked to one of the most basic male desires.



God bless you and I hope you can be brought much closer through this trial as you share your feelings with each other. Be a safe place for each other to express their feelings without being afraid of getting 'in trouble'. Feelings are always valid.



</answer>

Also take in account of what if you get him for child support and such. Yes, this may seem like overwhelming information, but it is better to be safe, knowledgeable and ready for anything that comes your way.



Best of luck, keep smiling and count your blessings.

<answer>



Your main question seems to be about having the father involved? I think that right now, while you are pregnant, he should only be around if he is going to be supportive. If it stresses you out it won't be good for you or your baby, particularly with your (medical) history. (I am really sorry for your loss, I cannot imagine what you have gone through.)



He may need time to get used to the idea that there will be a little one out there related to him. Who knows- he may be able to wrap his head around this any time now or sometime after the birth. Either way I don't think it is something you should have to decide right at this moment. Let it be a weight of your shoulders to allow yourself to think about it later.



You said in another post that you are young to be having a baby at 20 but you had decided to 'grow up and be a mother'. You may be young in years, but this kind of decision shows maturity. It is a difficult decision to put someone before yourself, and that ultimately is what you are doing.



Source(s):



29 year old mom of a 17 month old.



</answer>

<question>



Is this normal with my baby delivery?

</answer from>



<answer>



Periods are pretty unusual for guys, and you have a guy's avatar. Yes, it's very normal to go over, especially with a first pregnancy. The due date is only an estimate. An estimate which no one tells babies, so they come when they're ready.



</answer>

<answer from>



Sarah
Member since: 02 July 2006
Total points: 308 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was actually talking to a guy friend about this very subject just yesterday.



We were discussing how unfair it is that men don't really get a say in determining whether or not to bring a child into this world.  I, personally, am pro-choice (just to specify for those on a soapbox, pro-choice does not mean pro-abortion, it means pro-CHOICE). So is my friend.



However, we commented on how, if a man and a woman get pregnant (it does take two people to do that, after all) then really, it ultimately comes down to the woman to make the decision to keep the fetus or abort. While the man can give an opinion, the choice isn't really is, but he has to live with the consequences either way.



If the woman aborts, he no longer has a child. Some men prefer it that way, other men may be devastated.



If the woman keeps the fetus, then he is still responsible for paying for the child for the next 18 years, whether he wanted her to abort or not.



19 is young. You can't even buy a beer, but you're going to raise a child?  I'm not criticizing your choices, I'm simply putting it into perspective. If you're not able to handle raising a child, don't do it. There are too many children in the adoption systems right now as it is, and too many children are improperly cared for by teenagers who aren't ready to be parents. There's nothing wrong with doing what will ultimately be best for everyone, if you feel it is the right choice to make. Just weigh your options and figure out WHY you'd want a child at 19 years of age. You have three more decades to have children. But you never get to relive your 20's.



However, if you decide to keep the fetus, I'd have a long talk with the father and see why he wants you to abort.  If he can't financially take care of a child or isn't ready to be a dad, then think about whether or not you want him to be involved. But talk to him. And be fair. Remember, it took two of you to get into this mess, and it should take two of you to make the decision of how to handle it.



Source(s):



I was a young mother myself.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ulisha R
Member since: 26 June 2008
Total points: 117 (Level 1)



</answer from>

Honestly if its going to break your heart to get an abortion, if you decide to get it honestly you will regret it for the rest of your life. If you do abort it, you will get to your due date and be thinking 'what if' or 'how i wish' or 'i wonder what he/she would have looked like'.



I had a miscarriage and its heard to get out of my head even though it was almost 2 years ago. Just take this decision seriously please. its a little life that is half of you.

also a young mummy with some advice



</answer>

I know some people who's parents almost had them aborted (but by the grace of God were not), and I can't tell you how much of an asset they've been to this world, and how much they've enjoyed life. Once example was a 15 year old mother. They planned to go to mexico and have a backyard abortionist do it (since it wasn't legal at the time), but decided not to at the last minute. You're 19, not 14. You can raise this baby. You will be able to get a decent job (if you don't already have one) and if that isn't enough then your parents should be able to help out some. If you reallly think you can't handle it financially, put the child up for adoption. Abortion is NEVER the option. But remember, this decision is yours to make, because your boyfriend said so. His opinion was no longer valid after he said he'd stick by YOUR decision (which as you said was to keep YOUR child!)



PS: I'd like to add that my grandmother (my father's mother) got pregnant when she was 19. So you're definitely not too young. My father turned out to be a wonderful man, and hey, I wouldn't be here if she decided to abort him.



</answer>



<answer from>



d (^_^) b
Member since: 21 September 2008
Total points: 134 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

After all this was a choice of yours when you decided to have sex. I don't want to condemn you. I would like the best to happen for you and the baby now that he or she is in this world. Give the baby a chance to live. Of course it's best to stay together with your child, but if the responsibility is too much for you to handle, I highly recommend adoption. I had something to add to my other answer, but you have messages blocked, so I figured I'd tell you here. If you know how many days he's planning to be back in, you can get a tall clear glass and fill it with that many marbles (or something else small and individual like candies, etc.). Let's say he's planning to be back in 90 days. You'd put in 90 marbles, and every day that passed, you would take one out. You could get a visual idea of it and that should be supportive, because your mind can see him getting closer. You'll do great!

<question from>



ThisIsME
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 131 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What meds affect pregnancy?



Thank you to the people who responded to my other post with almost the same question.



For those of you who didn't see it- I suspect I am pregnant but I don't know for sure yet. On Saturday, I was in an accident where I fractured my jaw and had to get stitches. because of this, I was prescribed these meds:



Cefadroxil (1 gram)
Naproxen (500 mg)
Oxycodone (325 mg)



Will any/all of these have a bad effect on the possible baby?



</question>



<answer from>



Emily the Scientist
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 8314 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Religion & Spirituality



Biology



Infectious Diseases



Medicine



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I have just looked up those medications in MIMS:



Cefadroxil (I couldn't find that drug name in the Australian version of MIMS; the closest match I could find was another cephalosporin, Cefalexin):



Use in pregnancy: Category A



(Category A means "Drugs which have been taken by a large number of pregnant women and women of childbearing age without any proven increase in the frequency of malformations or other direct or indirect harmful effects on the fetus having been observed.")



Naproxen:



Use in pregnancy: Category C



(Category C means "Drugs that, owing to their pharmacological effects, have caused or may be suspected of causing harmful effects on the human fetus or neonate without causing malformations. These effects may be reversible.")



Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs inhibit prostaglandin synthesis and, when given during the latter part of pregnancy, may cause closure of the fetal ductus arteriosus, prolong labour and delay birth. Continuous treatment with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs during the last month of pregnancy should only be given on sound indications. During the last few days before expected birth, agents with an inhibitory effect on prostaglandin synthesis should be avoided. Aleve {a brand name for Naproxen} should, therefore, only be administered during pregnancy if the benefit justifies the potential risk.



Oxycodone:



Use in pregnancy: Category C



Reproductive toxicity studies with oxycodone in animals have not been conducted. Opioid analgesics cross the placenta. The use of oxycodone during labour may cause respiratory depression in the newborn infant. Babies born to opioid dependent mothers may be physically dependent and suffer withdrawal symptoms (convulsions, irritability, excessive crying, tremors, hyperactive reflexes, fever, vomiting, diarrhoea, sneezing and yawning).



If you suspect you're pregnant, you should tell your doctor before they prescribe anything for you.  They cannot give you adequate medical advice if you don't give them all the information and pregnancy is up there with allergic reactions in terms of doctor-need-to-knows.



Take care. =)



Source(s):



BSc (BmedSc), Hons



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you for looking that up :) I didn't expect anyone to do that. The cefadroxyl was the important one so I'm glad you told me about that.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Knocked Up
Member since: 07 March 2007
Total points: 528 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Gosh. Some people don't listen well do they. She doesn't KNOW if she's pregnant for sure. geesh. First of all Cefadroxil is a class B drug. They haven't done much research on its effects with pregnancy. I think it should probably be safe. Naproxen however should not be taken during pregnancy unless REALLY needed. Definitely don't take the oxycodone cause it's a category C. Which means it is harmful to unborn babies. I would call the doc and tell him you may be pregnant. If you really need painkillers, ask for Tylenol 3 with codeine. It's much safer.



</answer>

<question>



How did you tell your parents you were pregnant?



I'm not pregnant....yet.  My husband and I are wanting to try though.  I've always been the kind of person who never wanted any kids and my mom has always known this and it's going to be hard for me to tell her, even though I'm 24 years old and married.  Although she was great with me and my brother, my mom seems to have stopped liking kids the older she gets and I'm not so sure she'll be happy for me when the day does come.



Anyway I just read someone's answer and they said they had everything planned out that they were going to say and when the time came to confess all they were able to do was point at their stomach and start crying.  That made me laugh a little because that's exactly what I picture myself doing.



I want everyone's stories but I'd like some funny ones if anyone has any!



Thanks!



</question>

MercyAng...

</answer from>



<answer>



When your period is a week late you can do a urine test, before that it's really too early b/c the urine tests are not that sensitive. And if your stomach is just big overnight and your period isn't even due yet it's probably due to some other reason- not pregnancy-. usually when your pregnant you don't show until at LEAST 3 months if not 5-6 months. So you might have another medical problem going on if your stomach is really significantly bigger.. think ascites/liver failure at worst or possibly just bloating/constipation at least.



</answer>

<question>



More than once on the pill?



Ok this might seem like a dumb question but this happened to a friend of mine, my girlfriend has been on the pill for a few months and we haven't had any problems with no protection. I usually come like 2 or 3 times when we have sex and sometimes we do it again the same day. I was wondering if coming inside her more than once every time we have sex will make the pill a little more likely to fail?



</question>



<additional details>



Ok thanks this is good news haha.I know we should use condom's to be sure but we always wanted to use the pill and no protection. Thanks for your answers



</additional details>



<answer from>



WENDY
Member since: 30 July 2008
Total points: 657 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have no idea



</answer>



<answer from>



Jen
Member since: 22 May 2007
Total points: 119 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



No, that is not possible. The "pill" works with a females hormones to stop her from ovulating.



</answer>



<answer from>



Angelap
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 173 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Good question but I can't offer any good answers. But, I would suggest the condom for double protection.



</answer>



<answer from>



TC007
Member since: 27 February 2007
Total points: 728 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The pill is not affected by how much sperm is in a women's system. It is affected by certain drugs like antibiotics, having the stomach flu,  and obviously not taking it correctly.



If your girlfriend is taking it correctly then you should have no problem regardless of how much sex you have. However always bear in mind that the pill is only 99% effective so there is always a small chance of pregnancy even if she is on birth control.



Do not fear though. I was on the pill for 12 years and in the 5 years of unprotected sex with my husband I never fell pregnant until we wanted it!



</answer>



<answer from>



Me
Member since: 26 March 2006
Total points: 3101 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



The way birth control pills work is by having hormones that prevent ovulation (that's when the egg is released). If a woman doesn't ovulate, there is no egg. So it doesn't really matter how much sperm there is if there is no egg for them to fertilize.



On a side note, no birth control is absolutely perfect, so if you really really didn't want her to get pregnant you could use condoms too (I know, I know...) and make sure she follows the directions for the pills exactly (like take same time every day).



Source(s):



http://kidshealth.org/teen/sexual_health...



</answer>



<answer from>



MercyAng...
Member since: 19 March 2008
Total points: 249 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The amount of times you have sex don't affect the way birth control works. It works by stopping ovulation and preventing implantation in the uterus if a egg is released. So sperm/semen/amount of times you have sex have absolutely nothing to do with the protection birth control offers.



Source(s):



RN



</answer>

<answer from>



saladbar...
Member since: 11 April 2006
Total points: 229 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



First, take a deep breath.  Remind yourself you WILL be ok in the end.



Second, be prepared for your parents to be shocked and upset, but realize that they will give their real reaction after they have had time to consider what you've said.



Now, to tell them -- pick a quiet time to talk to them when they're not getting ready to run out of the house somewhere.  Sit them down, tell them you have something serious to tell them.  Tell them that you love them, you really need their support and love right now.  Then tell them that you're pregnant.  Be prepared for a lot of questions.  But by starting off telling them that you love them, and you need their love and support, you're likely to get it in the end.



Good luck!  Remember, there is a lot of help out there for moms to be.



</answer>

<answer>



I'm 25 and I got pregnant when I was 18 and still at school.  I don't wanna lye to you, your parents won't be happy about it.  Parents are over protective and they have too high expectations for their children.  Obviously they want you to finish your studies, work for yourself and get married before you can think of having a baby.  Unfortunately we cannot turn back the clock but try to overcome you obstacles and make something good out of your mistakes.  If you have a sister or maybe an adult who you are close to & whom they are close to your parents, I suggest you tell that person and ask them to tell your parents.  It becomes easier when they are told by an adult, that person can make them realize that this is not the end of the world.  They might be angry but give them sometime they will accept and recover, they love you and they won't just abandon you. Show them that you are sorry and you plan to do something with your life after the baby is born.  Remember, that child will be their grandchild, instant they will be spoiling him/her once they get used to the idea.  Take care of yourself, don't stress and good luck!



Tell your boyfriend as soon as possible, probably you might need the support from him.  But remember, he might not be ready for the baby and turn you away.  Be prepared and ready for anything, as I said take things one step at a time and what ever the outcomes be strong.  I know what I'm talking about, I have been there, I have recovered and I'm making something out of mylife.  Good Luck again.



</answer>

<question>



Is there a possibility of pregnancy?



I have been using oral contraceptives for almost 3 years now, even though I sometimes don't take them at the same time.  Sometimes I will skip, but immediately when I remember I will take one.  I was on my periods a week before, but before I had my periods, I had terrible stomach cramps which were unusual & I was a day late for my periods.  Still after my periods I'm still having pains on my lower abdomen, headaches, I'm bloated and constipated, and this have been going on for a week now.  So far I haven't recognize any other symptoms, unless probably its still early or maybe I should wait a little bit longer.



</question>



<answer from>



MercyAng...
Member since: 19 March 2008
Total points: 249 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

If you had your period and the bleeding was normal you probably are not pregnant, but if you miss your period next month then you should test.



</answer>



<answer from>



emma b and son due march 4th
Member since: 08 December 2007
Total points: 2231 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



if you had unprotected sex then yes you could be pregnant here's the sum.



man+women+no protection=possibly a baby.



missed pills=no protection. gl hun i hope you are but you need to find out asap due to the fact that you must stop these pills immediately



</answer>



<answer from>



Evelyne T
Member since: 07 April 2008
Total points: 128 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There's always a possibility of pregnancy, but pretty unlikely when you're on the pill.  I read something today that said only 64 out of 1000 women actually ovulate after stopping the pill for 10 days.



Constipation does cause abdominal pain.  Usually in the left side of the lower abdomen. There's no reason for you to continue to have constipation though.  There are tons and tons of things you can get that are over the counter.  Try colace (docusate sodium) or Miralax. They are the easiest to start with.  There's also bisacodyl or senokot which are a little stronger.  If your constipation is not resolved in a day or two after trying all that you should call your doctor.



Headaches are a totally different symptom.



The major worry for any woman with abdominal pain would be an ectopic pregnancy, which is life threatening, but is also really unlikely too.  And I just say that because no one is going to be able to tell you for sure what is the reason for your pain without seeing you.  Only you know what if what you are feeling is severe or really unusual for you.



Since I've been a nurse for awhile I've learned never to ignore any little nagging feelings I have.  I would probably try the laxatives first though if your pain is mild, and see if it fixes the pain in a day.



Source(s):



Medical nurse



</answer>

<answer>



Yes, it's better to wait b/c sometimes they can't see it til 22 weeks, and for examply if they did it at 18 weeks and cannot see the sex but everything looks normal and all the anatomy scans are measuring right they may not give you another ultrasound again the entire pregnancy. So if you really want to know the sex, wait, cuz if they don't see it there's a chance you might not need another ultra sound and alot of doc's won't just write for an ultrasound just to find out the sex if there's no other indication you need one. And I didn't really gain much weight at all by the time i was 18 weeks so don't worry. I think I had gained like 5 pounds by then or something, i still looked like i was like 2 or 3 months when i was 6 months but the baby measured perfectly at my ulstrasound, it all just depends how you carry.



Source(s):



me! I had 1 ultrasound in 2nd trimester for the anatomy scans, measurements, and all that and found out the sex, and i won't have anymore until i deliver (due in 1 week) I thought for sure I would get 1 more but they said I have no health probelms, baby's not at any risk for anything so they have no reason to do another.

<answer>



hi i got on to a sex telling test on the internet. you use drain clean crystals. pascoes is the brand name. it used to open blocked drains. it has a very high % of getting the sex right. you place about six table spoons of this drain cleaner in a jar you add a morning mid stream sample of your urine to it. put a lid on it and shake. then sit aside for a couple of minutes.be shure to wear gloves.if the crystals turn brown or green its a girl and if they turn blue its a boy. both of my girlfriends have done this test as early as 13 weeks and it has been 100% spot on.Its safe but don't forget to get rid of it as the fumes can over bearing. good luck.



</answer>

<question>



Can I request a C-section or is it up to the doctor?



I'm very scared of vaginal birth!! But then again, C-section is a major surgery too...im just really scared but I was wondering if we can choose how we want to give birth?

misunder...
Member since: 27 October 2006

</answer>



<answer from>



srhgreco
Member since: 19 September 2008
Total points: 587 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi the doctor will not let you choose you can only have a planned c-section if it is for medical reasons



</answer>



<answer from>



The cat did it.
Member since: 25 March 2006
Total points: 6735 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



</answer from>



<answer>



The only time you can request a c-section would be if you had already had a c-section with a previous birth.
I have had 3 c-sections and will say IMHO, go vaginally if you can.  The 'mommy pouch' is generally larger with a c-section and is darn near impossible to get rid of.  The recovery is longer and once you go that route, you will generally have to have c-secions every time (AMA is highly recommending the 'phasing out' of VBAC's)
There isn't anything to be afraid of... you can get pain medication and you will do just fine.  Don't opt for a major surgery just because you fear the other option.



Good Luck!!!  I hope this helped!!  :)



</answer>



<answer from>



Mr. A-Z
Member since: 25 January 2008
Total points: 388 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Choose vaginal. It hurts less than C-section.



</answer>



<answer from>



MercyAng...
Member since: 19 March 2008
Total points: 249 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



In most cases you can't choose. They will only c-section for various medical reasons because it is major surgery. You can always talk to your doctor though, some are better than others about "finding reasons" to c-sec. Keep in mine the recovery sucks from c-sec, and it's much easier on your body to deliver vaginally. In a c-sec they cut all the way through your abd muscles and although it will heal, often the muscles don't form back the way they were before and it's impossible to have a flat stomach again from the lack of muscle tone (even if you work out). And your at a much higher risk for bleeding loss, and complications just b/c it is surgery.
Just remember it's not the "easy way out" like some people make it seem.



Source(s):



i'm a RN



</answer>



<answer from>



Stephanie M
Member since: 22 March 2007
Total points: 5104 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The only reason you should have a c-section would be if it was medically necessary.  Major abdominal surgery for no reason isn't a good idea and a good OB would not do it.  Most won't do it unless there was a medical reason for it.  With any surgery there is risks and it shouldn't be taken lightly.



</answer>



<answer from>



TC007
Member since: 27 February 2007

I think it depends on which country you live in and whether you have medical insurance or not. If you go to a goverment hospital they may refuse you a C-section unless it is a medical emergency because of the cost of it.



If you have private health care then you can opt for a C-section or you can have natural birth. At least this is how it works in South Africa.\



Why don't you ask your doctor about it?

<answer>



please do not think that c section is the easy option. i had an emergency section after 52 hours of labor. i can tell you from my own experience that walking around for 5+ weeks slightly bent over (cos of fear you'll burst open)is not the best feeling in the world. i am pregnant again now and have been offered another section. you think i said yes? no chance. i will try to have a normal delivery. i don't know what nutter out there would want to put themselves through all that lol.



on the other hand you should tell your midwife/doctor your fears from the word go. they can recommend you have a section but you will have to convince them that your fear is genuine and that you are not just too posh to push, not saying that you are but believe me there is people out there that are.



i really hope you get what you want and i haven't said these things to scare you its just that i think you should know that a section is far from the easier road. one things for sure i'm praying i wont need another. x x x x x

my honest opinion ,though not always right.



my own experience.

<question>



Scared of having a c-section ?



I am having triplets, and am going to be having a c section.  I am overweight to begin with, and my Dr said because of that there is more of a risk for infection because there is more skin to cut into, and if the epidural don't work they will have to put a tube down my throat.  I was scared to death before he told me this, and now I am petrified that something may go wrong. Any body else who is overweight and had a csection, how did everything go ?



</question>



<additional details>



I am 31 weeks along



</additional details>



<answer from>



misunder...
Member since: 27 October 2006
Total points: 1546 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



i wasnt over weight but i did have a c-section and it went good. i had a bad infection and had to have an emergency one. everything went good and im sure that yours will too. the chance of infection is very little and the chance of the epideral not working thats even smaller. good luck!!



</answer>



<answer from>



yayy were having a baby
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 492 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



How far pregnant are you? if your still in your early days, i would suggest gentle excercise walks etc, you will be surprised at what little difference a little weight lose can do for you. As for the c-section, it is the safest options for your little bubbas, the stress your body will be under if you give birth naturally could be far worse then the risks involved with the c-section. Remember your doctor has done more c-sections then you can imagine, ask how many and if still in doubt talk to the midwives or another doctor. Good luck and please let us know how you get on.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ailing W
Member since: 19 August 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



don't ask around,no use. everything will be fine. sometimes you think too much will affect your health. i know it is not easy for you. be strong,tell yourself this is no big deals,you will be fine. if you r not happy ,scare or worried,your babies will be sad because they can feel it. don't let them feel guilty to you. you also don't want your babies to become in-confidence,sad,in-courage. now your job is to bring the happy healthy babies to the world and whatever happened to you is not important because you r the true wonderful mother in this world.

<answer from>



Param
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 153 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Week 13 symptons are as follows



Your Baby
By pregnancy week 13 your tiny baby may be over 3 inches long and weigh almost ¾ of an ounce! There is still plenty of growing your baby will undergo as you continue your pregnancy week by week.



Changes In Your Growing Baby
Though your baby is much larger than he was when he started 12 weeks ago, by 13 weeks pregnant your little munchkin is still pretty tiny. Despite that your baby looks fully formed, with a head, arms, legs and complete torso. Your baby's head won't look quite as disproportionate to the rest of his body by pregnancy 13 weeks. By this time your baby's liver will start producing insulin, a life saving hormone that will help your bay regulate his blood sugar as he grows and develops.



By pregnancy 13 weeks your baby's eyes will also start moving from the sides of his head to their final destination at the front of your baby's face.



Your Body's Development
By pregnancy week 13 your uterus is expanding even further. This sometimes causes some discomfort or mild cramping. Some women experience what is referred to as round ligament pain around pregnancy at 13 weeks. This pain while sometimes alarming is usually harmless. If you experience round ligament pain you may feel a short or brief sharp and stabbing pain along one side of your abdomen or the other. This usually happens when a woman is shifting positions quickly, say moving from her side to her back or getting up suddenly.



Most round ligament pain will disappear in a few minutes. If you notice pain that is accompanied by other symptoms including bleeding, omitting or cramping you should contact your health care provider immediately. This may be a sign that something more serious is occurring. Typically however round ligament pain is brief and easily relieved by simply relaxing or resting for a moment. It often serves as an important reminder for pregnant women to slow things down while pregnant.



Changes In Your Body
You deserve a huge pat on the back! You are now entering your second trimester. Pregnancy week 13 is definitely a time to cheer. By pregnancy at 13 weeks your risk for miscarriage drops significantly. Most women who carry to 13 weeks pregnant will continue to carry their baby to term.



This does not mean your risk for miscarriage is completely eliminated. There are rare instances where some women's risk of miscarriage continues through the 20th week. In some cases a condition called an incompetent cervix is to blame. Women who have an incompetent cervix are not able to carry their baby to term without medical intervention, because the cervix starts to shorten and open before 20 weeks pregnant. This causes the baby to be delivered too early.



Fortunately this is a pretty uncommon problem and once identified, a doctor can perform a procedure called a cerclage to help ensure the cervix remains closed for future pregnancies.



By 13 weeks pregnant while too small for maternity clothes, you are probably ready to move into a pair of sweat pants for a short time. Aside from your growing belly you may start noticing bumps forming on your breasts. These bumps are glands that help the breasts grow and develop during pregnancy. You may also find that your libido and energy start returning at roughly 13 weeks pregnant. Most women consider the second trimester the honeymoon phase of their pregnancy. Take advantage of your increasingly good spirits and energy level and invest in a little comfy lingerie or new bra for yourself. Many women find the increased blood flowing throughout their body heightens their sense of pleasure and ecstasy during intercourse. You might as well enjoy the experience while you can, the second trimester is only a few short months!



Source(s):



http://know-pregnancy-weekbyweek.blogspo...



</answer>

</question>

<answer from>



baby GIRL due march 4th!!

Total points: 2039 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



might sound strange but when that happens to me i go in a hot shower and squeeze a little bit of the colostrum out and they always feel better after that...its almost like they are gorging.

<asker's comment>



Oh my gosh thank you so much.... And that was weird looking haha!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Due Nov.25th w/2nd Boy
Member since: 19 October 2008
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is not much you can do to relieve the soreness but wait.



They will become less sore gradually over the next few weeks until they are just tender.  Then after delivery they will feel worse than now.  The pain is caused from the hormone level change your body is experiencing from being pregnant.  Don't worry it is something most women experience while pregnant.



</answer>



<answer from>



spud

<answer from>



TC007
Member since: 27 February 2007
Total points: 734 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



It sounds like you are being affected by the pregnancy hormones in a bad way. Hormones are pretty different for everyone.  I felt tired and irritable throughout my first trimester but now I feel great!



I'm sure you will feel so much better when you enter your second trimester.



There is also something called PRE-natal depression which hits women who are pregnant so maybe bear this in mind. I am not saying you have it but it is something to look into.



Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



DJJD
Member since: 28 May 2007
Total points: 9074 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its not unusual for some women 'not' to bloom in pregnancy. I felt awful all the way through with my first baby. I had morning sickness all the way through and felt whale like and very depressed. I put on a vast amount of weight and felt hideous. In these early stages, your body is going through a massive change and you will no doubt be feeling exhausted. Its normal in the early stages, especially when you have another child to care for. I am not sure about the pampering, but you should speak to your doctor who may be able to suggest some relaxation techniques. As a stay at home mum with a small baby, its easy to sit indoors and not bother to go out. A friend of mine once told me, 'make an effort to go out, every day, even if its just a little walk up the road'. It gives you a reason to make an effort to get dressed and blow away the cobwebs. A little exercise is good for you too.



</answer>

<answer>



sit down with your husband and really share your feelings he will do anything to help you i am sure of it. if the feelings get worse and you do become depressed, or continue to have hopeless thoughts you may want to speak to your doctor. postpartum depression can kick in well before you give birth & can become much worse aafter-wards you may not have it with one child and have a severe case of it with the next one it's very random and very very very hard to deal with. it's always good to be screened for it even if you are not showing strong signs of it. i am not trying to offend but to offer all possible options. if you can't speak with your husband, or it's not a depression, try to find a friend you can vent to at least try to talk it out with someone some how. i really hope something will help....

<question>

I'm 39 weeks, 5 days pregnant. I woke up from a nap at 6 p.m. (it is now 6 a.m.) with steady contractions accompanied with back pain that were about 4-7 minutes apart and lasting about 50 seconds each. I tried to ride it out most of the day by taking a warm bath, drinking fluids, and laying on my side. When I went to bed for the night (around midnight), the pain was so intense that I couldn't sleep. I decided to go to the hospital. I was checked, and told that I was a fingertip dilated and to take a sleeping pill and go home (around 4 a.m.). The doctor told me "I know you're uncomfortable, but you'll KNOW when you're in real labor." I tried explaining to my doctor that what I was feeling was not discomfort at all, it was extremely severe pain. I told her I could not imagine the contractions getting worse, and she even went as far as to crack a smile at me. She shrugged me off, told me to take Tylenol and use a heating pad for my back. I came home, and my contractions have only gotten worse. They are EXCRUCIATING, to the point where I'm literally hysterically crying and screaming through them and curled into a ball. They are still strong and regular and I don't know if my back or my stomach hurts more. More than anything, I want to go to the hospital, but I really do not want to run into the same people who are going to tell me the same thing. The pain is unbearable. What should I do? I already know that once businesses open, I'm going to find a new doctor.

<question>



Did anyone have high blood sugar in 32nd week of pregnancy.?



I got my glucose tolerance test done..fasting was 127 instead of 110, after 1 hour of glucose intake it was 263 and 2 hrs later it was 236. Normally it should be less than 140. What are the problems that one encounters due to such high sugar levels..



</question>



<answer from>



Mrs.Ting...
Member since: 18 June 2008
Total points: 1216 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



GESTATIONAL DIABETES IT KINDA SUCKS YOU HAVE YO MONITOR YOU SUGAR WITH A GLUCOSE METER EVERY TWO HOURS AFTER YOU EAT AND LIKE WITH ME I HAVE GB SO I TEND TO GET REALLY DIZZY IF MY SUGAR GOES UP AND I HAD TO BE PLACED ON A SPECIAL DIET BUT ANYWAY GOOD LUCK



Source(s):



39 WEEKS



</answer>



<answer from>



rosie_08...
Member since: 10 June 2007
Total points: 15870 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



We have a different numbering system in Australia so I'm not sure how that compares. Basically, gestational diabetes sucks. There are numerous health problems that will occur if you're not controlling it. That's pretty unlikely though. You'll probably be sent to a diabetes educator, dietician and be seeing an obstetrician every week until you give birth. Start reading up on the GI index and eat the lowest GI foods you can. Also read up on serving sizes. Apparently an orange is one serve, but I can only eat half or my bloods will spike. I'm 27 weeks now, and can no longer get my carbs from grains, so I am eating a heck of a lot of legumes. I'm really getting to hate legumes. You need to spread your carb intake out during the day. I was told to divide it between breakfast, lunch and dinner. That didn't work for me. I have to have a small amount at the three meals and morning and afternoon tea, and supper. Supper is really important for maintaining your blood sugars over night. It's not just how high or low you go, but also the variation, so stable is good.
I can't tell you what happens with insulin. I managed to keep diet controlled with my first pregnancy, and so far so good this time. Anyway, as I said, it sucks, but you've got to do what you've got to do, eh? It's definately not something to be slack about. If you overload your system by not controlling it, your baby gets overloaded too, causing his/her little pancreas to work overtime. That means when bub is born, it'll take a bit of time before it realises it doesn't have to work so hard, so it'llkeep producing too much insulin, and his/her blood sugars will drop severely. That means a stay in the special care unit while they get things back to normal. Also, the bub is at risk of getting too large by laying down fat stores in unhealthy places, which is starting off behind the eightball as far as health goes. That increases your odds of having to be induced early. Now you may want to be induced early to get rid of the discomfort of pregnancy, but babies of mothers with uncontrolled diabetes tend to be born large, but a bit immature.
Good thing is, if you control it, with diet if you can or insulin, it's pretty unlikely any of that nasty stuff will happen. I kept diet controlled with my daughter, and she was absolutely fine. I did have to be induced at 40 weeks, but that's standard procedure with diabetic mothers, and for good reason. Basically, ask lots of questions about anything you don't understand, and do as you are told!



</answer>

am i pregannt?



is this just an extra symptom, my friend said this happened to her.



i have sore breast, and other signs. i tested two days early .

<answer from>



Little girl coming in 4 days!
Member since: 25 September 2006
Total points: 9840 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your preggo, and the feeling that your about to start your period are pregnancy symptoms.  Early pregnancy and period symptoms are identical, thats why many ladies think they may be preggo.  But your period is no where in site!  Congrats!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



lingtan1...
Member since: 07 October 2008
Total points: 408 (Level 2)

Is there any chance of me being pregnant???? please answer?



I am on birth control (yasmin) and i had sex with my bf the first 2 weeks of october  and today i got some blood when i wiped. i've been sleeping in really late and eating carbs constantly. i'm not expecting my period until around november 7th. could i be pregnant? i never get spotting like that

<answer>



Unlikely but possible since it's not 100%, just take a test in two weeks to be sure, I'm sure you are fine!!



Source(s):



Mom of 1, 30 weeks with #2



</answer>



<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 30331 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



No birth control is perfect.  It is possible that you are pregnant.



However, it would be very early to be having symptoms, and nothing you describe is a typical symptom of pregnancy. So you probably AREN'T pregnant (if you took all your pills on schedule) but the only way to know for sure is to wait and see if your period comes at the end of the pill pack. If it doesn't, test.



</answer>



<answer from>



jakesmom...
Member since: 03 November 2007
Total points: 580 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You could be...but I'd lean more towards the birth control and irregular/inconsistent period.  I get that.  I never know when mine is coming/going.  It sucks, but, there is really nothing you can do - it's one of the side effects.



</answer>

sb

<answer>



If the pill is pretty new to you, it is still changing your body which can cause irregularity in your cycle.



Even if you take the pill you can still get pregnant.  You could be in that 1% of hopelessly and ridiculously fertile women.  If that is the case you should sell some eggs.



I am guessing you could also be having a urinary tract infection or a bladder infection if the blood is on the tissue only when you urinate, as opposed to spotting on your undergarments.



</answer>



<answer from>



Elizabeth N
Member since: 13 October 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Any time you are sexually active, you run the risk of becoming pregnant. Regardless of your method of birth control. All contraception methods has a chance of failure.



This could be implantation bleeding. Take a pregnancy test. Either over the counter or at the doctor's office. If you need a clinic, check this listing, they are usually very helpful. http://www.optionline.org



</answer>

<answer from>



Isabeu O (Finally a mummy!)
Member since: 02 January 2008
Total points: 15931 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



When it all comes down to it, pressing a magical spot on your foot will not spur labour on, if you body has not begun itself.



Reading your prior questions, I would sincerely hope you are not trying to bring labour on at your 36-37 weeks mark.
You will only exhaust yourself, and end up frustrated, and not in labour.



I visited the maternity acupressure site, google it.
It says to not try anything until you are over due.



So pressing spots on your body at 37 weeks is not only not going to work, it's going to make you look like a goon.



"Hey hun, why are you pressing your foot like that?"



"Oh. you know, trying to induce the baby before he's actually due..the usual..."



</answer>

<question>



Advice?..I want to keep my baby but Bf is adament he doesn't..?



My bf and I had only been together for 4 and a half months when i fell pregnant. I'm 27 and really should have known better..I already have 2 children age 2 and 5 from a previous marriage.



We had talked about what happened if i did fall pregnant and we were both ok with the fact. Then he decided he wasn't sure as we were having a few arguements..yet we still weren't taking precations. He was trying for a baby with a pevious gf for nearly 10 months..He seems to have it set in his mind he wasnt working and that was that.



I think he needs to see a counsellor as revealed to me that he had been abused as a young teenager, and ever since he has told me he has threatened suicide and all manner of things. One minute he tells me he loves me with all his heart and in the same breath he's telling he never wants to see me again..He runs away from everything and buries his head hoping it will go away..



So i'm now 9 weeks pregnant and we've only seen each other a few times since i told him. We use to be inseperable.



He keeps saying i'm not being fair on him by keeping a child he doesnt want. He can't seem to see that its my body and emotions that will go throught it all. I've already had 2 terminations and i don't want to go through anther one. Its as simple as that, but all i get is that i'm selfish etc etc..He said today if i got rid of the baby it would give us a chance to get to know each other without the stress of a baby..
I can see what he's saying but i just dont want to..
Any advice?



</question>



<additional details>



Just thought i'd add.. I had a termination at 17 and the other one was 4 months after I had my son..so at the time this was the right option for me..



I know we should have been using contraception and yes i was stupid..i'm old enough to know better and all the rest..that doesn't really help me now..



I do want this baby and there is no way I could go through adoption after giving birth.



I've been a single mother since my ex husband left me for another woman when my youngest was 5 and a half months old.



2 years on i'm doing very well..i'm not your stereotypical council estate single mother..and i never intended to be this,,(no offence to anyone) That was not how i was brought up..and dont intend it for my children..



</additional details>

He sounds selfish by NOT understanding what you want - this is a two way thing,  but at the end of the day this is your body and your baby.

You know in your heart that you want this baby,  he is being selfish wanting a termination and putting his views before your own,  is that a decent basis for any relationship?  He is selfish because he took the risks of having sex without using contraception and now is not willing to step up to the responsibility of that.



It is your body,  your baby,  do what you heart tells you. xx



Edit,
Just to add that I don't see this as either party being at "fault",  obviously both parties took the "risk of not using contraception",  but the huge difference is, he is the one willing to use abortion as his form of contraception the poster is not,  she is willing to stand up to her responsibilities and carry through with the pregnancy - that is the big difference.

<question>



Trisomy 18 - Have just had results from combined 12 weeks screening and they came back as a 1:2 chance.?



Trisomy 18 - Have just had results from combined 12 weeks screening and they came back as a 1:2 chance.?
Had a CVS test done today - i understand that the results from the CVS will give us a definite answer, but, how accurate is the combined screening? (blood test and ultrasound @ 12 weeks) the doctor said that the chances were extremely high being 1:2. and for future, what are the chances of this being the case in another of our pregnancies? We already have one son who is completely healthy, and we're a couple both under the age of 30! Is this a normal result?



</question>



<answer from>



starline...
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 245 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



that is high, it must have been the amount of fluid around the neck, my friend had a 1:3 chance and she had the same test and was negative for trisomy 18, I have one of those 12 week screening test this week good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Bianca
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 352 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



That is high, although waiting until you other results come back may be a good idea. You dont want to worry over nothing. Of course, although the ratio does sound high, it does not mean its a defiante. Being the age you are, and not knowing about any other factors, if you are both completly healthy the chances of this happening in any subsquent pregnancies would presumably be low. Wish you the best of luck



</answer>



<answer from>



Susan B
Member since: 24 June 2008
Total points: 1598 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm very sorry you have to go through this, but you will have the definitive results soon enough.  As I'm sure you realize, a 1:2 chance it quite high!  On the bright side, there is also a 1:2 chance that your baby does not have it, just like the chances of having a boy or a girl.  All you can do it wait for the results and keep you fingers crossed.



The chances of this happenning in another pregnancy are very low as Trisomy 18 occurs in only 1/3000 foetuses (and 1/6000 live births).  Try not to worry about it happening - chances really are slim to none.



Best of luck.



</answer>

<question>



Can real labor start and stop anytime?



Hi, im  due 2moro, and yesterday i had membrane sweep, and soon after i started having painful  contractions which were just like  braxton hicks ive had thru out my preg but only these  were painful, came every 10 minutes and lasted  aminute or just over, up untill this morning, i was gonna call the  labour ward  but they have since stopped completely. i have lost  the plug but nothing else,  i cant walk around much cos of a dislocated hip so im in bed mostly, can  sitting or laying down stop them  even if  they were real? Thanks in advance.



</question>



<answer from>



Isabeu O (Finally a mummy!)
Member since: 02 January 2008
Total points: 15931 (Level 6)



Contributing In:

</answer from>



<answer>



In the end, real labour will continue to progress,regardless of positions.. false labour wont.



</answer>



<answer from>



danicata...
Member since: 28 December 2007
Total points: 304 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had my membranes stripped yesterday too and i got the strong contractions, and as soon as i got on the recliner i noticed they stopped. I know you cant walk much, but i believe thats the best way to get them to go stronger. Sitting on a exercise ball can help, it helps open you pelivs a bit more and force the babys head to put pressure, try taking a warm bath, it helps the cervix to soften and dialate. These are all remedies that people have given me to help me since i cant walk much i have a horrible back, and it got worse with the pregnancy. Good luck!



</answer>

<answer from>



lucy&co
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had a similar situation 21 years ago.  I went into labor, spent the night in the hospital with decreasing labor pains and was sent home the next morning to wait until my pains lasted for a certain period of time and were a specific distance apart.  This never happened - I insisted that my husband take me back to the hospital the next day.  I had an emergency c section and a beautiful baby boy who spent 3 days in the neo natal unit.
The same thing happened to my friend - they kept telling her that her due day must have been wrong (because she never went into labor).  She wasn't so lucky.  Doctors are not always right.  DEMAND that they do an ultrasound or similar test to see what is going on with the baby.  Remember, doctors are human - they make mistakes.



</answer>

<question>



What do you think I should do?



I know that I should be consulting my doctor instead of Yahoo Answers with a problem like this, but my doctor has been absolutely no help to me so I need someone else's opinion.



I'm 39 weeks, 5 days pregnant. I woke up from a nap at 6 p.m. (it is now 6 a.m.) with steady contractions accompanied with back pain that were about 4-7 minutes apart and lasting about 50 seconds each. I tried to ride it out most of the day by taking a warm bath, drinking fluids, and laying on my side. When I went to bed for the night (around midnight), the pain was so intense that I couldn't sleep. I decided to go to the hospital. I was checked, and told that I was a fingertip dilated and to take a sleeping pill and go home (around 4 a.m.). The doctor told me "I know you're uncomfortable, but you'll KNOW when you're in real labor." I tried explaining to my doctor that what I was feeling was not discomfort at all, it was extremely severe pain. I told her I could not imagine the contractions getting worse, and she even went as far as to crack a smile at me. She shrugged me off, told me to take Tylenol and use a heating pad for my back. I came home, and my contractions have only gotten worse. They are EXCRUCIATING, to the point where I'm literally hysterically crying and screaming through them and curled into a ball. They are still strong and regular and I don't know if my back or my stomach hurts more. More than anything, I want to go to the hospital, but I really do not want to run into the same people who are going to tell me the same thing. The pain is unbearable. What should I do? I already know that once businesses open, I'm going to find a new doctor.



</question>

<question>



Is it true that you can get pregnant a couple days before and a couple days after your period?



i was wondering... i have heard that 3 days before and 3 days after your period you can get pregnant? is that true?



</question>



<answer from>



Preggerz til April
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 168 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



sometimes. but not often.  You get pregnant when you ovulate. duh.



</answer>



<answer from>



Vr
Member since: 25 March 2008
Total points: 5141 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes. You can also get pregnant while on your period (though it's not too common).



</answer>



<answer from>



Pippin
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 25358 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Newborn & Baby



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



You cannot get pregnant 3 days before your period, because you would have ovulated about 10-12 days before, and the egg died long ago.



It IS possible to get pregnant from sex 3 days after your period, because the sperm can live in your body for up to 5 days, and so may still be there when you ovulate.



(You can only actually get pregnant WHEN you ovulate, and you ovulate about 14 days before your next period.  Sperm can live for 5 days, the egg lives less than a day.  So there is roughly a 5-6 day window each month when sex can result in pregnancy.)



EDIT: Those thumbs down folks -- do you have ANY idea how reproduction works? How is it possible to get pregnant 3 days before a period?  Even if you did ovulate that late, it would result in a luteul phase far too short to support a pregnancy! (And if you ovulated late AND had a normal luteul phase, the period woulldn't come in 3 days, so it would be '3 days before your period.)



</answer>



<answer from>



Angellov...
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 1165 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes u can, it all depends on when your body everybody is different. i got pregnant around my last period lol.  Everybody ovulates at a different time not always when charts say they are suppose to.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sam.I.Am
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 158 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can get pregnant at anytime as long as you have a menstrual cycle. Whether it is before or after your period, it doesn't matter. That doesn't stop you from getting pregnant. It will only increase or decrease your chances.



</answer>

cathrl69

<answer>



a do-it-yourself pregnancy test, like clear blue, first response, etc. can give you accurate results, but going to the doctor and getting a blood test or seeing your gyno is always going to give you the 100% correct result. my cousin took a pregnancy test once, and it came out negative. she got another one about 3 days later and tried again, and still came out negative. she still didn't believe that she was not pregnant, so she visited her doctor, and it turns out - she was. lol, so in my opinion, i wouldn't go based off of one of those. even if it comes out positive.. still see your doctor. good luck!

<asker's comment>
